Subpart B - RELATED LAWS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Printed herein are the special acts pertaining to the city that are still current and nonamendatory of the Charter. Obvious misspellings have been corrected without notation. For stylistic purposes, a uniform system of headings, catchlines and citations to state statutes has been used. Additions made for clarity are indicated by brackets. 

ARTICLE I. - LAKE FRONT IMPROVEMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- The term commission has been editorially amended to council. 
State Law reference- Dredge and fill regulations, F.S. § 403.813 et seq. 

Sec. 1. - Authorization. 
    The City of St. Cloud, Florida, acting by and through its city council, is hereby empowered and given authority to reclaim, fill in, bulkhead and improve that part of the lake front on Lake East Tohopekaliga, lying between the north line of Lake Shore Boulevard, also known as "Lake Boulevard," "The Lake Boulevard," and "St. Cloud Boulevard," in said city and the waters of Lake East Tohopekaliga, within the limits of said city. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 13354 (1927), § 1) 
Sec. 2. - Title of lands vested in city. 
    The title to said property, including the lands reclaimed, filled in and/or improved, is now and forever hereafter shall be vested in the City of St. Cloud, Florida, for the use and benefit of the public of said city, and may be utilized by said city for any public purpose, including streets, boulevards, parks, avenues, promenades, alleys, squares, piers, recreation grounds and building sites for public buildings, and/or otherwise. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 13354 (1927), § 2) 
Sec. 3. - Improvements-Defined. 
    The improvements which said City of St. Cloud, Florida, is authorized to make on said property so reclaimed, filled in, and bulkheaded, within the limits aforesaid, shall consist of the filling, construction, reconstruction, grading, regrading, laying out, hard surfacing, maintenance, development, and improvement of streets, boulevards, parks, squares, piers, bulkheads and/or providing for construction and maintaining of sewerage, drainage, lighting, installation of water systems, laying of curbs, and the erection, construction, repair, reconstruction and maintenance of public buildings, and/or other public improvements. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 13354 (1927), § 3) 
Sec. 4. - Same-By resolution. 
    The city council of the City of St. Cloud, Florida, may from time to time pass such resolutions as it may deem proper, determining the necessity and/or beneficial value of any such improvements, and any such resolution shall be sufficient authority for the making, construction and/or maintenance of such improvements so determined to be necessary and/or beneficial to the said city. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 13354 (1927), § 4) 
Sec. 5. - Annual tax levy; millage. 
    Said City of St. Cloud, Florida, is hereby authorized, in addition to all other taxing powers conferred upon it by general and special acts, to levy an annual tax not to exceed ten (10) mills, upon all the taxable property in said city, for the purpose of paying for the cost of any such improvements and the maintenance thereof, and/or paying the interest on any bonds in this act authorized to be issued, and providing a sinking fund for the retirement of said bonds. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 13354 (1927), § 5; Ord. No. 81-B, § 13, 2-5-1981/3-19-1981) 
Sec. 6. - Bond issues. 
    In order to make any such improvements hereby authorized, said city council is hereby authorized to issue bonds of said city from time to time, not to exceed, at any one time, a par value of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00), such bonds to be in one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) denominations, and to carry interest at a rate not to exceed six (6) percent, and to fall due serially over a period not to exceed thirty (30) years. The maturity dates, interest rate and other terms and provisions of any such bonds are to be determined by resolution of the city council. No such bonds shall be issued without the prior authority of a majority of the taxpayers of said city, who shall be qualified electors of said city, qualified to vote at bond elections in said city, and who shall vote at an election to be held for the purpose of authorizing any such issue of said bonds. Any such election shall be held in accordance with the laws and ordinances governing special elections to be held in the City of St. Cloud, Florida. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 13354 (1927), § 6) 
Sec. 7. - Extent and nature of improvements. 
    The plan, nature and extent of the improvements to be made by the City of St. Cloud, Florida, in accordance with the authority herein conferred, including the grade to be established, the bulkhead line to be established, the topographical level to be established and all other necessary engineering and architectural features in connection with such improvements shall rest within the discretion of the City of St. Cloud, as expressed from time to time by resolution of said city council. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 13354 (1927), § 7) 
Sec. 8. - Bonds excluded from limitations. 
    All bonds issued under the provisions of this act shall be excluded from any limitation of bonded indebtedness, or other indebtedness of said city, prescribed by the Charter of said city or by any general or special law governing the said city. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 13354 (1927), § 8) 
ARTICLE II. - FACILITIES FOR PRODUCTION OF ELECTRICAL ENERGY 

Sec. 1. - Authority to provide. 
    The City of St. Cloud, Florida, in addition to the authority it now possesses under its present Charter, be, and it is hereby further authorized to jointly, with the City of Kissimmee, Florida, purchase, hire, construct, own, maintain and operate, both inside and outside the limits of said city, land and facilities necessary to produce electrical energy and to transmit such energy over joint or separate transmission facilities in conjunction with the City of Kissimmee, Florida, and to make such contracts as may be necessary in relation thereto, and to establish by ordinances of the city, if necessary, an authority or agency to accomplish the acquisition, construction, enlargement, improvement, operation and maintenance of the facilities with the City of Kissimmee, Florida, with the power to issue revenue obligations for the financing thereof. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 69-1533, § 1) 
Sec. 2. - Effective date. 
    This act shall take effect immediately upon its becoming a law. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 69-1533, § 2)

PART II - CITY CODE 
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "St. Cloud City Code" and may be so cited. 
(Code 1967, § 1-1; Code 1994, § 1-1) 
Charter reference- Code title, § 3.19. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless the content clearly indicates otherwise: 
    City. The terms "the city" or "this city" shall be construed as if the words "of St. Cloud" followed it and shall extend to and include its several officers, agents and employees. 
    City council. Whenever the term "city council" is used, it shall be construed to mean the city council of the City of St. Cloud, Florida. 
    Code. Whenever the term "Code" is used, it shall mean and refer to the St. Cloud City Code. 
    Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done, a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given, or such act is done, shall be counted in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall not be counted. 
    Corporate limits. Wherever in this Code an act is prohibited, declared unlawful, required to be performed, directly or by implication, such references shall imply "within the corporate limits of the City of St. Cloud." 
    County. The term "county" shall mean the County of Osceola. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or some other city officer or employee to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize the head of the department or other officer or employee to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section specify otherwise. 
    F.S. Whenever the abbreviation "F.S." is used, it shall refer to the official Florida Statutes as adopted by the state legislature, as amended or transferred. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. 
    Oath. The term "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the terms "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the terms "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Officer or office. Reference to any office or officer of the city, state or county, includes any person authorized by law to perform the duties of such office or officer. 
    Or, and. The term "or" may be read as "and," and the term "and" may be read as "or" if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The term "person" shall include and is applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property. 
    Shall; may. The term "shall" is mandatory; the term "may" is permissive. 
    State. The term "state" shall be construed to mean the State of Florida. 
    Tense. Words used in the present or past tense include the future as well as the present and past. 
(Code 1967, § 1-2; Code 1994, § 1-2) 
State Law reference- Definitions of terms used in the Florida Statutes, F.S. § 1.01. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be the titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1967, § 1-3; Code 1994, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - History notes. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the sections. 
Sec. 1-5. - References to chapters or sections. 
    All references to chapters or sections are to the chapters and sections of this Code unless otherwise specified. 
(Code 1994, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-6. - References and editor's notes. 
    The references and editor's notes appearing throughout the Code are not intended to have any legal effect, but are merely intended to assist the user of the Code. 
(Code 1994, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-7. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance of the city in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. 
(Code 1994, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-8. - Provisions considered continuation of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code so far as they are the same as those of the St. Cloud city Code, 1994, and of ordinances existing at the time of adoption of this Code shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not new enactments. 
(Code 1994, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-9. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following when not inconsistent with this Code: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred before the effective date of this Code. 
(2)  Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issue of any bonds of the city, or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract, right, agreement, lease, deed or other instrument or obligation assumed by the city. 
(3)  Any administrative ordinances or resolutions of the city not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code. 
(4)  Any right or franchise granted by any ordinance. 
(5)  Any ordinance or resolution dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city. 
(6)  Any appropriation ordinance. 
(7)  Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes. 
(8)  Any ordinances prescribing through streets, parking and traffic regulations, speed limits, one-way traffic, limitations on load of vehicles, or loading zones. 
(9)  Any land use, building, planning, zoning, including the land development regulations, or rezoning ordinance or amendment to the zoning map. 
(10)  Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city. 
(11)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor. 
(12)  Any subdivision ordinance or ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city. 
(13)  Any ordinance annexing territory or excluding territory or any ordinance extending the boundaries of the city. 
(14)  Any ordinance establishing positions, classifying positions, setting salaries of city officers and employees or establishing any retirement or pension plans and trusts or any personnel regulations. 
(15)  Any temporary or special ordinances. 
(16)  Any ordinance calling an election. 
(17)  Any ordinance establishing a fee, charge, deposit, rate or assessment. 
(18)  The purchasing policy of the city. 
(19)  Any provision of Laws of Fla. ch. 65-2166, as amended, or any special act provision which has been converted to ordinances by F.S. § 166.021 which has not been superseded or repealed or is not inconsistent with this Code. 
    All such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein. All ordinances are on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1994, § 1-8) 
Sec. 1-10. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1967, § 1-4; Code 1994, § 1-9) 
State Constitution reference- "No bill attainder, ex post facto law, nor any law impairing the obligation of contracts, shall ever be passed." Declaration of Rights, Fla. Const. art. I, § 17. 
Sec. 1-11. - Effect of amendments to Code. 
(a)  Any and all additions and amendments to this Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the city council to make the same a part hereof, shall be deemed to be incorporated in this Code so that reference to the Code shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. 
(b)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, article, division, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section _____ of the St. Cloud City Code is hereby amended to read as follows:...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  If a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the St. Cloud City Code is hereby amended by adding a section to be numbered _____, which section reads as follows:...." The new section may then be set out in full as desired. 
(e)  All sections, divisions, articles, chapters, or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, division, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1967, § 1-6; Code 1994, § 1-10) 
Charter reference- Following the publication of the first St. Cloud City Code, and at all times thereafter, the ordinances, resolutions and Charter amendments, shall be printed in substantially the same style as the Code currently in effect, and it shall be suitable in form for integration therein, § 3.19(c). 
Sec. 1-12. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code, and shall also include all amendments to the Charter during the period. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages that have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code that have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions. 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in catchlines, headings and titles. 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers. 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ through _____." The inserted section numbers will indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code. 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
(Code 1994, § 1-11) 
Charter reference- Authority of the city to adopt a code of ordinances, § 3.19. 
Sec. 1-13. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1967, § 1-7; Code 1994, § 1-12) 
State Law reference- Unlawful alteration of public records, F.S. §§ 831.01, 839.13. 
Sec. 1-14. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 1-5; Code 1994, § 1-13) 
Sec. 1-15. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
    Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the city any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful, or an offense, or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any ordinance shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 60 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1967, § 1-8; Code 1994, § 1-14) 
State Law reference- Fines and forfeitures in county court payable to municipality, F.S. § 34.191; punishment for misdemeanors, F.S. §§ 775.082, 775.083.

(a)  Each member of the city council, other than the mayor, shall receive as an annual base salary in the amount indicated below, based upon the population of the city:

DIVISION 2. - MEETINGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Procedure for meetings, § 3.14. 
State Law reference- Meetings open to public, F.S. ch. 286. 

Sec. 2-51. - Regular and special meetings of council. 
    The city council shall hold regular meetings not less than once a month, normally the same to be held on the second Thursday of each month at 6:30 p.m., at the city hall; provided, however, by simple motion or call of the mayor, passed or announced at any previous meeting, the regular meeting for the following month may be held on the day and at the hour set forth in the motion or call with notice to absent members. Special or substitute meetings may be held on the call of the mayor or majority of councilmembers, made at times other than during a meeting, upon no less than 24 hours' notice to each member, with public notice. 
(Code 1967, § 20-1; Code 1994, § 2-36; Ord. No. 90-ZZZZ, § I, 12-6-1990; Ord. No. 91-I-1, § 1, 7-11-1991; Ord. No. 91-L-2, § 1(2-1), 1-23-1992; Ord. No. 93-L, § 1(2-1), 3-25-1993) 
Sec. 2-52. - Change of regular meeting. 
    Any provisions of this Code notwithstanding, any proposed ordinance changing the regular council meeting time, date or place shall be passed on first reading (i.e., introduced and regularly set for public hearing) only upon unanimous vote. Any such proposed ordinance failing to receive an unanimous vote on such first reading, but receiving a majority vote, shall be set for two public hearings, with regular public notice of each hearing; the first such hearing shall be held not less than 28 days following introduction, and the second such hearing shall be held not less than 28 days following the first public hearing, with final consideration being had following the second hearing. 
(Code 1994, § 2-37; Ord. No. 90-ZZZZ, § I, 12-6-1990; Ord. No. 91-I-1, § 1, 7-11-1991) 
Sec. 2-53. - Resolution or emergency ordinance. 
    No resolution shall be adopted and no ordinance shall be considered for adoption as an emergency ordinance, introduced and set for public hearing or passed on first reading, where consideration thereof is solely at the request of the city manager or the city attorney, or where it is proposed other than as set forth in section 2-54, without a copy of the proposed ordinance or resolution or a copy with reasonably similar verbiage having been sent to all councilmembers not less than 72 hours in advance of such consideration, unless such bulletin requirement first shall be waived by either an affirmative four-fifths vote of the council or by unanimous vote of those members in attendance. 
(Code 1994, § 2-64; Ord. No. 90-NNNN, § I(d), 11-8-1990) 
State Law reference- Uniform minimum procedure for adoption of ordinances and resolutions, F.S. § 166.041. 
Sec. 2-54. - Emergency consideration. 
    At any regular meeting or at any special meeting, the mayor's order or any councilmember's motion receiving three affirmative votes shall require the council's consideration of: 
(1)  Any ordinance for passage on first reading; 
(2)  Any emergency ordinance for adoption (four affirmative votes required for adoption); or 
(3)  Any resolution for adoption; provided the mayor's order or such councilmember's motion includes an emergency finding. Without such emergency finding the bulletin times set forth in section 2-53 shall be required for consideration. 
(Code 1994, § 2-65; Ord. No. 90-NNNN, § I(e), 11-8-1990) 
Secs. 2-55-2-80. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - COTERMINOUS ENTITIES 

Sec. 2-151. - Defined. 
(a)  A coterminous entity is defined as any board, commission or committee, where the member's terms of office for such entity correspond with the terms for the mayor and councilmembers. 
(b)  All city boards, commissions or committees shall be coterminous entities (except the construction board of adjustments and electric utility advisory committee), where not in conflict with state law or Charter law and except as noted below in sections 2-154 and 2-155. No other provision of sections 2-152 through 2-155 withstanding, the terms of all coterminus entity members shall continue until their successors are selected. 
(Code 1994, § 2-86; Ord. No. 92-J-1, § 1, 6-22-1992; Ord. No. 96-06, § I, 5-9-1996) 
Charter reference- Board of adjustment, § 7.04. 
Sec. 2-152. - Numbered seats. 
    The seat or position of each member of all coterminous entities shall be numbered; in the case of five-member coterminous entities, the seats shall be numbered from one through five, inclusive. In like manner, the seats of coterminous entities with greater than five members shall be numbered from one through the number greater than five, inclusive. 
(Code 1994, § 2-87; Ord. No. 92-J-1, § 2, 6-22-1992) 
Sec. 2-153. - Appointment/confirmation and nomination/election. 
    Where not in conflict with the laws of the state or with the Charter, selection of members for all five-member coterminous entities and selection of members for seats numbered one through five, inclusive, of all coterminous entities with greater than five members shall be by appointment/confirmation; i.e., appointment to each particular seat is made by the councilmember who's council seat number corresponds to the seat number of the subject entity seat, confirmed by a majority vote of the city council. Any appointment not so confirmed shall require a repeat of the procedure with new appointees named until a particular seat-numbered councilmember's appointee is confirmed. Coterminous entity members for seats numbered greater than five shall be selected by council majority vote election from a list of nominees, where each councilmember is entitled to name one nominee for each numbered seat greater than five. 
(Code 1994, § 2-88; Ord. No. 92-J-1, § 3, 6-22-1992) 
Editor's note- On June 22, 1992, such conflict existed with F.S. § 162.05 requiring three-year staggered terms for the code enforcement board and in the selection of members of the police and firefighter pension board of trustees and general employees pension board of trustees, where some members are selected by the employees. 
State Law reference- Code enforcement board requirements, F.S. § 162.05. 
Sec. 2-154. - Noncoterminous entities and others. 
    Members of all noncoterminous entities, of the police/firefighters pension board and of the general employees pension board shall be selected by council majority vote election from a list of nominees, where each councilmember is entitled to name one nominee. When more than one selection is required for a particular entity, after each selection, the councilmember whose nominee was elected may name an additional nominee to the list. The terms of noncoterminous entity members of the police/firefighters pension board shall terminate on the third Tuesday in March of their terminal year; the terms of noncoterminous entity members of the general employees pension board shall terminate in accordance with the operating rules and procedures as established by the board. However, no other provision of this article withstanding, the terms of all noncoterminus entity members shall continue until their successors are selected. 
(Code 1994, § 2-89; Ord. No. 92-J-1, § 4, 6-22-1992; Ord. No. 2006-114, § 1, 5-25-2006) 
Sec. 2-155. - Special purpose entities (ad hoc). 
    The provisions of this division shall not apply to special purpose (ad hoc) entities as may be established by the city council from time to time, but nothing in this section shall prohibit the use of the procedures set forth in this division as a guide therefor. 
(Code 1994, § 2-90; Ord. No. 92-J-1, § 5, 6-22-1992) 
Secs. 2-156-2-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCE[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Charter reference- City fiscal year, § 6.01; submission of budget and budget message, § 6.02. 
State Law reference- Municipal borrowing, F.S. § 166.101 et seq.; municipal finance and taxation, F.S. § 166.201 et seq.; financial matters, F.S. ch. 218. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-181. - City manager to keep set of books. 
    The city manager or, at the city manager's delegation, the finance director shall keep an accurate and complete set of books showing the amount on hand, amounts received, amounts expended and the balances thereof at the end of each month for each and every fund carried by the city, and no warrant or cash disbursement shall ever be drawn in excess of the known balances to the credit of that fund as kept by the city manager or finance director. 
(Code 1967, § 2-15; Code 1994, § 2-146; Ord. No. 2003-39, § I, 6-26-2003) 
Sec. 2-182. - Fee for returned checks. 
    The fee charged to a customer of the city for the return of a check or draft for nonpayment is established at the maximum allowed by state law. 
(Code 1967, § 2-16; Code 1994, § 2-147; Ord. No. 2003-39, § I, 6-26-2003) 
State Law reference- Fee for returned checks, F.S. § 166.251. 
Sec. 2-183. - Uncollectible returned checks and unpaid balances. 
    As a primary method of establishing a means to collect returned (NSF) checks and unpaid balances (with the exception of public safety fines, code enforcement fines, and EMS uncollectible debt) due to the city, the finance department has established procedures for collection of nonutility returned checks and the procedures are on file in the city clerk's office. Upon failure of these procedures, and an item is determined to be uncollectible, the city manager and/or his designee are authorized to write off unpaid balances or accounts on a case-by-case basis. The limitation of the amount for each item that may be written off shall be $7,500.00. If the amount to be written off exceeds the authorized amount, it shall be presented to city council by resolution for approval. Items that have been written-off may be forwarded to a collection agency to further attempt recuperation of the funds owed to the city. 
(Code 1994, § 2-148; Ord. No. 2003-39, § I, 6-26-2003) 
Sec. 2-184. - Depositories of city funds; security. 
(a)  The city is authorized to deposit city funds in any bank or savings and loan association and, pursuant to the Investment of Local Government Surplus Funds Act of the Florida Statutes (F.S. § 218.40 et seq.), is authorized to enter into an agreement for the investment of surplus funds with the state board of administration. Any bank or savings and loan association in which city funds are deposited shall be required, at its own expense, to furnish security acceptable to the city council covering any amounts therein deposited over and above the amounts insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Securities for the deposit of city funds shall be restricted to the type of securities provided by law for deposits of funds of the state. 
(b)  The city council shall provide, by resolution, the persons authorized to provide the state board of administration with changes in agency account and the persons authorized to transmit or withdraw funds to or from the board. 
(Code 1967, § 2-13; Code 1994, § 2-149; Ord. No. 2003-39, § I, 6-26-2003) 
Charter reference- Independent audits of city accounts, § 3.12. 
State Law reference- State board of administration, F.S. § 215.44 et seq. 
Sec. 2-185. - Withdrawal of funds; procedure. 
    All money drawn from any bank holding the same under the terms of this article shall be drawn upon a warrant issued by the city. Such warrant shall, as to number and amount and person to whom drawn, and purpose for which drawn together with copies of documents, be placed in the minutes of the city council. Each warrant drawn shall be signed by the city manager or, at his delegation, by the assistant city manager or the director of finance. 
(Code 1967, § 2-14; Code 1994, § 2-150; Ord. No. 2003-39, § I, 6-26-2003) 
Sec. 2-186. - Qualified investment securities for city funds. 
(a)  When in the judgment of the city manager or his designee, consistent with guidelines approved by the city council, a sufficient amount of money has accumulated in the accounts or funds of the city or when the city has accumulated monies by reason of the sale of securities, the city manager or his designee may purchase investment securities at prevailing market rates on behalf of and in the name of the city in: 
(1)  The Local Governmental Surplus Funds Trust Fund; 
(2)  Negotiable direct obligations of, or obligations the principal and interest of which are unconditionally guaranteed by, the United States Government and its agencies; 
(3)  Non-negotiable interest-bearing time certificates of deposit or savings accounts in state or federal banks, state or federal savings and loan associations as permitted and/or prescribed by state or federal law; 
(4)  Negotiable interest-bearing time certificates of deposit issued by institutions whose long-term debt is rated at least AA or equivalent by Standard and Poor's or Moody's Rating Service; 
(5)  Obligations of federal agencies including, but not limited to, Federal Home Loan Association, Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, including Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation participation certificates, Student Loan Marketing Association, or obligations guaranteed by the Government National Mortgage Association; 
(6)  Bankers acceptances which are issued by domestic institutions whose long-term debt is rated at least AA or equivalent by Standard and Poor's or Moody's Rating Service; 
(7)  Repurchase agreements and reverse repurchase agreements comprised of only those investment instruments as otherwise authorized herein; 
(8)  State and/or local government taxable and tax-exempt debt, general obligation and/or revenue bonds, rated at least AA by Standard and Poor's or Moody's; 
(9)  Collateralized mortgage obligations (CMOs) rated AAA or equivalent by Standard and Poor's or Moody's' and backed by subsection (5) of this section; 
(10)  Mortgage derivative securities including stripped mortgage-backed securities rated AAA or equivalent by Standard and Poor's or Moody's Rating Service and backed by subsection (5) of this section; 
(11)  Fixed-income mutual funds comprised of only those investment instruments as otherwise authorized herein; 
(12)  Investment and reinvestment agreements comprised of only those securities as otherwise authorized herein; 
(13)  Commercial paper rated A-1, P-1, F-1, or DUFF-1; 
(14)  Corporate debt issued by corporations whose long-term debt is rated at least AA or equivalent by Standard and Poor's or Moody's Rating Service; or 
(15)  Asset-backed securities rated at lease AAA by Standard and Poor's or Moody's must be credit enhanced. Enhancement may not be in the form of a letter of credit (LOC). 
(b)  The city manager or his designee, consistent with guidelines approved by the city council, is authorized to sell such obligations or securities purchased pursuant to this section at the prevailing market price and to pay the proceeds of such sale into the proper accounts or funds of the city. 
(c)  The city manager or his designee shall develop and present, for approval, to the city council investment policies addressing, at a minimum, the issues of investment objectives, maturity, risk diversification, institutions used, perfection, safekeeping and custody, delivery vs. payment, trust-receipt and confirmation, authorized institutions, issuers and dealers, and internal controls and investment procedures. 
(d)  Nothing herein contained shall be interpreted or construed to abrogate any specific provision contained in any bond ordinance of the city relating to the investment of bond proceeds temporarily available in specific funds or accounts or escrow accounts held by an agent for purposes of deficiencies of bonds. 
(e)  Nothing herein contained shall be interpreted or construed to abrogate any specific provision contained in any pension ordinance of the city relating to the investment of pension funds available in specific funds. 
(Code 1994, § 2-151; Ord. No. 93-1, §§ 1-3, 4-22-1993; Ord. No. 01-24, §§ 1-5, 6-14-2001; Ord. No. 2003-39, § I, 6-26-2003) 
State Law reference- Investment of public funds, F.S. §§ 166.251, 218.40 et seq. 
Sec. 2-187. - Purchasing policy. 
    The purchasing policy adopted by the city council shall be amended by resolution from time to time. A copy is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1994, § 2-152; Ord. No. 2003-39, § I, 6-26-2003) 
Sec. 2-188. - Sale or lease of surplus real property. 
(a)  Whenever the city council determines that a parcel of real property is surplus and it is in the best interest of the city to sell or lease the real property for a term of five years of more, the issue shall be submitted to a vote of the city council. An approving vote of the majority of all the members of the city council shall be required before any sale of real property or lease of real property for a term of five years or more is authorized. 
(b)  When any proposal for the disposition of real property owned by the city, whether by sale or by lease for a term of five years or more, shall receive a majority vote of all of the members of the city council, such action shall not be effective unless it has been acted upon by the city council after a public hearing preceded at least seven days by publication of a notice of the proposed action. Provided, however, in the event the city procures the proposal through use of a competitive procurement process, the council shall not be required to receive additional bids at the public hearing. 
(c)  The city council shall not approve the sale, lease or other alienation of real property owned by the city for a price or rental below the city's estimate of fair market value or fair rental value thereof, except for specific good cause shown and except in cases involving alienation to another public agency. 
(d)  The term "notice" as used in this section shall mean an advertisement placed in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, which advertisement shall include the following information: 
(1)  The date, time and place of the hearing; 
(2)  The legal description of the real property involved and, if the legal description is a metes and bounds description, a sketch depicting the location of the real property; 
(3)  The street address or approximate street location of the property; 
(4)  The names and addresses of all parties in interest to the proposed land transaction; 
(5)  The city's estimate of the fair market value or the fair rental value of the real property involved; and 
(6)  The proposed sale price or lease payments. 
(e)  This section shall not apply to concession agreements awarded on a competitive basis. 
(f)  All leases and sales and contracts for leases or sales of real property heretofore made by the city are hereby ratified and confirmed. 
(g)  The procedures set forth herein (as they relate only to the sale or lease of light and water plant and public utilities of the city) shall be in addition to the procedures required under section 2.04(a) of the city Charter. This section shall not be construed as to enlarge in any way the applicability of the procedures set forth in section 2.04(a) of the city Charter. 
(Code 1994, § 2-153; Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 9-22-1994; Ord. No. 2003-39, § I, 6-26-2003; Ord. No. 2005-07, § I, 1-13-2005) 
Sec. 2-189. - Extraordinary expenses and services. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Extraordinary expense shall be that expense and those related costs and fees that are incurred by the city for any extraordinary service including, but not limited to, the city's actual cost of labor and materials associated with the use of any specialized extinguishing or abatement agent, chemical, neutralizer or similar equipment (or equipment damage) or materials that are employed to extinguish, confine, neutralize, contain or clean any hazardous material that is or may be involved in a fire, accidental spill, or the threat of any fire or accidental spill. 
    Extraordinary service is one performed by the city fire department or any other city department or bureau that, in the judgment of the city manager or his designee, is additional to or above the normal services provided by such departments or bureaus. "Extraordinary services" may include, but are not limited to, crowd safety, security and traffic control; evacuation and emergency housing; the abatement and disposition of hazardous materials; spills or the threat of spills of toxic chemicals; leaks or threats of leaks of toxic or hazardous gases; other imminent or perceived or possible threats to the health, safety or welfare of the city residents that may be detailed or contemplated in the definition of "extraordinary expense"; and those instances where a property owner has been previously warned about violations of the City Code that, in the judgment of the city manager or his designee, are a particular threat to the health, safety or welfare of the city residents, and for which the owner (or owner's agent, or person in charge of the property) has neglected to comply or has refused compliance therewith. 
(b)  Administration. The city manager or his designee shall collect all fees as follows: 
(1)  Fees and costs shall encompass all manpower, equipment (or equipment damage), material and maintenance expenses in such a form as to ensure for the city's full reimbursement for charges for those services actually rendered. A particular cost or fee schedule need not be memorialized in this section or elsewhere in the city Code or by further formal action by the city council, the city council's approval of this section constituting an authorization for the city manager or his designee to collect all such fees and costs pursuant to his receipt of related expenditures or costs that are submitted to him by the affected city departments or bureaus. 
(2)  Within 30 days of the date of the extraordinary or dangerous occurrence giving rise to the extraordinary service, the affected department or bureau shall submit its extraordinary service-related costs, fees, charges, expenses, or any of these things or all of these things in combination, to the city manager or his designee for his review. At such time as all costs, fees and so forth related to extraordinary services have been collected and reviewed by the city manager or his designee, but in any case not later than 60 days from the date of the rendering of the extraordinary services, the city manager or his designee shall send a bill of consolidated costs, fees and so forth to the property owner, agent or manager, with a demand that a full remittance be made within 30 days of receipt of the bill. 
(3)  It is also contemplated that local, state or federal agencies may bill, fine or penalize the city for matters (including, but not limited to, a cleanup cost, fee or expense) relating to an extraordinary or dangerous occurrence, and the city manager or his designee shall, if possible, include any and all such costs or fees in the consolidated bill sent to the property owner. The city shall not, however, waive any right to collect such local, state or federal costs if they are not included with the consolidated bill, and are not charged to the property owner or his agent within the consolidated billing (60-day) period. In this regard, the city manager or his designee shall expect reimbursement of all local, state or federal costs within 30 days of the owner's (or his agent's) receipt of the bill for these particular costs, fees and so forth. 
(4)  In cases of hardship or where circumstances are such that a full remittance cannot be made to the city within the 30-day period, the city council shall hereby authorize the city manager or his designee to enter into negotiations with the property owner or his agent for an extended payback period of time not to exceed six months, and for which the city may charge the state statutorily mandated interest payment on judgments, pursuant to F.S. §§ 55.03 and 55.04. 
(5)  All monies received under the provisions of this section shall be placed in an account established for the express purpose of reimbursing the various city departments and bureaus for those actual costs and expenses necessary to furnish fire, police and other emergency or public safety services or protection provided by the city as outlined herein. 
(c)  Litigation. The city may enforce the provisions of this section by civil actions in a court of competent jurisdiction for the collection of any amounts due hereunder, plus attorney's fees or for any other relief that may be appropriate. 
(d)  Municipal services not to be refused for nonpayment. Nothing in this section shall authorize any city department or bureau, or any department personnel or bureau personnel, to refuse or delay any municipal service to any person, firm, organization or corporation that has not reimbursed the city for an extraordinary municipal service as provided under this section. Furthermore, nothing in this section shall be construed to demand reimbursement to the city for those municipal services that are normally provided to city residents and others as a matter of the city's general operating procedures, and for which the levying of taxes or the demand for reimbursement is normally made. 
(Code 1994, § 2-154; Ord. No. 94-35, § I, 9-22-1994; Ord. No. 2003-39, § I, 6-26-2003) 
Sec. 2-190. - Schedule of fees to be charged by the police department. 
    The police department is authorized to charge a fee for certain services as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. The schedule of fees to be charged by the police department will be kept on file in the city clerk's office, and may be amended from time to time by resolution. 
(Code 1994, § 71-1; Ord. No. 97-27, § 1, 10-23-1997) 
Secs. 2-191-2-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUDGET[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference- Budget, § 6.02 et seq. 

Sec. 2-211. - Budget message. 
    The city manager's message shall explain the budget in fiscal terms and in terms of the work programs. It shall outline the proposed financial policies of the city for the ensuing fiscal year, describe the important features of the budget, indicate any major changes from the current year in financial policies, expenditures, and revenues together with the reasons for such changes, summarize the city's debt position and include such other materials as the manager deems desirable or which the city council may require. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 65-2166, § 6.03; Code 1994, § 2-161) 
Sec. 2-212. - Amendments after adoption. 
(a)  Supplemental appropriations. If, during the fiscal year, the manager certifies that there are available for appropriation revenue in excess of those estimated in the budget, the city council may, by resolution, make supplemental appropriations for the year up to the amount of each excess. 
(b)  Emergency appropriations. To meet a public emergency affecting life, health, property or the public peace, the city council may make emergency appropriations. Such appropriations may be made by resolution. To the extent that there are no available unappropriated revenues to meet such appropriations, the council may by such resolution authorize the issuance of emergency notes, which may be renewed from time to time, but the emergency notes and renewals of any fiscal year shall be paid not later than the last day of the fiscal year succeeding that in which the emergency appropriations were made. 
(c)  Reduction of appropriations. If, at any time during the fiscal year, it appears probable to the manager that the revenues available will be insufficient to meet the amount appropriated, he shall report to the city council without delay, indicating the estimated amount of the deficit, any remedial action taken by him and his recommendations as to any other steps to be taken. The council shall then take such further action as it deems necessary to prevent or minimize any deficit and for that purpose it may reduce one or more appropriations. 
(d)  Transfer of appropriations. At any time during the fiscal year, the manager may, on notification to the city council, transfer part or all of any unencumbered appropriation balance among programs within a department, office or agency and, upon written request by the manager, the council may, by resolution, transfer all or part of any unencumbered appropriation balance from one department, office or agency to another. 
(e)  Limitations; effective date. No appropriation may be reduced below any amount required by law to be appropriated or by more than the amount of the unencumbered balance thereof. The supplemental and emergency appropriations and reduction of or transfer of appropriations authorized by this section may be made effective immediately upon adoption. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 65-2166, § 6.09; Code 1994, § 2-162) 
Sec. 2-213. - Lapse of appropriations. 
    Every appropriation, except an appropriation for a capital expenditure, shall lapse at the close of the fiscal year to the extent that it has not been expended or is unencumbered. The foregoing sentence shall not be interpreted so as to be in conflict with Charter section 6.06(c). An appropriation for a capital expenditure will continue in force until the purpose for which it was made has been accomplished or abandoned; the purpose of any such appropriation shall be deemed abandoned if three years pass without any disbursement from, or encumbrance of, the appropriation. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 65-2166, § 6.10; Code 1994, § 2-163) 
Sec. 2-214. - Administration budget. 
(a)  Work programs and allotments. At such times as the manager shall specify, each department, office or agency shall submit work programs for the ensuing fiscal year showing the requested allotments of its appropriations within the year. The manager shall review and authorize such allotments with or without revision as early as possible in the fiscal year. He may revise such allotments during the year if he deems it desirable and shall revise them to accord with any supplemental, emergency, reduced or transferred appropriations made pursuant to section 2-212. 
(b)  Payments and obligations prohibited. No payment shall be made or obligation incurred against any allotment or appropriation except in accordance with appropriations duly made and unless the manager or his designee first certifies that there is an unencumbered balance in such allotment or appropriation and that sufficient funds therefrom are or will be available to cover the claim or meet the obligation when it becomes due and payable. Any authorization of payment or incurring of obligation in violation of the provisions of the Charter shall be void and any payments so made illegal; such action shall be cause for removal of any officer who knowingly authorized or made such payment or incurred such obligation, and he shall be liable to the city for any amount so paid. However, except where prohibited by law, nothing in the Charter shall be construed to prevent the making or authorizing of payments or making of contracts for capital improvements to be financed wholly or partly by the issuance of bonds or to prevent the making of any contract or lease for providing for payments beyond the end of the fiscal year, provided that such action is made or approved by resolution. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 65-2166, § 6.11; Code 1994, § 2-164) 
Secs. 2-215-2-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LAND USE REGULATION FEES 

Sec. 2-231. - Imposition; conformance with division. 
    No land use regulation fee (impact fee) shall be imposed by any entity upon the lands contained within the corporate limits of the city unless such imposition and the provisions of the ordinance, resolution or other implementing instrument is in conformity with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1967, § 2-12(a); Code 1994, § 2-176) 
Sec. 2-232. - Restrictions on use of funds. 
(a)  No funds collected from any land use regulation fee (impact fee) however, whenever and by whomever imposed on land within the corporate limits of the city shall be expended, directly or indirectly, in payment of any project undertaken prior to the imposition of the impact fee. 
(b)  No funds collected from any increase of a land use regulation fee (impact fee) however, whenever and by whomever the increase is imposed on land within the corporate limits of the city shall be expended, directly or indirectly, in payment of any project undertaken prior to the imposition of the impact fee increase. 
(c)  No funds collected from any land use regulation fee (impact fee) however, whenever and by whomever imposed on land within the corporate limits of the city shall be expended, directly or indirectly, in payment of interest or principal of bonded indebtedness, the funds from which were used or committed for use in payment of a project undertaken prior to the imposition of the impact fee. 
(d)  No funds collected from any increase of a land use regulation fee (impact fee) however, whenever and by whomever the increase is imposed on land within the corporate limits of the city shall be expended, directly or indirectly, in payment of interest or principal of bonded indebtedness, the funds from which were used or committed for use in payment of a project undertaken prior to the imposition of the impact fee increase. 
(e)  The term "indirect" as used in subsections (a) through (d) of this section includes, but is not limited to, the use of impact fees or impact fee increases, funds to replace funds derived from another source and the "another source" funds being used as here prohibited; and shall include the use of impact fees or impact fee increases, funds in payment of interest or principal of refund bonded indebtedness where the proceeds of the refund bonds were used to refund bonds issued for projects undertaken prior to the imposition of the impact fee or impact fee increase. 
(Code 1967, § 2-12(b)-(f); Code 1994, § 2-177; Ord. No. 89-III, 5-3-1990) 
Secs. 2-233-2-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CODE ENFORCEMENT[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal code enforcement, F.S. ch. 162; local government code enforcement boards, F.S. § 162.01 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-261. - Code enforcement special magistrate. 
(a)  Appointed. The city council shall appoint a code enforcement special magistrate for purposes of reviewing alleged violations of the City Code in accordance with F.S. ch. 162, as may be amended. 
(b)  Qualifications. The code enforcement special magistrate shall be a member in good standing of the Florida Bar and shall have such other qualifications as the council may determine. 
(c)  Powers and duties. The code enforcement special magistrate shall have all of the powers and duties granted under F.S. ch. 162, pt. I (F.S. § 162.01 et seq.). The city hereby adopts such provision by reference as if set out fully herein. 
(d)  References in City Code or Land Development Code. Wherever any ordinance or provision of the City Code or the City Land Development Code shall reference the code enforcement board it shall be deemed to reference and apply to the code enforcement special magistrate as created herein. 
(Ord. No. 2015-15 , § 1, 3-12-2015) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-15 , § 1, adopted March 12, 2015, amended § 2-261 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 2-261 pertained to code enforcement board and derived from the Code of 1967, §§ 2-71(a), (b); the Code of 1994, § 2-211; and Ord. No. 95-25, § I, June 8, 1995. 
Secs. 2-262-2-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CODE ENFORCEMENT CITATIONS 

Sec. 2-281. - Authorization. 
    In accordance with and under the authority of F.S. ch. 162, part II (F.S. § 162.21 et seq.), the city hereby creates a supplemental and additional method of enforcing its codes and ordinances by the issuance of citations for violation of city codes and ordinances. Nothing contained herein shall prohibit the city's enforcement of its codes or ordinances by any other means. 
(Code 1994, § 2-236; Ord. No. 99-18, § 1, 7-8-1999) 
Sec. 2-282. - Applicable codes and ordinances. 
    A schedule of codes and ordinances, which may be enforced pursuant to the supplemental code enforcement citation procedures contained herein, is attached to Ordinance No. 2012-23 as "Exhibit A" and incorporated by reference as if fully set forth in this section. The schedule of codes and ordinances shall include such codes and ordinances as they may be from time to time amended, renumbered, codified or recodified including codes and ordinances enacted subsequent to the adopting of this division. 
(Code 1994, § 2-237; Ord. No. 99-18, § 1, 7-8-1999; Ord. No. 2001-15, § 1, 1-11-2001; Ord. No. 2003-31, § 1, 4-10-2003; Ord. No. 2004-119, § 1, 10-14-2004; Ord. No. 2008-014, § V, 1-24-2008; Ord. No. 2011-03, § 1(Exh. A), 2-10-2011; Ord. No. 2012-23, § 1(Exh. A), 5-24-2012) 
Sec. 2-283. - Code enforcement officers. 
(a)  The city council is hereby authorized to designate, by resolution, certain employees or agents as "code enforcement officers." Code enforcement officers so designated shall have the powers and limitations as prescribed herein and by statute. 
(b)  The designation of code enforcement officers and their training and/or qualifications of code enforcement officers shall be established by the city manager or his designee in accordance with applicable statutes, resolutions and ordinances. 
(c)  Pursuant to the requirements of F.S. ch. 162, part II (F.S. § 162.21 et seq.), and consistent with the procedures set forth in this article, a code enforcement officer may issue a citation alleging a violation of any of the codes or ordinances enumerated in Exhibit "A" which is on file in the office of the city clerk. A code or ordinance violation for which a citation is issued pursuant to this article shall be deemed a civil infraction. 
(Code 1994, § 2-238; Ord. No. 99-18, § 1, 7-8-1999) 
Sec. 2-284. - Procedures; investigation of violations; issuance of citations. 
(a)  A code enforcement officer is hereby authorized to issue a citation to any person for violation of any code or ordinance listed in Exhibit "A" which is on file in the office of the city clerk when, based upon personal investigation, the code enforcement officer has reasonable cause to believe that a violation has occurred. The word "person" shall include an individual, corporation, business trust, estate, partnership, association, two or more persons having a joint or common interest, or any other legal entity. 
(b)  Except as provided by subsection (c) of this section, the code enforcement officer shall provide notice to the person that the person has committed a violation of such code or ordinance and shall establish a reasonable time period within which the person must correct the violation. Such time period to correct the violation shall not exceed 30 days. 
(c)  A code enforcement officer is not required to provide the person with a reasonable time period to correct the violation prior to issuing a citation and may immediately issue a citation if a repeat violation is found or if the code enforcement officer has reason to believe that the violation presents a serious threat to the public health, safety or welfare, or if the violation is irreparable or irreversible. 
(d)  Written warning notices, if applicable, and citations shall be provided to the alleged violator by hand delivery by the code enforcement officer. In the absence of the alleged violator, issuance of a written warning notice or citation may be accomplished by leaving a copy at the alleged violator's residence with any person residing therein who is 15 years of age or older and informing the person of the contents, or by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested. 
(e)  Issuance of a written warning notice or citation to a business may be accomplished by leaving a copy at the business during regular business hours with any employee and informing the employee of the contents, or by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested. Each employee of the business shall be deemed to be an agent of the business for service of warning notices and citations. 
(f)  If upon personal investigation the code enforcement officer finds that the violation has not been corrected within the time period, a code enforcement officer may issue a citation for a civil infraction to the person accused of committing the violation. 
(g)  The citation shall be in such form as prescribed by resolution of the council and consistent with the requirements of F.S. ch. 162, part II (F.S. § 162.21 et seq.). 
(h)  Each violation of a code or ordinance is a separate civil infraction. Each day such violation continues shall be deemed to constitute a separate civil infraction. 
(i)  The maximum civil penalty for each violation shall not exceed $500.00 plus any applicable court costs. 
(j)  After issuing a citation to an alleged violator, the code enforcement officer shall: 
(1)  Deposit the original citation and one copy of the citation with the clerk of court for the county court; 
(2)  Provide the person cited with one copy; and 
(3)  Retain one copy in the code enforcement officer's department or division file. 
(k)  If the person cited refuses to sign the citation, the code enforcement officer shall write the words "refused" or "refused to sign" in the space provided for the person's signature. The code enforcement officer shall then leave a copy of the citation with the person cited, if possible, and shall contact the city police department to file the necessary reports alleging a violation of F.S. § 162.21(6), which provides that a person who willfully refuses to sign and accept a citation issued by a code enforcement officer shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree punishable as provided in F.S. § 775.082 or 775.083. 
(Code 1994, § 2-239; Ord. No. 99-18, § 1, 7-8-1999) 
Sec. 2-285. - Payment of fines; court hearings. 
(a)  If the person elects not to contest the citation, the person shall pay in full the applicable reduced civil penalty as set forth in Exhibit "A" which is on file in the office of the city clerk to the clerk of the court within 14 days after issuance of the citation. 
(b)  If the person cited elects to pay the applicable reduced civil penalty set forth in Exhibit "A," which is on file in the office of the city clerk, the person shall be deemed to have admitted the infraction and waived the right to a hearing. If the person cited fails to pay the civil penalty by the fourteenth day after issuance of the citation or fails to request a court hearing within the time prescribed, the person shall have waived any right to contest the citation, and a judgment shall be entered against the person cited in an amount up to the maximum civil penalty, which shall not exceed $500.00. 
(c)  If the person elects to contest the citation, the person shall appear in court before a county court judge on such date and time as provided for on the citation to request a hearing date. The date and time on the citation to request a hearing date shall not be sooner than 21 days after the citation is issued. 
(d)  A county judge, after a hearing on the citation, shall make a determination whether or not a violation of this article has been committed. If a violation is found to have occurred, the county judge may impose a civil penalty up to the maximum civil penalty in an amount not to exceed $500.00 plus applicable court costs. 
(e)  The judge may provide for the civil penalty to be paid within such time as the judge determines to be appropriate. If the person found to be in violation fails to pay the fine within the time provided, a civil judgment shall be entered against that person in the amount up to the maximum civil penalty not to exceed $500.00. 
(f)  Should the person cited schedule a hearing as provided for herein, and thereafter fail to appear at such hearing, the person shall be deemed to have waived the right to contest the citation, and a civil judgment shall be entered against the person in an amount up to the maximum civil penalty. Provided, however, that the court shall have the discretion to continue or reschedule any hearing when it determines that doing so will further the interest of justice. In such an event, the clerk shall notify the code enforcement officer and the person cited of the date and time of the new hearing. 
(Code 1994, § 2-240; Ord. No. 99-18, § 1, 7-8-1999) 
Sec. 2-286. - Procedures for payment of civil penalty. 
    Payment of any civil penalty imposed by this article shall be made to the clerk of the court, who shall forward the monies collected to the director of finance for the city for deposit into the appropriate city fund for distribution and use by the code enforcement division of the city department that issued the citation upon which the penalty was collected. If a judgment has been entered for the civil penalty, the clerk of the court shall notify the county when the judgment has been paid, and the necessary satisfaction of judgments shall be prepared and recorded in the official records of the county. A portion, as determined by the clerk of the court and approved by city, of each penalty collected shall be retained by the clerk of the court as an administrative fee. 
(Code 1994, § 2-241; Ord. No. 99-18, § 1, 7-8-1999) 
Sec. 2-287. - Violation classifications and civil penalties. 
    Violations of county codes or ordinances and the applicable reduced civil penalty shall be classified as follows: 
Violation Classification Reduced Civil Penalty Class I $ 25.00 Class II 100.00 Class III 200.00 Class IV 500.00  
City codes or ordinances subsequently enacted or amended may set forth the applicable civil penalty for violations by designating the appropriate violation classification as provided in this section. 
(Code 1994, § 2-242; Ord. No. 99-18, § 1, 7-8-1999) 
Secs. 2-288-2-310. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ANNEXATIONS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Annexation, F.S. ch. 171. 

Sec. 2-311. - Procedures for voluntary annexation. 
(a)  All requests for voluntary annexation to the city shall be initiated by filing with the city manager a properly executed petition for annexation, certificate of title and statement of intended use, on such forms as shall be established by the city manager, and the city manager shall furnish such forms to any potential applicant upon request. 
(b)  Upon receipt by the city manager of the properly completed and executed petition for annexation, certificate of title and statement of intended use, the city manager shall submit copies of the documents to the city building department and the city attorney for their review. 
(c)  The city building department head will review the information concerning the requested annexation, will discuss same with all other city department heads and will make a written report to the planning commission containing comments and recommendations concerning the impact of the intended use of the property involved upon all city services. If the information submitted with the petition for annexation is not sufficient for the building department head to prepare the required report, the applicant for annexation shall provide such additional information as shall be required by the building department head upon request, and if such information is not provided as requested, the building department head shall be under no obligation to provide the written report to the planning commission and the annexation process will be suspended until such time as the requested information is provided or the city council shall otherwise direct. 
(d)  Upon receipt of the report from the building department head, the city planning commission will investigate and review all information concerning the requested annexation, will afford the applicant for annexation an opportunity to meet with the planning commission and discuss the annexation, and will make written recommendation to the city council concerning the annexation, including therein any suggested amendments or conditions to the annexation. 
(e)  The city council will, at its next regular meeting, following receipt of written recommendation from the planning commission, consider the annexation request and decide what action to take thereupon, which action may include but not be limited to directing the preparation for introduction of an ordinance annexing the property involved, continuing action on the annexation until a later date or declining to further consider the annexation. If the council shall decide to introduce an ordinance granting the requested annexation, the procedure for adoption of such ordinance shall be as set forth in the statutes of the state, the city Charter and this Code. 
(f)  The provisions of this section are declared to be advisory only, and notwithstanding any of the above and foregoing provisions, the city council shall retain the right in its sole discretion to take any action it shall deem fit with regard to any annexation request including but not limited to the waiving of any of the requirements set forth above unless such waiver shall be prohibited by the statutes of the state or the city Charter. 
(Code 1967, § 2-9; Code 1994, § 2-256) 
State Law reference- Supplemental procedure for voluntary annexations, F.S. § 171.044. 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Liquors and beverages, F.S. ch. 561 et seq. 

Sec. 4-1. - Conformity with state law; definitions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be construed according to and in conformity with the acts of the legislature of the state, concerning alcoholic beverages, as set forth in F.S. chs. 561, 562, 563, 564, and 565, as amended and hereinafter referred to collectively as the "Beverage Law." The definitions and classifications contained in the Beverage Law are hereby adopted in construing the terms of this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1; Code 1994, § 6-1; Ord. No. 2000-52, § 1, 11-9-2000) 
Sec. 4-2. - Hours of sale. 
(a)  Generally. The hours of sale of intoxicating liquors, wines or beer in the city are between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m., all days except for Sunday. 
(b)  Sunday sales. Sunday sales shall be allowed as on any weekday subject to the following hours of sales restrictions: 
(1)  On-premises consumption and service. Sunday sales of alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption and service shall only be permitted between the hours of 11:00 a.m. Sunday and 2:00 a.m. of the following day. Notwithstanding the above, for the following establishments the sale, consumption and service of alcoholic beverages may begin at 7:00 a.m. on Sunday. 
a.  Nonprofit subordinate lodges or clubs of national fraternal or benevolent associations; 
b.  Golf clubs, tennis clubs and beach or cabana clubs, which are municipally owned or leased; 
c.  Nonprofit corporations or clubs devoted to promoting community, municipal, or county development or any phase of community, municipal, or community development; and 
d.  Nonprofit clubs promoting, developing and maintaining cultural relations of people of the same nationality. 
(2)  Off-premises consumption. Sunday sales of alcoholic beverages for off-premises consumption shall only be permitted between the hours of 9:00 a.m. Sunday and 2:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(c)  Time and regulations for cessation of alcoholic beverage sales. Any establishment that dispenses alcoholic beverages in the city for consumption on the establishment's premises, at the hour of 2:00 a.m., shall cause all outside lights on the premises occupied by it to be extinguished and all entrances and exits to such establishment to be locked and not opened except to admit the proprietor and his employees to enter and to permit the egress of the proprietor, employees, and customers of such place from the premises. In no instance shall open containers of alcoholic beverages be accessible to customers, members or guests of members, or be permitted to be in the open patronage area of the establishment one-half hour after the time for cessation of alcoholic beverage sales has expired. Customers, members or guests of members, within the establishment shall be required by the proprietor or his employees to leave the establishment within one hour after the cessation of alcoholic beverage sales has expired. Nothing herein shall be construed to permit any place to sell, serve or permit alcoholic beverages to be sold or served during the prohibited hours as defined in subsections (a) and (b) of this section. 
(Code 1967, § 3-3; Code 1994, § 6-2; Ord. No. 94-8, § I, 4-14-1994; Ord. No. 00-52, § 2, 11-9-2000; Ord. No. 02-22, § 1, 6-13-2002) 
State Law reference- Municipalities may regulate hours of sale of alcoholic beverages, F.S. §§ 562.14, 562.45(2). 
Sec 4-3 - Consumption or possession upon public property; penalty. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic beverage, including beer and wine, upon any city owned parks and beaches, city property or street, alley or sidewalk of the city, except as provided for in article III, division 27, entertainment district. This section shall not apply to any city owned property which is subject to a management contract, or sidewalk cafés. For those properties, alcohol consumption shall be governed by rules established jointly by the managing entity and the city manager. Further, this section shall not apply to those portions of the above named properties included within the boundaries established by the city council for a special event for which permission to consume alcoholic beverages is given in conjunction with the permission for the event. In addition, the city council shall have the right to limit the type of alcoholic beverage to be consumed when granting any such permit. 
(b)  Carrying open containers. It shall be unlawful for any person to carry an opened bottle, can, or other container containing an alcoholic beverage, including beer and wine, upon any city parks, city beaches, city property or street, alley or sidewalk of the city, except as provided for in article III, division 27 entertainment district as described in section 4-3(c). Further, this subsection shall not apply to those portions of the above named properties included within the boundaries established by the city council for a special event for which permission to carry open containers of alcoholic beverages is given in conjunction with the permission for the event, or sidewalk cafés. In addition, the city council shall have the right to limit the type of alcoholic beverage to be consumed when granting any such permit. In no event will consumption occur directly from glass containers. 
(c)  Entertainment district. Open containers for alcoholic beverages may be permitted within the entertainment district as described in article III, division 27, entertainment district of this Code. 
(d)  Permits, procedure. Notwithstanding subsections (a) and (b) of this section, permits for the consumption of alcoholic beverages in parks and recreation areas may be obtained by application to the city manager or the city manager's designee in accordance with the following procedure. 
(1)  A person seeking issuance of a permit shall file an application stating the following: 
a.  The name, address and age of the applicant; 
b.  The name and address of the person or association sponsoring the activity, if any; 
c.  The day and hours for which the permit is desired; 
d.  The park or portion thereof for which the permit is desired; 
e.  Any other information reasonably necessary to a determination as to whether a permit should be issued; 
f.  Variances required from park rules. 
(2)  A use permit shall [be] issued if the city manager determines: 
a.  The proposed activity or use of the park will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the general public's enjoyment of the park. 
b.  The proposed activity and use will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the promotion of public health, welfare, safety and recreation. 
c.  The proposed activity or uses that are reasonably anticipated will not include violence, crime or disorderly conduct. 
d.  The proposed activity will not entail extraordinary or burdensome expense or police operation by the city. 
e.  The facilities desired have not been reserved for other use on the date and hour requested in the application. 
(e)  Appeal. Within ten days after the receipt of an application the city manager shall inform an applicant in writing of the decision to grant or deny a permit. For denial, the notification shall include the reason for the denial. Any person denied a permit shall have the right to appeal to the city council by serving written notice thereof on the city clerk within five working days of such refusal.
