(2)  The facility, office, or building is owned or leased by a publicly held corporation whose shares are traded on a national exchange and whose total assets at the end of the corporation's most recent fiscal quarter exceeded $50,000,000.00; 
(3)  The facility, office, or building is affiliated with an accredited medical school where training is provided for medical students, medical residents, or fellows; 
(4)  The facility, office, or building is owned by a corporate entity exempt from federal taxation under 26 U.S.C. § 501(c)(3); 
(5)  The facility, office, or building is licensed as a facility pursuant to F.S. ch. 395; 
(6)  The facility, office, or building is owned or operated by a public agency; or 
(7)  The facility, office, building, or pharmacist: 
a.  Does not purchase, store or dispense more than an aggregate of 5,000 unit doses of schedule II substances as defined herein on a monthly basis. The pharmacy may exceed the monthly aggregate by up to ten percent provided the pharmacy's annual aggregate of schedule II substances does not exceed 60,000 unit doses; and 
b.  Has no principals, officers and/or pharmacists with criminal convictions under F.S. ch. 893 within the last ten years; and 
c.  Executes an agreement for pain medication license exemption in substantially the format as adopted by the city council that will result in the revocation of the certificate of use and local business tax receipt and inability of the facility, office, building or pharmacist, or any successor entity or person, to apply for any certificate of use or local business tax receipt within the city for the next 24 months upon determination by the city manager or his/her designee based on the recommendation of the police chief of any violation of the agreement; and 
d.  Files a monthly affidavit by the seventh day of each month for the previous month with the police chief identifying the types and quantities of schedule II substances as defined herein: 
1.  That were purchased during the reporting period, and 
2.  That were sold during the reporting period. 
3.  That were stored during the reporting period. 
e.  The owners and operator of the facility, office, or building have not had a pain medication license suspended, revoked, non-renewed or denied in the previous 24 months. 
(8)  The facility, office, building or pharmacist is located within a retail store that has a minimum of 40,000 square feet of retail and that maintains more than 20 locations within the State of Florida. 
    Non-exempt pharmacy means a facility, office, building, or other establishment which engages in the storing and dispensing of prescription substances and do not meet the criteria of an exempt pharmacy. A non-exempt pharmacy shall be required to obtain a pain medication license 
    Schedule II means a substance that has a high potential for abuse and has a currently accepted but severely restricted medical use in treatment in the United States, and abuse of the substance may lead to severe psychological or physical dependence and as defined in F.S. § 893.03, as amended from time to time. For the purposes of this article, the following substances are exempted from the definition of schedule II substances and shall not be counted in the monthly or annual aggregate unit doses: Nabilone, Phenyclidine, 1- Phenylcyclohexylamine, 1-Piperidinocyclohexanecarbonitrile, Amobarbital, Amphetamine, Glutethimide, Methamphetamine, Methylphenidate, Pentobarbital, Phenmatrazine, Phenylacetone, and Secobarbital. 
(Ord. No. 2011-71, § 2, 10-27-2011; Ord. No. 2017-38 , § 1, 9-28-2017) 
Sec. 12-151. - Pain medication licensing procedure. 
(a)  License required. It shall be unlawful for any pain management clinic to prescribe any schedule II controlled substance or non-exempt pharmacy to store and dispense any schedule II controlled substance without first obtaining a pain medication license from the City of St. Cloud. 
(b)  Pain medication licensing procedure. Any pain management clinic holding a license duly granted by the State of Florida to prescribe schedule II controlled substances or any non-exempt pharmacy holding a license duly granted by the State of Florida to store and dispense schedule II controlled substances may apply for a pain medication license. The applicant shall pay a fee for the review and processing of the application as set forth in section 12-152. The application shall be processed using the procedures and criteria listed in this article. In the event that such an establishment is under contract for sale, the current owner and the potential future owner, under contract, must submit a joint application for a pain medication license. The fee for the issuance of the pain medication license shall be the same as for a new license and shall be paid prior to issuance of the license. A pain medication license granted to a duly licensed establishment shall allow the pain management clinic to lawfully prescribe schedule II substances or non-exempt pharmacy to lawfully store and dispense schedule II substances within the City of St. Cloud. Pain medication licenses are hereby deemed to be a privilege granted by the city council, and are declared to be and are regulatory in nature, and revocable pursuant to the procedures set forth in this chapter. 
(c)  Revocation of existing pain medication licenses and approvals, and establishment of pain medication licensing procedure. The ability to prescribe and/or dispense schedule II substances within the city is hereby declared to be and is a privilege subject to review and approval, suspension, termination, and the imposition of conditions as provided below, and no person may reasonably rely upon the granting of or the continuation of that privilege. Pain management clinics and pharmacies, as defined under section 12-150, that do not fall under an exemption and that wish to prescribe or dispense schedule II substances after December 31, 2011, including any pain management clinic or pharmacy to whom an authorization or approval for prescribing or dispensing has previously been granted by the city or which was not previously required to obtain any city approval, shall be required to make an application and receive approval for a pain medication license no later than December 31, 2011. 
(Ord. No. 2011-71, § 2, 10-27-2011; Ord. No. 2017-38 , § 1, 9-28-2017) 
Sec. 12-152. - Application and review procedures for pain medication licenses. 
(a)  Application. One application per location for a pain medication license shall be submitted, on a form furnished by the city, to the city manager or his/her designee, along with a nonrefundable application fee of $500.00 per location. The amount of the application fee may be modified by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  Public notice. All owners of property located within 500 feet of the parcel for which a new pain medication license is requested shall be notified of the application. The letter of notification will set forth a description of the request and a date, time and place of the hearing before the city council. Letters will be mailed by the city to said property owners by first-class mail using a certified list provided by the applicant as part of its application. The required notification shall be postmarked at least 15 days prior to the hearing date at which the application will be heard before the city council. Staff is authorized to charge the applicant a reasonable fee for the city's cost of preparing and mailing notices. 
(c)  Public hearing. The city council, in accordance with the procedures of this chapter, shall conduct a public hearing on the application for a pain medication license, during which staff and the licensee may address the city council. 
(d)  Determination. The city council shall approve, approve with conditions, or deny the request for a pain medication license in accordance with the procedures of this article. 
(1)  Approval. The city council may approve an application for a pain medication license upon a determination that the subject application is consistent with the health, safety, and welfare of the city and pursuant to the criteria and conditions set forth in sections 12-153 and 12-154 of this article. 
(2)  Conditional approval. The city council may require, as a condition of the privilege of granting of a pain medication license, compliance with any reasonable condition deemed to be necessary to mitigate or eliminate the potential adverse effects of such dispensing and prescribing schedule II substances, in addition to the conditions provided in section 12-154. These conditions may include, without being limited to, provision by the owner or operator at his/her expense measures designed for security, crowd control, noise attenuation, crime prevention or reduction, and other similar protections designed to mitigate the effects of the operation of the pain management clinic or non-exempt pharmacy. 
(3)  Denial. An application which is determined by the city council to be inconsistent with the public health, safety, and welfare or the review criteria set forth herein, shall be denied. Any applicant who makes an application which is denied, after any appeal therefrom, shall be precluded from making another application for 24 months from the date of such denial of the application or conclusion of the appeal. 
(Ord. No. 2011-71, § 2, 10-27-2011; Ord. No. 2017-38 , § 1, 9-28-2017) 
Sec. 12-153. - Review criteria for pain medication licenses. 
    An application for a pain medication license shall be submitted to the city manager or his/her designee. The development review committee shall review the application, based on the criteria of this section and consistency of the application with the public health, safety, and welfare of the city, and shall make a recommendation to the city manager or his/her designee. The city manager or his/her designee shall prepare a report to the city council recommending approval, approval with conditions, or denial, based upon the following criteria: 
(1)  The amount and degree of law enforcement activities generated by the operation of any such establishment, by previous similar establishments in the same location or at any location involving any of the same owners or operators. Consideration will be given as to whether the calls are initiated by the pain medication license holder and what efforts have been taken to reduce unlawful activity at establishments owned or operated by the applicant; 
(2)  Pursuant to F.S. § 166.0442, all owners or operators or any other party with a proprietary interest in such establishment shall undergo fingerprinting to be submitted to the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) for a state and national criminal history record check. Criminal history record checks shall be conducted in order to provide assurances that such persons have no criminal convictions, including, but not limited to, convictions under F.S. ch. 893 within the last ten years; 
(3)  The adverse effects of prescribing, storing, and/or dispensing schedule II substances shall not place an undue burden on the neighborhood in proximity to the establishment, especially with respect to patron activities and effects of noise, traffic, parking, and vehicular use; and 
(4)  Compatibility with the existing uses in the neighborhood in proximity to the establishment. 
(5)  The amount and degree of security measures in place, including, but not limited to: impact resistant glass, exterior lighting, security cameras, video recordings, alarm and panic system, crime prevention through environmental design ("CPTED") standards, principals, and signage. 
(Ord. No. 2011-71, § 2, 10-27-2011; Ord. No. 2017-38 , § 1, 9-28-2017) 
Sec. 12-154. - Mandatory conditions for pain medication licenses. 
    All pain medication licenses shall require compliance with the following conditions: 
(1)  During all hours of operation, the pain management clinic or non-exempt pharmacy shall comply with the following conditions: 
a.  Each pain management clinic or non-exempt pharmacy shall be registered separately for each location within the city regardless of whether each clinic or pharmacy is operated under the same business name or management as another clinic or pharmacy; 
b.  Each application for a pain management clinic or non-exempt pharmacy shall disclose each owner and operator of such clinic or pharmacy, and individual principals of any entity that owns such clinic or pharmacy; 
c.  The pain management clinic or non-exempt pharmacy shall not limit the form of payment for goods or service to cash only; 
d.  The pain management clinic or non-exempt pharmacy shall not accept cash for payment of goods and services associated with the prescribing or dispensing of schedule II substances except for insurance co-pays, coinsurance, or deductibles; and 
e.  Such other conditions as the city council determines are reasonably related to the public health, safety and welfare. 
(2)  Non-exempt pharmacies. During all hours of operation, the pharmacy shall comply with the following conditions: 
a.  The non-exempt pharmacy shall have a State of Florida licensed pharmacist physically on premises at all times during all hours of operation; 
b.  The non-exempt pharmacy shall post a copy of all licensed pharmacists' licenses; 
c.  The non-exempt pharmacy shall require a valid state or federal photo identification, or passport, to identify the patient or, in the case of a minor, his/her parent or legal guardian's similar identification, prior to the dispensing of any schedule II substances; 
d.  The non-exempt pharmacy shall only dispense any schedule II substances as defined in section 12-150 between the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m.; 
e.  The non-exempt pharmacy shall not dispense more than a 30-day supply of any schedule II substance provided the patient's valid identification is from the State of Florida. For any patient whose valid identification is outside the State of Florida, the pharmacy shall not dispense more than a 72-hour supply of any schedule II substance except that a pharmacy may dispense up to a 30-day supply of any schedule II substance provided the patient presents: 
1.  A valid photo identification, in accordance with this section, and 
2.  A utility bill that is not older three months, that is in the name of the patient or the patient's spouse, and that shows a City of St. Cloud address. 
f.  The non-exempt pharmacy shall maintain a legible copy of the prescription for schedule II substances as defined by section 12-150, the patient's photo identification for each prescription dispensed or delivered, and the utility bill, if applicable. The records must be maintained for a minimum of two years. Such records shall be available for inspection and copying by the law enforcement agencies, as permitted by F.S. § 893.07, for a minimum of two years; 
g.  The delivery, including mail-order delivery, of all schedule II substances shall be prohibited except: 
1.  To any facility licensed under F.S. ch. 400 or 429; or 
2.  While fully complying with this article to any St. Cloud address listed on the patient's valid photo identification; or 
3.  While fully complying with this article to the St. Cloud address listed on the utility bill for the patient or the patient's spouse, if applicable. 
h.  Provide a monthly summary report to the police department for all schedule II substances as defined in section 12-150 that have been dispensed by this facility. The monthly report shall be provided by the seventh day of each month for the previous month. At a minimum, the report shall include the following: 
1.  A list of all physicians that have prescribed schedule II substances and the business address of the prescribing physician; 
2.  The number of prescriptions written by each physician or physicians' office; 
3.  The number of prescriptions associated with each type of schedule II substances; 
4.  Certification from the applicant that the non-exempt pharmacy is in compliance with all provisions of the pain medication license; and 
5.  A current listing of all suppliers/wholesalers for all schedule II substances. 
(3)  Pain management clinics. During all hours of operation, the pain management clinic shall comply with the following conditions: 
a.  The pain management clinic shall only operate between the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.; 
b.  Prior to prescribing any schedule II substances, the licensed physician shall perform a physical examination of a patient on the same day at the same location that he or she prescribes any schedule II substance. The physical exam shall be performed by the licensed physician and shall not be performed by a nurse or physician's assistant. A written report of the physical examination shall be placed in the patient record; 
c.  The physician shall require a valid state or federal photo identification, or passport, to identify the patient or, in the case of a minor, his/her parent or legal guardian's similar identification, prior to the prescribing of any schedule II substances; 
d.  A physician shall not prescribe more than a 30-day supply of any schedule II substance provided the patient's valid identification is from the State of Florida. For any patient whose valid identification is outside the State of Florida, the physician shall not prescribe more than a 72-hour supply of any schedule II substance except that a physician may prescribe up to a 30-day supply of any schedule II substance provided the patient presents (i) a valid photo identification in accordance with this section and (ii) a utility bill that is not older [than] three months, that is in the name of the patient or the patient's spouse, and that shows a City of St. Cloud address; 
e.  The physician shall maintain a legible copy of the prescription for schedule II substances as defined by section 12-150, the patient's photo identification for each prescription; and the utility bill required by this section, if applicable. The records must be maintained for a minimum of two years. Such records shall be available for inspection and copying by the law enforcement agencies, as permitted by law, for a minimum of two years; 
f.  Each prescription must be clearly documented in the patient record. All written prescriptions must include the name, address, substance name, amount prescribed, and detailed instructions; 
g.  The pain management clinic shall establish and submit to the city as part of the pain medication license application written policies and procedures governing the management of pain that are reviewed every year and revised more frequently as needed. The written policies and procedures shall include at least the following: 
1.  A written procedure for systematically conducting periodic assessment of patient's pain; 
2.  Criteria for the assessment of pain, including, but not limited to: pain intensity or severity, pain character, pain frequency or pattern, or both; pain location, pain duration, precipitating factors, responses to treatment and the personal, cultural, spiritual, and/or ethnic benefits that may impact an individual's perception of pain; 
3.  A written procedure for the monitoring of a patient's pain; 
4.  A written procedure to insure the consistency of pain rating scales across the pain management clinic; 
5.  Requirements for documentation of a patient's pain status on the medical record; 
6.  A procedure for educating patients and, if applicable, their families about pain management when identified as part of their treatment; 
7.  A written procedure for systematically coordinating and updating the pain treatment plan of patient in response to documented pain status; and 
8.  Whether or not the pain management clinic requires patients to enter into a narcotic medication agreement, and if so, whether the agreement addresses: the risks associated with taking schedule II substances; requirements for the patient to use one pharmacy to fill all schedule II prescriptions; a requirement that the patient not utilize illegal or illicit drugs or obtain additional prescriptions for schedule II substances; a requirement that prescriptions not be transferred, shared, traded or sold; authorization for the pain management clinic to contact other physicians and pharmacies to validate compliance; indicators of patient misuse, abuse or diversion that may result in non-compliance or violation of the agreement; and the consequences for non-compliance or violation of the agreement, including, but not limited to, patient authorization for referral to law enforcement; and 
9.  Whether or not the physician requires random drug screening. 
h.  Each pain management clinic shall develop, revise as necessary and implement a written plan for the purpose of annual training and educating staff on pain management policies and procedures. The plan shall be submitted and reviewed as part of the application for pain medication license. The plan shall include mandatory educational programs that address at least the following: 
1.  Orientation of new staff to the pain management clinic's policies and procedures on pain management; 
2.  Training of non-clerical staff on the dangers of prescription drug diversion, the signs of misuse and abuse, and the importance of patient compliance with prescribed regimens; 
3.  Patient rights; and 
4.  Implementation of the plan shall include records of attendance of each program for each member of the pain management clinic's staff. 
i.  Provide a monthly summary report to the police department for all schedule II substances as defined in section 12-150 that have been prescribed by this facility. The monthly report shall be provided by the seventh day of each month for the previous month. At a minimum, the report shall include the following: 
1.  List of all physicians that have prescribed schedule II substances, with their business addresses; 
2.  The number of prescriptions written by each physician or physician's office; and 
3.  The number of prescriptions associated with each type of schedule II substances. 
(Ord. No. 2011-71, § 2, 10-27-2011; Ord. No. 2017-38 , § 1, 9-28-2017) 
Sec. 12-155. - Issuance, revocation, and renewal of pain medication license. 
(a)  Approval and issuance. Following consideration of the application for pain medication license by the development review committee, the committee shall forward its recommendation for approval, denial, or conditional approval of the license to the city manager or his/her designee and the city manager or his/her designee shall place the application, with recommendations, on the next available city council agenda, for public hearing. Upon approval or conditional approval of an application for a pain medication license by the city council, based on the criteria of this article, the pain medication license shall be issued, for a period of one year. 
(b)  Revocation, suspension, or imposition of additional conditions and/or restrictions. 
(1)  If, at any time, the city manager or his/her designee determines that any pain medication license holder has failed to comply with any applicable conditions of its license, or is operating in a manner harmful to the public health, safety or welfare and not in compliance with the terms of this article he/she may place on the city council public hearing agenda an item to determine whether the pain medication license should be revoked. The city manager or his/her designee shall prepare a report with analysis showing the compliance or non-compliance with the following criteria: 
a.  During the operation of the pain management clinic or non-exempt pharmacy, the pain medication license holder has or has not complied with all conditions imposed at the time of license issuance; or 
b.  During the operation of the pain management clinic or non-exempt pharmacy, the pain medication license holder has or has not taken all reasonable precautions to discourage unlawful activity, including vandalism, crimes against property or persons, disturbances, loitering of patrons, narcotics use or distribution, excessive noise, vehicular use by impaired patrons, and illegal activity of any kind by employees, patrons or others associated with the establishment; or 
c.  During the operation of the pain management clinic or non-exempt pharmacy, the pain medication license holder has or has not taken all reasonable efforts to prevent nuisances and/or criminal activity both inside and outside the establishment; or 
d.  During the hours of operation, the pain medication license holder has or has not exceeded the number of occupants set by the city building and fire officials as the maximum capacity (persons) for the establishment; or 
e.  The pain medication license holder is in compliance with public health, safety or welfare. 
(2)  The city manager or his/her designee, on the recommendation of the police chief, shall have the power to enter an order immediately revoking a pain medication license or suspending the operation of said facility indefinitely. 
(3)  Within 30 days of the suspension of the operation of the facility, as noted above, a public hearing on said revocation, suspension, or imposition of additional conditions shall be conducted in the manner described in section 12-152. The city council will consider the matter de novo, and will determine whether the city manager or his/her designee was justified in revoking and/or suspending the pain medication license. The presumption of the correctness of the decision may be overcome by the license holder, upon a showing of competent substantial evidence that the finding of the city manager or his/her designee was not correct. The burden of proof will be on the applicant seeking the reinstatement of a revoked license or suspended facility. 
(4)  After consideration of the matter, the city council may revoke or suspend the pain medication license or allow the licensee to continue operating with the prescribing of schedule II substances for pain management clinics or dispensing of schedule II substances for non-exempt pharmacies, subject to any reasonable additional conditions deemed necessary to mitigate or eliminate the adverse effects of such operation. 
(5)  Should the pain medication license be revoked, no reapplication for a pain medication license by the owners or operators shall be considered for any location within a 24-month period following the date of final revocation. After the expiration of the 24-month period, a new application and corresponding fee must be submitted. 
(c)  Renewal of pain medication license. Each pain medication license shall be required to be renewed no later than one year following the date of initial granting of the license. The annual renewal of any pain medication license shall be processed by the city manager or his/her designee and reviewed based upon the criteria of this article. If the city manager or his/her designee approves the renewal, the license shall be renewed upon payment of the nonrefundable annual fee in the amount of $200.00 per registered address. The amount of the renewal fee may be modified by resolution of the city council after a public hearing. If the city manager or his/her designee denies the renewal, the licensee shall have ten days from the date of the notice of denial to appeal the decision to the city council in accordance with section 12-152. The notice of appeal shall be timely submitted to the city manager and the city shall schedule a public hearing within 30 days of the receipt of the notice. The city council shall consider the appeal and make a decision with reasons stated using the provisions, terms and criteria set forth in this article. At the time of the requested license renewal, the city manager or his/her designee may, based on the criteria of subsection 12-153 recommend the imposition of additional conditions upon the pain medication licensee. If additional conditions are recommended by the city manager or his/her designee, the renewal shall be placed on the city council agenda for public hearing on the proposed imposition of additional conditions, in accordance with subsection 12-152. If a license is non-renewed or the council denies an appeal of the non-renewal, the owners and operators shall not be allowed to apply for a new pain medication license for a period of 24 months. In the event the city non-renews, revokes, or denies a pain medication license, the city reserves the right to contact the appropriate local, state and federal agencies for administrative or criminal action. 
(d)  Appeal procedure. Appeal of any city council decision regarding the issuance, suspension, revocation or non-renewal of pain medication license shall be to the circuit court, in the manner provided by state law. In accordance with state law, failure to appeal within 30 days of the rendition of the decision shall result in the applicant waiving his right to appeal. 
(e)  Transferability. A pain management license shall not be transferable. Any change in ownership shall require the new owner to reapply for a new license prior to the prescribing, storing or dispensing of schedule II substances. 
(Ord. No. 2011-71, § 2, 10-27-2011; Ord. No. 2017-38 , § 1, 9-28-2017) 
Secs. 12-156-12-169. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SECONDHAND DEALERS, PAWNBROKERS AND PRECIOUS METAL PURCHASES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-21, § 2, adopted May 24, 2014, added provisions to the Code as Art. V, §§ 12-140-12-144. Inasmuch as there were already provisions so designated, these provisions were redesignated as Art. VI, §§ 12-170-12-15 at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 12-170. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Consignment shop means a shop engaging in the business of accepting for sale, on consignment, secondhand goods which, having once been used or transferred from the manufacturer to the dealer, are then received into the possession of a third party. 
    Pawn means an advancement of funds on the security of pledged goods on condition that the pledged goods are left in the possession of the pawnbroker for the duration of the pawn and may be redeemed by the pledgor on the terms and conditions contained in F.S. § 539.001. 
    Pawnbroker means any person who is engaged in the business of making pawns; who makes a public display containing the term "pawn," "pawnbroker," or "pawnshop" or any derivative thereof; or who publicly displays a sign or symbol historically identified with pawns. A pawnbroker may also engage in the business of purchasing goods which includes consignment and trade. 
    Pawnshop means the location at which a pawnbroker conducts business. 
    Pledged goods means tangible personal property that is deposited with, or otherwise delivered into the possession of a pawnbroker in connection with a pawn. "Pledged goods" does not include titles or any other form of written security in tangible property in lieu of actual physical possession, including, but not limited to, chose in action, securities, printed evidence of indebtedness, or certificates of title and other instruments evidencing title to separate items of property, including motor vehicles. For purposes of federal and state bankruptcy laws, a pledgor's interest in his or her pledged goods during the pendency of a pawn is a right of redemption only. 
    Secondhand dealer means any person, corporation, or other business organization or entity that is not a secondary metals recycler subject to F.S. § 538.18 et seq. and that is engaged in the business of purchasing, consigning, or trading secondhand goods. 
    Secondhand goods means personal property previously owned or used, that is not metals property regulated under F.S. § 538.18 et seq., and that is purchased, consigned, or traded as used property. Such secondhand goods do not include office furniture, pianos, books, clothing, organs, coins, motor vehicles, costume jewelry, cardio and strength training or conditioning equipment designed primarily for indoor use, and secondhand sports equipment that is not permanently labeled with a serial number. For purposes of this article, "secondhand sports equipment" does not include golf clubs. 
    Secondhand store means the place or premises at which a secondhand dealer is registered to conduct business. 
(Ord. No. 2012-21, § 2, 5-24-2012) 
Sec. 12-171. - Permit. 
    The provisions of this section shall apply to all secondhand dealers and pawnbrokers unless specifically provided for in this article. 
(1)  Permit required. Secondhand dealers and pawnbrokers shall be required to obtain and maintain a valid permit from the city. Every applicant for a permit to engage in the business of secondhand dealer or pawnbroker shall file with the city a written application prepared and provided by the city, and signed by the applicant. Each application shall contain an agreement that the applicant accepts the permit, if granted, upon the condition that it may be suspended at any time upon conviction of a violation of this article. The application shall contain the following information: 
a.  The names and residences of the applicants, if an individual, partnership or firm, or the names of principal officers and their residences, if the applicant is an association or corporation. 
b.  The length of time such applicants, if an individual, firm or partnership, or the manager or person in charge, if the applicant is an association or corporation, have resided in the city, their places of previous employment, whether they, or any of them, have been convicted of a felony and, if so, for what offense, when, and in what court. 
c.  Whether the applicants, or officers, or manager of the applicants has been a pawnbroker or secondhand dealer previously, or employed by such. 
d.  The detailed nature of the business to be conducted and the kind of materials to be collected, bought, sold or otherwise handled. 
e.  The premises where such business is to be located or carried on. 
(2)  Criminal History Record Check. Pursuant to F.S. § 166.0442, the applicant shall undergo fingerprinting to be submitted to the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) for a state and national criminal history record check. 
(3)  Investigation of application; issuance or refusal of permit; reapplication upon refusal. Upon the filing of the application as provided for in subsection 12-141(1), after investigation, and the payment to the city of any applicable fees, the applicant shall be issued a permit to engage in the business of secondhand dealer. No permit shall be refused, except for a specified reason. No applicant to whom a permit has been refused shall make further application until a period of at least six months shall have elapsed since the last previous rejection unless he can show that the reason for such rejection no longer exists. 
(4)  Persons to whom permit shall not be issued. No permit shall be issued to any person, or the member or officers of associations, partnerships, or corporations, who have been convicted within two years of the date of application of a violation of this section or to any person who has within five years of the date of application, been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor offense, other than minor traffic offenses. 
(5)  Designated place of business. Every pawnbroker or secondhand dealer permit shall designate the place of business in or from which the dealer receiving such permit shall be authorized to carry on such business. No such dealer shall remove his or her place of business from the location designated in the permit until a written approval has been secured from the city and the same shall have been endorsed upon the permit under which such business is carried on. 
(6)  Recordkeeping requirements. Secondhand dealers and pawnbrokers as defined in this article shall comply with the applicable recordkeeping and reporting requirements of F.S. § 538.04 and F.S. § 539.001, as amended. 
(7)  Holding. Secondhand dealers and pawnbrokers as defined in this article shall comply with the applicable holding requirements of F.S. § 538.06 and F.S. § 539.001, as amended. 
(8)  Inspection of records and premises. The premises and required records of each secondhand dealer and pawnbroker are subject to inspection as established in F.S. § 538.05 and F.S. § 539.001. 
(Ord. No. 2012-21, § 2, 5-24-2012; Ord. No. 2017-38 , § 3, 9-28-2017) 
Sec. 12-172. - Prohibitions. 
    It is unlawful for a pawnbroker or any employee of the pawnbroker or a secondhand dealer or any employee of the secondhand dealer to do or allow any of the following acts: 
(1)  Knowingly make a transaction with any person: 
a.  Under the influence of drugs or alcohol when such condition is visible or apparent; 
b.  Under the age of 18 years; or 
c.  Using a name other than such person's own name or the registered name of such person's business. 
(2)  Have a pawn shop or secondhand store open or engage in or conduct business as a pawnbroker or secondhand dealer between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(3)  Conduct any transaction at a drive-through window or similar device. 
(4)  Fail to pay any sales tax owed to the state department of revenue or fail to have a sales tax registration number. 
(5)  Engage in both pawn transactions and title loan transactions from the same secondhand dealer location. 
(6)  Use the word "pawn" or "pawnbroker" in any transaction, documentation, advertising or promotional materials, signs, displays, banners, or other materials of any nature relating to the secondhand dealer's business if the secondhand dealer engages in title loan transactions. 
(Ord. No. 2012-21, § 2, 5-24-2012) 
Sec. 12-173. - Limitation on pawn shop permits. 
(a)  Pawn shops shall be permitted at the rate of one per 20,000 of population, or fraction thereof. A population of less than 20,000 will allow one pawn shop. When the population reaches 20,001, a second pawn shop will be permitted. When the population reaches 40,001, a third pawn shop will be permitted. This pattern will continue as population growth occurs. 
(b)  Pawn shops existing as of the effective date of this article shall not be counted in the population limitations and not subject to the permit limitations set forth herein. Provided, however, that such pawn shops shall apply for and obtain a permit and comply with all requirements as contained herein. A pawn shop that was opened prior to the effective date of this article and subsequently ceases operation shall not be allowed to reopen or reestablish in another location except in accordance with the City Code. 
(c)  The city shall not issue any permit to operate as a pawnbroker, except to renew any permit in good standing, unless the number of dealers permitted has been reduced below the maximum prescribed herein. 
(d)  No permit for a pawn shop shall be issued for a location located within a one-mile radius of any other pawn shop. 
(Ord. No. 2012-21, § 2, 5-24-2012) 
Sec. 12-174. - Precious metal and coin purchases. 
(a)  Record keeping for precious metals. Every person dealing in precious metals such as gold, silver, and platinum, shall keep a record, at the time of purchase, of all purchases from private individuals who are not licensed dealers regularly engaged in buying and selling of precious metals. This record will be on a form provided by the city and the following information shall be obtained: 
(1)  The date of the transaction; 
(2)  The number that appears on the seller's driver's license, or comparable identification used; 
(3)  The type of identification used; 
(4)  The name and address of the seller as it appears on the item of identification; 
(5)  A complete and accurate description of such property; and 
(6)  The signature of the seller. 
(b)  Record keeping for coins. In the event coins are purchased in such large numbers that it is impractical to describe each coin separately, the description may consist of a general description of the various denominations of coins included, together with the total weight or face value thereof. 
(c)  Records shall be available. Records shall be made available to any law enforcement agency or officer upon request and shall be preserved for a period of one year after purchase. If the dealer preserves the records as aforesaid, then any requirement that the articles be retained for ten days shall not apply to gold, silver, platinum or other precious metals. 
(Ord. No. 2012-21, § 2, 5-24-2012) 
Sec. 12-175. - Enforcement. 
    Failure to comply with any of the provisions of this Code shall be enforceable as provided by applicable law, including, but not limited to, sections 2-261 and 2-281 of the City Code. Each day of noncompliance with this article shall be deemed a separate offense. Violators shall further be subject to certificate of use suspension or revocation as set forth in section 12-137. 
(Ord. No. 2012-21, § 2, 5-24-2012) 
Chapter 14 - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS 

Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cable mile means a linear mile of trunk or distribution cable as measured from the nearest point of access to the then-existing system, provided that tension is technically feasible from that point of access, and located within the public rights-of-way. The total cable length shall exclude the drop cable necessary to serve individual subscriber premises. 
    Cable system means a facility, consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception, and control equipment that is designed to provide cable service which includes video programming and which is provided to multiple subscribers within a community, but such term does not include: (i) a facility that serves only to retransmit the television signals of one or more television broadcast stations; (ii) a facility that serves only subscribers in one or more multiple-unit dwellings under common ownership, control, or management, unless such facility or facilities use any public right-of-way; (iii) a facility of a common carrier, except that such facility shall be considered a cable system to the extent such facility is used in the transmission of video programming directly to subscribers; or (iv) any facilities of any electric utility used solely for operating its electric utility systems. 
    Distribution or feeder lines means those intermediate cable distribution lines that connect the main trunk lines to the small drop lines that lead into residences or into the premises of other customers. 
    Drop lines means those lines or cables which extend from a distribution source to an individual customer. 
    Franchise means authorization by the city to construct and operate a cable system in the city, regardless of whether such authorization is called a franchise, franchise agreement, permit, license, resolution, contract, certificate, or other designation. 
    Franchise area means the incorporated areas of the city. 
    Grantee means a person who has applied for and has been granted an initial or renewal franchise, or has been granted the expansion, modification or transfer of an existing franchise. 
    Gross subscriber receipts means all revenues received from the supplying of cable service, including but not limited to installation fees, disconnect and reconnect fees, fees for basic cable service, including the transmission of broadcast signals and access and origination channels, and per-program and per-channel charges. 
    Trunk lines means the major distribution cable used in cable television systems. 
(Code 1994, § 22-1; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-2. - Grant of nonexclusive franchise. 
(a)  Any person desiring to use public rights-of-way to construct, install, operate or maintain all or any part of a cable system, within the corporate boundaries of the city shall apply to the city for a franchise. 
(b)  The issuance of a franchise shall allow the grantee to install, construct, maintain and operate a cable system along, under, over, through, across and upon the public easements and rights-of-way within the city in accordance with and subject to the requirements and restrictions of section 14-9. The rights herein granted shall extend to any area annexed to the city. In the event the city annexes property into the municipal limits of the city, and said area is presently being served by a county franchised company, said franchised company shall be obligated to obtain a franchise pursuant to this chapter herein in order to continue serving the annexed area. Said company shall be obligated to pay the city a franchise fee for said area in accordance with this chapter. In the event the company serving the annexed area desires to extend its service beyond the annexed area, said company shall be required to apply for and obtain a franchise pursuant to the terms and conditions of the chapter prior to construction/installation of any additional cable outside the annexed area. The city shall notify the current grantee of any annexations including the legal description of the annexed area. 
(c)  The right to use and occupy public easements and rights-of-way for the purposes herein set forth shall not be exclusive, and the city reserves the right to grant the use of easements and rights-of-way to any person at any time. The city shall not grant any overlapping franchises for cable service within its jurisdiction on terms or conditions more favorable or less burdensome than those in any existing franchise within the city. 
(d)  Before constructing its cable system, the grantee will obtain any necessary permits required by the city. 
(e)  The grantee shall not transfer or assign a franchise or the rights therein without prior consent of the city. Such consent shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(Code 1994, § 22-2; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-3. - Requirements for grant, transfer, renewal, or material modification of franchise. 
    No applicant shall be entitled to have a franchise granted, transferred, renewed or materially modified until the following minimum conditions are satisfied: 
(1)  The applicant has submitted an application in accordance with this chapter. 
(2)  A duly advertised public hearing has been held by the council on the application in accordance with F.S. § 166.046, this chapter and any other applicable state or federal law or regulation. 
(3)  The council has approved the franchise in accordance with F.S. § 166.046, this chapter, and any other applicable state or federal law or regulation. 
(4)  The applicant has complied with all other provisions of this chapter and any applicable state or federal law or regulation. 
(Code 1994, § 22-3; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-4. - Application contents. 
    The application for an initial franchise or a transfer of an existing franchise shall be filed with the city manager or his designee and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Application information. The application shall set forth, contain, or be accompanied by but not limited to the following: 
a.  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant. 
b.  A detailed statement of the corporate or other business entity organization of the applicant, including but not limited to the following: 
1.  The names and residence addresses of all general partners and corporate officers of the applicant. 
2.  The names, residence addresses and business addresses of all persons and entities having, controlling or being entitled to have or control 15 percent or more of the ownership of the applicant and the respective ownership share of each such person or entity. 
3.  The names and addresses of any parent company or subsidiary of the applicant and of any other business entity owning or controlling in whole or in part or owned or controlled in whole or in part by the applicant. 
4.  A detailed description of all previous experience of the applicant in providing cable services or related or similar services. 
5.  A detailed and complete financial statement of the applicant, prepared by a certified public accountant, for the fiscal year immediately preceding the date of the application hereunder, or a letter or other acceptable evidence in writing from a responsible lending institution or funding source, addressed to both the applicant and the county, setting forth a clear statement of its intent as a lending institution or funding source to provide whatever capital shall be required by the applicant to construct and operate the proposed system in the county. 
6.  A statement identifying, by place and date, any other cable system franchise awarded to the applicant, its parent or subsidiary; the status of the franchise with respect to completion thereof; and if requested by the city, the total cost of completion of such system; and the amount of applicant's and its parent's or subsidiary's resources committed to the completion thereof. 
7.  A detailed description of the proposed plan of operation of the applicant, which shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(i)  A detailed map indicating all areas proposed to be served, and a proposed time schedule for the installation of all equipment necessary to become operational throughout the entire area to be served. 
(ii)  A statement or schedule setting forth all proposed classifications of rates and charges to be made against subscribers and all rates and charges as to each of any said classifications, including installation charges, service charges, special, extraordinary or other charges. The purchase price, terms and nature of any optional or required equipment, device or other thing to be offered for sale to any subscriber shall be described and explained in detail. 
(iii)  A detailed statement describing the actual equipment and operational standards proposed by the applicant. 
(iv)  Any other reasonable information which could materially affect the granting of the franchise and request by the city. 
(2)  Principals, officers, and related entities. The names, business addresses, business telephone numbers, and offices or employment positions of: (i) all principals and officers of the applicant; (ii) all persons having a controlling interest in or holding more than ten percent of the outstanding ownership interest in the applicant; and (iii) any parent, subsidiary or affiliate of the applicant. 
(3)  Additional information. Any further information as is necessary to comply with state or federal law or regulations. 
(4)  Modification. An application for material modification of a franchise shall be filed with the city and shall contain all information pertinent to the requested modification. 
(5)  Request for renewal. A request for renewal shall be processed under the Cable Communications Act and Federal Communications Commission provisions. 
(6)  Request for transfer. A request for transfer shall be processed pursuant to the federal law and Federal Communications Commission provisions. 
(Code 1994, § 22-4; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-5. - Franchise agreement. 
    Upon granting a franchise, transfer, renewal or material modification, the council shall execute and deliver an agreement within 60 days of the public hearing. An agreement granting a franchise shall be set forth in Exhibit "A" to the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, which is on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1994, § 22-5; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-6. - Term of franchises and renewals. 
    All franchises and renewals, if granted, shall be for not more than 15 years each. Such franchises shall be subject to renewal by the city in accordance with this chapter and the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, 47 USC 521 et seq., or successor legislation, and any other state or federal laws or regulations then applicable. 
(Code 1994, § 22-6; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-7. - Compliance with laws, regulations and ordinances. 
    At all times during the term of its franchise, the grantee shall be subject to all lawful exercise of the police power by the city and to such reasonable regulation as the city shall hereafter by resolution or ordinance provide, to the extent not inconsistent with the franchise agreement. The construction, operation, and maintenance of the system by the grantee shall comply with the National Electrical Safety Code, as amended and revised. The grantee shall comply with all other applicable state and federal laws, rules and regulations now in effect or hereinafter adopted or enacted. 
(Code 1994, § 22-7; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-8. - Liability and indemnification. 
(a)  The grantee shall hold the city harmless from all losses sustained by the city, including court costs and reasonable attorneys' fees, on account of any suit, judgment, execution, claim or demand whatsoever arising out of the construction, operation, maintenance, or removal of the cable system by grantee. 
(b)  The grantee shall maintain liability insurance insuring the city and grantee with regard to all damages mentioned in subsection (a) of this section in the minimum amounts of: 
(1)  $2,000,000.00 for bodily injury or death to any one person, within the limit; however, of $4,000,000.00 for bodily injury or death resulting from any one accident; and 
(2)  $2,000,000.00 for property damage resulting from any one accident. 
(c)  The grantee shall file a certificate of insurance with the city manager during the term of the franchise. 
(d)  The grantee shall maintain in full force and effect throughout the duration of its franchise sufficient worker's compensation insurance coverage to adequately and fully protect its employees as required by law. 
(e)  The grantee shall post a performance bond in favor of the city in the amount of $100,000.00 conditioned upon the faithful performance and discharge of the material obligations imposed by the franchise and this chapter. The city's right to recover under the bond shall be in addition to any other rights retained by the city under this chapter and other applicable law. Any proceeds recovered under the bond may be used to reimburse the city for loss of unpaid payments of the franchise fee and other valuable consideration which may be owed to the grantor for the grant of the franchise, and such additional reasonable expenses as may be incurred by the city as a result of grantee's failure to comply with the obligations imposed by the franchise including, but not limited to, attorney's fees and costs of any action or proceeding, and the cost of removal or abandonment of any property, or other costs which may be due the city. 
(f)  The bond and all insurance policies shall be in a form reasonably satisfactory to the city attorney and shall require 30 days' written notice of any cancellation to both the city and the grantee. Upon cancellation of the bond or insurance policies, the grantee shall obtain, pay all premiums for, and file with the city, written evidence of the issuance of replacement bond or insurance policies within 30 days after receiving the notice of cancellation. 
(g)  All insurance policies and bonds shall be written by a company qualified to do business in the state. The grantee shall promptly file with the city all certificates of coverage. The city shall have the right to review the insurance levels required herein and may revise same to meet current industry standards at two-year intervals. 
(h)  If franchise fees are paid directly to the city by the grantee, any duly authorized agent of the city shall have the right, power, and authority to inspect and audit the current records of the gross revenue of the grantee at any reasonable time and with reasonable notice. 
(Code 1994, § 22-8; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-9. - Construction requirements. 
    The grantee shall have the capability of serving customers in an area consisting of 30 percent of the city within three years of the execution of the grantee's initial franchise agreement. A grantee shall have the capability of serving customers in an area consisting of 60 percent of the city within five years of the execution of the grantee's initial franchise agreement. These three-year and five-year requirements will be tolled in the event legal action is required to prevent or stop illegal discriminatory pricing practices by any other grantee. A grantee shall not be required to build those sections of the city that do not meet a general density standard of 30 homes per cable mile, including interconnecting trunk. The grantee shall commence good-faith installation and construction of its cable system and performance of its obligations hereunder within one year of the date of execution of an initial franchise agreement, and failure to commence such good-faith installation and construction within such one-year period, shall be grounds for forfeiture of grantee's performance bond. However, such action shall be taken only after a public hearing is held by the council during which the grantee may show cause why such action should not be taken. A grantee shall provide service, when requested, to all structures within 150 feet of its trunk lines. 
(Code 1994, § 22-9; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-10. - Conditions on street occupancy and system construction. 
(a)  Use. All transmission and distribution structures, lines, and equipment erected by the grantee within the city shall be so located as to cause minimum interference with the rights or reasonable convenience of adjacent property owners. The grantee shall comply with the city's tree trimming regulations. 
(b)  Restoration. Upon disturbing pavement, sidewalks, driveways, or other surfacing, the grantee shall, at its own expense and in a reasonable manner, replace and restore such places so disturbed in as good condition as before the work was commenced, and in a reasonable condition as approved by the city. 
(c)  Relocation. The grantee shall promptly and at its own expense relocate or modify any part of its cable system which the city may reasonably request, to accommodate street improvement of city sewer, water, electric, communications or other city facilities occupying any part of the public streets as may be required by the city or other governmental authority; provided that such facilities do not provide services which compete with a service provided on grantee's system. To the extent that other users of the rights-of-way are compensated for relocating their facilities the grantee shall also be compensated for relocating their facilities. 
(d)  Placement of fixtures. The grantee shall not place any fixtures or equipment where they will interfere with any currently existing gas, electric, telephone, cable, or sewer and water lines, fixtures, and equipment. The grantee's lines and equipment shall not interfere with travel on city easements and rights-of-way. 
(e)  Temporary removal of wires for building moving. On the request of any person holding a building moving permit issued by city, county or state, the grantee shall temporarily raise or lower its wires to permit the moving of buildings or structures. The expense of such temporary removal or raising or lowering of wires shall be paid in advance to grantee by the requesting party. The grantee shall be given at least five business days advance notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes. 
(f)  No property right. Nothing in this chapter shall grant to the grantee any property right in city-owned property, nor shall the city be compelled to maintain any of its property any longer than, or in any fashion other than, in the city's judgment, its own business or needs may require. 
(g)  Permits, easements, and agreements. The city shall not be required to assume the responsibility for the securing of any rights-of-way or easements as required by the grantee, nor shall the city be responsible for securing any permits or agreements with other persons or utilities. 
(h)  Utility agreements. Before constructing its cable system, the grantee shall have appropriate pole attachment agreements with all applicable telephone and electric utilities, if such agreements can be reached upon reasonable terms. 
(i)  Locating underground facilities. 
(1)  Before any grantee installs underground cables, wires, or other equipment in the service area of any existing cable system, the grantee must give any existing cable operator notice, either in writing or by telephone confirmed by a locate validation number assigned by the operator. Within three working days after such notice, the existing cable operator shall locate within the public easements and rights-of-way, at no costs to the grantee, its existing underground cable system facilities and shall mark the facilities by use of flags or marker paint. Nothing in this section shall be deemed to require any existing cable operator to locate-its system for a grantee in easements and rights-of-way in excess of 2,500 linear feet during any period of three working days. 
(2)  All grantees when installing lines and equipment shall exercise reasonable care not to damage other lines and property previously in place. All underground cable installations made by grantees in public easements and rights-of-way shall comply with the following minimum depth requirements at the time of installation: 
a.  For drop lines: at least six inches below the ground; 
b.  For distribution or feeder lines: 18 inches below the ground; and 
c.  For trunk lines: 24 inches below the ground. 
(3)  These requirements shall in no way relieve any person or grantee from the obligation to request locates of any existing operator's underground facilities. 
(Code 1994, § 22-10; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-11. - Prohibition. 
    No person shall construct, install, maintain, or operate a cable system within public easements or rights-of-way in the city or on any property of the city unless a franchise has first been obtained and unless such a franchise is in full force and effect. Such franchise shall not take the place of any other license or permit which may be legally required of the grantee in order to conduct such a business. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided by law, and the city may sue for injunction against any violation hereof. 
(Code 1994, § 22-11; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-12. - Programming. 
    During the term of its franchise, the grantee shall carry the signals of all local broadcast stations now or hereafter required by the Federal Communication Commission (FCC) to serve the city. 
(Code 1994, § 22-12; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-13. - System security: tampering with cable television equipment. 
    The grantee shall have the right at all times to take any legal action necessary to preserve the security of its cable system and to assure appropriate uses thereof by its subscribers. In addition, any person who willfully or maliciously damages, or causes to be damaged, any wire, cable, conduit, apparatus or equipment of the grantee with intent to obtain a signal or impulse therefrom without the grantee's authorization, shall be subject to prosecution in accordance with law. 
(Code 1994, § 22-13; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-14. - Service standards. 
(a)  The grantee shall maintain and operate the system and render efficient service in accordance with the rules and regulation as set forth from time to time by the Federal Communications Commission. The grantee shall install and operate the cable system so that there will be no interference with television reception, radio reception, telephone communications or other installations which are now installed and in use by the city or any person in the city. 
(b)  The grantee shall carry signals of television stations in accordance with applicable Federal Communications Commission signal carriage rules presently in effect and as may be amended by the Federal Communications Commission. The grantee shall maintain a system with capability of carrying a minimum of 36 channels. 
(c)  The cable system shall be maintained at all times in conformity with Federal Communications Commission rules and regulations presently in effect and as may be amended from time to time. 
(d)  The grantee shall render efficient services, make repairs promptly, and interrupt service only for good cause and for the shortest time possible. If possible, such interruptions shall be preceded by notice to affected subscribers, and shall occur during periods of minimum use. 
(e)  The grantee shall be responsible for the installation and maintenance of the service wiring from the cable point of entrance to the television set to the extent consistent with applicable law and customer agreements. 
(f)  Upon termination of service to any subscriber, the grantee shall promptly remove all its facilities and equipment from the premises of such subscriber upon his request. 
(g)  The grantee shall adopt procedures for the investigation and resolution of complaints related to the operation of the grantee's cable system. The grantee shall have the responsibility for administering and implementing these procedures. 
(Code 1994, § 22-14; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-15. - Grantee and grantor rules and rights. 
(a)  The grantee shall have the authority to promulgate such rules, regulations, terms, and conditions governing the conduct of its business as are reasonably necessary to enable the grantee to exercise its rights and to perform its obligations under this chapter and to assure uninterrupted service to its customers. The city retains all rights it currently has and future rights it is granted under federal and state, laws. 
(b)  The city reserves the right to adopt from time to time, in addition to the provisions contained herein and in addition to existing ordinances, such additional regulations as are necessary in the exercise of its police/enforcement power. Such regulations, by ordinance or otherwise, shall be reasonable and shall not be inconsistent with terms of the franchise agreement. Such additional regulations shall not be adopted without opportunity for all persons to be heard and notice to all grantees. 
(c)  The city shall give the grantee 30 days' written notice before formal consideration of any rule, regulation, term or condition hereunder. 
(d)  The city shall have the right to install and maintain free of charge upon the grantee's poles, wire and pole fixtures necessary for a police alarm system, or traffic control system if such wire and pole fixtures do not interfere with the grantee's cable system. 
(e)  The city shall have the right to inspect the grantee's maps, plans, and other similar materials related to the operation of the cable system within the city during normal business hours. 
(f)  The city shall have the right to supervise all construction or installation work performed subject to the provisions of this chapter and make such inspections as the city shall find necessary to ensure compliance with the terms of this chapter and other pertinent provisions of law. 
(Code 1994, § 22-15; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-16. - Complaints. 
    Excluding conditions beyond the control of the grantee, the cable operator will begin working on "service interruptions" promptly and in no event later than 24 hours after the interruption becomes known. The grantee must begin actions to correct other service problems the next business day after notification of the service problem. Upon request, but not more frequently than annually, the grantee shall supply the city with copies of all written complaints on a form approved by it and indicate the disposition of each. Such records shall be available for city inspection at all times during business hours. The form for such complaint shall indicate the day on which the complaint was received and the day on which it was resolved. 
(Code 1994, § 22-16; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-17. - Local office. 
    The grantee shall maintain an office within or near the city, but in no event outside of the county. This office shall be open to the public during all reasonable business hours. Service, installation, and maintenance capability shall be available through this office. If the office is not within the city, the grantee shall provide service to customers at their residences or places of business. Such service shall include delivery and pickup of equipment. The grantee shall maintain a local telephone number and sufficient lines to handle customer inquiries and complaints. 
(Code 1994, § 22-17; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-18. - Special services. 
(a)  The grantee provides basic and standard cable service without installation charges or monthly service charges for one initial outlet to public schools, city hall, city police, fire stations or other city facilities and public libraries, provided such outlets are located within 150 feet, as measured along a public rights-of-way or easement, of the constructed cable system. Requests for such service shall come from the city manager. 
(b)  The grantee shall make available without charge a local government access channel for noncommercial local governmental use, the allocation and use of such to be determined by the council. The grantee shall provide to the city a switch to permit the city to insert the programming of Access Osceola government/educational channel onto the city government access channel. Some customers may not receive the city access channel due to the fact that the technical design of the cable system does not precisely correspond to municipal boundaries. 
(c)  The grantee agrees to provide support as specified in the franchise agreement to the city for the purchase of equipment for use with the government access channel. 
(Code 1994, § 22-18; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-19. - Franchise fee. 
    The grantee shall pay the city a franchise fee as determined by F.S. ch. 202, The Communications Services Tax Simplification Law. In the event that state law changes and rescinds the communications services tax or allows the city to collect a franchise fee directly from the grantee in place of the communications services tax, then for each year during the term of the franchise, the grantee shall pay to the city a franchise fee of five percent of the grantee's gross subscriber receipts derived from the operation of the grantee's cable system in the franchise area. The franchise fee shall be due and payable monthly, no later than 60 days following the end of each month. All payments due hereunder shall be made by the grantee to the city and shall be sent to the Director of Finance, City Hall, 1300 Ninth Street, St. Cloud, Florida, 34769. 
(Code 1994, § 22-19; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-20. - Transfer. 
    The grantee shall not sell or transfer its cable system or any portion thereof, nor any right, title or interest in the same, nor shall the grantee transfer any right under its franchise to any other person without prior approval of the city council, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(Code 1994, § 22-20; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Sec. 14-21. - Termination of franchise. 
(a)  The city may terminate and cancel a franchise and all rights and privileges of the grantee thereunder if the grantee: 
(1)  Violates any material provision of its franchise or violates any rule, order, or determination of the city made pursuant to this chapter or the franchise, except where such violation, other than of subsection (a)(2) of this section, is without fault or through excusable neglect; 
(2)  Becomes insolvent, unable or unwilling to pay its debts, or is adjudged a bankrupt; or 
(3)  Practices any fraud or deceit upon the city. 
(b)  Such termination and cancellation shall be by ordinance duly adopted after 60 days' written notice to the grantee and an opportunity to cure and shall in no way affect any of the city's rights under this chapter, any other franchise, or any provision of law. However, before any franchise may be terminated and cancelled under this section, the grantee must be given an opportunity to be heard before the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 22-21; Ord. No. 91-C-2, 11-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-66, § 2, 10-23-2003) 
Chapter 16 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes:
