State Law reference- Florida Funeral and Cemetery Services Act, F.S. ch. 497. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 16-1-16-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MOUNT PEACE CEMETERY 

Sec. 16-31. - Sale of lots. 
(a)  The prices for the purchase of grave spaces or lots in Mount Peace Cemetery are on file in the city clerk's office as adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  Veterans and their surviving spouses may be buried in those sections reserved for veterans of United States wars. Upon presentation of written proof that the Veterans' Administration will not pay the costs of the burial plot for an honorably discharged veteran of a United States war (as defined by the Veterans' Administration) to the city manager, the cost of the plot may be refunded, for those veterans who were residents of, or maintained a residence in, the city at the time of and up to six months before their death. 
(c)  No deeds to grave spaces will be executed, and no burial will be permitted until the total purchase price of the lot or grave space has been paid in full to the city. 
(d)  No owner of a lot or burial space in the cemetery shall sell or convey the same to any other person or corporation other than to the city without the written consent of the city. The city reserves the right to pay no more than the original price of the lot. 
(Code 1967, § 71/2-16; Code 1994, § 26-26; Ord. No. 93-D-2, § I, 1-27-1994) 
Sec. 16-32. - Burial services. 
    The opening and closing of all graves in Mount Peace Cemetery shall be prohibited unless the city has been previously notified in writing by the party responsible for handling the burial and/or the funeral arrangements. The city will not open or close any gravesite. 
(Code 1967, § 71/2-17(a); Code 1994, § 26-27) 
Sec. 16-33. - Cemetery policies, rules and regulations. 
    The city council shall by resolution adopt such policies, rules and regulations that are necessary for the orderly and safe use and efficient administration and maintenance of the cemetery for the benefit of all citizens. 
(Ord. No. 2008-37, § II, 5-22-2008) 
Chapter 18 - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT INCENTIVES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-107, § 3, adopted Jan. 24, 2008, repealed Ch. 18 in its entirety and enacted a new Ch. 18 to read as set out herein. Former Ch. 18, §§ 18-1-18-11, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1994, § 29-1-29-11; Ord. No. 96-10, § 3, adopted May 9, 1996; Ord. No. 00-05, §§ I-VIII, adopted Feb. 10, 2000. 

Sec. 18-1. - Intent and purpose. 
    The purposes of this chapter are to amend the economic development incentive program and fund as established herein, which is used to attract, retain and provide favorable conditions for the growth of target industry and business that provides high quality employment opportunities for the citizens of the City of St. Cloud and enhances the economic foundations of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2007-107, § 3, 1-24-2008) 
Sec. 18-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where context clearly requires otherwise: 
(1)  Average wage means the average of all wages and salaries in Osceola County. Average wage will be that wage estimated or calculated by the most recent state department of labor statistics. 
(2)  Base wage means compensation received by an employee for fulfilling job functions. Compensation may include benefits such as, but not limited to, medical insurance and employer funded retirement plans. Compensation shall not include benefits such as payment of any mandatory federal employer contribution, state employer contribution, vacations, holidays or sick leave. 
(3)  Business or industry means any business entity authorized to do business in the state, city or county, including all members of an affiliate group of corporations as defined in F.S. § 220.03(1)(b). 
(4)  Business development areas means any program, activity or venture in which the city participates as a partner, investor or grantee related to any federal, state or local government program involving the development or creation of a business or industry, related enterprise, program, area or development. 
(5)  Expansion of an existing business or industry means the expansion of a business or industry by or through additions to real and personal property on a site co-located with a target industry or business operation owned by the same owner, relocation to a larger facility within the city's planning area or an expansion of a business operation presently existing within the city's planning area. 
(6)  Jobs means full-time equivalent positions, as such terms are consistent with terms used by the state department of labor and employment security and the United States Department of Labor for purposes of unemployment compensation tax administration and employment estimation. Jobs shall not include temporary construction jobs involved with the construction of facilities for the project or, temporary, part-time or contract employees or any jobs which have previously been included in any application for benefits in this chapter. 
(7)  New business means a business or industry which heretofore does not exist within the city or the city's planning area, first begins its operations on a site located within the city or the city's planning area and is clearly separate from any other operation owned by the same business or industry. 
(8)  Planning area means that area as defined under the joint stipulation agreement by and between the Osceola County Board of County Commissioners and the St. Cloud City Council dated November 8, 2004, or any future agreements by both parties establishing the City of St. Cloud's ultimate city limits. 
(9)  Project means the creation of a new business or industry or the expansion of an existing business or industry. 
(10)  Target business or industry means those industries or businesses identified by and pursuant to criteria developed by the city council, as may be adopted from time to time by resolution. 
(11)  Utility service area means the areas within City of St. Cloud and Osceola County which are served by the City of St. Cloud Water and Sewer Utilities. 
(Ord. No. 2007-107, § 3, 1-24-2008) 
Sec. 18-3. - Economic development expendable trust fund. 
(a)  The "economic development incentives expendable trust fund" previously established by Ordinance 96-10 is hereby retitled "economic development expendable trust fund" and hereinafter referred to as "trust fund". 
(b)  The trust fund shall be utilized to implement programs established or supported by the city council that assists in creating a healthy and vibrant economy. Such uses may include, but not be limited to, incentive programs, partnerships with other governmental economic development agencies, grants or annual dues for private economic development agencies, economic development consultants employed by the city, marketing and assistance in the development and improvement of commercial areas within the planning area. 
(c)  The trust fund may be funded by whatever incomes or transfers from other funds the city council deems appropriate and allowed by law. If at any time the city council chooses to retire the trust funds of the trust fund shall be transferred back to the appropriate contributing funds. 
(Ord. No. 2007-107, § 3, 1-24-2008) 
Sec. 18-4. - Use of trust funds. 
(a)  Trust funds can be used for any expense pertaining to a new location or expansion of a target industry, business or business development area. Expenses that are eligible include, but are not limited to, impact and permit fees, relocation costs, land acquisition, on-site and off-site improvements, building construction, loan interest pay-down, lease-hold improvement, employee training programs, or any other legitimate business expense. 
(b)  Proposed use of trust funds shall be stated [in] the application for said grant and incorporated in the grant agreement which must be approved by adoption of a resolution of the city council. 
(c)  The maximum distribution of trust fund monies shall be the balance in the trust fund at the time of distribution. This paragraph shall not be interpreted to restrict the city council from authorizing an appropriate transfers to the trust fund account prior to distribution or the city's ability to access other economic development accounts which may be available to the city such as the City of St. Cloud - OUC Business Development and Customer Retention Fund for all or a portion of the distribution. 
(Ord. No. 2007-107, § 3, 1-24-2008) 
Sec. 18-5. - Criteria for jobs creation grants. 
(a)  The city may award a grant in an amount determined by the city council per new job created or an existing job retained for projects which are for the purpose of relocation of an existing industry or business or the establishment of a new industry or business within the planning area. This grant may be in addition to grants awarded by Osceola County or any other federal or State of Florida agency grants. 
(b)  In addition to any other applicable requirement or criteria as may be set by law or agreement, the following criteria will be applied in awarding grants for job creation and retention from the trust fund, the OUC/St. Cloud Economic Development Fund or other funds deemed appropriate by the city council: 
(1)  The grantee should be a target industry or business pursuant to an adopted resolution by the city council. 
(2)  New or retained jobs must be permanent, full time jobs paying a minimum base wage of 115 percent of the Osceola County average wage. 
(3)  In addition [to] the minimum base wage as stated above, the employer must offer paid benefits to include, but not be limited to, medical insurance. 
(4)  A minimum of ten new jobs meeting the above qualifications must be created or retained. 
(5)  New jobs must be created within one year of the award of the grant. New and retained jobs must be maintained for a minimum of three years or a longer period as determined by the city council at the time of the grant award. 
(6)  The city council may determine other factors such as, but not limited to, a willingness to hire St. Cloud and Osceola County residents, the purchase of locally produced products, the use of local contractors for construction and maintenance of facilities and providing job training for the local residents hired. 
(Ord. No. 2007-107, § 3, 1-24-2008) 
Sec. 18-6. - Speculative building incentive plan. 
(a)  In order to create a more attractive market for the relocation, establishment or expansion of target industry and business to the City of St. Cloud, it is determined that an increase of certain types of building inventory is necessary. In order to accomplish said increase in these building inventories, the city may elect to offer deferral of impact fees and waiver of certain permit and inspection fees to developers willing to construct speculative buildings in the office, flex and industrial building categories. 
(b)  The minimum building criteria to qualify for this incentive plan is as follows: 
(i)  Office buildings must be built and designed as "class A" buildings. A "class A" office building is generally defined as a multi-story building constructed with concrete or masonry materials that is designed for corporate and professional use. To qualify for this plan, the building must be a minimum of 25,000 square feet in size. Except for common areas the building should be left in shell form to allow for custom client build-out. 
(ii)  Flex buildings are generally defined as a multi-use facility designed to accommodate light industrial, production and office. They should not be used for institutional uses such as places of religious worship, recreational uses such as gymnasiums or retail. To qualify for this plan, the building must be a minimum of 30,000 square feet in size, be constructed of concrete or masonry materials, contain a glass front and overhead doors in the rear, contain a minimum of two-hour fire-rated demising walls, a minimum 16-foot clear ceiling span and bay sizes of no less than 2,500 square feet. The building should be left in shell form to accommodate custom client build-outs. 
(iii)  Industrial buildings are designed for manufacturing, warehousing and distribution. To qualify for this plan the building must be a minimum of 30,000 square feet, be constructed of concrete or masonry materials, loading docks must be a minimum of 48 inches in height, bays must be a minimum of 3,000 square feet, ceiling heights must be a minimum 20-foot clear span, all demising walls must have a minimum of a two-hour fire rating and truck courts must have a minimum depth of 100 feet. The building should be left in shell form to accommodate custom client build-outs. 
(iv)  Requests for variances to land development code requirements for amenities such as landscaping and parking shall not be permitted if application for this plan has been made. 
(v)  In the event the owner/developer of the building is also a user/occupant of the building, the speculative portion of the building must be a minimum of 50 percent of the portion of the building that is being occupied by said owner developer. In no case shall the total size of the building be less than the minimum sizes stated above. 
(c)  The benefits of this speculative building plan are as follows: 
(1)  Transportation and public safety impact fees assessed by the city shall be paid by the developer at the time of the issuance of the certificate of occupancy for space being leased to a business or industry occupying all or a portion of the building. Said fees shall be assessed based on the amount of square footage being occupied and continue to be assessed in this manner until the building is occupied in its entirety. In any case the impact fees on the entire building shall be paid by the developer within 18 months from the time a certificate of completion is issued for the building shell and site improvements. 
(2)  In order to reserve capacity during the concurrency review, water and sewer capacity reservation fees are due at the time as normally required by city council resolution. Speculative buildings meeting the requirements of this incentive plan shall pay 25 percent of the water and sewer reservation fees in effect at the time they are due. 
New construction that has a multi-meter building service shall be assessed at the full rate in effect at the time of the issuance of a water meter for that portion of the building being leased or occupied and served by said water meter. Impact fees related to each meter shall be assessed based upon the proposed use and current equivalent residential unit (ERU) calculation method approved by city council. Impact fees to be paid prior to the placement of the water meter shall be the impact fees assessed for the area served by said meter less a prorated (by square footage to be occupied and served by said meter) portion of the actual reservation fees previously paid. Remaining impact fees shall continue to be assessed in this manner until the building is occupied or served in its entirety. 
New construction that has a master meter shall be assessed at the full rate in effect at the time of the issuance of a water meter for the entire building being served by said water meter. Fees for the area served by the water meter shall be assessed based upon the proposed use and current equivalent residential unit (ERU) calculation method approved by city council. Impact fees to be paid prior to the placement of the water meter shall be the impact fees assessed for the area served by the meter less the reservation fees which were paid previously. 
Changes of use may alter the total impact fees due and may require submittal of an application for and issuance of a new certificate of capacity. In the event that additional impact fees are due as the result of the change in use, the balance of all water and sewer impact fees assessed by the city shall be paid at the rate in effect at the time of placement of the new water meter or the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for commercial renovation not requiring a new or replacement water meter. 
(3)  Permit and inspection fees normally assessed by the city shall be waived on the building shell and the site improvements. Permit and inspection fees for tenant build-outs will be assessed by the city as normal. For an owner/occupant, this benefit shall be prorated and applicable only to that portion of the building/site not occupied by the owner. 
(Ord. No. 2007-107, § 3, 1-24-2008) 
Sec. 18-7. - Other incentives. 
(a)  The city may from time to time create a custom incentive plan that is not defined or described in this chapter for an individual business, industry or development, targeted or not, if it is determined by the city to be a benefit to the city as a whole. These incentive plans may include, but not be limited to, cash awards, the financing of impact fees or supplying additional infrastructure needs. These custom plans should be for business and industry that supplies services or products that fill public need or such commercial projects that will have a major economic impact to the city. 
(b)  These types of plans shall follow all application and approval process[es] set out in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2007-107, § 3, 1-24-2008) 
Sec. 18-8. - Review of economic development incentive applications. 
(a)  Applicants may make application for grant funds with the city's economic development office or whatever office or department the city manager may designate from time to time. A staff level review team appointed by the city manager will review the application and make recommendations with regard to the application. Additional information, if any, shall be requested of the applicant in writing following the initial staff review. A report shall be prepared as to whether the grant application should be approved and if so any award amounts, what fund the awards should be taken from, conditions to be placed on the award and any monitoring to be done by the city after the award is made. The recommendation and report shall then be forwarded to the city council for their approval. 
(b)  The grant application shall be made on an application form made available by the city and shall include, but not be limited to, the following information: 
(1)  A complete description of the project. 
(2)  The location of the existing or proposed facility, any applicable development activity and the project commencement date. 
(3)  The amounts and proposed use of grant funds requested. 
(4)  Proposed utility usage if applicable. 
(5)  Complete information on existing employment and any new employment created by the project. 
(6)  An annual impact statement. 
(c)  This application procedure may be required by the city for any other incentive programs such as impact fee job credits which are provided by the city by separate ordinance or resolution. 
(Ord. No. 2007-107, § 3, 1-24-2008) 
Sec. 18-9. - Grant agreements. 
    Each applicant that is approved for a grant or incentive program shall execute a grant agreement. The said agreement shall include but not limited to the following: 
(1)  All criteria specific to the grant or incentive plan approved by the city council. 
(2)  An expenditure schedule for any cash awards. 
(3)  The date or schedule for the issuance of funds by the city. 
(4)  A schedule of company records or reports required for auditing and monitoring purposes by the city to ensure all criteria for the grant or incentive plan is being met by the recipient. 
(5)  Terms of repayment of the grant or benefits of the incentive plan in the event the recipient fails to perform under the terms and conditions of the grant award or incentive plan. 
(6)  If the location of the project falls within the planning area but is not currently located within the city limits and cannot be annexed due to state statutory regulation, an agreement for future annexation shall be required unless this provision is specifically waived by city council. 
(Ord. No. 2007-107, § 3, 1-24-2008) 
Chapter 20 - ELECTIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Regular elections; special elections; method of holding elections, § 8.01; recall of members of the city council, §§ 3.07, 3.08; qualification of voters, § 8.02; registration of voters, § 8.03; canvass of election returns by city council, § 8.04; nomination of candidates in city elections, § 8.05; use of voting machines authorized in city elections, § 8.08; adoption of ordinances by initiative and referendum, §§ 9.01, 9.02. 
State Law reference- Florida election code, F.S. chs. 97-106. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - City manager to advertise election. 
    Before any regular or special election, the city manager, or his designee, shall advertise a resolution of the city council prescribing the date the election is to be held, the date of any primary election, the offices to be voted for and/or the issues to be submitted to the electors, the nomination period for candidates, and the precinct locations. The resolution shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least 30 days prior to the date of the election. 
(Code 1967, § 8-1; Code 1994, § 30-2; Ord. No. 97-32, § 1, 11-13-1997; Ord. No. 2015-22 , § 1, 6-11-2015) 
Sec. 20-2. - General election and primary election. 
    The 2016 general election for city council seats 1, 2 and 3 shall occur on Tuesday, November 1, 2016. Thereafter, all general elections shall be as set forth in the City Charter, unless the city council adopts an ordinance changing the date to correspond with any Osceola County or State of Florida election date occurring in November. In the event there are more than two candidates who qualify for any one seat, there shall be a primary election. In 2016 the primary election, if needed, shall be held on August 30, 2016. Thereafter, the primary election shall be held on such date as set forth by resolution of the city council. In the event one of the candidates receives a majority of the votes in the primary election, he or she shall be declared elected. In the event no candidate receives a majority of the votes, the two candidates for whom the highest numbers of votes were cast shall stand for election at the general election. 
(Ord. No. 2015-22 , § 2, 6-11-2015) 
Sec. 20-3. - Qualifying. 
    Candidates for any elective office shall qualify with the Osceola County Supervisor of Elections and set forth by resolution during a qualifying period beginning at 12:00 noon on the 71st day prior to the first primary and ending at noon the 67th day prior to the date of the first primary as prescribed in the state statutes or by city council. 
(Ord. No. 2015-22 , § 2, 6-11-2015) 
Sec. 20-4. - Term of office. 
    The term for each candidate elected shall begin at noon on the second Thursday following the November election. 
(Ord. No. 2015-22 , § 2, 6-11-2015) 
Secs. 20-5-20-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CANVASSING BOARD 

Sec. 20-31. - Created. 
    There shall be a canvassing board for each city election composed of three members appointed as provided in either section 20-32 or 20-33, whichever is applicable. 
(Code 1994, § 30-36; Ord. No. 91-B, § I, 1-17-1991) 
Sec. 20-32. - Appointment-Elections not involving mayor or councilmember. 
    For any election at which the office of mayor or councilmember is not involved, the three members of the canvassing board shall be selected by the city council from its members. 
(Code 1994, § 30-37; Ord. No. 91-B, § II, 1-17-1991) 
Sec. 20-33. - Same-Elections involving mayor or councilmember. 
    For any election at which the office of mayor or councilmember is involved: 
(1)  First, the three members of the canvassing board shall be selected by the city council from those of its members: 
a.  Who are not candidates in the election to be canvassed, or who are candidates but are without opposition in the election to be canvassed; and 
b.  Who are not active participants in the candidacy of any candidate who has opposition in the election to be canvassed. 
(2)  Second, if there are less than three members of the city council who meet the criteria of subsection (1) of this section, the city council shall, at its next regular meeting following the last day for nomination as a candidate in the election to be canvassed, by resolution make a finding of that fact and shall find the number of canvassing board alternate members required. 
(3)  Any councilmember who is not a candidate in the election to be canvassed, or who is a candidate but is without opposition in the election to be canvassed, but who is, or intends to be, an active participant in the candidacy of any candidate who has opposition in the election to be canvassed, shall file with the city manager, on or before the last day for nomination as a candidate in the election to be canvassed, a written statement of such active participation. 
(Code 1994, § 30-38; Ord. No. 91-B, § III, 1-17-1991; Ord. No. 97-33, § I, 11-13-1997) 
Charter reference- Election and terms of city council, § 3.01(c); oath of office, § 3.01(d). 
Sec. 20-34. - Appointment of alternate members. 
(a)  Appointing officer. In the event of a finding by the city council that one or more canvassing board alternate members are required, the mayor shall make the request, as set forth in subsection (b) of this section, of one of the following county judicial and legislative officers, in the event one or more refuse or fail to perform such mayoral request, in the order listed: the senior county judge, any county judge, the chairman of the county board of commissioners, and any member of the county board of commissioners who represents a county district in which a portion of this city is located. 
(b)  Mayoral request. The mayor shall request of the judicial or legislative office that he appoint the number of canvassing board alternate members as the city council has found to be required, with such alternate being a person who: 
(1)  Is a qualified elector of the city; and 
(2)  Is not an active participant in the candidacy of any candidate who has opposition in the election to be canvassed. 
(Code 1994, § 30-39; Ord. No. 91-B, § IV, 1-17-1991) 
Chapter 22 - EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes:
