State Law reference- Emergency continuity of government, F.S. ch. 22; state emergency management act, F.S. § 252.31 et seq.; state of emergency, F.S. § 870.041 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1-22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Medical telecommunications and transportation, F. S. ch. 401. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abode means an abiding place; a place in which one stays; a place in which to continue; a place in which to dwell, to sojourn. See Dwelling. 
    Boardinghouse means an establishment with lodging for four or more persons, where meals are regularly prepared and served and where food is placed upon the table family-style, without service or ordering of individual portions from a menu, and where there is compensation paid for the food, lodging or care. 
    Dwelling means a building or portion thereof designed exclusively for residential occupancy, including one-family, two-family and multifamily dwellings, but not including hotels, motels, boardinghouses, roominghouses, house trailers, whether such trailers be mobile or located in a stationary fashion as on blocks or other foundations, tents, houseboats, travel trailers or other forms of temporary or portable housing. 
    Dwelling, multifamily, or multiple-family dwelling means a building containing three or more dwelling units. 
    Dwelling, multiple, means three or more dwelling units intended to be rented and maintained under central ownership and management, such as cooperative apartments, condominiums, RV and mobile home parks and the like, with or without master utility connections. Multiple dwellings primarily available for less than one week rental shall be considered a tourist home, motel, motor hotel or hotel. 
    Dwelling, single-family, means a building containing only one dwelling unit. 
    Dwelling, two-family or duplex, means a building containing only two dwelling units. 
    Dwelling unit means each single-family dwelling and each living accommodation within all two-family dwellings or duplexes, multiple dwellings, townhouses and multifamily dwellings, including those of conventional construction, manufactured housing and mobile homes; and each living accommodation within a master utility metered mobile home or recreational vehicle park. 
    Foster care facility means a structure in which the owners or operators are subject to licensing or approval by the state department of children and family services, live permanently and provide full-time care and supervision in a family living environment to a maximum of three full-time clients who are unrelated to the owners or operators. 
    Foster group home means a structure in which the owners are subject to licensing and approval by the state department of children and family services, and provide basic care and supervision in a family living environment for four or more clients who are unrelated to the owners or operators. 
    Guesthouse or cottage means a detached accessory building located on the same premises of the main residential building, intended for intermittent or temporary occupancy by a nonpaying guest, and which has no cooking facilities and is not rented. The guesthouse or cottage shall be considered with the main residential building as if one structure. 
    Hotel, motel, motor hotel, motor lodge, tourist court are to be considered synonymous and mean a building or a group of buildings in which sleeping accommodations are offered to the public and intended primarily for rental to transients with daily charge, as distinguished from multiple-family dwellings (apartments) and roominghouses or boardinghouses, where rentals are for periods of a week or longer and occupancy is generally by residents rather than transients. 
    Lodging unit means each sleeping accommodation within a hotel, motel, motor hotel, motor lodge, tourist court, and within a roominghouse, boardinghouse, retirement center and like facilities. 
    Medical unit means each bed space within a foster group home, nursing home, rest home, convalescent home, congregate living home and like facilities. 
    Mobile home, manufactured housing, means a single-family dwelling unit designed for long-term occupancy, with plumbing and electrical connections provided for attachment to outside systems to be transported after fabrication on its own wheels, or on a flatbed or other trailer, arriving at the site where it is to be occupied, complete and ready for occupancy, except for incidental unpacking and assembly operations, location on a foundation, and connection to utilities. 
    Modular home or modular unit means a residence suitable for yearround use that is substantially fabricated off the site where it is to be occupied; and which is designated for transportation, usually on a trailer, either as a whole unit or in major segments to a lot where it is assembled, connected to utilities and finished for authorized occupancy. Such home or unit shall be classified according to its dwelling use. 
    Month means the city electrical utility billing period, normally 28 to 31 consecutive days, with no calendar year having more than 12. 
    Motel. See Hotel. 
    Nursing home means a community residential facility which provides food, shelter, diagnosis, treatment, individualized continuing evaluation, planning, 24-hour supervision and coordination and integration of health or rehabilitative services to help each client reach his maximum functioning capabilities. The capacity of such facility shall not be less than three clients. This definition shall include rest home and convalescent home. 
    Retail business means a business which is primarily concerned with the sale or rental of tangible goods. 
    Retirement center means a facility, in the nature of multiple-family housing, with no provision for routine nursing and/or medical care. 
    Roominghouse means an establishment with lodging for four or more persons where there is compensation paid for lodging or care. 
    Service business means a business primarily concerned with providing professional or technical advice, aid or help, and includes trade schools. 
    Townhouse means a single-family dwelling constructed as a part of a series of dwellings, all of which are either attached to adjacent dwellings by party walls or are located immediately adjacent thereto with no visible separation between walls or roofs. 
    Utilized abode, business or industry means an abode, business or industry which is available for nominal human living, conduct of business or industry, temporary or long-term, and normally with utilities available. Electrical service to an entity for any portion of a month shall be prima facie evidence of the entity being utilized during the month; provided, any entity to which electrical service has been discontinued shall not be considered as a utilized entity. 
(Code 1994, § 34-26; Ord. No. 90-CC, § 2, 9-13-1990) 
Sec. 22-32. - System established. 
    An emergency medical services (EMS) system is hereby established within the city, to be provided by city fire department personnel and with city capital equipment and materials from within the fire department. 
(Code 1967, § 91/2-1; Code 1994, § 34-27) 
Sec. 22-33. - Advanced life support services. 
    The level of EMS service established shall be that known as "advanced life support" as defined under the Florida Emergency Medical Services Grant Act (F.S. § 401.101 et seq.) and the state administrative regulations promulgated thereunder. The city manager is authorized and directed to take whatever actions are necessary or desirable on an emergency basis to begin advanced life support emergency medical services. 
(Code 1967, § 91/2-2; Code 1994, § 34-28) 
Sec. 22-34. - Usage fees authorized. 
    As a primary method of funding the emergency medical services system's dispensation, including but not limited to the administration, operation and maintenance costs of the system, emergency medical services usage fees are imposed against the person of anyone to whom emergency medical service is provided. 
(Code 1967, § 91/2-3; Code 1994, § 34-29) 
Sec. 22-35. - Schedule of usage fees. 
    The city council shall from time to time by resolution set the schedule of usage fees and charges for users of the emergency medical services, and these usage fees for such services shall be levied and collected administratively. Furthermore, the city manager and/or his designee are authorized to write off unpaid balances or accounts on a case-by-case basis due to hardship or other appropriate circumstances. 
(Code 1967, § 91/2-4; Code 1994, § 34-30; Ord. No. 90-SSSS, § 1, 11-8-1990; Ord. No. 95-40, § 2, 10-12-1995) 
Secs. 22-36-22-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SUBSCRIPTION CHARGES AND FEES 

Sec. 22-51. - Applicability. 
    The owner, tenant and subtenant, individually and collectively, of each utilized abode, of each utilized retail business, or each service business and each utilized industrial entity within the corporate limits of the city shall subscribe to the availability of city emergency medical services and pay therefor the subscription charge imposed and the monthly availability fee imposed. 
(Code 1994, § 34-51; Ord. No. 90-CC, § 3, 9-13-1990) 
Sec. 22-52. - Availability subscription charge. 
    As a primary method of funding the costs of establishing or reestablishing an EMS availability account, there is hereby imposed an EMS availability subscription charge upon such owner, tenant and subtenant, of each utilized abode, utilized retail business, utilized service business and utilized industry. The city council shall from time to time set by resolution the schedule of availability subscription charge, and this charge for such services shall be levied and collected administratively. Furthermore, the city manager and/or his designee are authorized to write off unpaid balances or accounts on a case-by-case basis due to hardship or other appropriate circumstances. The amount of such subscription charge is to be on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1994, § 34-52; Ord. No. 90-CC, § 4, 9-13-1990; Ord. No. 97-08, § I, 4-24-1997) 
Sec. 22-53. - Abode availability fee. 
(a)  Fee imposed. There is imposed hereby a monthly EMS abode availability fee on the owner, tenant and subtenant, individually and collectively, of each utilized abode within the corporate limits of the city, as a primary method of funding the costs of the EMS system's availability, including, but not limited to, the capital, administrative and fixed costs of the EMS system. 
(b)  Abode classification. All abodes within the corporate limits of the city for the purposes of fixing the amount of the monthly abode availability fee are classified as follows: 
(1)  Class A: Each dwelling unit. 
(2)  Class B: Each lodging unit. 
(3)  Class C: Each medical unit. 
(c)  Fee amount. The amount of the EMS abode availability fee herein imposed shall be as currently established or hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1994, § 34-53; Ord. No. 90-CC, § 5, 9-13-1990; Ord. No. 95-40, § 1, 10-12-1995) 
Sec. 22-54. - Retail business availability fee. 
(a)  Fee imposed. There is imposed hereby a monthly EMS retail business availability fee on the owner, tenant and subtenant, individually and collectively, of each utilized retail business within the corporate limits of the city, as a primary method of funding the costs of the EMS system's availability, including, but not limited to, the capital, administrative and fixed costs of the EMS system. 
(b)  Retail business classification. All retail businesses within the corporate limits of the city for the purposes of fixing the amount of the monthly retail business availability fee are classified as follows: 
(1)  Class D, small retail business: 0 to 9,999 square feet of gross floor area. 
(2)  Class E, medium retail business: 10,000 to 14,999 square feet of gross floor area. 
(3)  Class F, large retail business: 15,000 or more square feet of gross floor area. 
(c)  Fee amount. The amount of the EMS retail business availability fee herein imposed shall be as currently established or hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1994, § 34-54; Ord. No. 90-CC, § 6, 9-13-1990; Ord. No. 95-40, § 1, 10-12-1995) 
Sec. 22-55. - Service business availability fee. 
(a)  Fee imposed. There is imposed hereby a monthly EMS service business availability fee on the owner, tenant and subtenant, individually and collectively, of each utilized service business within the corporate limits of the city, as a primary method of funding the costs of the EMS system's availability, including, but not limited to, the capital, administrative and fixed costs of the EMS system. 
(b)  Service business classification. All service businesses within the corporate limits of the city for the purposes of fixing the amount of the monthly service business availability fee are classified as follows: 
(1)  Class G, small service business: 0 to 9,999 square feet of gross floor area. 
(2)  Class H, medium service business: 10,000 to 14,999 square feet of gross floor area. 
(3)  Class I, large service business: 15,000 or more square feet of gross floor area. 
(c)  Fee amount. The amount of the service business availability fee herein imposed shall be as currently established or hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1994, § 34-55; Ord. No. 90-CC, § 7, 9-13-1990; Ord. No. 95-40, § 1, 10-12-1995) 
Sec. 22-56. - Industrial availability fee. 
(a)  Fee imposed. There is imposed hereby a monthly EMS industrial availability fee on the owner, tenant and subtenant, individually and collectively, of each utilized industry within the corporate limits of the city, as a primary method of funding the costs of the EMS system's availability, including, but not limited to, the capital, administrative and fixed costs of the EMS system. 
(b)  Fee amount. The amount of the EMS industrial availability fee shall be a monthly amount in whole dollars equal to the number of persons employed by the subject industry in the city on January 1 of each year in which such availability fee obligation is incurred, divided by 250, with the resultant rounded up to a whole number. The minimum monthly charge shall be set from time to time by the city council by resolution. 
(Code 1994, § 34-56; Ord. No. 90-CC, § 8, 9-13-1990; Ord. No. 95-40, § 1, 10-12-1995) 
Sec. 22-57. - Exempt entities. 
    Specifically exempt from the imposition of any EMS availability fee are the following uses: 
(1)  Governmental; 
(2)  Churches; 
(3)  Daycare centers, child or adult; 
(4)  Schools, public or private, but not trade; and 
(5)  Fraternal organizations. 
(Code 1994, § 34-57; Ord. No. 90-CC, § 9, 9-13-1990) 
Sec. 22-58. - Noncompliance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, tenant or subtenant, individually or collectively, of any utilized abode, or any owner, tenant or subtenant, individually or collectively, of any utilized place of business or industry within the city, to fail to subscribe for such EMS system for such utilized abode, place of business or industry, through failure to timely pay the EMS availability fee, so long as the abode, place of business or industry is utilized. 
(Code 1994, § 34-58; Ord. No. 90-CC, § 10, 9-13-1990) 
Sec. 22-59. - Enforcement. 
    In addition to all other penalties as generally provided by this Code for failure to comply with the provisions of any municipal ordinance, compliance herewith shall be enforced by the code enforcement board as provided by law. 
(Code 1994, § 34-59; Ord. No. 90-CC, § 11, 9-13-1990) 
Sec. 22-60. - Regulation. 
    The city manager is authorized and directed to prepare reasonable administrative regulations and policies in regard to the collection of the subscription charges, and the availability and user fees here established, as orderly administration shall require, and the same shall be approved and adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. Such regulations and polices shall include provisions for the establishment of an EMS fund, which shall be maintained separate and apart from other funds of the city, into which revenue from the charges and fees hereby established shall be paid and from which expenditures from EMS shall be made; and may include provisions to permit appropriation from the general fund as a loan to the EMS fund for the purchase of EMS capital equipment, repayment to be made to the general fund over a five-year period. 
(Code 1994, § 34-60; Ord. No. 90-CC, § 12, 9-13-1990) 
Chapter 24 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Environmental control, F.S. ch. 403. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Use and condition of private property visible from public street. 
    Private property which is visible from any public street within the city shall be maintained in such a manner so as not to create an unsightly condition due to litter or storage of materials or equipment, or due to deterioration of either complete or partial structures. 
(Code 1994, § 66-8; Ord. No. 95-23, § 1, 5-25-1995) 
Secs. 24-2-24-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - JUNKED, WRECKED, ABANDONED PROPERTY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Abandoned or lost property, F.S. § 705.101 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 24-31-24-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - VEHICLES 

Sec. 24-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned vehicle means a wrecked, stolen, stripped or neglected vehicle, which for a continuous period of more than seven days is physically located on the same private property parcel. The lack of a motor vehicle registration tag, properly attached to the vehicle shall be prima facie evidence that a wrecked, stolen, stripped or neglected vehicle located on private property, in addition to being an inoperable vehicle, is an abandoned vehicle. 
    Carport means an accessory structure or portion of a principal structure, consisting of a roof and supporting members such as columns or beams, unenclosed from the ground to the roof on at least two sides, and designed or used for the storage of motor-driven vehicles owned and used by the occupants of the building to which it is accessory. 
    Dangerous vehicle means a vehicle which represents or poses a danger to the public or the vehicle itself by reason of its physical location or condition (e.g., obstructing vehicular or pedestrian traffic, containing broken glass, leaking flammable liquids). 
    Derelict vehicle means a vehicle which, for a continuous period of more than 24 hours, has physically occupied the same right-of-way space or has been located on the same public property parcel, and which is a wrecked, stolen, stripped or inoperable vehicle. 
    Enclosed building means a structure which has in place all of its vertical walls; nevertheless, one wall may be lintelled and faced to accept and with a folding or hinged wall or door. 
    Inoperable vehicle means a vehicle incapable of safe operation under its own power upon a right-of-way. The lack of a motor vehicle registration tag properly attached to the vehicle shall be prima facie evidence that the vehicle is an inoperable vehicle. A motor vehicle registration tag shall not be current unless the same can be determined from an on-site inspection of the tag's expiration date. 
    Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, organization or entity of any kind holding ownership or control of the subject property, real or personal as the context may require. 
    Property means any real property within the city which is not a right-of-way. 
    Repair, major, means the removal from the frame and the disassembly of the components of the power train of a motor vehicle to include either the engine, transmission or rear axle assembly; and shall include auto body work which involves the removal of the part to be repaired, fender, door panel, hood, trunk lid and the like. 
    Repair, minor, means those repairs which are not major or moderate repairs. 
    Repair, moderate, means in-frame repair of the engine which involves the removal of the cylinder head, oil pan, or the in-frame repair of the rear axle; and includes, but is not limited to, repair of brakes; repair of steering system, ball joints, steering arms and idler arms; and repair of the suspension system, shock absorbers, struts, wheel alignment and springs. 
    Right-of-way is synonymous with street, road, highway and alley, and means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly dedicated or maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular traffic. 
    Stripped vehicle means a vehicle which is inoperable due to the removal of a major part or multiple minor parts of the vehicle. 
    Vehicle means a machine propelled by power other than human power designed to travel by use of wheels, treads, runners or slides, and transport persons or property or pull machinery and shall include, without limitation, automobile, truck, boat, recreational, trailer, motorcycle, tractor, buggy and wagon. 
    Wrecked vehicle means a vehicle which is inoperable due to one or more deformities which are the result of impact. 
(Code 1994, § 38-36; Ord. No. 91-G, § I, 6-27-1991; Ord. No. 02-33, § I, 8-8-2002; Ord. No. 2003-75, § I, 12-11-2003) 
Sec. 24-52. - Prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to permit, allow or suffer any abandoned, dangerous, derelict, inoperable, stripped or wrecked vehicle to be parked within the city. 
(b)  To the extent not otherwise prohibited by fire and building codes as the same regulate the above-referenced vehicles, subsection (a) of this section shall not apply with regard to a vehicle: 
(1)  Parked completely in an enclosed building or parked completely within a carport and covered with a standard vehicle cover. 
(2)  For a period of less than nine months, when the vehicle is on the premises of a licensed business enterprise operated in a lawful place and in a lawful manner provided the same is necessary to the operation of such business. 
(3)  In an appropriate storage place or depository legally approved and maintained for said purpose. 
(Code 1994, § 38-37; Ord. No. 91-G, § I, 6-27-1991; Ord. No. 02-37, § II, 8-8-2002; Ord. No. 2003-75, § II, 12-11-2003) 
Sec. 24-53. - Enforcement. 
    Any person violating this division shall be subject to enforcement as permitted under chapter 2, article VI. 
(Code 1994, § 38-38; Ord. No. 91-G, § I, 6-27-1991) 
Sec. 24-54. - Dangerous vehicles; impoundment. 
    Immediate removal or proper repair shall be accomplished for any dangerous vehicle upon notice. In the event of such notice or in the event of reasonably attempted notice, where immediate removal or proper repair is not accomplished, a dangerous vehicle may be impounded by the city without prior notice of such impoundment and with imposition of costs. 
(Code 1994, § 38-39; Ord. No. 91-G, § I, 6-27-1991) 
Sec. 24-55. - Vehicles undergoing major repair. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit, allow or suffer a vehicle to undergo major repair on any real property located in a zoning district other than those districts in which vehicle major repair use is permitted under the land development code of the city, and unless a city occupational license for vehicle major repair is in effect for the subject vehicle major repair location. The prohibition of this section shall not apply to vehicle major repair performed within an enclosed building, or otherwise out of the public's view, and which has a reasonable personal individual nexus with the subject property (as opposed to a multiple, business or commercial nexus). 
(Code 1994, § 38-40; Ord. No. 91-G, § I, 6-27-1991) 
Sec. 24-56. - Vehicles undergoing moderate repair. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit, allow or suffer a vehicle to undergo moderate repair on any real property located in a zoning district other than those districts in which vehicle major repair use is permitted under the land development code of the city, unless a city occupational license for vehicle major repair (mobile mechanic) is in effect for the person performing the vehicle moderate repair and providing such repair is completed within seven calendar days. The prohibition of this section shall not apply to vehicle moderate repair performed within an enclosed building, or otherwise out of the public's view, and which has a reasonable personal individual nexus with the subject property (as opposed to a multiple business or commercial nexus). 
(Code 1994, § 38-41; Ord. No. 91-G, § I, 6-27-1991) 
Secs. 24-57-24-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NOISE CONTROL 

Sec. 24-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial area means an area classified by the zoning code as neighborhood business, business commercial, highway business, industrial 1, 2, and 3 (I-1, I-2, and I-3), central business 1 and 2 (CBD-1 and CBD-2). 
    Emergency means any occurrence or set of circumstances involving actual or imminent physical trauma or property damage threatened or caused by an emergency. 
    Noise disturbance means any sound which: 
(1)  Endangers or injures the safety or health of humans or animals; 
(2)  Annoys or disturbs a reasonable person of normal sensitivities; or 
(3)  Endangers or injures personal or real property. 
    Plainly audible sound means any sound for which the information content of that sound is communicated to the listener such as, but not limited to, understandable spoken speech or comprehensible musical rhythms. 
    Real property line means an imaginary line along the surface and its vertical plane extension which separates the real property owned, rented or leased by one person from that owned, rented or leased by another person, excluding intrabuilding real property divisions. 
    Residential area means an area classified by the zoning code as residential. 
(Code 1994, § 38-62; Ord. No. 94-17, § VI, 5-12-1994) 
Sec. 24-82. - Exemptions. 
    The following shall be exempt from the provisions of this article: 
(1)  Noise alerting persons to the existence of an emergency or in the performance of emergency work. 
(2)  Chimes, bells and music emanating from religious establishments. 
(3)  City refuse operations. 
(4)  Traditional community events, such as parades or sports events. 
(5)  Routine maintenance of public service facilities. 
(Code 1994, § 38-63; Ord. No. 94-17, § VII, 5-12-1994) 
Sec. 24-83. - Enforcement. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to enforcement as permitted under section 1-15 and/or chapter 2, article VI. 
(Code 1994, § 38-64; Ord. No. 94-17, § VIII, 5-12-1994) 
Sec. 24-84. - Owner's and lessee's responsibility. 
    It shall be a violation of this section for an owner or a lessee who is present on any property that he owns or leases to allow a noise disturbance to be created or exist from such property so as to violate those prohibitions listed in section 24-86. 
(Code 1994, § 38-65; Ord. No. 94-17, § IX, 5-12-1994) 
Sec. 24-85. - Noise disturbances prohibited generally. 
    No person shall make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any noise disturbance. 
(Code 1994, § 38-66; Ord. No. 94-17, § X, 5-12-1994) 
Sec. 24-86. - Specific prohibitions. 
    The following acts, among others (this enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive), are declared to be noise disturbances in violation of this article: 
(1)  Horns, signaling devices, etc. The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle on any street or public place of the city for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time, thereby creating a noise disturbance. 
(2)  Radios, phonographs, television sets, musical instruments, etc. 
a.  Playing, using, operating, or permitting to be played, used or operated any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner: 
1.  As to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of neighboring inhabitants; 
2.  At any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for the persons who are in the same dwelling unit of any multiple dwelling in which such machine or device is operated and who are voluntarily listeners thereto; or 
3.  As to create a noise disturbance. 
b.  It shall be a violation to commit any one of the enumerated acts listed in this section. 
c.  The operation of any such set, instrument, phonograph, machine or device between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. in such manner as to create a plainly audible sound either at a distance of 50 feet from the building, structure or vehicle in which it is located or so that a person inside a building which is across a residential property line from the source of the sound is able to hear the plainly audible sound shall be prima facie evidence and create a presumption that a noise disturbance exists in violation of this article. 
(3)  Loudspeakers, amplifiers for advertising. The using, playing, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound upon the public street of a residential area for the purpose of commercial advertising or attracting the attention of the public to any building or structure. 
(4)  Yelling, shouting, etc. Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or singing on the public streets between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. so as to create a noise disturbance. 
(5)  Animals, birds, etc. The keeping of any animal or bird which by causing frequent or long continued noise creates a noise disturbance in a residential area. 
(6)  Exhaust. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motorboat, automobile or other motor vehicle (with the exception of construction or agricultural equipment either on a job site or traveling on the highways) without the use of a muffler or other device which will reduce the noise to such a level so as not to be a noise disturbance and so as to comply with any applicable state law governing motor vehicle noise. 
(7)  Loading, unloading, opening boxes. The creation of a loud and excessive noise to amount to a noise disturbance in a residential area in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle with the opening and destruction of bales, boxes, crates and containers between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(8)  Schools, courts, churches, hospitals. The creation of any noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church or court while the school, institution of learning, church or court is in use, or adjacent to any hospital, which interferes with the workings of such institution or which disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospital. 
(9)  Construction activities, pile drivers, hammers, etc. The operation between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of any pile driver, steam shovel, pneumatic hammer, derrick, steam or electric hoist, power saw or other construction appliance or machine so as to create a noise disturbance across a residential or commercial real property line. 
(10)  Domestic power tools. Operating or permitting the operation of any mechanically powered saw, drill, grinder, lawn or garden tool or similar tool between 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following day so as to create a noise disturbance across a residential or commercial real property line. 
(11)  Construction activities and domestic power tools on Sunday. Operating or permitting the operation of any pile driver, steam shovel, pneumatic hammer, derrick, steam or electric hoist, power saw or other construction appliance or machine, or any mechanically powered saw, drill, grinder, lawn or garden tool or similar tool between 9:00 p.m. on Saturday and 9:00 a.m. on Sunday so as to create a noise disturbance across a residential or commercial real property line. 
(Code 1994, § 38-67; Ord. No. 94-17, § XI, 5-12-1994) 
Sec. 24-87-24-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LITTER[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- State litter law, F.S. § 403.413. 

Sec. 24-111. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized private receptacle means a litter storage and collection receptacle as required and authorized by the city manager or his designee under the city's refuse collection system. 
    Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Handbill means any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature. 
    Litter means garbage, refuse and rubbish as defined in this section and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as prohibited in this article tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. 
    Newspaper means any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law and newspaper duly entered with the United States Postal Service, in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law; and, in addition thereto, means and includes any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four issues per year and sold to the public. 
    Owner means the fee simple owner of a private premises or the occupant thereof and, in the event of multiple units, the owner or the property owners' association, as the case may be. 
    Park means a park, reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other public area in the city, owned or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Passover symbol means that symbol which the owner or occupant and, in the event of multiunits, the owner, of any private premises shall give by display or notice to the distributor of newspapers that the distributor shall make no delivery to such premises. 
    Private premises means any dwelling, house, building or other structure designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building or other structure. 
    Public place means any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and buildings. 
    Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body wastes), including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, and solid market and industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yards clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1967, § 16-142; Code 1994, § 38-86) 
Sec. 24-112. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this article shall be enforced under the provisions of chapter 2, article VI. 
(Code 1967, § 16-162; Code 1994, § 38-87) 
Sec. 24-113. - Use of receptacles required. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the city except in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles for collection. 
(Code 1967, § 16-143; Code 1994, § 38-88) 
Sec. 24-114. - Placement in receptacles so as to prevent scattering. 
    Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
(Code 1967, § 16-144; Code 1994, § 38-89) 
Sec. 24-115. - Sweeping into gutters, drains, sidewalks, etc. 
(a)  No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully or intentionally place, or cause to be placed sand, shell, leaves, trash and debris of any kind in any gutter, curb and street gutter, storm drain, drain or ditch of any kind, within the limits of the city, so as to hinder, impede or in any way interfere with the drainage provided by the gutter, drain or ditch. 
(Code 1967, §§ 16-145, 23-5; Code 1994, § 38-90) 
Sec. 24-116. - Merchants' duty to keep sidewalks free of litter. 
    No person owning or occupying a place of business shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying places of business within the city shall keep the sidewalk in front of their business premises free of litter. 
(Code 1967, § 16-146; Code 1994, § 38-91) 
Sec. 24-117. - Litter thrown from vehicles. 
    No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the city or upon private property. 
(Code 1967, § 16-147; Code 1994, § 38-92) 
Sec. 24-118. - Parks. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any park within the city except in public receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any street or other public place. Where public receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere as provided herein. 
(Code 1967, § 16-149; Code 1994, § 38-93) 
Sec. 24-119. - Lakes and fountains. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any fountain, pond, lake, stream, bay or any other body of water in a park or elsewhere within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 16-150; Code 1994, § 38-94) 
Sec. 24-120. - Depositing handbills on uninhabited or vacant premises. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any handbill in or upon any private premises which are temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant. 
(Code 1967, § 16-152; Code 1994, § 38-96) 
Sec. 24-121. - Distribution of handbills prohibited where properly posted. 
    No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any handbill upon any private premises if requested by anyone thereon not to do so or if there is placed on the premises, in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof, a sign bearing the words: "no trespassing," "no peddlers or agents," "no advertisement," "no solicitors," or any similar notice indicating in any matter that the occupants of the premises do not desire to be molested or have their right of privacy disturbed or to have any such handbills left upon such premises. 
(Code 1967, § 16-153; Code 1994, § 38-97) 
Sec. 24-122. - Posting notices on utility poles, trees, etc. 
    No person shall post or affix any notice, poster or other paper or device, calculated to attract the attention of the public, to any lamppost, public utility pole or shade tree or upon any public structure or building, except as may be authorized or required by law. 
(Code 1967, § 16-154; Code 1994, § 38-98) 
Sec. 24-123. - Litter on occupied private property. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private property within the city, whether owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private property. 
(Code 1967, § 16-155; Code 1994, § 38-99) 
Sec. 24-124. - Owner to maintain premises free of litter. 
    The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter. This section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection. 
(Code 1967, § 16-156; Code 1994, § 38-100) 
Sec. 24-125. - Litter on vacant lots. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private property within the city, whether owned by such person or not. 
(Code 1967, § 16-157; Code 1994, § 38-101) 
Sec. 24-126. - Exemption for political literature. 
    Except as provided under section 24-122, which shall control, the other provisions of this article shall not apply to the distribution of political handbills upon private premises; however, such political handbills shall be placed in such a manner as to prevent their being carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or private premises. 
(Code 1967, § 16-158; Code 1994, § 38-102) 
Sec. 24-127. - Newspaper delivery to private premises displaying passover symbol. 
    It shall be unlawful to distribute newspapers or newsprint type classified ad publications to any private premises where the owner displays a passover symbol in such a manner as to give reasonable notice of the same, unless there shall be a current subscription agreement in force between the newspaper publication and the owner or occupant of the subject premises and, in the case of multiple units, an agreement with the owner or the property owners' association, as the case may be. 
(Code 1967, § 16-159; Code 1994, § 38-103) 
Sec. 24-128. - Newspaper delivery lawful to private premises not displaying passover symbol. 
    No provision of this article shall prohibit the distribution of newspapers or newsprint type classified ad publications to and upon private premises which do not display a passover symbol. 
(Code 1967, § 16-160; Code 1994, § 38-104) 
Sec. 24-129. - Acceptable passover symbol; reasonable notice. 
(a)  Standard symbols. The following are adopted as acceptable standard passover symbols: 
(1)  A green reflector, two inches in diameter, Stimsonite or equal, being placed in plain view at the approximate midpoint of the front yard of the subject premises. 
(2)  Such two-inch diameter green reflector placed on both sides of a rural-type mailbox. 
(3)  A green traffic reflector, four inches by four inches, Stimsonite or equal, being placed upon the paved street immediately in front of the subject premises and six feet from the pavement's edge, toward the centerline of the street. 
(b)  Placement. The placement of any one of the acceptable standard passover symbols listed in subsection (a) of this section on a particular premises is found to constitute reasonable notice. 
(Code 1967, § 16-161; Code 1994, § 38-105) 
Secs. 24-130-24-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - WEEDS AND DEBRIS 

Sec. 24-161. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Property means the abutting park strip, i.e., that parcel of land which abuts the fee simple property, and abuts the roadway curb; and if there is not curb, then that parcel of land which abuts the fee simple property, and abuts the roadway pavement; and if there is neither curb nor roadway pavement, then that parcel of land which abuts the fee simple property, and abuts the traveled way. 
    Rank growth means the growth of weeds, grass, undergrowth, palmettos or other vegetation, excluding trees, above a height of 12 inches from the ground, on any unimproved property, and shall include the growth of weeds, grass, undergrowth, palmettos or other vegetation, excluding trees, shrubbery and ornamental flowers reasonably arranged in beds, above a height of eight inches from the ground on any improved property. 
(Code 1994, § 38-126; Ord. No. 91-I-2, § 1(28-2), 3-12-1992) 
Sec. 24-162. - Accumulation declared nuisance. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any property owner or tenant, either or both, to permit, allow or suffer any rank growth of weeds, grass, undergrowth, palmettos or other vegetation which might communicate fire or serve as a breeding place for or harbor insects, rodents, snakes or other pests or vermin, and which is likely to affect the health of citizens of the community to occur on such owner's or tenant's property, and permitting, allowing or suffering the same is declared a nuisance. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any property owner or tenant, either or both, to permit, allow or suffer on any lot, parcel or area of land, the accumulation of any litter or debris which is likely to deter any person from using the public streets or other public travelways or present a present danger to the life or limb of the users thereof; or which emits foul or noxious odors; or which is likely to serve as a place for the breeding of flies, mosquitoes, or other insects known to be instrumental in the transmission of communicable diseases; or which serves as a haven or refuge for mice, rats, snakes or other animals or reptiles, likewise known to be transmitters of such communicable diseases; or which may constitute a fire hazard or otherwise be hazardous to the public health and safety; and the permitting, allowing or suffering the same is declared a nuisance. 
(Code 1967, § 28-1; Code 1994, § 38-127; Ord. No. 91-W-1, § I, 9-5-1991; Ord. No. 91-I-2, § 1(28-1), 3-12-1992) 
Sec. 24-163. - Exemptions. 
    The following lands shall be fully exempt from mowing or otherwise complying with the provisions of section 24-162: 
(1)  All lands designated as wetlands/conservation by the land use element of the city comprehensive plan, those lands within an agriculture zoning district and all public lands, including those used for solid waste disposal and wastewater reclamation. 
(2)  Any unimproved contiguous lands of 21/2 acres or more in area, which are buffered from the public road right-of-way and buffered from abutting improved parcels, provided: 
a.  The buffers contiguous to the public road right-of-way are nonexempt (mowed) lands not less than ten feet in width; and 
b.  The buffers contiguous to improved parcels are nonexempt (mowed) lands not less than 60 feet in width. 
(3)  Improved land or improved parcel is defined for purposes of this article as lands on which there is a structure. 
(Code 1994, § 38-128; Ord. No. 91-I-2, § 1(28-3), 3-12-1992) 
Sec. 24-164. - Nonaccessible areas exempt. 
    Lands or portions thereof which are nonaccessible areas shall be exempt from complying with the provisions of section 24-162. For the purpose of this section, generally, lands shall be nonaccessible due to natural causes (e.g., when the groundwater table level and/or the soil stability reasonably prohibits mowing machine maintenance) . In determining other nonaccessible areas, nonaccessibility shall have the reasonable plain word meaning and shall be determined by the reasonable man test, but in every case shall be due to natural causes. The exemption of this section shall not be continuous but shall apply as conditions warrant from time to time and shall continue only so long as the nonaccessibility continues. In any enforcement action, the sworn testimony of the city manager or his designee that the subject lands are not nonaccessible shall be prima facie evidence of that fact. 
(Code 1994, § 38-129; Ord. No. 91-I-2, § 1(28-4), 3-12-1992) 
Sec. 24-165. - Natural-state parcels exempt. 
    Portions of the grounds of an improved parcel which are a natural-state landscape treatment shall be exempt from complying with the provisions of section 24-162. For the purpose of this section, natural-state shall have the reasonable plain word meaning and shall be determined by the reasonable man test. The exemption of this section shall continue only so long as the actual natural-state landscape treatment continues. In any enforcement action, the sworn testimony of the city manager or his designee that the subject lands are not natural-state landscape treatment shall be prima facie evidence of that fact. 
(Code 1994, § 38-130; Ord. No. 91-I-2, § 1(28-5), 3-12-1992) 
Sec. 24-166. - Penalty for violation; enforcement. 
    Any person violating section 24-162 shall be subject to penalty and enforcement as permitted under this Code, and particularly under chapter 2, article VI, code enforcement board. 
(Code 1994, § 38-131; Ord. No. 91-W-1, § I, 9-5-1991; Ord. No. 91-I-2, § 1(28-6), 3-12-1992) 
Sec. 24-167. - Notice to remove and appeal process. 
(a)  Service of notice. If the city manager or his designee finds and determines that a nuisance as described and declared in section 24-162 exists, he shall so notify the record owner of the offending property and demand that such owner cause the condition to be remedied. The notice shall be given by both physical posting on the property in the name of the property owner and by certified mail or personal delivery to the owner or owners as their names and addresses are shown upon the public records of the county. Notice shall be deemed complete and sufficient when so physically posted and personally delivered or placed in the U.S. mail postage prepaid. 
(b)  Contents of notice. The notice required by subsection (a) of this section shall contain the following: 
(1)  Name and address of the owner of the property, according to the public records of the county. 
(2)  Location of the property on which the violation exists. 
(3)  A statement by the code inspector that the property has been inspected pursuant to this article and that a violation of section 24-162 has been determined to exist on the property, which violation constitutes a nuisance. 
(4)  A description of the condition which causes the property to be in violation. 
(5)  A requirement that the record owner of the property remedy the violation within 15 calendar days from the date of the notice, failing which the city will remedy the condition and assess against the record owner the costs thereof plus an administrative charge. 
(6)  A statement that, if the costs and administrative charge are not paid within 30 calendar days of invoice date, a lien will be placed on the property which is enforceable by foreclosure on the property. 
(7)  An estimate of the total cost if the violation is remedied by the city. Such estimate is not to be interpreted or construed as the final cost which may be assessed, but only as a good-faith approximation of such cost. The final assessable cost may be greater or lesser than the estimate. 
(8)  A statement that the record owner of the property may, within 15 calendar days from the date of the notice, submit a written appeal, from the determination of a nuisance, which must contain all reasons, evidence and argument that the cited condition does not constitute a violation. 
(c)  Appeal. Within 15 calendar days from the date of the notice, the owner of the property may appeal to show that the condition does not constitute a nuisance. Such appeal shall be addressed to the city manager and shall state the name of the property owner, the location of the cited property, and the specific grounds upon which the owner relies in order to show that the cited condition does not constitute a nuisance. 
(Code 1994, § 38-132; Ord. No. 95-43, § 1, 11-30-1995) 
Sec. 24-168. - Removal by city. 
(a)  If after 15 calendar days from the date of the notice no written appeal has been filed and the condition described in the notice has not been remedied, the city manager or his designee may cause the condition to be remedied by the city at the expense of the property owner. If a written appeal has been filed and the finding of nuisance is upheld, the city manager or his designee may cause the condition to be remedied by the city at the expense of the property owner unless the city council otherwise directs. 
(b)  If a written appeal has been filed and the finding of nuisance is reversed, the city will not assess any cost or administrative penalties against the property. 
(c)  In cases involving major nuisance conditions requiring immediate, direct action to abate hazards imminently dangerous to the health, welfare or safety of the public, the city may, upon the city manager's authorization, or the authorization of the city manager's designee, cause the conditions to be immediately remedied by city-authorized lot cleaning. Notice of such lot cleaning shall be given within five calendar days after the lot cleaning and according to the procedures detailed in section 24-167, except that the notice shall explain that the property contained hazards requiring immediate remedy, that the lot has already been cleaned, and that the property owner has 15 calendar days from the date of the notice to apply to city council to show why costs of cleaning should not be assessed against his property. Such emergency lot cleaning shall be at the expense of the property owner; however, the property owner may make a written request for a hearing before city council as above provided within 15 calendar days from the date of notice that his lot had to be cleaned and that a charge is being assessed therefor. 
(Code 1994, § 38-133; Ord. No. 95-43, § 1, 11-30-1995) 
Sec. 24-169. - Collection of costs and records; lien; secured property. 
(a)  After causing the condition to be remedied, the city manager or his designee shall certify to the director of finance the expense incurred in remedying the condition, whereupon such expense, plus a charge to cover city administrative expenses, plus any administrative penalty as provided in section 24-170, shall become a lien upon such property, which shall be payable with interest at the rate of eight percent per annum from the date of such certification until paid. Notice of such lien may be filed in the office of the clerk of the circuit court and recorded among the public records of the county. 
(b)  If such lien is not paid within three months, the city council may authorize foreclosure of the lien, and the owner of the property shall be responsible for the payment of all costs and fees, including attorney's fees of the city, in the foreclosure action. Such lien may be satisfied at any time prior to the authorization of foreclosure by payment thereof including accrued interest. After the authorization of foreclosure, the lien may be satisfied by the payment of the lien amount, the accrued interest, plus the amount of any costs and fees, including attorney's fees of the city, which have been incurred relating to the lien. 
(c)  If the subject property is secured by locks or otherwise, the city shall have the authority to enter such property for purposes of remedying the violative condition, and any additional costs incurred by the city in gaining access to the property or in resecuring the property after cleaning shall be considered expenses of remedying the condition. 
(Code 1994, § 38-134; Ord. No. 95-43, § 1, 11-30-1995) 
Sec. 24-170. - Administrative charge; administrative penalty. 
(a)  In addition to the actual cost of remedying the violation cited under section 24-162, the city may also assess a charge to cover administrative expenses incurred in securing and monitoring the services of a private contractor to remedy the violation. Such administrative charge shall be reviewed and approved by the city council at least on an annual basis. 
(b)  If a second violation of section 24-162 is cited against the same property and property owner within 12 months from the date of the first citation, an administrative penalty of $100.00 shall additionally be assessed five calendar days after the second citation. If the condition is abated by the owner during that five-day period, the penalty will not be assessed. If a third violation of section 24-162 is cited against the same property owner within 12 months from the date of the first citation, an administrative penalty of $200.00 shall additionally be assessed five calendar days after the third citation. If the condition is abated by the owner during that five-day period, the penalty will not be assessed. Subsequent violations cited against the same property and property owner shall be treated in the same manner as a third violation. 
(Code 1994, § 38-135; Ord. No. 95-43, § 1, 11-30-1995) 
Secs. 24-171-24-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TREE PRESERVATION 

Sec. 24-201. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Diameter breast height (DBH) means the diameter width, in inches, of a tree measured at four and one-half feet above the existing grade. 
    Dripline means the imaginary vertical line that extends downward from the outermost portion of the tree crown to the ground. 
    Hedge means a close planting of shrubs which forms a compact, dense, living barrier when mature. 
    Palm means a single unbranched trunk with leaves either like a fan or like a feather, and having a short, shallow, dense root system making them easy to transplant. 
    Park tree means trees, shrubs, and all other woody vegetation in public park areas having individual names, and all areas owned by the city, or to which the public has free access as a park. 
    Shrub means a self-supporting woody species of plant characterized by persistent stems and branches spring from the base. 
    Street tree means a tree, shrub, and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues, or rights-of-way within the city. 
    Tree means any living self-supporting woody plant which has a main trunk diameter of at least four inches measured 41/2 DBH. 
(Code 1994, § 51-1; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-202. - Responsibility of department of parks and recreation. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the department of parks and recreation to study, investigate, evaluate, and administer a plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, relocation, removal, replacement, and/or disposal of all trees, palms, shrubs, hedges and other vegetation located in parks, along streets and in other public areas. 
(Code 1994, § 51-2; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-203. - Other duties of department of parks and recreation. 
    The department of parks and recreation, when requested by the city manager or his designee, shall investigate, evaluate, report, and make recommendations upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of the department's duties and responsibilities. 
(Code 1994, § 51-3; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-204. - Tree advisory committee established; bylaws. 
    The city has created and established a city tree advisory committee, under the direction of the city department of parks and recreation. The city tree advisory committee shall follow bylaws adopted by the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 51-4; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-205. - Duties and responsibilities of tree advisory committee. 
    The mission of the tree advisory committee is to act as a citizen advisory board in coordination with the department of parks and recreation's landscape designer or his designee and other organizations dealing with the parks and recreation, conservation, and/or the environment and to plan and physically implement programs of tree planting and preservation, conservation and environmental awareness for all residents of the city and surrounding county. 
(Code 1994, § 51-5; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-206. - Trees to plant. 
    The following list constitutes official tree and palm species for planting in parks, along streets and in other public areas, within the city. No other species of tree and/or palm will be permitted without prior approval of the department of parks and recreation.
