Palm (Phoenix reclinata) Canary Island Date Palm (Phoenix canarensis) Cabbage/Sabal Palm (Sabal palmetto) Washingtonia Palm (Washingtonia robusta) Queen Palm (Syagrus romanzoffianum)  
(Code 1994, § 51-6; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-207. - Tree spacing. 
    The spacing of trees will be in accordance with the species size classes listed in section 24-206, and no tree may be planted closer together than the following: Small tree, 20 feet; medium tree, 30 feet; large tree, 50 feet, except in special plantings designed and/or approved by the department of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1994, § 51-7; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-208. - Palm spacing. 
    The spacing of palms will be in accordance with the species size classes listed in section 24-206, and no palm may be planted closer together than the following: Small palm, five feet; large palm, ten feet, except in special plantings designed and/or approved by the department of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1994, § 51-8; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-209. - Distance from curbs and sidewalks. 
    The distance a tree and/or a palm may be planted from curbs or curblines and sidewalks will be determined by the department of parks and recreation. Tree/palm selection, site evaluation, safety factors, and aesthetic value will be taken into consideration. 
(Code 1994, § 51-9; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-210. - Distance from street corners and fireplugs. 
    The distance a tree and/or a palm may be planted from street corners and fireplugs shall be a minimum distance of 30 feet. Tree/palm selection, site evaluation, safety factor, and aesthetic values will be determined by the department of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1994, § 51-10; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-211. - Utilities. 
    The distance of a tree and/or a palm planted from overhead utility wires will be in accordance with the species size classes listed in section 24-206, small trees and palms, directly under; medium trees, 20 feet; large trees and palms, 30 feet. 
(Code 1994, § 51-11; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-212. - Other utilities. 
    The department of parks and recreation shall have the right to plant, prune, alter, maintain, relocate, remove any tree, palm, shrub, hedge and other vegetation, within the streets, parks, and other public areas, as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry, value and beauty of such public lands. The department of parks and recreation may remove or cause or order to removed, any tree, palm, shrub, hedge and other vegetation, or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to public utilities or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. 
(Code 1994, § 51-12; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-213. - Public tree care. 
    The department of parks and recreation shall have the right to plant, prune, alter, maintain, relocate, remove any tree, palm, shrub, hedge and other vegetation, within the streets, parks and other public areas, as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry, value and beauty of such public lands. The department of parks and recreation may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree, palm, shrub, hedge and other vegetation, or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature injurious to public utilities or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. 
(Code 1994, § 51-13; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-214. - Tree topping. 
    It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, service, company, firm, or city department to top, head-out, hatrack, and/or stub any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public areas. Tree severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted as determined by the department of parks and recreation. Pollarding can be an accepted method of pruning, under unusual circumstances. This method will be required to be performed on such tree once a year, for the lifetime of the tree. 
(Code 1994, § 51-14; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-215. - Pruning; corner clearance. 
    Every owner of any tree, palm, shrub, hedge, and other vegetation, overhanging any street within the city, shall be aware that the department of parks and recreation shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any streetlamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the sidewalk. The department of parks and recreation shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The department of parks and recreation shall have the right to prune any tree, palm, shrub, hedge, and other vegetation, on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or signage. 
(Code 1994, § 51-15; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-216. - Dead or diseased trees and/or palms on private property. 
    It shall be a violation of this Code for any owner of real property to allow to be maintained any dead or diseased tree and/or palm on private property within the city, when such tree and/or palm constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees and/or palms within the city. 
(Code 1994, § 51-16; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002; Ord. No. 2004-87, § I, 8-26-2004) 
Sec. 24-217. - Removal of stumps. 
    All stumps of streets, parks, and other public areas shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. The department of parks and recreation is not required to fill and/or replace ground-out area with topsoil and/or sod. The department of parks and recreation will be responsible for the removal of the sawdust and chips left by the stump grinding. 
(Code 1994, § 51-17; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-218. - Replacement trees. 
    The department of parks and recreation shall replace trees removed up to a two-for-one ratio. Species selection, installation, and maintenance shall be the responsibility of the department of parks and recreation. If sufficient room is not available onsite, the trees may be donated to the property owner. An information and maintenance guide will be given to the property owner at the time of planting or donating. 
(Code 1994, § 51-18; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-219. - When replacement not required. 
    Palms, shrubs, hedges and other vegetation are not required for replacement or donating. 
(Code 1994, § 51-19; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-220. - Tree service. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, service, company, firm or city department to engage in the business or occupation of pruning, treating, or removing street, park, and/or other public area trees/palms, within the city without prior approval by the department of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1994, § 51-20; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-221. - Tree protection. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, property owner, contractor, company, and/or firm to engage in the business or occupation of construction without the protection of tree barriers surrounding existing tree/palm, located in parks, along streets and in other public areas. Construction shall include but not be limited to, land clearing/grubbing, earthwork, building of homes, garages, driveways, and/or other permanent improvements. The department of parks and recreation shall inspect and/or approve the tree barriers prior to commencement of work. Each tree barrier shall be in accordance with the city's land development code, section 8.3.2. 
(Code 1994, § 51-21; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-222. - Tree removal and replacement not required under certain circumstances. 
    The department of parks and recreation will not be required to remove, relocate, and/or replace any tree, palm, shrub, hedge and other vegetation, if a proposed walkway or driveway is to be installed by a property owner, business, and/or contractor. 
(Code 1994, § 51-22; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-223. - Unnatural objects found in tree and/or palm. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, company, or city department to inflict damage to a tree and/or palm by the installation of permanent and/or temporary methods, which shall include but not be limited to, nails, screws, wires, ropes, brackets, birdhouses, swings, and signage. 
(Code 1994, § 51-23; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-224. - Prohibited plant list. 
    The following list of trees are restricted as replacement stock and shall be removed from all streets, parks and other public areas: 
Common Name (Botanical Name) Common Name (Botanical Name) Australian Pine (Casuarina spp.) Punk Tree (Malaleuca quinguenervia) Ear Tree (Enterolobium cyclocarpum) Chinaberry (Melia azedarach) Eucalyptus Tree (Eucalyptus spp.) Chinese Tallow (Sapium sebiferum) Silk Oak (Grevillea robusta) Weeping Fig (Ficus spp.) Brazillian Pepper Tree (Schinus terebinthifolius)  
(Code 1994, § 51-24; Ord. No. 97-38, § 1, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-225. - Violation. 
    The department of parks and recreation shall issue a "stop work order" to any person, service, company, firm, or city department found in the act of cutting down, destroying, damaging or removing any tree and/or palm, without prior approval. 
(Code 1994, § 51-25; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Sec. 24-226. - Enforcement. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to enforcement as permitted under section 1-15 and/or chapter 2, article VI. 
(Code 1994, § 51-26; Ord. No. 01-51, § 1, 1-10-2002) 
Secs. 24-227-24-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - POLLUTANT DISCHARGE ELIMINATION 

Sec. 24-261. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized enforcement agency means employees or designees of the city manager of the municipal agency designated to enforce this article. 
    Best management practices (BMPs) means schedules of activities, prohibitions of practices, general good housekeeping practices, pollution prevention and educational practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices to prevent or reduce the discharge of pollutants directly or indirectly to stormwater, receiving waters, or stormwater conveyance systems. BMPs also include treatment practices, operating procedures, and practices to control site runoff, spillage or leaks, sludge or water disposal, or drainage from raw materials storage. 
    City means the City of St. Cloud. 
    Clean Water Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 USC 1251 et seq.), and any subsequent amendments thereto. 
    Construction activity means activities subject to NPDES construction permits. Permits will be required for construction projects resulting in land disturbance of one acre or more. Such activities include but are not limited to clearing and grubbing, grading, excavating, and demolition. 
    Hazardous materials means any material, including any substance, waste, or combination thereof, which because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics may cause, or significantly contribute to, a substantial present or potential hazard to human health, safety, property, or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed. 
    Illegal discharge means any direct or indirect nonstormwater discharge to the storm drain system, except as exempted in section 24-263. 
    Illicit connections means: 
(1)  Any drain or conveyance, whether on the surface or subsurface, which allows an illegal discharge to enter the storm drain system, including but not limited to any conveyances which allow any nonstormwater discharge including sewage, process wastewater, and wash water to enter the storm drain system and any connections to the storm drain system from indoor drains and sinks, regardless of whether said drain or connection had been previously allowed, permitted, or approved by an authorized enforcement agency. 
(2)  Any drain or conveyance connected from a commercial or industrial land use to the storm drain system which has not been documented in plans, maps, or equivalent records and approved by an authorized enforcement agency. 
    Industrial activity means activities subject to NPDES industrial permits as defined in 40 CFR 122.26 (b)(14). 
    National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) stormwater discharge permit means a permit issued by the EPA that authorizes the discharge of pollutants to waters of the United States, whether the permit is applicable on an individual, group, or general areawide basis. 
    Nonstormwater discharge means any discharge to the storm drain system that is not composed entirely of stormwater. 
    Plan for compliance means a plan submitted to the city by a person who causes or permits a violation, which established specific corrective actions to be taken and dates by which each action shall be completed to abate or mitigate the impacts of the violation. 
    Person means any individual, association, organization, partnership, firm, corporation or other entity recognized by law and acting as either the owner or as the owner's agent. 
    Pollutant means anything which causes or contributes to pollution. Pollutants may include, but are not limited to, paints, varnishes, and solvents; oil and other automotive fluids; nonhazardous liquid and solid wastes and yard wastes; refuse, rubbish, garbage, litter, or other discarded or abandoned objects, and accumulations, so that the same may cause or contribute to pollution; floatables; pesticides, herbicides, and fertilizers; hazardous substances and wastes; sewage, fecal coliform and pathogens; dissolved and particulate metals; animal wastes; wastes and residues that result from constructing a building or structure; and noxious or offensive matter of any kind. 
    Premises means any building, lot, parcel of land, or portion of land whether improved or unimproved including adjacent sidewalks and parking strips. 
    Storm drainage system means publicly owned facilities by which stormwater is collected and/or conveyed, including but not limited to any roads with drainage systems, municipal streets, gutters, curbs, inlets, piped storm drains, pumping facilities, retention and detention basins, natural and humanmade or altered drainage channels, reservoirs, wetlands, and other drainage structures. 
    Stormwater means any surface flow, runoff, and drainage consisting entirely of water from any form of natural precipitation, and resulting from such precipitation. 
    Wastewater means any water or other liquid, other than uncontaminated stormwater, discharged from a facility. 
(Code 1994, § 38-150; Ord. No. 2007-50, § II(38-150), 6-14-2007) 
Sec. 24-262. - Prohibition of water pollution. 
(a)  A person shall not discharge, or cause to flow from a storage system or other container, any pollutant into the stormwater drainage system except in concentrations or quantities explicitly authorized by an approved NPDES discharge permit or by a plan for compliance, or that are consistent with the utilization of approved BMPs. 
(b)  A person shall not connect any apparatus discharging any pollutant, in any quantity, to any part of the stormwater drainage system except as explicitly authorized by an approved NPDES permit or by a plan for compliance, or as results from approved BMPs. 
(c)  A person shall not improperly store, handle, or apply any pollutant in a manner that will cause its exposure to rainfall or runoff and discharge as point pollution or nonpoint source pollution into the stormwater drainage system except in concentrations and quantities authorized by and approved NPDES discharge permit or by a plan for compliance, or as results from approved BMPs. 
(Code 1994, § 38-151; Ord. No. 2007-50, § II(38-151), 6-14-2007) 
Sec. 24-263. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The following discharges are exempt from discharge prohibitions established by this article: water line flushing or other potable water sources, landscape irrigation or lawn watering, diverted stream flows, rising groundwater, groundwater infiltration to storm drains, uncontaminated pumped groundwater, foundation or footing drains (not including active groundwater dewatering systems), crawl space pumps, air conditioning condensation, springs, noncommercial washing of vehicles, natural riparian habitat or wetland flows, swimming pools (if dechlorinated, typically less than one PPM chlorine), firefighting activities, and any other water source not containing pollutants, and discharges specified in writing by the authorized enforcement agency as being necessary to protect public health and safety. 
(b)  Dye testing is an allowable discharge, but requires a verbal notification to the authorized enforcement agency prior to the time of the test. 
(Code 1994, § 38-152; Ord. No. 2007-50, § II(38-152), 6-14-2007) 
Sec. 24-264. - Enforcement, penalties, and compliance. 
(a)  The city may enter a site at any time during normal business hours, and at other reasonable times, to inspect, investigate, or monitor activities. If the person in charge of the site does not consent to any entry by the city, the city manager or designee shall obtain an administrative search warrant from a court with jurisdiction by showing that reasonable administrative standards for inspecting the site have been met. 
(b)  If a discharge is observed which represents an immediate hazard to public health or safety, or aquatic life, the city manager or designee may enter any property or structure, except a dwelling, as necessary to prevent or stop the hazard. 
(c)  A person shall not hinder, prevent, or unreasonably refuse to permit any inspection, investigation, or monitoring. 
(d)  Upon finding a violation, the city manager or designee may issue a notice of violation, stop order, or corrective order to any person causing or permitting the violation. 
(e)  A person who has submitted a plan for compliance and any amendment to it shall be approved by the city manager or designee. If the violation involves a person engaged in agriculture, a plan for compliance shall be developed. 
(f)  A person who has submitted a plan for compliance that has been approved by the city manager or designee is not in violation as long as the person acts in accordance with the plan for compliance. 
(g)  Each day a violation continues is a separate offense. 
(h)  The city manager or designee may issue a stop work order to any person when performing activities authorized by a building permit. 
(i)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to enforcement as permitted under section 1-15 and/or section 2-261 et seq. 
(j)  In addition to any other remedy allowed by law, the city may seek injunction or other appropriate judicial relief to prevent or stop any violation. 
(Code 1994, § 38-153; Ord. No. 2007-50, § II(38-153), 6-14-2007) 
Sec. 24-265. - Liability for expenses caused by violation. 
(a)  In an immediate danger to the public safety, the city manager or designee shall notify the responsible party by the most expeditious means, and the party who was notified shall remove the illegal discharge or pollutant by the time stated in the notice. If it is not so removed, the city may remove, mitigate, and clean up the illegal discharge or pollutant. The cost of that removal, mitigation, and cleanup shall be paid to the city by the person who did not remove, mitigate, and clean up the illegal discharge or pollutant. 
(b)  If, after an inspection by the city, the city manager or designee finds that a pollutant discharge poses an immediate hazard to the public health or safety to the storm drainage system in the city, the city manager or designee shall take action necessary to abate the pollutant discharge, protect the public, and mitigate any damage that the pollutant discharge has caused to the storm drainage system. Any cost incurred in carrying out actions shall be paid by the person as specified in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1994, § 38-154; Ord. No. 2007-50, § II(38-154), 6-14-2007) 
Secs. 24-266-24-299. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - POND MAINTENANCE 

Sec. 24-300. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized enforcement agency means employees or designees of the city manager of the municipal agency designated to enforce this article. 
    Best management practices (BMPs) means schedules of activities, prohibitions of practices, general good housekeeping practices, pollution prevention and educational practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices to prevent or reduce the discharge of pollutants directly or indirectly to stormwater, receiving waters, or stormwater conveyance systems. 
    City means the City of St. Cloud. 
    City manager means the city manager or designee. 
    Clean Water Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. § 1251 et seq.), and any subsequent amendments thereto. 
    National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) Stormwater Discharge Permit means a permit issued by the EPA that authorizes the discharge of pollutants to waters of the United States, whether the permit is applicable on an individual, group, or general area-wide basis. 
    Plan for compliance means a plan submitted to the city by a person, who causes or permits a violation, which established specific corrective actions to be taken and dates by which each action shall be completed to date or mitigate the impacts of the violation. 
    Person means any individual, association, organization, partnership, firm, corporation or other entity recognized by law and acting as either the owner or as the owner's agent. 
    Premises means any pond, lot, parcel of land, or portion of land whether improved or unimproved including adjacent sidewalks and parking strips. 
    Storm drainage system means publicly-owned facilities by which stormwater is collected and/or conveyed, including, but not limited to, any roads with drainage systems, municipal streets, gutters, curbs, inlets, piped storm drains, pumping facilities, retention and detention basins, natural and human-made or altered drainage channels, reservoirs, wetlands, and other drainage structures. 
    Stormwater means any surface flow, runoff, and drainage consisting entirely of water from any form of natural precipitation, and resulting from such precipitation. 
(Ord. No. 2012-020, § 2, 5-10-2012) 
Sec. 24-301. - Pond maintenance. 
(a)  The minimum required maintenance of dry ponds shall be: 
(1)  Grass shall not be any higher than eight inches. 
(2)  The pond shall be dry 72 hours after the last rain event. 
(3)  The pipes coming into the pond and the outfall shall be free of obstruction and functioning as designed. 
(4)  There shall be no visible erosion of the maintenance berms or side slopes. 
(5)  All portions of the pond shall have a continuous groundcover to prevent erosion. 
(b)  The minimum required maintenance of wet ponds shall be: 
(1)  Grass shall not be any higher than eight inches. 
(2)  The pipes coming into the pond and the outfall shall be free of obstruction and functioning as designed. 
(3)  There shall be no visible erosion of the maintenance berms or side slopes. 
(4)  All portions of the pond's berms and side slope shall have a continuous groundcover to prevent erosion. 
(5)  At least 80 percent of the water surface shall remain free of weed or algae growth. 
(6)  Sedimentation in the ponds shall be cleaned out to maintain depth of normal pool. 
(Ord. No. 2012-020, § 2, 5-10-2012) 
Sec. 24-302. - Exemptions. 
    The following ponds are exempt from maintenance requirements established by this article: natural ponds, borrow pits, ponds that do not accept public stormwater, ponds that do not discharge into the storm drainage system, and ponds under construction which has not been placed into service by the South Florida Water Management District. 
(Ord. No. 2012-020, § 2, 5-10-2012) 
Sec. 24-303. - Enforcement and compliance. 
(a)  The city may enter a premise at any time during normal business hours, and at other reasonable times, to inspect or investigate. If the person in charge of the premise does not consent to any entry by the city, the city manager shall obtain an administrative search warrant from a court with jurisdiction by showing that reasonable administrative standards for inspecting the site have been met. 
(b)  If improper maintenance is observed which represents an immediate hazard to public health or safety, or aquatic life, the city manager may enter any premise as necessary to prevent or stop the hazard. 
(c)  A person shall not hinder, prevent, or unreasonably refuse to permit any inspection. 
(d)  Upon finding a violation, the city manager may issue a notice of violation to any person causing or permitting the violation. 
(e)  A person who has submitted a plan for compliance and any amendment to it shall be approved by the city manager. 
(f)  A person who has submitted a plan for compliance that has been approved by the city manager is not in violation as long as the person acts in accordance with the plan for compliance. 
(g)  In addition to any other remedy allowed by law, the city may seek injunction or other appropriate judicial relief to prevent or stop any violation. 
(Ord. No. 2012-020, § 2, 5-10-2012) 
Sec. 24-304. - Liability for expenses caused by violation. 
(a)  In an immediate danger to the public safety, the city manager shall notify the responsible party by the most expeditious means, and the party who was notified shall take corrective actions to properly maintain the pond(s) by the time stated in the notice. If the corrective actions are not completed, the city may remove, maintain, or cleanup the pond(s). The cost of that removal, maintenance, or cleanup shall be paid to the city by the person who did not remove, maintain, or cleanup the pond(s). 
(b)  If, after an inspection by the city, the city manager finds that the pond(s) poses an immediate hazard to the public health or safety, the city manager shall take action necessary to abate the hazard, protect the public, and mitigate any damage that the lack of maintenance has caused the private pond or storm drainage system. Any cost incurred in carrying out actions shall be paid by the person as specified in subsection (a). 
(Ord. No. 2012-020, § 2, 5-10-2012) 
Sec. 24-305. - Penalty. 
(a)  Civil penalties. 
(1)  Any user who is found to have violated an order of the city council or who willfully or negligently failed to comply with any provision of this article and the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued hereunder shall be fined for each offense. Each day on which a violation shall occur or continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. 
(2)  Any violations of this article of the City Code shall follow the following fine schedule: 
a.  First Offense - $250.00. 
b.  Second Offense - $500.00. 
(3)  In addition to the penalties provided herein, the city may recover reasonable attorneys' fees, court costs, court reporters' fees and other expenses of litigation by appropriate suit at law against the person found to have violated this article or the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued hereunder. Any person, customer or consumer in violation of any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage incurred by the city by reason of such violation. In addition to any penalty provided by law for the violation of any of the provisions of this article, the city may bring suit in the appropriate court to enjoin, restrain, or otherwise prevent the violation of any of the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Falsifying information. Any person who knowingly makes any false statement, representation or certification in any application, record, report, plan or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this article, or wastewater contribution permit, or who falsifies, tampers with or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this article shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or by imprisonment for not more than six months, or by both. 
(c)  Code enforcement board. Any user aggrieved pursuant to the terms of this section may appeal said action to the city code enforcement board, or its successor entity. Such appeals shall be taken within 30 days of the date of notification to the user of the penalty hereunder and shall be subject to a filling fee of $50.00 for the initiation of the appeal. Notice of the appeal shall be timely provided to the office of the public services administrator and shall specify the grounds on which the appeal is based. The code enforcement board shall consider the appeal at its next available hearing and determine whether a violation or violations have occurred as provided in this article. In the event that the code enforcement board determines that the violation or violations did occur, the board shall deny the appeal and uphold the determination of the penalty, whereupon, the user shall have 15 days to pay the penalty. If the code enforcement board determines that the violation or violations did not occur, then the board shall grant the appeal and the user shall be entitled to a return of the subject filing fee paid for this appeal. Alternatively or supplementary, compliance with this article may be enforced by the direct action of the city before the city code enforcement board as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2012-020, § 2, 5-10-2012) 
Chapter 26 - HUMAN RELATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:
