ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 40-1-40-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC SERVICE TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Public service tax, F.S. § 166.231 et seq. 

Sec. 40-31. - Levy of gas and electricity tax. 
(a)  Gas. There is levied by the city, within the corporate limits of the city, on every purchase of metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied petroleum gas or manufactured gas), within the corporate limits, a tax in the amount of ten percent of the payments received by the seller of such utility's services or commodity. Subject to the provisions of section 40-35, the tax shall in every case be paid by the purchaser for the use of the city to the seller of such gas at the time of paying the charge therefor. 
(b)  Electricity; city and outside-city charges. The monthly charge for electric service under the rate schedule which is on file in the city clerk's office is subject to the city tax for customers within the corporate limits or an equivalent charge for customers outside the corporate limits. The city tax and outside city charge shall not be applied to any cost of fuel not reflected in the base rate on October 1, 1973, in accordance with F.S. § 166.231(1)(b). 
(c)  Exemption. Purchases of such electricity or gas when purchased by an industrial consumer which uses the electricity or gas directly in industrial manufacturing, processing, compounding, or a production process, at a fixed location in the municipality, of items of tangible personal property for sale, may be, upon request of the purchaser, exempt from the levy of tax hereunder. 
(Code 1967, § 24-14; Code 1994, § 70-26; Ord. No. 91-N-1, § 1(24-14), 8-1-1991; Ord. No. 97-05, § I, 4-24-1997; Ord. No. 2003-34, § I, 6-12-2003) 
Sec. 40-32. - Payment by purchaser; delinquency. 
    It shall be the duty of every seller of electricity, and metered or bottled gas (natural liquefied petroleum or manufactured), to collect from the purchaser for the use of the city the tax levied by this article, at the time of collecting the selling price charged for each transaction and to report and pay over on or before the 15th day of each calendar month unto the city manager, all such taxes levied and collected during the preceding calendar month. However, if the total taxes levied and collected during the preceding calendar month is less than $10.00, and the total taxes levied and collected but not paid to the city is less than $10.00, the seller shall report and pay on or before the 15th day of each calendar month following such quarter ending in March, June, September and December all such taxes levied and collected since the last payment. It shall be unlawful for any seller to collect the price of sale of electricity, and metered or bottled gas (natural liquefied petroleum or manufactured), without at the same time collecting the tax levied by this article in respect to such sale unless such seller shall elect to assume and pay such tax without collecting the same from purchaser. Any seller failing to collect such tax at the time of collecting the price of any sale where the seller has not elected to assume and pay such tax shall be liable to the city for the amount of such tax in like manner as if the same had actually been paid to the seller, and the city council shall cause to be brought all suits, actions and to take all proceedings in the name of the city as may be necessary for the recovery of such tax; provided, however, that the seller shall not be liable for the payment of such tax upon uncollected charges. If any purchaser shall fail, neglect or refuse to pay to the seller the seller's charge and the tax hereby imposed and as hereby required on account of the sale for which such charge is made, or either, the seller shall have and is hereby vested with the right, power and authority to immediately discontinue further service to such purchaser until the tax and the seller's bill has been paid in full. 
(Code 1967, § 24-15; Code 1994, § 70-28; Ord. No. 91-N-1, § 1(24-16), 8-1-1991; Ord. No. 97-05, § II, 4-24-1997) 
Sec. 40-33. - Records of sales of electricity and gas. 
    Every seller of electricity, and metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied petroleum or manufactured) shall keep complete records showing all sales in the city of such commodities or service. The records shall show the price charged upon each sale, the date thereof and the date of payment thereof, and such records shall be kept open for inspection by the duly authorized agents of the city during business hours on all business days. The duly authorized agents of the city shall have the right, power and authority to make such transcripts thereof during such times as they may desire. 
(Code 1967, § 24-16; Code 1994, § 70-29; Ord. No. 91-N-1, § 1(24-17), 8-1-1991) 
Sec. 40-34. - Exemption of governmental units. 
    The United States of America, the state and the political subdivisions and agencies, boards, commissions and authorities thereof are hereby exempted from payment of the tax levied by this article. 
(Code 1967, § 24-17; Code 1994, § 70-31; Ord. No. 91-N-1, § 1(24-19), 8-1-1991) 
Sec. 40-35. - Computing tax, metered or bottled gas. 
    In all cases where the seller of metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied petroleum or manufactured), collects the price thereof at monthly periods, the tax hereby levied by section 40-31(a) may be computed on the aggregate amount of sales during each period, provided that the amount of tax to be collected shall be the nearest whole cent to the amount computed. 
(Code 1967, § 24-19; Code 1994, § 70-32; Ord. No. 91-N-1, § 1(24-20), 8-1-1991; Ord. No. 97-05, § III, 4-24-1997) 
Sec. 40-36. - Failure of purchaser to pay tax; penalty. 
    Any purchaser willfully violating or refusing to pay the tax imposed by this article, where the seller has not elected to assume any pay such tax, and any seller willfully violating the provisions of this article, or any officer, agent or employee of any provider/seller willfully violating the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished pursuant to section 1-15. 
(Code 1967, § 24-20; Code 1994, § 70-34; Ord. No. 91-N-1, § 1(24-22), 8-1-1991) 
Secs. 40-37-40-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - INSURANCE PREMIUM TAX 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY

DIVISION 2. - PROPERTY DAMAGE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Property damage insurance premium tax authorized, F.S. § 175.101. 

Sec. 40-81. - Tax levied; amount. 
    There is assessed, imposed and levied on every insurance company, corporation or other insurer now engaging in or carrying on, or which shall hereafter engage in or carry on the business of insuring against property loss or damage, as shown by the records of the insurance commissioner of the state, an excise or license tax in addition to any license tax or excise tax now levied by the city, which tax shall be in the maximum amount allowed by state law of the gross amount of receipts of premiums from policyholders on all premiums collected on fire and tornado insurance policies covering property within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 24-47; Code 1994, § 70-66) 
Sec. 40-82. - When tax due and payable. 
    The license or excise tax levied in this division shall be due and payable annually on March 1. 
(Code 1967, § 24-48; Code 1994, § 70-67)

Sec. 40-101. - Tax levied; amount. 
    There is hereby assessed, imposed and levied on every insurance company, corporation or other insurer now engaging in or carrying on, or which shall hereafter engage in or carry on the business of insuring with respect to casualty risks, as shown by the records of the insurance commissioner of the state, an excise or license tax in addition to any license tax or excise tax now levied by the city, which tax shall be in the maximum amount allowed by law of the gross amount of receipts of premiums from policyholders on all premiums collected on casualty insurance policies, covering property within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 24-59; Code 1994, § 70-81)

(Code 1967, § 24-60; Code 1994, § 70-82)

ARTICLE IV. - LOCAL BUSINESS TAX[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-22, § 1, adopted May 24, 2012, changed the title of Art. IV from "Occupational license tax" to "Local business tax". 
State Law reference- Occupational license tax authorized, F.S. ch. 205. 

Sec. 40-131. - Definitions. 
    The definitions of F.S. § 205.022 and as such section may be from time to time amended or renumbered are adopted and incorporated by reference. 
(Code 1994, § 70-106; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-106), 3-13-2008) 
Sec. 40-132. - Local business tax receipt required. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall engage in or manage any business, profession, occupation, trade, amusement or industry in the city without first making application and having procured a local business tax receipt from the city manager, or his designee, which local business tax receipt shall not be issued prior to receipt of the amount hereinafter provided. All local business tax receipts provided for herein shall be issued for and apply to only one business address or one physical location within the city. Whenever any business, occupation, profession or privilege shall fall into more than one of the classifications contained in the schedule set forth in this article, such occupation, business, profession, or privilege shall be required to comply with the local business tax receipt requirements and to pay only one local business tax fee, that being the greater of the tax imposed under, or pertaining to, each classification or privilege. 
(Code 1994, § 70-107; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2004-77, § 1, 7-8-2004; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-107), 3-13-2008) 
State Law reference- Authority for levy, F.S. § 205.043. 
Sec. 40-133. - Application for local business tax receipt. 
(a)  Persons or other entities applying for local business tax receipts shall apply on forms as prescribed by the city manager. The city manager or his designee shall require the application to disclose such relevant information as the applicant's full name, mailing and street address, federal employer's identification number or social security number, and the applicant's relationship to the business for which the tax receipt is sought. The physical location being approved for proper zoning classification must be an actual street address. State agency approvals are also required for some occupations. 
(b)  Any person or entity that knowingly makes a false statement in connection with any application for local business tax receipts shall be subject to prosecution as provided for in section 40-136. This shall be in addition to the provisions for suspension or revocation and code enforcement board judicial proceedings. 
(c)  Prior to the issuance of a home occupation local business tax receipt, an applicant shall be required to sign an affidavit stating compliance with all matters reflected in the definition of home occupation in the land development code. Any person or entity who knowingly takes actions contrary to the terms of such affidavit relating to the home occupation shall be deemed to have committed a code violation and shall be subject to prosecution as provided in section 40-136. This shall be in addition to the provisions for suspension or revocation and code enforcement board proceedings in chapter 2, article VI, or judicial proceedings. 
(d)  Applications for a local business tax receipt will expire 60 days from date received if applicant ceases process and does not pursue in good faith. Applications being held for a city administrative and/or zoning process are exempt from expiration. 
(Code 1994, § 70-108; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2004-77, § 1, 7-8-2004; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-108), 3-13-2008; Ord. No. 2012-22, § 1, 5-24-2012) 
Sec. 40-134. - Terms of local business tax receipt; transfer. 
(a)  No business tax receipt shall be issued for more than one year and all business tax receipts shall be sold by the city manager beginning July 1 of each year and shall be due and payable on or before September 30 of each year. Local business tax receipts shall expire on September 30 of each year. In the event that September 30 falls on a weekend or holiday, the tax shall be due and payable on or before the first working day following September 30. 
(b)  All local business tax receipts may be transferred to a new owner where there is a bona fide sale of the business upon payment of a transfer fee of ten percent of the annual local business tax as provided by state law, and the presentation of evidence of the sale and the original local business tax receipt. If the sale of the business involves a change of business name, or type of business, a new local business tax receipt shall be required. 
(c)  Upon written request and presentation of the original local business tax receipt and payment of the transfer fee of ten percent of the annual local business tax, any local business tax receipt may be transferred from one location to another properly zoned location in the city, as long as the name of the business or type of business remains the same. Written request of the transfer of any business must be made prior to business relocation. 
(d)  A new local business tax receipt shall be required whenever there is a change of business name or the type of business is changed, or the conditions of (b) and/or (c) of this section are not met. 
(Code 1994, § 70-109; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-109), 3-13-2008; Ord. No. 2012-22, § 1, 5-24-2012) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.043. 
Sec. 40-135. - Expiration, fractional local business tax receipts. 
    All local business tax receipts shall expire at midnight on September 30 of each year, except as otherwise provided by law. Any persons who were not liable for local business tax receipt during the first half of the local business tax year may be issued a local business tax receipt during the second half of the local business tax year beginning April 1 upon the payment of one-half the amount fixed as the price of such local business tax receipt and physical location being approved for proper zoning. 
(Code 1994, § 70-110; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-110), 3-13-2008) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.053. 
Sec. 40-136. - Failure to obtain required local business tax receipt; violations of article; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates the provisions of this article or otherwise fails to obtain a local business tax receipt as required by this article, shall be subject to prosecution in the manner provided by F.S. ch. 162 or F.S. § 166.0415 and, upon conviction, such person shall be subject to a fine, imprisonment, or both. 
(b)  Any person engaging in or managing any business, occupation, or profession without first obtaining a local business tax receipt, if required, is subject to a penalty of 25 percent of the local business tax determined to be due, in addition to any other penalty provided by law or this article. 
(c)  Any person who engages in any business, occupation, or profession covered by this chapter, who does not pay the required local business tax and who does not obtain the required local business tax receipt is subject to civil actions and penalties, including court costs, reasonable attorneys' fees, additional administrative costs incurred as a result of collection efforts, and a penalty of up to $250.00. 
(Code 1994, § 70-111; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-111), 3-13-2008) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.053. 
Sec. 40-137. - Issuance of local business tax receipt; manner, forms, public display. 
    The city manager or his designee shall fill out and validate each local business tax receipt before issuing the license to the person paying him the necessary amount therefor. The person obtaining the local business tax receipt for a commercial location shall keep the local business tax receipt displayed in a conspicuous and prominent location at the place of business open to the view of the public and subject to the inspection of all duly authorized officers of the city. The person obtaining the local business tax receipt for a home occupation shall keep the local business tax receipt available in the home or vehicle for inspection by all duly authorized officers of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 70-112; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-112), 3-13-2008) 
Sec. 40-138. - Delinquent local business tax receipt; penalty. 
    Whenever any local business tax provided by this article to be paid to the city is not paid by the due date of September 30, the tax is delinquent, and subject to a delinquency penalty of ten percent for the month of October, plus an additional five percent penalty for each subsequent month of delinquency until paid. The total delinquency penalty may not exceed 25 percent of the business tax. Any person who engages in any business, occupation, or profession covered by this chapter who does not pay the required local business tax within 150 days after the initial notice of tax due, and who does not obtain the required local business tax receipt is subject to civil actions and penalties, including court costs, reasonable attorneys' fees, additional administrative costs incurred as a result of collection efforts, and an additional delinquent penalty of up to $250.00. 
(Code 1994, § 70-113; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-113), 3-13-2008; Ord. No. 2012-22, § 1, 5-24-2012) 
Sec. 40-139. - Other licenses, taxes and regulations to be in addition to local business tax. 
    The provisions of this article are cumulative and in addition to all other state, county and city laws which require licenses or permits, or provide for the collection of taxes, license and permit fees, and other charges; and no local business tax receipt issued hereunder shall exempt the local business tax receipt from any other license, permit, fee or tax required by law, or compliance with all applicable ordinances, rules and laws. See chapter 12, article II, for regulations regarding peddlers and solicitors. 
(Code 1994, § 70-114; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-114), 3-13-2008) 
Sec. 40-140. - Employed professionals. 
    Professionals who are required to obtain a local business tax receipt under a regulatory statute, but are prohibited from engaging in a profession, business, or occupation unless under the direct supervision of another person having paid the local business tax to the city, shall not be required to obtain a separate individual local business tax receipt provided the professional is an employee of that supervisory professional. A professional who engages in the above-referenced activity as an independent contractor or agent of the supervisory professional is required to obtain a local business tax receipt. A department of business and professional regulation license shall not relieve the licensee from the payment of any local business tax imposed on any business. 
(Code 1994, § 70-115; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2004-77, § 1, 7-8-2004; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-115), 3-13-2008) 
Sec. 40-141. - Industrial, manufacturing uses with on-site sewage disposal system require additional approval. 
    Pursuant to F.S. § 381.0065, a local business tax receipt shall not be issued to the owner or tenant of a building located in an area zoned or used for industrial or manufacturing purposes, or its equivalent, when such building is served by an on-site sewage disposal system, without first obtaining written permission or approval from the appropriate state agency. 
(Code 1994, § 70-116; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-116), 3-13-2008) 
Sec. 40-142. - Exemptions-Generally. 
(a)  The exemptions provided for in F.S. ch. 205 which have been listed in this article are hereby adopted and incorporated in this article by reference, except and not including F.S. § 205.054. 
(b)  College and school students may, with the approval of their athletic association or authorization of their school, sell the pennants, badges, insignia and novelties of their school without being required to pay a local business tax. 
(Code 1994, § 70-117; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-117), 3-13-2008) 
State Law reference- Exemptions, F.S. § 205.063. 
Sec. 40-143. - Same-Motor vehicles. 
    Vehicles used by any person licensed under this article for the sale and delivery of tangible personal property at either wholesale or retail from his place of business on which a license is paid shall not be construed to be separate places of business, and no license may be levied on such vehicles or the operators thereof as salespersons or otherwise. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.063. 
Sec. 40-144. - Same-Farm, aquacultural, grove, horticultural, floricultural, tropical piscicultural, and tropical fish farm products. 
(a)  No local business tax receipt shall be required of any natural person for the privilege of engaging in the selling of farm, aquacultural, grove, horticultural, floricultural, tropical piscicultural, or tropical fish farm products, or products manufactured therefrom, except intoxicating liquors, wine, or beer, when such products were grown or produced by such natural person in the state. Such exemption shall not exempt farm and nursery products from any required licensing and/or inspections by the state. 
(b)  A wholesale farmers' produce market shall have the right to pay a tax of not more than $200.00 for a local business tax receipt that will entitle the market's stall tenants to engage in the selling of agricultural and horticultural products therein, in lieu of such local business tax receipts to so engage. Such exemption shall not exempt farm and nursery products from any required licensing and/or inspections by the state. 
(Code 1994, § 70-118; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-118), 3-13-2008) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.064. 
Sec. 40-145. - Same-Nonresident persons regulated by the state department of business and professional regulation. 
    If any person engaging in or managing a business, profession, or occupation regulated by the state department of business and professional regulation has paid an occupational license tax for the current year to the county or municipality in the state where the persons permanent business location or branch office is maintained, no other local governing authority may levy an occupational license tax, or any registration or regulatory fee equivalent to the occupational license tax, on the person for performing work or services on a temporary or transitory basis in another municipality or county. In no event shall any work or services performed in a place other than the count or municipality where the permanent business location or branch office is maintained be construed as creating a separate business location or branch office of that person for the purposes of this chapter. Any properly licensed contractor asserting an exemption under this section who is unlawfully required by the local governing authority to pay an business tax, or any registration or regulatory fee equivalent to the business tax, shall have standing to challenge the propriety of the local governments actions, and the prevailing party in such a challenge is entitled to recover a reasonable attorney's fee. 
(Ord. No. 2012-22, § 1, 5-24-2012) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.065. 
Sec. 40-146. - Same-Certain disabled persons, the aged, and widows with minor dependents. 
    F.S. § 205.162 exempts certain persons who are unable or incapable of doing manual labor from local business tax receipt requirements within their resident county. The provisions and requirements of this statute are adopted by reference as though set out herein. 
(Code 1994, § 70-119; Ord. No. 02-30, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-119), 3-13-2008) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.162. 
Sec. 40-147. - Same-Disabled veterans of any war or their unremarried spouses. 
    F.S. § 205.171 exempts certain honorably discharged veterans who at the time of his or her application for a local business tax receipt shall be disabled from performing manual labor. The provisions and requirements of this statute are adopted by reference as though set out herein. Proof of the right for the exemption shall be required. 
(Code 1994, § 70-120; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-120), 3-13-2008) 
Sec. 40-148. - Same-Practicing religious tenets. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to require a local business tax receipt for practicing the religious tenets of any church. 
(Code 1994, § 70-121; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-121), 3-13-2008) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.191. 
Sec. 40-149. - Charitable, etc., organizations; occasional sales, fund raising; exemption. 
    No local business tax receipt shall be required of any charitable, religious, fraternal, youth, civic, service, or other such organization when the organization makes occasional sales or engages in fund raising projects when the projects are performed exclusively by the members thereof and when the proceeds derived for the activities are used exclusively in the charitable, religious, fraternal, youth, civic, and service activities of the organization. 
(Code 1994, § 70-122; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-122), 3-13-2008) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.192. 
Sec. 40-150. - Mobile/manufactured home setup operations; local license prohibited; exception. 
    A duly licensed mobile/manufactured home dealer or a duly licensed mobile/manufactured home manufacturer, or an employee of such dealer or manufacturer, who performs setup operations as defined in F.S. § 320.822, need not be taxed to engage in such operations. However, such dealer or manufacturer shall be required to obtain a local business tax receipt for the permanent business location or branch office at the applicable tax rate for the business activity, which local business tax receipt shall not require for its issuance any conditions other than those required by F.S. ch. 320. 
(Code 1994, § 70-123; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-123), 3-13-2008) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.193. 
Sec. 40-151. - Prohibition of local business tax receipt without exhibition of state license or registration. 
(a)Any  person applying for or renewing a local business tax receipt to practice any profession or engage in or manage any business or occupation regulated by the department of business and professional regulation, the Florida Supreme Court, or any other state regulatory agency, including any board or commission thereof, must exhibit an active state certificate, registration, or license, or proof of a copy of the same, before such local receipt may be issued. Online renewals may provide for electronic certification by an applicant to meet this requirement. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to contracting regulated under F.S. 489.113, 489.117, 489.119, 489.131, 489.511, 489.513, 489.521, or 489.537. 
(Code 1994, § 70-124; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-124), 3-13-2008; Ord. No. 2012-22, § 1, 5-24-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-22, § 1, adopted May 24, 2012, changed the title of § 40-151 from "Proof of required state license or registration prerequisite to issuance of local business tax receipt" to "Prohibition of local business tax receipt without exhibition of state license or registration". This historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.194. 
Sec. 40-152. - Pharmacies and pharmacists. 
    No local business tax receipt shall be issued to operate a pharmacy unless the applicant shall first exhibit a current permit issued by the board of pharmacy; however, no local business tax receipt shall be required in order to practice the profession of pharmacy. 
(Code 1994, § 70-125; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-125), 3-13-2008) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.196. 
Sec. 40-153. - Assisted living facilities. 
    No local business tax receipt shall be issued for the operation of an assisted living facility pursuant to F.S. ch. 400, part II (F.S. § 400.401 et seq.) without first ascertaining that the applicant has been licensed by the agency for health care administration to operate such facility at the specified location or locations. The agency for health care administration shall furnish sufficient instructions for making the above-required determinations. 
(Code 1994, § 70-126; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-126), 3-13-2008) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.1965. 
Sec. 40-154. - Pest control. 
    Pest control applicators that do not maintain a business location in the city shall be exempt. For purposes of this section, a business location is defined as something permanent such as, by way of illustration and not limitation, an office or branch office, warehouse, storage facility or any other related facility which would be involved in the operation of the pest control business. The mere servicing of customers in the city does not constitute a business location. 
(Code 1994, § 70-127; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-127), 3-13-2008) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.1967. 
Sec. 40-155. - Health studios. 
    A local business tax receipt may not be issued or renewed for the operation of a health studio pursuant to F.S. §§ 501.012-501.019 or ballroom dance studio pursuant to F.S. § 501.143, unless such business exhibits a current license, registration, or letter of exemption from the state department of agriculture and consumer services. 
(Code 1994, § 70-129; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-129), 3-13-2008) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.1969. 
Sec. 40-156. - Sellers of travel. 
    A local business tax receipt may not be issued or renewed for engaging in the business as a seller of travel pursuant to F.S. ch. 559, part XI (F.S. § 559.926 et seq.) unless such business exhibits a current registration or letter of exemption from the department of agriculture and consumer services. 
(Code 1994, § 70-130; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-130), 3-13-2008) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.1971. 
Sec. 40-157. - Telemarketing. 
    A local business tax receipt may not be issued or renewed for the operation of a telemarketing business under F.S. §§ 501.604 and 501.608 unless such business exhibits a current license or registration from the department of agriculture and consumer services or a current affidavit of exemption. 
(Code 1994, § 70-131; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-131), 3-13-2008) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.1973. 
Sec. 40-158. - Auction houses, auctioneers. 
    Pursuant to F.S. ch. 468, part VI (F.S. § 468.381 et seq.), all auctioneers and auction houses are required to be licensed by the state and must present their state license before receiving a city local business tax receipt for their permanent business or branch location in the city. However, no city local business tax receipt or any other fee shall be charged for the practice of auctioning in addition to the local business tax receipt required by this article. 
(Code 1994, § 70-132; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-132), 3-13-2008) 
Sec. 40-159. - Insurance companies. 
    Each insurance company writing any class of insurance upon any person or property residing or located within the city shall be required to obtain a local business tax receipt. It is the intent hereof that it is insurance companies, in addition to agents or agencies, that are obligated to obtain an local business tax receipt and that the local business tax receipt will be required from those companies doing business within the city, regardless of whether a local office or agent is maintained. 
(Code 1994, § 70-133; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-133), 3-13-2008) 
Sec. 40-160. - Child-care program law. 
    A local business tax receipt shall not be issued for an adult or child care facility regulated under F.S. ch. 400 or F.S. ch. 402 without the city manager or his designee first ascertaining that the applicant has been licensed by the state department of children and family services to operate such facility at the specified location. 
(Code 1994, § 70-134; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-134), 3-13-2008) 
Sec. 40-161. - Lodging and eating establishments, membership campgrounds. 
    The city shall not issue a local business tax receipt to any business coming under the provisions of F.S. ch. 509 until a license has been procured for such business from the division of hotels and restaurants, state department of business and professional regulation. Mobile food stands not specifically listed shall be taxed at a fixed location as catering and must have a primary location licensed as catering or restaurant by the state. 
(Code 1994, § 70-135; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2004-77, § 1, 7-8-2004; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-135), 3-13-2008) 
Sec. 40-162. - Landlord, owner of rental property(ies). 
    Any person or entity owning property within the city limits of St. Cloud who rents or leases said property shall obtain a local business tax receipt. The local business tax fee will be assessed by property owner. 
(Code 1994, § 70-135A; Ord. No. 2004-77, § 1, 7-8-2004; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-135A), 3-13-2008; Ord. No. 2012-22, § 1, 5-24-2012; Ord. No. 2016-37 , § I, 6-9-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-22, § 1, adopted May 24, 2012, changed the title of § 40-162 from "Landlord, owner of rental property" to "Landlord, owner of rental property(ies)". This historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes.

    Local business tax receipts shall be paid to the city per annum, unless otherwise provided. Local business tax fees are as follows:

Sec. 40-164. - Local business tax for licensed contractors. 
    A contractor who is regulated by the department of business and professional regulation who has paid a local business tax for the current year to a county or other municipality in the State of Florida where his permanent business location or branch office is maintained shall not be required to obtain a local business tax receipt in the city. Such contractors must demonstrate compliance with the state requirements for contractors and be registered with the city (see section 12-1). Contractors with a permanent business location in the city must obtain, in addition to registration, a local business tax receipt at the rate shown in section 40-163. 
(Code 1994, § 70-137; Ord. No. 02-30, § 1, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 2004-77, § 1, 7-8-2004; Ord. No. 2008-29, § 1(70-138), 3-13-2008; Ord. No. 2012-22, § 1, 5-24-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-22, § 1, adopted May 24, 2012, changed the title of § 40-164 from "Occupational license, contractors" to "Local business tax for licensed contractors". This historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Secs. 40-165-40-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ADDITIONAL HOMESTEAD EXEMPTION 

Sec. 40-191. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide an additional homestead exemption, through the mileage rates levied by the city, to those elderly citizens of the county who demonstrate the need for same. 
(Code 1994, § 70-139; Ord. No. 02-40, § 1, 9-26-2002) 
Sec. 40-192. - Definitions. 
    All terms used in this article shall have those meanings as set forth in F.S. § 196.075, or as it may be amended from time to time. 
(Code 1994, § 70-140; Ord. No. 02-40, § 1, 9-26-2002) 
Sec. 40-193. - Applicability. 
    Any person, 65 years of age or older, who has legal or equitable title to real estate located within the municipal limits of the city; maintains his permanent residence thereon and such residence qualifies and receives homestead exemption pursuant to section 6(a), article VII, of the Florida Constitution; and has a household income which does not exceed $20,000.00, or such other amount as adjusted annually, shall be entitled to make application for an additional homestead exemption of $8,000.00. This additional homestead exemption, if granted, shall be applicable to the ad valorem tax mileage rates levied by the city. 
(Code 1994, § 70-141; Ord. No. 02-40, § 1, 9-26-2002) 
Sec. 40-194. - Annual procedural requirements. 
    Every person claiming the additional homestead exemption, pursuant to this article, must file an application with the county property appraiser, on or before March 1, of the year for which such exemption is claimed. Such application shall include a sworn statement of household income, for all members of the household, and shall be filed on the form prescribed by the state department of revenue. Supporting documentation, such as copies of federal income tax returns, wage and earnings statements, and/or such other documentation, which the property appraiser may find necessary to verify the income received by all members of a household, for the prior year, must be filed in accordance with the requirements of the property appraiser. 
(Code 1994, § 70-142; Ord. No. 02-40, § 1, 9-26-2002) 
Sec. 40-195. - Waiver of exemption. 
    Failure to file the application and sworn income statement by March 1, or failure to file the required supporting documentation in accordance with the requirements of the property appraiser in any given year, shall constitute a waiver of the additional homestead exemption privilege for that year. 
(Code 1994, § 70-143; Ord. No. 02-40, § 1, 9-26-2002) 
Sec. 40-196. - Commencement date. 
    This additional homestead exemption shall commence with the 2003 tax roll. As such, the property appraiser may accept applications with sworn income statements, and supporting documentation for the year 2003, beginning January 2, 2003. 
(Code 1994, § 70-144; Ord. No. 02-40, § 1, 9-26-2002) 
Sec. 40-197. - Annual adjustment. 
    The $20,000.00 income limitation, as stated in section 40-193, shall be adjusted annually in accordance with the formula set forth in F.S. § 196.075(3), or as it may be amended from time to time, and shall be applicable as of January 1 each year. 
(Code 1994, § 70-145; Ord. No. 02-40, § 1, 9-26-2002) 
Sec. 40-198. - Annual impact report. 
    On or before July 1 of each year that this article is in effect, the city manager, or a designee thereof, shall prepare and deliver, to the city council, a report, which communicates the impact this article has on the financial status of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 70-146; Ord. No. 02-40, § 1, 9-26-2002) 
Chapter 42 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- State traffic law generally, F.S. ch. 316; municipal regulation prohibited in matters covered by state traffic law, F.S. § 316.007; municipal traffic authority generally, F.S. § 316.008; establishment of local speed limits, F.S. § 316.189. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - Definitions. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this section, the following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in F.S. § 316.003, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means any narrow passage or thoroughfare, not meant as a substitute for a street or highway, but designated, intended or adapted to serve as a means of accommodation to a limited neighborhood, for chiefly local convenience. 
    Curb means the lateral boundaries of that portion of a street designed for the use of vehicles whether marked by curb stones or not so marked. 
    Parkway means the portion of a street between the curblines or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines not designated or intended for use of pedestrians, and that portion of Florida Avenue lying between the paved roadways of the street. 
(Code 1967, § 25-1; Code 1994, § 74-1) 
Sec. 42-2. - Powers and duties of city manager in regard to traffic safety. 
(a)  The city manager or, as he may direct, the police chief, except as otherwise directed by this chapter and except as otherwise directed from time to time by simple motion of the city council, shall have the power and is authorized to regulate the operation and parking of vehicles within the corporate limits of the city by the erection or placing of proper signs or markers indicating prohibited or limited parking, one-way streets, through or arterial streets, stop streets, U-turns, play streets, school zones, hospital zones, loading and unloading zones, quiet zones and other signs or markers indicating the place and manner of operating or parking vehicles within the corporate limits of the city; the city manager or his designee is hereby authorized to designate crosswalks, safety zones, bus stops and taxicab stands and to erect signs prohibiting the parking of vehicles other than buses and taxicabs in such stands; the city manager or his designee shall have the power and he is hereby authorized to designate truck routes and to regulate the parking of vehicles of various sizes and weights; the city manager or his designee shall further have the power and he is hereby authorized to cause all such necessary signs or markers to be erected or placed on any street or part of a street when he deems such action necessary. It shall also be the general duty of the city manager to determine the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic control devices. The city manager or his designee is further empowered and authorized to mark off traffic lanes on streets and parts of streets indicating and directing the flow of traffic, when in his judgment such action is necessary. The existence of such signs, signals or markers at any place within the corporate limits of the city shall be prima facie evidence that such signs or markers were erected or placed by and at his direction and in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Any person failing or refusing to comply with the directions indicated on any sign or marker erected or placed in accordance with the provisions of this section when so placed or erected shall be guilty of a violation of this Code and subject to the penalties set out in section 1-15. 
(c)  All such signs, signals or markers presently in place within the corporate limits of the city are hereby approved and confirmed. Hereafter when the city manager or police chief, as his designee, shall remove or relocate any such sign or shall exercise any of the powers designated herein, he shall, at the next regular meeting, report all matters to the city council. The council may, by simple motion, otherwise direct, but unless otherwise directed, the same shall stand confirmed and approved. 
(Code 1967, § 25-2; Code 1994, § 74-2) 
Sec. 42-3. - Through streets. 
    Any person driving or riding a vehicle in the city shall bring the vehicle to a full stop immediately before entering a street designated as a through street regardless of whether or not the street is marked with a stop sign or signal. The following streets or highways are hereby designated as through streets: 
Lakeshore Boulevard from city limits to city limits. 
Seventeenth Street from east city limits to Michigan Avenue, thence from Michigan Avenue to Indiana Avenue, thence from Indiana Avenue to Vermont Avenue, thence from Vermont Avenue west to Columbia Avenue. 
Tenth Street from east city limits to Pennsylvania Avenue thence from Massachusetts Avenue west to city limits. 
Thirteenth Street (St. Cloud Highway) from city limits to city limits. 
All paved avenues from Seventeenth Street to St. Cloud Highway, thence from St. Cloud Highway to Tenth Street, thence from Tenth Street to Lakeshore Boulevard. 
(Code 1967, § 25-30; Code 1994, § 74-3) 
Sec. 42-4. - Designated city street along lakefront. 
(a)  The East Lake Tohopekaliga lakefront from the ordinary high water mark thereof as a southern boundary to a line parallel to the high water mark and 1,000 feet northerly thereof as a northern boundary from the east city limits line and the northerly extension thereof to the west city limits line and the northerly extension thereof less that portion of the above-described strip known as the city boat basin and the city beach area is declared to be and it is designated as a city street. 
(b)  No bicycle, bus, moped, motorcycle, motor-driven cycle, pneumatic-tire vehicle, road tractor, school bus, semitrailer, trailer, truck or truck tractor as the same is defined under the Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law, F.S. § 316.003, shall be permitted to use the above-designated street, the same being reserved for other motor vehicles. 
(c)  Unless specifically authorized by the city manager or his designee, after review and recommendation by the development review committee for a nonprofit special event, all permitted motor vehicles using the above designated street shall strictly conform to the Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law, F.S. § 316.003, and subprovisions thereunder and specifically, but not limited to F.S. § 316.272, Exhaust System; Prevention of Noise and F.S. § 316.293, Motor Vehicle Noise. 
(Code 1994, § 66-7; Ord. No. 83-Y, §§ 1-3, 11-17-1983; Ord. No. 95-20, § 1, 3-9-1995) 
Sec. 42-5. - Obedience to signs regulating weight of vehicles, indicating school or hospital zone, etc., or otherwise regulating traffic. 
    No driver of a truck shall operate such motor vehicle on any street where signs have been placed prohibiting trucks over a certain weight to be operated thereon, unless the truck is not in excess of the weight permitted on such street. Where signs are placed indicating schools, school zones, hospitals and sanitariums, the drivers of vehicles shall proceed slowly and cautiously and with as little noise as possible; and, the drivers of vehicles shall obey all other signs regulating vehicle traffic in the city. 
(Code 1967, § 25-32; Code 1994, § 74-4) 
Sec. 42-6. - Signs at reserved parking spaces. 
    All parking spaces reserved by permission of the city shall be marked with a sign indicating such reservation. 
(Code 1967, § 25-39; Code 1994, § 74-5) 
Sec. 42-7. - Diversion of traffic; safety zones; loading zones. 
(a)  At all points where traffic is congested, the chief of police or any police officer on duty shall have authority to divert vehicular traffic temporarily until order has been restored. Also, at points where traffic is congested, the city manager and chief of police, with the approval of the council, shall establish safety zones for the convenience and safety of the public, opposite which no vehicle shall be parked. In each block in the business section where necessary they shall likewise establish certain limits, which shall be reserved for the purpose of loading and unloading merchandise from the respective places of business in the block. 
(b)  The city manager and chief of police, with the approval of the council, are authorized to designate a certain area sufficient for the width of at least one vehicle at the entrance of hotels, hospitals, theaters, and all public buildings, which area shall be kept open at all times for the movement and discharge of business going to and from such buildings. 
(Code 1967, § 25-40; Code 1994, § 74-6) 
Sec. 42-8. - Bicycles on sidewalks. 
    Except as provided herein, no person shall ride a bicycle on the sidewalks within the central business districts as defined in the land development code and other areas posted by the city. Employees of the city in the performance of their official public duties shall be permitted to operate a bicycle on any sidewalk within the city limits. 
(Code 1967, § 25-46; Code 1994, § 74-7; Ord. No. 2004-63, § 1, 6-10-2004) 
Sec. 42-9. - Parades, gatherings, etc. 
    Whenever the city council or the city manager gives a permit for any parade, public gathering or celebration, the city manager may order any street or portion of a street to be cleared of all vehicles during the parade, public gathering or celebration. 
(Code 1967, § 25-75; Code 1994, § 74-8) 
Sec. 42-10. - Combat automobile theft program. 
(a)  The Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law authorizes counties and municipalities to enact ordinances to establish "combat automobile theft" (CAT) programs whereby vehicle owners may enroll their vehicles giving advance written consent to law enforcement officers to stop their enrolled vehicles if they are being operated between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m., provided the CAT decal is properly displayed in the lower left corner of the vehicle's rear window. 
(b)  A "combat automobile theft" (CAT) program, as authorized under the Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law, is hereby established in the city. The program shall include: 
(1)  Consent forms to be executed by motor vehicle owners who enroll vehicles in the program. 
(2)  CAT program decals which conform to the specifications, colors and design of the uniform CAT decal established by the state department of law enforcement for use throughout the state. 
(3)  All other provisions of the "combat automobile theft" program as provided for in the Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law. 
(c)  Administration of the program shall be conducted by the police department. 
(Code 1994, § 74-9; Ord. No. 94-7, § 1, 3-10-1994) 
State Law reference- Authority for this section, F.S. § 316.008(6). 
Secs. 42-11-42-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SKATEBOARDING 

Sec. 42-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Central business district of the city means that area of the city defined and shown on the zoning map of the city of the land development code as central business district one (CBD-1) and central business district two (CBD-2) as the same may be amended from time to time. 
    Skateboard means a board made of wood, fiberglass or other material or combination of materials mounted on two axles, front and rear, with two wheels made of clay, polyurethane or other material or combination of materials attached to each axle. The term "skateboard" includes motorized skateboards propelled by a motor mounted on the skateboard. 
    Skateboarding means lying, sitting, squatting, kneeling or standing upon a skateboard and propelling oneself by any means which causes the skateboard to move, including but not limited to: jumping on a skateboard; being pulled or pushed while situated on a skateboard; pushing the ground or other surface with one foot while keeping one's other foot on the skateboard; riding a skateboard from one elevation to a lower elevation; or operation of a motor mounted on a skateboard. 
(Code 1967, § 16-120; Code 1994, § 74-31) 
Sec. 42-32. - Use regulated. 
(a)  Skateboarding is prohibited on all streets, sidewalks and alleys within the central business district of the city. 
(b)  Skateboarding is prohibited generally upon any roadway within the city, except when a person using a skateboard is crossing a roadway on a crosswalk not within the central business district; and when so crossing, such person shall be granted all rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians; and as otherwise prohibited by F.S. § 316.2065. 
(c)  Skateboarding is prohibited on all private property in the city, where posted. 
(Code 1967, § 16-121; Code 1994, § 74-32) 
Sec. 42-33. - Enforcement. 
    Enforcement of section 42-32 shall be as provided under F.S. ch. 162, including supplemental enforcement procedures as now or hereafter enacted by ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 16-122; Code 1994, § 74-33) 
Secs. 42-34-42-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing or parking prohibited in specified places, F.S. § 316.1945 et seq. 

Sec. 42-61. - Generally. 
(a)  Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer, parking enforcement specialist or official traffic control device, no person shall: 
(1)  Stop, stand or park a vehicle: 
a.  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
b.  On a sidewalk. 
c.  Within an intersection. 
d.  On a crosswalk. 
e.  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless the the state department of transportation indicates a different length by signs or markings. 
f.  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic. 
g.  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway. 
h.  On a bicycle path. 
i.  Outside of a parking space designated by roadway markings. 
j.  At any place where official traffic control devices and/or signs prohibit stopping. 
k.  In a public park, except in a designated parking area. 
l.  On the roadway or shoulder of a limited access facility, except as provided by regulation of the state department of transportation, or on the paved portion of a connecting ramp; except that a vehicle which is disabled or in a condition improper to be driven as a result of mechanical failure or crash may be parked on such shoulder for a period not to exceed six hours. This provision is not applicable to a person stopping a vehicle to render aid to an injured person or assistance to a disabled vehicle in obedience to the directions of a law enforcement officer or to a person stopping a vehicle in compliance with applicable traffic laws. 
m.  For the purpose of loading or unloading a passenger on the paved roadway or shoulder of a limited access facility or on the paved portion of any connecting ramp. This provision is not applicable to a person stopping a vehicle to render aid to an injured person or assistance to a disabled vehicle. 
(2)  Stand or park a vehicle in the public right-of-way, whether occupied or not, except momentarily to pick up or discharge a passenger: 
a.  In front of a public or private driveway. 
b.  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant. 
c.  Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection. 
d.  Within 30 feet upon the approach to any flashing signal, stop sign or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway. 
e.  Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within 75 feet of such entrance (when properly sign-posted). 
f.  On an exclusive bicycle lane. 
g.  At any place where official traffic control devices and/or signs prohibit standing. 
(3)  Park a vehicle whether occupied or not, except temporarily for the purpose of, and while actually engaged in, loading or unloading merchandise or passengers at any place where official signs prohibit parking. 
(4)  Park overtime in violation of signs with stated time limits for parking vehicle, occupied or unoccupied, remaining longer than time posted on signs. 
(b)  No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any such prohibited area or away from a curb such a distance as is unlawful. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to the driver or owner of any vehicle which is disabled while on the paved or main traveled portion of a street or highway in such manner and to such extent that it is impossible to avoid stopping and temporarily leaving the disabled vehicle in such position, or to passenger-carrying buses temporarily parked while loading or discharging passengers, where street or highway conditions render such parking off the paved portion of the highway hazardous or impractical. 
(Code 1994, § 74-51; Ord. No. 94-18, § I, 5-12-1994) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 316.1945. 
Sec. 42-62. - Parking spaces provided by governmental agencies or nongovernmental entities for certain disabled persons. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park a vehicle in any parking space designated with the international symbol of accessibility or the caption "Parking by Disabled Permit Only" or with both such symbol and caption, unless such vehicle displays a parking permit or license plate issued under F.S. §§ 316.1958, 320.084, 320.0842, 320.0843, 320.0845 or 320.0848, or displaying a special license plate or parking permit issued to a handicapped person by any other state, and such vehicle is transporting a person eligible for such license plate or parking permit. However, any person who is chauffeuring a disabled person shall be allowed, without need for an identification parking permit or special license plate, momentary parking in any such parking space for the purpose of loading or unloading a disabled person. No penalty shall be imposed upon the driver for such momentary parking. 
(b)  When a person is in violation of a parking space specially designed and marked for the exclusive use of physically disabled persons, the law enforcement officer or parking enforcement specialist shall: 
(1)  Have the vehicle in violation removed to any lawful parking space or facility or require the operator or other person in charge of the vehicle immediately to remove the unauthorized vehicle from the parking space. The cost of removal shall be the responsibility of the person in charge of the vehicle or registered owner and shall be at the owner's expense. 
(2)  Charge the operator or registered owner of the vehicle for violation of this article. 
(Code 1994, § 74-52; Ord. No. 94-18, § II, 5-12-1994) 
Sec. 42-63. - Additional parking regulations. 
(a)  Every vehicle stopped or parked upon a two-way roadway shall be so stopped or parked with the right-hand wheels parallel to and within 12 inches of the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway, unless designated by roadway markings and/or signs that permit angle parking. 
(b)  Every vehicle stopped or parked upon a one-way roadway shall be so stopped or parked parallel to the curb or edge of the roadway, in the direction of authorized traffic movement, with its right-hand wheels within 12 inches of the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway, or its left-hand wheels within 12 inches of the left-hand curb or edge of the roadway. 
(Code 1994, § 74-53; Ord. No. 94-18, § III, 5-12-1994) 
Sec. 42-64. - Notice of illegally parked vehicle. 
    Whenever any motor vehicle without driver is found parked, stopped or standing in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by ordinance of the city, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user and shall conspicuously affix to such a vehicle a traffic citation or notice in writing, on a form provided by the chief administrative officer of the police department, such notice in writing to be in duplicate form and approved by the county judge, for the driver to answer the charge against him within 48 hours, during the hours and at a place specified in the notice. 
(Code 1994, § 74-54; Ord. No. 94-18, § IV, 5-12-1994) 
Sec. 42-65. - Liability for payment of parking ticket violations. 
(a)  Any person issued a municipal parking ticket by a parking enforcement specialist or officer shall be deemed to be charged with a noncriminal violation and shall comply with the directions on the ticket. In the event that payment is not received or a response to the ticket is not made within the time period specified thereon, the county court or its traffic violations bureau shall notify the registered owner of the vehicle which was cited, by certified mail, of the ticket. Upon receipt of the notification, the registered owner shall comply with the court's directive. 
(b)  Any person who fails to satisfy the court's directive and any person who elects to appear before a designated official to present evidence shall be deemed to have waived his right to the civil penalty provisions of the ticket. The official, after a hearing, shall make a determination as to whether a parking violation has been committed and may impose a fine not to exceed $250.00 plus court costs. 
(Code 1994, § 74-55; Ord. No. 94-18, § V, 5-12-1994) 
Sec. 42-66. - Presumption regarding illegal parking, operating, stopping, etc. 
(a)  In any prosecution charging a violation of any ordinance governing the stopping, standing, parking or operating of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked or operated in violation of any such ordinance or emulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of such parking or operating the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who stopped, stood, parked or operated such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. 
(b)  The foregoing stated presumption shall apply only when the procedure as prescribed in this article has been followed. 
(Code 1994, § 74-56; Ord. No. 94-18, § VI, 5-12-1994) 
Sec. 42-67. - Disposition of penalties; suspension. 
(a)  All penalties collected upon a finding of violation of ordinance shall be paid into the municipal treasury and deposited in the general fund. 
(b)  The county court magistrates are hereby authorized to suspend the payment of any costs or penalty and to remit any costs and penalties for any violation of any provision of this article. The alleged offenders may request hearings before payment of penalties. 
(Code 1994, § 74-57; Ord. No. 94-18, § VII, 5-12-1994) 
Sec. 42-68. - Authority to impound vehicles. 
(a)  Members of the police department are hereby authorized to remove a vehicle from a street to the nearest garage or other place of safety, or to a garage designated or maintained by the police department or by this municipality, under the circumstances hereinafter enumerated: 
(1)  When a vehicle upon a street is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic, or the persons in charge of the vehicle are by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody and removal. 
(2)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street and is so parked illegally as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic. 
(3)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street continuously for more than 24 hours and is abandoned, derelict, inoperable, stripped or wrecked as defined in section 24-51. 
(4)  When removal is necessary in the interest of public safety because of fire, flood, storm or other emergency reason. 
(5)  Parking violations for handicapped/disabled spaces. 
(b)  No vehicle impounded in an authorized garage as herein provided shall be released therefrom until the charges for towing such vehicle into the garage and storage charges have been paid. 
(Code 1994, § 74-58; Ord. No. 94-18, § VIII, 5-12-1994; Ord. No. 2003-75, § III, 12-11-2003) 
Sec. 42-69. - Penalty for violation. 
(a)  The penalty amounts for violations of this article shall be on file in the city clerk's office. 
(b)  The penalty for failure to timely pay the fees described in subsection (a) of this section or request a hearing within ten days of the date of violation shall be an additional late fee to be paid at the time the above-referenced amount is paid. 
(Code 1994, § 74-59; Ord. No. 94-18, §§ IX, XIII, 5-12-1994) 
Sec. 42-70. - Amendments. 
    Section 42-69, which references the penalty amounts for violations, may be amended from time to time by resolution, and such amounts shall be kept on file in the city clerk's office; however, sections 42-61 through 42-68 inclusive may be amended from time to time by ordinance. 
(Code 1994, § 74-60; Ord. No. 94-18, § X, 5-12-1994) 
Secs. 42-71-42-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - GOLF CARTS 

Sec. 42-80. - Use of golf carts upon designated streets. 
    It shall be lawful for a person holding and in possession of a valid driver's license to operate a golf cart, as defined by F.S. § 320.01(22), upon certain designated streets within the boundaries of the city. No such golf cart shall be operated on any other portion of the right-of-way of city, county or state roads except the paved portion of the right-of-way of said street, and there shall be no operation of golf carts on sidewalks, parks or other portions of city lands, the Lakefront Trail and spurs or extensions thereof, rights-of-way or city streets except as specifically designated herein, and public golf courses and private lands allowing such use. All use of golf carts on designated city streets shall be in strict accordance with F.S. § 316.212 or any amendments thereto or any other provisions of Florida Statutes regulating the use of golf carts on public streets. All persons operating a golf cart on city streets must comply with all other applicable traffic laws regarding the operation of such a vehicle. Nothing herein shall relieve the operator of a golf cart from compliance with all laws and ordinances otherwise pertaining to the operation of a vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2015-25 , § 2, 9-24-2015) 
Sec. 42-81. - State and county roads not authorized. 
    Nothing herein shall be deemed to authorize the operation of a golf cart on a state or county road or right-of-way or to allow the crossing of a state or county road other than at such crossings and in such locations as shall be permitted and specified by the F.S. § 316.212 or by specific authorization from the state, or an administrative agency thereof, or by the county. 
(Ord. No. 2015-25 , § 2, 9-24-2015) 
Sec. 42-82. - Licensed use; revocable. 
(a)  The operation of a golf cart on designated city streets shall be deemed to be a licensed use of those streets and to be revocable upon the will of the city council in its legislative capacity based on its consideration of the health, safety and welfare of the public arising from such use. 
(b)  The issuance of a license or other permission for the operation of golf carts on city streets shall not limit or otherwise preclude the city council from the amendment of this article, revocation of this article, contracting or expanding the streets or roads on which golf carts can be operated, or the designation of crossing points for state and county roads. All persons operating golf carts on city streets under this license from the city shall do so on the condition that there shall be no claim for any monetary loss or other claim for the loss of allowed golf cart operation on such streets or any monetary claim therefore based on a claim for action in reliance on the provisions of this article. The city council retains the unlimited legal authority to revoke, amend or to otherwise legislate as to the operation of golf carts on city streets without liability of any kind arising from its legislative decisions. 
(Ord. No. 2015-25 , § 2, 9-24-2015) 
Sec. 42-83. - Waiver of claim. 
    Any person operating a golf cart enjoying a license hereunder for such purpose and all persons who are passengers in such golf cart shall be deemed to have waived any claim against the city for its legislative decision to allow the operation of such golf carts on designated city streets in compliance with this article, and this article is declared by the city commission to be a legislative act of the city pursuant to the authority granted by state statute. 
(Ord. No. 2015-25 , § 2, 9-24-2015) 
Sec. 42-84. - Parking. 
    Golf carts operated on designated city streets, when parked in public parking spaces, such golf carts shall be parked in a manner within such space side by side or in another fashion that allows either golf cart to leave the space when desired. It shall be the obligation of each golf cart operator to park the golf cart in a manner that will allow the use of the public parking space by another golf cart. This section shall be applicable to such areas as are specifically designated for vehicle parking use either on city streets or off the right-of-way of city streets, in parking lots owned and controlled by the city, or in such other areas as are designated by signage or ground marking for such usage, and on public lands specifically allowing such use. Identified handicapped parking spaces may be used by golf carts complying with the law for use of these spaces by vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 2015-25 , § 2, 9-24-2015) 
Sec. 42-85. - Driver's license. 
    All persons operating a golf cart on designated city streets shall, upon request of a law enforcement officer, be in possession of a valid driver's license; it shall be unlawful for a golf cart to be operated on designated city streets by any person who is not the owner of and in possession of a valid driver's license. No person may operate a golf cart on city streets who has a suspended driver's license or whose driver's license has been revoked. 
(Ord. No. 2015-25 , § 2, 9-24-2015) 
Sec. 42-86. - Registration of golf carts. 
    All golf carts operating on city streets, prior to such operation, shall be registered with the city on an annual basis by such persons and in such a manner as is administratively determined by the city manager. The registration process shall include the payment of an annual registration fee in the amount of $25.00. An inspection to verify road worthiness, and the presence of required equipment may be instituted by the city as a condition of registration and operation of a golf cart on city designated streets. Decals reflecting a valid registration must be visibly affixed to each registered golf cart on the back driver's side of said golf cart in a location that is easily visible to law enforcement personnel. Such registration and decal must be current at all times the golf cart is operated on city streets. No registration is required for golf carts which are not operated on city streets. 
(Ord. No. 2015-25 , § 2, 9-24-2015) 
Sec. 42-87. - Required equipment. 
    All golf carts operated on designated streets must be equipped with efficient brakes, reliable steering, a horn meeting the standards of F.S. § 316.271, safe tires, a rearview mirror, and red reflectorized warning devices in both the front and rear of such golf cart, at all times while the golf cart is operated on designated city streets. All golf carts operated between sunset and sunrise on designated city streets shall also be properly equipped with headlights, brake lights, turn signals and a windshield. The provisions of this article may be enforced by law enforcement officers and as to such matters not requiring action only by a law enforcement officer, by both city code enforcement officers and law enforcement officers. 
(Ord. No. 2015-25 , § 2, 9-24-2015) 
Sec. 42-88. - Designated streets. 
    The city streets within the borders delineated on the exhibits attached hereto and labeled "Golf Cart Boundary" are the designated city streets on which golf carts may be operated, and only in those designated areas. The crossings of state and county roads as depicted thereon shall be lawful for the operation of golf carts only when and if those crossings are approved by the appropriate state and county agencies having jurisdiction over that decision. It is unlawful for a golf cart to cross a state or county road at any other location. 
(Ord. No. 2015-25 , § 2, 9-24-2015) 
Editor's note- The above-referenced exhibits attached to the ordinance from which this section derived are on file at the offices of the city and available for viewing during regular business hours. 
Sec. 42-89. - Number of occupants, speed and required insurance. 
(a)  The number of occupants in any golf cart being operated on the designated streets of the city shall be restricted to the number of seats on the golf cart, not exceeding the number of persons for which the golf cart was designed and which is consistent with the number of seats provided by the golf cart manufacturer. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any occupant of a golf cart to stand at any time while the golf cart is in motion. 
(c)  All golf carts permitted to travel on designated city streets within the city shall have a maximum attainable speed of 30 miles per hour. 
(d)  It is unlawful for a person to drive a golf cart at such a slow speed as to impede or block the normal and reasonable movement of traffic, except when reduced speed is necessary for safe operation or in compliance with law. It is the duty of the operator of a golf cart to leave the paved surface of a designated street to allow other motor vehicles to proceed at the lawful speed on such street as an exception to this article and subparagraph (e) below. 
(e)  It is unlawful for a golf cart to be operated on city sidewalks, rights-of-way and other locations on which a motor vehicle cannot be operated, and as proscribed by state statute or city ordinance, except for compliance with subparagraph (d) above. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any golf cart to be operated on the designated streets of the city unless and until the owner(s) thereof has purchased liability insurance insuring against personal injury and damage to property relative to the operation of golf carts on said designated city streets. The said insurance must be in full force and effect at all times the golf cart is operated on designated city streets. Proof of insurance must be presented to the city upon registration and licensing of the golf cart to operate on designated city streets, and to a law enforcement officer or code enforcement officer upon request. 
(Ord. No. 2015-25 , § 2, 9-24-2015) 
Sec. 42-90. - Enforcement. 
    Violations of this article shall be enforced pursuant to the provisions of F.S. § 316.212(8) and city ordinances by a law enforcement officer or city code enforcement officer as such officer's legal authority and jurisdiction allows. Code enforcement officers shall have the right to enforce all matters having to do with golf cart required equipment, the streets upon which golf carts may be operated, the lawful parking of golf carts and all other matters not exclusively within the jurisdiction of and lawful authority of law enforcement officers. In addition, other avenues for the enforcement of violations of this article may be enforced by city code enforcement officers and the city code enforcement board or special magistrate as their jurisdiction and legal authority allows. 
(Ord. No. 2015-25 , § 2, 9-24-2015) 
Secs. 42-91-42-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TRESPASS, NONCONSENSUAL AND VEHICLE IMMOBILIZATION TOWING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-49 , § 2, adopted Sept. 15, 2016, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as Art. V, §§ 42-75-42-81. Inasmuch as there were already provisions so designated, at the discretion of the editor the new provisions were redesignated as Art. V, §§ 42-111-42-117. 

Sec. 42-111. - Scope. 
    No towing or immobilization service shall immobilize, tow, or otherwise transport a vehicle for compensation when the point of origin of the tow or transportation is within the municipal boundaries of the City of St. Cloud unless such towing or immobilization service complies with the requirements of F.S. chs. 713 and 715, and the applicable provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2016-49 , § 2, 9-15-2016) 
Sec. 42-112. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Authorized driver/agent means a person legally authorized to be in control of the vehicle or to act on behalf of the vehicle owner, including the registered owner or lessee, contract lessee, operator, lienholder, or person authorized by any of the foregoing to act on behalf of same. Such agency may be established by any valid or easily verified record form, including, but not limited to, electronic mail, electronic record, or facsimile transmission. 
    Connected in reference to a vehicle means that at least two of the vehicle's wheels are raised from the ground and the connection is in compliance with the requirements of F.S. § 316.222 (related to stop lamps and turn signals) and F.S. § 316.525 (requirements for vehicles hauling loads). 
    Drop means an instance where the vehicle owner or authorized driver/agent arrives at the scene prior to the complete installation of an immobilization device and the departure of the immobilization agent; it shall also mean an instance in which the vehicle owner or authorized driver/agent arrives at the scene after the vehicle has been connected to the towing or removal apparatus, but before the tow truck has left the premises or parking lot with the vehicle. 
    Duly authorized agent means a person designated by and acting on behalf of a real property owner per contractual agreement to request trespass towing. The duly authorized agent shall have no affiliation with the towing or immobilization service providing the trespass towing service. The real property owner shall only appoint duly authorized agents with a direct connection to the property (e.g., board member, employee of the property management company or home/condo owner's association, employee or lessee of the real property owner, or State of Florida licensed security agency contracted by the real property owner). 
    Gross vehicle weight means the weight of a vehicle as specified by the vehicle's manufacturer. 
    Immobilize, immobilizing, and immobilization means the use of a "boot" or other mechanism that causes a vehicle to be immobile or otherwise renders a vehicle immobile or inoperable. 
    Nonconsensual towing means the removal and storage of wrecked or disabled vehicles from an accident scene or the removal and storage of vehicles in the event the owner or operator is incapacitated, unavailable, leaves the procurement of wrecker service to the law enforcement officer at the scene, or otherwise does not consent to removal of the vehicle, excepting, however, all incidents of "trespass towing" as defined herein. 
    Property owner means that person who exercises dominion and control over a parcel of real property, including, but not limited to the legal title holder, lessee, a resident manager, a property manager, or other duly authorized agent who has legal authority to bind the owner. A person providing a towing or immobilization service may not be appointed as a duly authorized agent for a property owner. 
    Roam towing means trespass towing of vehicles by a towing or immobilization service without express written authorization from the property owner for each vehicle removed. 
    Storage site means all sites to which vehicles towed from within the City of St. Cloud will be stored.
