(c)  At any hearing held pursuant to this article, testimony taken must be under oath and recorded stenographically. The transcript so recorded will be made available to any member of the public or any party to the hearing upon payment of the usual charges therefor. 
(d)  After the city council has reviewed the evidence, it may issue an order to the user responsible for the discharge directing that, following a specified time period, the sewer service be discontinued unless adequate treatment facilities, devices or other related appurtenances shall have been installed on existing treatment facilities, devices or other related appurtenances and are properly operated. Further orders and directives as are necessary and appropriate may be issued. 
(e)  If any person discharges sewage, industrial wastes or other wastes into the city's wastewater disposal system contrary to the provisions of this article, federal or state pretreatment requirements or any order of the city, the city attorney may commence an action for appropriate legal and/or equitable relief in the circuit court of the county. 
(Code 1967, § 21-104; Code 1994, § 78-56) 
Secs. 44-67-44-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONNECTION FEES AND DEPOSITS 

Sec. 44-91. - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this division to provide for the recovery of costs from users of the city's wastewater disposal system for the implementation of the program established herein. The applicable charges or fees shall be set forth in the city's schedule of charges and fees; current rates as listed shall be reviewed and revised periodically. 
(Code 1967, § 21-51; Code 1994, § 78-66) 
Sec. 44-92. - Adoption of charges and fees. 
(a)  The city may adopt charges and fees which may include: 
(1)  Fees for reimbursement of costs of setting up and operating the city's pretreatment program. 
(2)  Fees for monitoring, inspections and surveillance procedures. 
(3)  Fees for reviewing accidental discharge procedures and construction. 
(4)  Fees for permit applications. 
(5)  Fees for filing appeals. 
(6)  Fees for consistent removal by the city of pollutants otherwise subject to federal pretreatment standards. 
(7)  Other fees as the city may deem necessary to carry out the requirements contained in this article. 
(b)  These fees relate solely to the matters covered by this article and are separate from all other fees chargeable by the city. 
(Code 1967, § 21-52; Code 1994, § 78-67) 
Sec. 44-93. - Costs for sanitary sewer service taps. 
(a)  Sewer service tap charges inside city limits. In the absence of an agreement where the city and a developer, after public hearing, have established tap fees for a particular development, minimum sewer service tap charges for property located in the city limits shall be as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time for each four-inch tap, or for each six-inch tap, or for each eight-inch tap. Any tap required to utilize a service lateral larger than eight inches shall be considered a sewerage extension, the provisions for which are set forth in division 7 of this article. These charges shall apply only to a tap requiring no more than 30 linear feet of four-inch, six-inch or eight-inch service lateral. Where more than 30 feet of such service lateral is required to reach the property to be served, the property owner shall pay, in addition to the charge set forth above, all costs, including labor and materials, of installation of all service lateral in excess of 30 linear feet. 
(b)  Sewer service tap charges outside city limits. No sewer service tap shall be made to property outside the city limits until the applicant has complied with division 7 of this article, and specifically with section 44-202(b)(2). In the absence of an agreement where the city and a developer, after public hearing, have established tap fees for a particular development, minimum sewer service tap charges for property located outside the city limits shall be the amount on file in the city clerk's office for each four-inch tap, or for each six-inch tap, or for each eight-inch tap. Any tap required to utilize a service lateral larger than eight inches shall be considered a sewerage extension, the provisions for which are set forth in section 44-203. These charges shall apply only to a tap requiring no more than 30 linear feet of four-inch or six-inch service lateral. Where more than 30 feet of such service lateral is required to reach the property to be served, the property owner shall pay, in addition to the charge set forth above, all costs, including labor and materials, of installation of all service lateral in excess of 30 linear feet. 
(c)  Property requiring extension. Where a sewerage extension is required to provide service to the property, the provisions of division 7 of this article shall govern. 
(d)  General provisions. 
(1)  A charge in the amount on file in the city clerk's office shall be paid by the property owner for plugging a discontinued service line. Where such discontinuance shall be the result of the condemnation, removal or burning of a building, notice shall be given to the building inspector of such fact. 
(2)  Sewer service taps will not be made on a trunk line that is subject to surcharging or head pressure. 
(3)  All service laterals located in a public right-of-way or within a city utility easement shall be and remain the property of the city and shall be maintained by the city. 
(4)  Any portion of a service lateral located upon privately owned property or any other property not owned by the city shall be maintained by and at the expense of the property owner. 
(Code 1967, § 21-57; Code 1994, § 78-68; Ord. No. 92-M-1, § 2(21-57), 9-10-1992) 
Sec. 44-94. - Residential, general service and high risk prepayments. 
(a)  A single-family residential sanitary sewer service prepayment as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time shall be paid to the city by the customer at or before commencement of sewer service to such customer, except as provided for in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  A single residential sewer service prepayment may not be required provided the following conditions are satisfied: 
(1)  The customer has a satisfactory credit rating per the credit screening vendor the city utilizes. 
(2)  Within the immediate 24 months preceding the commencement of service, the customer has two calendar years of satisfactory payment of a residential sewer service with the city. 
(3)  The customer provides a letter from a public utility provider for electric, water or sewer service that demonstrates a satisfactory payment history of a residential service with the utility provider within the immediate 24 months preceding the commencement of service. 
(c)  Prepayments for single family residential sewer service shall be applied to the customer's bill after two calendar years of satisfactory payment of the account. Prepayments not refunded within 24 months shall be paid interest on the original dollars annually (not compounded) at a rate specified during the budget process, but not more than six percent. All interest earned will be applied to the customer's bill at the time of termination or at the next billing period after two calendar years. 
(d)  A service other than single-family residential service prepayment equal to the base and consumption charges for one and one-half months' services for the history at that address, but not less than the amount on as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time, to the service address, as estimated by the sewer utility, shall be paid to the city by the customer at or before commencement of sewer service to such customer at any single-service address, and if any customer shall receive sewer service at more than one service address, a prepayment shall be required and paid for each such service address, except as provided for in subsection (e) of this section. The prepayment shall be retained by the city until the account is terminated. If their service shall be disconnected for nonpayment, the prepayment shall be applied to payment of the account after disconnection. 
(e)  For prepayments in excess of an amount as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time in place of a cash prepayment, the customer may, at the discretion of the city manager or his designee, provide the city with a letter of credit from a bank with a branch office located within the corporate limits of the city or a surety bond issued by a surety company with no less than an A-rating by the A.M. Best Rating Agency. The letter of credit or surety agreement must allow the city manager or his designee to execute the letter of credit or surety agreement in favor of the city for payment of the utility bill of the customer. 
(f)  Any customer may be charged an administrative high risk sewer service prepayment based on nonsatisfactory payment credit history resulting in a poor credit rating for the service address in question during the previous 24-month period. This amount will not exceed three times the regularly-calculated prepayment amount for the service address in question. If sufficient payment history is not available, the high risk prepayment shall be in the amount estimated by the city manager or his designee. 
(g)  Any customer having been granted two extensions of the due date for payment of a utility bill in any 12-month period shall be required to pay a payment arrangement fee per additional arrangement. The payment arrangement fee as adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time shall be billed to the customer. 
(Code 1967, § 21-56; Code 1994, § 78-69; Ord. No. 91-M, § 15, 3-21-1991; Ord. No. 96-24, § I, 10-10-1996; Ord. No. 2013-14, § I, 7-11-2013) 
Secs. 44-95-44-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - INSTALLMENT, SERVICE, FACILITY AND VOLUME CHARGES 

Sec. 44-111. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means the person who applies for a building permit. 
    Boardinghouse means an establishment with lodging for four or more persons, where meals are regularly prepared and served and where food is placed upon the table family style, without service or ordering of individual portions from a menu, and where there is compensation paid for the food, lodging or care. 
    City manager means the city manager or the city officials he may designate to carry out the administration of this division or any particular portion, as the context may require. 
    Dwelling means a building or portion thereof designed exclusively for residential occupancy, including one-family, two-family, and multifamily dwellings, but not including hotels, motels, boardinghouses, roominghouses, house trailers, whether such trailers be mobile or located in a stationary fashion as on blocks or other foundations, tents, houseboats, travel trailers or other forms of temporary or portable housing. 
    Dwelling, multifamily, means a building containing three or more dwelling units. 
    Dwelling, multiple, means three or more dwelling units intended to be rented and maintained under central ownership and management, cooperative apartments, condominiums, RV and mobile home parks and the like, with or without master utility connections. Multiple dwellings primarily available for less than one week rental shall be considered a tourist home, motel, motor hotel or hotel. 
    Dwelling, single-family, means a building containing only one dwelling unit. 
    Dwelling, two-family or duplex, means a building containing only two dwelling units. 
    Foster care facility means a structure, in which the owners or operators are subject to licensing or approval by the state department of health and rehabilitative services, live permanently, and provide full-time care and supervision in a family living environment to a maximum of three full-time clients who are unrelated to the owners or operators. 
    Foster group home means a structure, in which the owners or operators are subject to licensing and approval by the state department of health and rehabilitative services, and provide basic care and supervision in a family living environment for four or more clients who are unrelated to the owners or operators. 
    General service unit means a nonresidential unit, including but not limited to, a boardinghouse, foster care facility, foster group home, hotel, motel, motor hotel, motor lodge, tourist court, tourist cottages, nursing home, retail business, retirement center, roominghouse, service business, and an industrial entity. 
    Guest house or cottage means a detached accessory building located on the same premises of the main residential building, intended for intermittent or temporary occupancy by a nonpaying guest, and which has no cooking facilities and is not rented. The same shall be considered with the main residential building as if one structure. 
    Hotel, motel, motor hotel, motor lodge, tourist court. These terms are to be considered synonymous, and mean a building or a group of buildings in which sleeping accommodations are offered to the public and intended primarily for rental to transients with daily charge, as distinguished from multiple-family dwellings (apartments) and roominghouses or boardinghouses, where rentals are for periods of a week or longer and occupancy is generally by residents rather than transients. 
    Mobile home, manufactured housing mean a single-family dwelling unit designed for longterm occupancy, with plumbing and electrical connections provided for attachment to outside systems to be transported after fabrication on its own wheels, or on flatbed or other trailer, arriving at the site where it is to be occupied, complete and ready for occupancy, except for incidental unpacking and assembly operations, location on a foundation, and connection to utilities. 
    Modular home or modular unit means a residence suitable for yearround use that is substantially fabricated off the site where it is to be occupied; and which is designated for transportation (usually on a trailer) either as a whole unit or in major segments to a lot where it is assembled, connected to utilities and finished for authorized occupancy. Such home or unit shall be classified according to its dwelling use. 
    Month means the city utility billing period, normally 28 to 31 consecutive days, with no calendar year having more than 12. 
    Motel. See Hotel. 
    Nursing home means a community residential facility which provides food, shelter, diagnosis, treatment, individualized continuing evaluation, planning, 24-hour supervision and coordination and integration of health or rehabilitative services to help each client reach his maximum functioning capabilities. The capacity of such facility shall not be less than three clients. This definition shall include resthome and convalescent home. 
    Residential unit means each single-family dwelling, and each living accommodation within all two-family dwellings or duplexes, multiple dwellings, townhouses, and multifamily dwellings, including those of conventional construction, manufactured housing and mobile homes; and each living accommodation within a master water utility metered two-family dwellings or duplexes, multiple dwellings, mobile home or recreational vehicle park. 
    Retail business means a business which is primarily concerned with the sale or rental of tangible goods. 
    Retirement center means a facility, in the nature of multiple-family housing, with no provision for routine nursing and/or medical care. 
    Roominghouse means an establishment with lodging for four or more persons where there is compensation paid for lodging or care. 
    Service business means a business primarily concerned with providing professional or technical advice, aid or help, and includes trade schools. 
    Townhouse means a single-family dwelling constructed as a part of a series of dwellings, all of which are either attached to the adjacent dwellings by party walls or are located immediately adjacent thereto with no visible separation between walls or roofs. 
    Utilized residential unit or general service unit means a unit which is in use as a place of nominal human living, conduct of business or industry, temporary or longterm, and normally with utilities available. Electrical service to a unit for any portion of a month shall be prima facie evidence of the unit being utilized during that month; provided, any unit to which electrical service has been discontinued shall not be considered as utilized. A unit occupied by a tenant is a utilized unit. Current city accounts for a unit where the tenant is the named customer is prima facie evidence that the unit is occupied, i.e., utilized. 
(Code 1994, § 78-81; Ord. No. 91-M, § 2, 3-21-1991; Ord. No. 2013-14, § III, 7-11-2013) 
Sec. 44-112. - Rules of construction. 
    The provisions of this division shall be liberally construed so as to effectively carry out its purpose in the interest of the public health, safety and welfare. For the purposes of administration and enforcement of this division, unless otherwise stated in this division, the following rules of construction shall apply to the text of this division: 
(1)  In case of any difference of meaning or implication between the text of this article and any caption, illustration, summary, table, or illustrative table, the text shall control. 
(2)  The word "shall" is always mandatory and not discretionary; the word "may" is permissive. 
(3)  The phrase "used for" includes "arranged for," "designed for," "maintained for" or "occupied for." 
(4)  Unless the context clearly indicates the contrary, where a regulation involves two or more items, conditions, provisions, or events connected by the conjunction "and," "or" or "either ... or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows: 
a.  "And" indicates that all the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events shall apply. 
b.  "Or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events may apply singly or in any combination. 
c.  "Either ... or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events shall apply singly but not in combination. 
(5)  The words "include" or "includes" shall not limit a term to the specific example but is intended to extend its meaning to all other instances or circumstances of like kind or character. 
(Code 1994, § 78-82; Ord. No. 91-M, § 1, 3-21-1991) 
Sec. 44-113. - Sanitary sewer account-Name. 
    A sanitary sewer account shall be established in the name of the customer, who shall be the owner, or the owner's tenant, of any residential unit or general service unit for which the sanitary sewer impact fee has been paid or otherwise satisfied. There shall be a separate sanitary sewer account for each residential unit and for each general service unit; however, all residential units served by a water meter which serves more than one unit, i.e., served by a master water meter, shall constitute a single sanitary sewer account. Extraordinary physical service water meter connections for residential units, general service units or mixed units shall be governed by regulation as authorized in this article. 
(Code 1994, § 78-83; Ord. No. 91-M, § 3, 3-21-1991) 
Sec. 44-114. - Same-Instatement charge imposition. 
    All residential and all general (nonresidential) units are required to instate municipal sewer service when such service is available. As a primary method of funding the costs of establishing (instatement) or reestablishing (reinstatement) a sanitary sewer account for such sewer service, there is imposed a sanitary sewer account instatement charge upon each residential unit and upon each general service unit served with municipal sanitary sewer service. 
(Code 1994, § 78-84; Ord. No. 91-M, § 4, 3-21-1991) 
Sec. 44-115. - Same-Instatement charge amount. 
    The amount of the sanitary sewer account instatement charge is set as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time; provided, however: 
(1)  All residential or general service units with sanitary sewer service existing on April 1, 1991, shall be exempt from the initial sanitary sewer account instatement charge; and 
(2)  Each residential unit and general service unit for which a sanitary sewer impact fee is paid on and after April 1, 1991, shall be exempt from the initial sanitary sewer account instatement charge; but 
(3)  All subsequent instatements (or reinstatements) of a sanitary sewer account shall pay the full sanitary sewer account instatement charge. 
(Code 1994, § 78-85; Ord. No. 91-M, § 5, 3-21-1991) 
Sec. 44-116. - Monthly sanitary sewer charge imposed. 
    A charge for sanitary sewer service for residential and general service units is levied and established consisting of a monthly sanitary sewer facility charge and a monthly sanitary sewer volume charge. These facility and volume charges are as set forth in the rate schedules of sections 44-117 and 44-121. 
(Code 1994, § 78-86; Ord. No. 91-M, § 6, 3-21-1991) 
Sec. 44-117. - Sanitary sewer facility charge-Rate schedule. 
(a)  The sanitary sewer facility charge represents an availability fee for the sanitary sewer service. The minimum monthly sanitary sewer charge, even with no usage, shall be the monthly sanitary sewer facility charge. Additionally, the minimum monthly sanitary sewer facility charge for multifamily residential units served by a master water meter shall be the product of the number of residential units served by the master meter and the appropriate charge in the rate schedule for a three-quarter-inch or smaller water meter located inside or outside the municipal limits of the city as applicable. For all other residential and general service connections, the facility charge shall be as shown on the rate schedule and shall be the appropriate rate for the water meter size and property location, being inside or outside the municipal limits of the city. The rate schedule and any changes thereto shall be adopted by resolution of the city council and maintained on file in the city clerk's office. 
(b)  Staff shall bring forward any proposed rate adjustments to the city manager. Provided that the recommendation is consistent with rate provisions in effect per a resolution adopted in accordance with subsection (a) of this section. All proposed adjustments shall require that the city manager properly advertise and hold a separate public hearing at which time the recommendation shall be presented to city council for approval. 
(Code 1967, § 21-53; Code 1994, § 78-87; Ord. No. 91-M, § 7, 3-21-1991; Ord. No. 91-V, § 1, 5-23-1991; Ord. No. 2003-48, § II, 10-23-2003; Ord. No. 2008-68, § II(78-87), 1-8-2009; Ord. No. 2014-27, § II, 7-10-2014; Ord. No. 2016-57 , § II, 11-17-2016) 
Sec. 44-118. - Same-Customer other than owner. 
    For a residential unit or a general service unit where the customer is other than the owner, the customer's monthly statement (the utility bill) shall reflect the monthly sanitary sewer facility charge. 
(Code 1994, § 78-88; Ord. No. 91-M, § 8, 3-21-1991) 
Sec. 44-119. - Same-Vacant premises. 
    In the case of a vacant residential unit or a vacant general service unit the sanitary sewer facility charge as levied and established in section 44-116 shall be against the owner, and the owner's monthly statement (the utility bill) shall reflect such sanitary sewer facility charge. 
(Code 1994, § 78-89; Ord. No. 91-M, § 9, 3-21-1991) 
Sec. 44-120. - Same-Discontinuance. 
    The owner of any residential unit or any general service unit may make written application to terminate such unit's sanitary sewer account on a form to be supplied by the city manager where: 
(1)  Such unit is not being utilized; and 
(2)  All city accounts for such unit due by the owner are current; 
The unit's sanitary sewer account and the corresponding sanitary sewer service to the unit shall terminate. Thereafter, reinstatement of municipal sanitary sewer service shall require sanitary sewer account instatement and the associated charges in sections 44-114 and 44-115. 
(Code 1994, § 78-90; Ord. No. 91-M, § 10, 3-21-1991) 
Sec. 44-121. - Sanitary sewer volume charge. 
(a)  The sanitary sewer volume charge together with the sanitary sewer facility charge equals the monthly sanitary sewer charge in section 44-116. The sanitary sewer volume charge shall be the product of the metered number of 1,000-gallons of potable water used and the applicable rate for the consumption and property location, being inside or outside the municipal limits of the city. The rate schedule is on file in the city clerk's office and may be changed from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  Staff shall bring forward any proposed rate adjustments to the city manager. Provided that the recommendation is consistent with rate provisions in effect per a resolution adopted in accordance with subsection (a) of this section. All proposed adjustments shall require that the city manager properly advertise and hold a separate public hearing at which time the recommendation shall be presented to city council for approval. 
(Code 1967, § 21-54; Code 1994, § 78-92; Ord. No. 91-M, § 12, 3-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-48, § IV, 10-23-2003; Ord. No. 2008-68, § II(78-92), 1-8-2009; Ord. No. 2016-57 , § II, 11-17-2016) 
Sec. 44-122. - Collection and billing. 
    The monthly sanitary sewer charge imposed pursuant to section 44-116 shall be collected by the city and deposited in the sewer system revenue fund, and no monies in excess of 9.5 percent of the combined potable water, reclaimed water, and sanitary sewer system metered revenue shall be transferred out of the water and sewer enterprise funds as an administrative transfer. In no case shall an administrative transfer cause the net income for the fund to be negative. For the purpose of establishing the budget in any given year, metered revenue shall refer to the second prior year's metered revenue collected. The term, "administrative transfer" used within this section is defined as a nonreciprocal transfer of revenues, meaning there is not a cost of service associated with this transfer. This administrative transfer is further defined as a return on investments of the water and sewer utility to the city. This section shall not be construed to prevent or establish the transfer of funds for reasonable administrative costs and those required by bond or loan covenants. Each customer, i.e., each unit service address, shall be billed monthly for services rendered, and if not paid within 15 days from the date of billing, the potable water service for such unit service address may be discontinued until all delinquent charges for such potable water service have been paid in full. 
(Code 1967, § 21-54; Code 1994, § 78-92; Ord. No. 91-M, § 12, 3-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-48, § IV, 10-23-2003; Ord. No. 2008-68, § II(78-92), 1-8-2009) 
Sec. 44-123. - Enforcement, sanitary sewer service charges. 
    Any unpaid sanitary sewer monthly service charge shall become a lien against the property or premises served and shall be of equal status as an ad valorem tax lien against the property. In addition and supplemental thereto, compliance herewith shall be enforced by the code enforcement board as provided by law and relief on open account/account stated may be sought before a state court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1967, § 21-55; Code 1994, § 78-93; Ord. No. 91-M, § 13, 3-21-1991) 
State Law reference- Limitation on lien, F.S. § 180.135. 
Secs. 44-124-44-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - IMPACT FEES 

Sec. 44-141. - Imposition. 
    There is hereby imposed upon all impact-generating land development activity a sewer impact fee due prior to the city's placement of a water meter or sewer meter if so equipped. Payment shall be made in the form of cash, cashier's check, or certified check; however, other forms of payment shall be accepted provided they are accepted two weeks prior to the placement of a water meter or sewer meter if so equipped. The impact fee shall be determined in accordance with procedures set out in section 44-142. However, if the building permit is for less than the entire contemplated development, the fee shall be computed for the amount of development covered by the permit. In the case of an addition to a building presently connected to the potable water system, the impact fee shall be paid prior to the issuance of a building permit for the construction of such addition, as provided in section 44-142(a)(1)(d). The obligation for payment of impact fees shall run with the land, as shall the resulting privilege. 
(Code 1967, § 21-58; Code 1994, § 78-106; Ord. No. 91-H-2, § 21-58(a), 12-19-1991; Ord. No. 98-39, § I, 1-28-1999; Ord. No. 2006-150, § I(78-106), 11-9-2006) 
Sec. 44-142. - Determination of fee. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided herein, the sewer impact fee shall be determined by the following: 
(1)  Residential and general service. 
a.  As a condition to providing offsite improvements for the sewer system, all residential land developments serviced by a three-quarter-inch meter shall be charged the amount adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time, and on file in the city clerk's office per equivalent residential unit (ERU), wherein one ERU equals 265 gallons per day (GPD) of wastewater flow. A residential land development serviced by a three-quarter-inch meter shall be considered to be equal to one ERU. 
b.  As a condition to providing offsite improvements for the sewer system, all residential land developments served by a meter size larger than three-quarters inch, and all general service land developments shall be charged the amount adopted by resolution of the city council, and on file in the city clerk's office per equivalent residential unit (ERU), wherein one ERU equals 265 gallons per day (GPD) of wastewater flow. The method of calculating the number of ERUs shall be based upon the estimated water flow as calculated by a meter size equivalency factor. The equivalent meter concept relates the flow for those meters larger than three-quarters inch to that of the volume of flow for a three-quarters-inch meter. The three-quarters-inch water meter size is the size most frequently used by the residential customer. A factor relates the non-three-quarters-inch meter to the three-quarters-inch meter flow as used in the potable water rate as follows: 
Meter Size Equivalency Factor 3/4? 1.00 1? 1.67 1&half? 3.33 2? 5.33 3? 10.00 4? 16.67 6? 33.33 8? 50.00 10? 133.33 12? 186.67 14? 250.00 16? 304.67  
Meter Size Equivalency Factor = ERUs 
The applicant may submit a written request for consideration of an alternate ERU calculation. Any such request must be accompanied by a sanitary sewer use estimate signed and sealed by a professional engineer. This alternative ERU calculation is subject to approval by the city manager or his designee. 
c.  The minimum impact fee for all residential land developments serviced by a water meter size larger than three-quarters inch and all general service land developments shall be one ERU per each unit. 
d.  Additions to existing residential or general service building. There shall be no additional impact fee due when application is made for a building permit to construct any addition to a single-family residential building served by a three-quarter inch meter. When application is made for a building permit to construct any addition to a residential building serviced by a meter size larger than three-quarters inch, or any general service building, which will increase the demand for sewer service to the building or structure already connected to the city sanitary system, impact fees for such addition shall be paid prior to the issuance of a building permit for its construction, and sanitary sewer impact fees to be paid for such additions shall be calculated based on the total number of ERUs which are calculated by the formula in section (a)(1)b. of this section. 
(2)  Industrial users special provisions. Industrial users that are determined to be significant users, defined in section 44-31 and regulated by this article, may be required to pay additional impact fees as determined by the city manager. Such additional impact fees shall be designed to establish just and equitable fees or their equivalent and standards of service appropriate to the circumstances of the specific impact on the city sewerage system. 
(3)  Redevelopment or replacement. Where new development involves the redevelopment of land such that existing impact generating development is removed or substantially altered, the new development impact fees shall be computed on the additional or new impacts only. Impact fees shall be computed for the existing development and such sum shall then be subtracted from the impact fees calculated for the new development. The property shall receive an impact fee credit based on the number of equivalent residential units (ERU's). The ERU credit shall be equal to the greater of: 1) the number of (ERU's) assessed at time of original impact fee payment for the existing development, if available, or 2) the number of ERU's currently vested based upon the meter size in use or historically used at the property at any point the property was served by the city's sewer system. Prior use or credit information is subject to verification and approval by the city manager or his designee. It is the city's intent to collect impact fees for only that additional impact generated by redevelopment over and above the impact attributable to the existing development. 
(b)  Outside-the-city surcharge. In addition to the uniform sewer impact fees herein imposed, there is hereby imposed, on all outside-the-city off-site impact generating land development activity, a surcharge equal to 25 percent of such sewer impact fees, due, payable, and collectable in the same manner as that prescribed for the otherwise uniform sewer impact fees. 
(c)  Periodic review of sewer impact fee amounts. The city manager shall periodically review the fees adopted by resolution set forth in this section. The review period shall not exceed five years. 
(Code 1967, § 21-58; Code 1994, § 78-107; Ord. No. 91-H-2, § 21-58(b), 12-19-1991; Ord. No. 92-V(b), 3-26-1992; Ord. No. 2003-05, § 1, 2-13-2003; Ord. No. 2006-150, § II(78-107), 11-9-2006; Ord. No. 2010-052, § 1, 12-9-2010) 
Sec. 44-143. - Properties using septic tanks when city sanitary sewer service is available. 
    Any property utilizing a septic tank system for sanitary sewer disposal despite the availability of city sanitary sewer service to such property shall not be required to connect to the city sanitary sewer system until such time as its septic tank system shall malfunction and require repair. At that time, no permit shall be issued for the performance of such repairs, and such property shall connect to the city sanitary sewer system. 
(Code 1967, § 21-59; Code 1994, § 78-108; Ord. No. 91-H-2, § 21-59, 12-19-1991) 
Sec. 44-144. - Alternative impact fee calculation authorized for significant industrial users. 
    If an applicant believes that the cost of improvements needed to serve his industrial development is less than the fee established under this division, the applicant may submit an alternative fee calculation to the city manager pursuant to the provisions of section 44-145. If the city manager finds that the data, information, assumptions, formulae and methodology used by the applicant to calculate the alternative impact fee satisfy the subject requirements, the alternative impact fee shall be deemed the impact fee due and owing for the proposed development. 
(Code 1967, § 21-60; Code 1994, § 78-109; Ord. No. 91-H-2, § 21-60, 12-19-1991) 
Sec. 44-145. - Procedure for review of alternative impact fee calculation for significant industrial users. 
(a)  Alternate calculations. The alternative impact fee calculation shall be based on data, information, assumptions, formulae, and methodology contained in this division and the studies prepared by independent sources, provided that: 
(1)  The independent source is accepted standard source of engineering and planning data or information; 
(2)  The independent source is a local study carried out by a qualified planner or engineer pursuant to an accepted methodology of planning or engineering; or 
(3)  Where different data, information, assumptions, formulae, or methodology are employed, such differences shall be specifically identified and justified. 
(b)  Submission. An alternative impact fee calculation shall be undertaken through the submission of an application for review of an alternative impact fee calculation for the impact fee component for which an alternative impact fee calculation is requested. 
(c)  City manager determination. Within 20 days of receipt of an application for review of an alternative impact fee calculation, the city manager shall determine if the application is complete. If the city manager determines that the application is not complete, he shall send a written statement specifying the deficiencies by mail to the person submitting the application. The application shall be deemed complete if no deficiencies are specified. The city manager shall take no further action on the application until it is deemed complete. 
(d)  City manager review. When the city manager determines the application is complete, he shall review it and render a written decision in 30 days on whether the fee should be modified, and if so, what the amount should be. 
(e)  Adjustment by agreement. If the city manager finds that the data, information, assumptions, formulae and/or methodology used by the applicant to compute the alternative impact fee calculation satisfies the requirements of this division, the fee determined in the alternative impact fee calculation shall be deemed the fee due and owing for the proposed land development activity. This adjustment in the fee shall be set forth in a fee agreement which shall be entered into pursuant to section 44-146(b). 
(f)  Appeal. A determination by the city manager that the alternative impact fee calculation does not satisfy the requirements of this section may be appealed to the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 21-61; Code 1994, § 78-110; Ord. No. 91-H-2, § 21-61, 12-19-1991) 
Sec. 44-146. - Presumption, agreement and security requirements. 
(a)  Maximum sewer impact generated. The proposed development shall be presumed to generate the maximum impact generated by the development in accordance with the approved site plan and/or requested building permits. 
(b)  Special sewer impact fee agreement. In lieu of the payment of fees as calculated in section 44-142, any applicant may propose to enter into an impact agreement with the city designed to establish just and equitable fees or their equivalent and standards of service appropriate to the circumstances of the specific development proposed. Such an agreement shall include, but shall not be limited to, provisions which: 
(1)  Modify the presumption of maximum impact set forth in subsection (a) of this section, and provide an impact fee which may differ from that set forth in section 44-142, by specifying the nature of the proposed development for the purposes of computing actual impact, provided that the agreement shall establish legally enforceable means for ensuring that the impact will not exceed the impact generated by the agreed upon development. 
(2)  Permit the construction of specific improvements in lieu of, or with a credit against, the impact fees component developer to recover the actual cost of such improvements in excess of the amount, which would have been assessed under this division. 
(3)  Any agreement proposed by an applicant pursuant to this subsection (b) shall, with formal public hearing and after recommendation by the planning commission, be presented to and approved by the city council prior to the issuance of a building permit. Any such agreement may provide for execution by mortgagees, lienholders or contract purchasers in addition to the landowner, and may permit any party to record such agreement in the official records of the county. The city council shall approve such an agreement only if it finds that the agreement will apportion the burden of expenditure for new facilities in a just and equitable manner, consistent with the principal of rational nexus as set forth in state law. 
(c)  Homestead installment payments. For any property designated as a homestead under F.S. ch. 222, the city council may permit the sewer impact fee to be paid by installments in lieu of the fee payment requirements in section 44-142, as the particular circumstances shall dictate. Evidence of the debt due, reflecting the payment terms, together with evidence of a marketable lien encumbering the property served, shall be executed in recordable form and the evidence of lien together with a copy of the evidence of debt shall be filed in the public records of the county. 
(Code 1994, § 78-111; Ord. No. 91-H-2, § 21-62, 12-19-1991; Ord. No. 2003-05, § 2, 2-13-2003) 
Sec. 44-147. - Credits. 
(a)  Generally. An applicant shall be entitled to a credit against any sewer impact fee component assessed in an amount equal to the cost of off-site improvements contributed or previously contributed, paid for or committed to by the applicant or his predecessor in interest as a condition of any development permit required and/or issued by the city for the same development or for excess collection or transmission capacity constructed by the applicant or his predecessor in interest where such excess capacity is constructed at the request of the city and credit for same is agreed to by the city in advance of the creation of the excess capacity and provided for in an impact fee agreement. On-site facilities constructed for reclaimed wastewater distribution and disposal may be considered for a credit. The cost of such improvements shall be based on the following criteria: 
(1)  The actual cost, or estimated cost of the improvements based on recent bid information of the city; and 
(2)  Average cost determination, as set forth in the city sanitary sewer impact fee methodology. 
Improvements required by previous development permits shall not be given a credit unless they meet the requirements of this subsection. 
(b)  Credit nontransferable. Credit for contributions, payments, construction or dedications of any impact fee component shall not be transferable to another component. Credit shall be transferable only within the same component and within the same development. 
(c)  Credit application. The credit determination shall be made by the city manager upon application. The application shall include: 
(1)  A drawing of the contributed or to be contributed improvement prepared by an engineer registered by the state showing his seal. 
(2)  An appraisal of the contributed or to be contributed land fixing value of the land as of the date of issuance of earliest building permit, actual contribution or agreement to contribute, whichever is earliest. 
(3)  The actual cost, with appropriate documentation, or projected cost, with appropriate documentation, of any improvement contributed or to be constructed and contributed. 
(d)  Credit agreement. If the application for credit is approved by the city manager a credit agreement shall be prepared and signed by the applicant and the city. It shall specifically outline the contribution, payment, construction or land dedication, the time by which it shall be completed, dedicated, or paid, and any extensions thereof, and the dollar credit the applicant shall receive for the contribution, payment, construction or land. 
(e)  Appeal. A determination by the city manager as to an application for credit may be appealed to the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 78-112; Ord. No. 91-H-2, § 21-63, 12-19-1991) 
Sec. 44-148. - Impact fee revenue restrictions; return of unused funds. 
(a)  Sewer fund restricted account-impact fee. All sanitary sewer impact fees collected shall be held in a trust fund known as the sewer fund restricted account-impact fee. Funds may be appropriated from this trust fund only by the city council upon its determination that the proposed expenditure is for the expansion of the system, as below provided. Any improvement which directly or indirectly is associated with expansion may be determined by the city council, at their sole discretion, to be an expansion of the system, and nothing herein contained shall prohibit same. 
(b)  Identification of funds to meet deficiency. When the city council determines that the purpose of a proposed capital improvement, in whole or part, is to overcome a deficiency not attributable to new growth and development, the city manager shall identify sources of funds to meet such deficiency proportion of the improvement for city council approval prior to the utilization of any impact fees. 
(c)  Fund use, limitation. The collected impact fees shall be used solely for the purpose of acquisition, expansion and development of the capital assets, including debt service determined to be needed to serve new development, to include the principal and interest of loans or parts of loans. 
(d)  Refund. All funds derived from sewer impact fees shall be expended on a first-in, first-out basis. Any such funds, not expended within seven years of their collection date, upon the generating property's then owner's timely application, shall be refunded to such owner. To be timely an application shall be received by the city manager within eight years of the subject collection date. No fee refund shall be made without timely application, and any funds remaining more than eight years after collection shall be deemed abandoned. With his annual budget to the city council, the city manager shall make report as to abandoned sewer impact funds and recommend appropriation improving sanitary sewer service. 
(Code 1994, § 78-113; Code 1967, § 21-62; Ord. No. 91-H-2, § 21-64, 12-19-1991) 
Sec. 44-149. - Exemptions. 
    The following shall be exempted from the payment of impact fees to the extent there is no increase in impact associated with the property or use: 
(1)  Minor alterations. Alteration or minor expansions of an existing structure where the use, number of housing units, or number of fixture units in the case of nonresidential construction is not changed. 
(2)  Accessory building. The construction of an accessory building or structures. 
(3)  Replacement. A replacement of a building or structure with a new building or structure of the same use provided that no additional impact to the sanitary sewer system is created by such replacement. 
(4)  Public schools. Public school facilities as exempted by F.S. § 1013.371(1)(a). 
(Code 1994, § 78-114; Ord. No. 91-H-2, § 21-65, 12-19-1991) 
Secs. 44-150-44-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - USE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 44-171. - General discharge prohibitions. 
(a)  No user shall contribute or cause to be contributed directly or indirectly any pollutant or wastewater which will interfere with the operation or performance of the POTW. These general prohibitions apply to all such users of the POTW, whether or not the user is subject to national categorical pretreatment standards or any other national, state or local pretreatment standards or requirements. A user may not contribute the following substances to any POTW: 
(1)  Any liquids, solids or gases which, by reason of their nature or quantity, are or may be sufficient, either alone or by interaction with other substances, to cause fire or explosion or be injurious in any other way to the POTW or to the operation of the POTW. At no time shall two successive readings on an explosion hazard meter, at the point of discharge into the system (or at any point in the system), be more than five percent nor any single reading over ten percent of the lower explosive limit (LEL) of the meter. Prohibited materials include, but are not limited to, gasoline, kerosene, naphtha, benzene, toluene, xylene, ethers, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, peroxides, chlorates, perchlorates, bromates, carbides, hydrides and sulfides, and any other substances which the city, the state or the EPA has notified the user is a fire hazard or a hazard to the system. 
(2)  Solid or viscous substances which may cause obstruction to the flow in a sewer or other interference with the operation of the wastewater treatment facilities such as, but not limited to, grease, garbage with particles greater than one-half inch in any dimension, animal guts or tissues, paunch manure, bones, hair, hides or fleshings, entrails, whole blood, feathers, ashes, cinders, sand, spent lime, stone or marble dust, metal, glass, straw, shavings, grass clippings, rags, spent grains, spent hops, wastepaper, wood, plastics, gas, tar, asphalt residue, residues from refining or processing of fuel or lubricating oil, mud, or glass grinding or polishing wastes. 
(3)  Any wastewater having a pH less than 5.0, unless POTW was specifically designed to accommodate such wastewater, or wastewater having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and/or personnel of the POTW. 
(4)  Any wastewater containing toxic pollutants in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other pollutants, to injure or interfere with any wastewater treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a toxic effect in the receiving waters of the POTW, or to exceed the limitations set forth in a categorical pretreatment standard. A toxic pollutant shall include, but not be limited to, any pollutant identified pursuant to section 307(a) of the act. 
(5)  Any noxious or malodorous liquids, gases or solids which, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, are sufficient to create a public nuisance or hazard to life or are sufficient to prevent entry into the sewers for their maintenance and repair. 
(6)  Any substance which may cause the POTW's effluent or any other product of the POTW, such as residues, sludges or scums, to be unsuitable for reclamation and reuse or to interfere with the reclamation process where the POTW is pursuing a reuse and reclamation program. In no case shall a substance discharged to the POTW cause the POTW to be in noncompliance with sludge use or disposal criteria, guidelines or regulations developed under section 405 of the act; any criteria, guidelines or regulations affecting sludge use or disposal developed pursuant to the Solid Waste Disposal Act, the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substances Control Act, or state criteria applicable to the sludge management method being used. 
(7)  Any substance which will cause the POTW to violate its NPDES and/or state disposal system permit or the receiving water quality standards. 
(8)  Any wastewater with objectionable color not removed in the treatment process such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions. 
(9)  Any wastewater having a temperature which will inhibit biological activity in the POTW treatment plant resulting in interference but in no case wastewater with a temperature at the introduction into the POTW which exceeds 40 degrees Celsius (104 degrees Fahrenheit). 
(10)  Any pollutants, including oxygen-demanding pollutants (BOD, etc.), released at a flow and/or pollutant concentration which a user knows or has reason to know will cause interference to the POTW. In no case shall a slug load have a flow rate or contain concentrations or qualities of pollutants that exceed, for any time period longer than 15 minutes, more than five times the average 24-hour concentrations, quantities or flow during normal operation. 
(11)  Any wastewater containing any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the city manager in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations. 
(12)  Any wastewater which causes a hazard to human life or creates a public nuisance. 
(b)  When the city manager determines that a user is contributing to the POTW any of the above-enumerated substances in such amounts as to interfere with the operation of the POTW, the city manager shall: 
(1)  Advise the user of the impact of the contribution on the POTW; and 
(2)  Develop an effluent limitation for such user to correct the interference with the POTW. 
(Code 1967, § 21-16; Code 1994, § 78-126) 
Sec. 44-172. - Federal categorical pretreatment standards. 
    Upon the promulgation of the federal categorical pretreatment standards for a particular industrial subcategory, the federal standard, if more stringent than limitations imposed under this article for sources in that subcategory, shall immediately supersede the limitations imposed under this article. The city manager shall notify all affected users of the applicable reporting requirements under 40 CFR 403.12. 
(Code 1967, § 21-17; Code 1994, § 78-127) 
Sec. 44-173. - Modification of federal categorical pretreatment standards. 
    Where the city's wastewater treatment system achieves consistent removal of pollutants limited by federal pretreatment standards, the city may apply to the approval authority for modification of specific limits in the federal pretreatment standards. "Consistent removal" shall mean reduction in the amount of a pollutant or alteration of the nature of the pollutant by the wastewater treatment system to a less toxic or harmless state in the effluent which is achieved by the system in 95 percent of the samples taken when measured according to the procedures set forth in 40 CFR 403.7(c)(2), "General Pretreatment Regulations for Existing and New Sources of Pollution," promulgated pursuant to the act. The city may modify pollutant discharge limits in the federal pretreatment standards if the requirements contained in 40 CFR 403.7 are fulfilled and prior approval from the approval authority is obtained. 
(Code 1967, § 21-18; Code 1994, § 78-128) 
Sec. 44-174. - Pollutant limitations. 
    Minimum criteria for discharge of pollutants and limitations of such discharge shall be the same as the criteria for all waters at all times and all places within the state and listed under Water Quality Standards, F.A.C. ch. 62-3 of the rules of the department of environmental protection titled "Water Quality Standards," and F.A.C. ch. 62-600 et seq., "Wastewater Facilities." Specific limitations of above standards are listed below. No person shall discharge wastewater containing in excess of the below-listed specific pollutant limitations: 
Pollutant Limitation (mg/l) Arsenic 0.05 Cadmium 0.0008 Copper 0.03 Cyanide 0.005 Lead 0.03 Mercury 0.0007 Nickel 0.1 Silver 0.00007 Chromium (total) 1.0 Zinc 0.003 Identifiable chlorinated hydrocarbons (total) 0.4 Phenolic compounds which cannot be removed by the city's wastewater treatment processes 0.000001  
(Code 1967, § 21-19; Code 1994, § 78-129) 
Sec. 44-175. - State requirements. 
    Revised state requirements and limitations on discharges shall apply in any case where they are more stringent than federal requirements and limitations or those in this article. 
(Code 1967, § 21-20; Code 1994, § 78-130) 
Sec. 44-176. - City's right of revision. 
    The city reserves the right to establish by ordinance more stringent limitations or requirements on discharges to the wastewater disposal system if deemed necessary to comply with the objectives presented in this article. 
(Code 1967, § 21-21; Code 1994, § 78-131) 
Sec. 44-177. - Excessive discharge, diluted discharge. 
    No user shall ever increase the use of process water or in any way attempt to dilute a discharge as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment to achieve compliance with the limitations contained in the federal categorical pretreatment standards or in any other pollutant-specific limitation developed by the city or state. (Comment: Dilution may be an acceptable means of complying with some of the prohibitions set forth in section 44-171(a)(3), the pH prohibition.) 
(Code 1967, § 21-22; Code 1994, § 78-132) 
Sec. 44-178. - Accidental discharges. 
(a)  Responsibility. Each user shall provide protection from accidental discharge of prohibited materials or other substances regulated by this article. Facilities to prevent accidental discharge of prohibited materials shall be provided and maintained at the owner's or user's own cost and expense. Detailed plans showing facilities and operating procedures to provide this protection shall be submitted to the city for review and shall be approved by the city before construction of the facility. All existing users shall complete such a plan by January 1, 1986. No user who commences contribution to the POTW after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall be permitted to introduce pollutants into the system until accidental discharge procedures have been approved by the city. Review and approval of such plans and operating procedures shall not relieve the industrial user from the responsibility to modify the user's facility as necessary to meet the requirements of this article. In the case of an accidental discharge, it is the responsibility of the user to immediately telephone and notify the POTW of the incident. The notification shall include location of the discharge, type of waste, concentration and volume and corrective actions. 
(b)  Written notice. Within five days following an accidental discharge, the user shall submit to the superintendent a detailed written report describing the cause of the discharge and the measures to be taken by the user to prevent similar future occurrences. Such notification shall not relieve the user of any expense, loss, damage or other liability which may be incurred as a result of damage to the POTW, fish kills or any other damage to person or property; nor shall such notification relieve the user of any fines, civil penalties or other liability which may be imposed by this article or other applicable law. 
(c)  Notice to employees. A notice shall be permanently posted on the user's bulletin board or other prominent place advising employees whom to call in the event of a dangerous discharge. Employers shall ensure that all employees who may cause or suffer such a dangerous discharge to occur are advised of the emergency notification procedure. 
(Code 1967, § 21-23; Code 1994, § 78-133) 
Sec. 44-179. - Monitoring facilities. 
(a)  The city shall require to be provided and operated at the user's own expense monitoring facilities to allow inspection, sampling and flow measurement of the building sewer and/or internal drainage systems. The monitoring facility should normally be situated on the user's premises, but the city may, when such a location would be impractical or cause undue hardship on the user, allow the facility to be constructed in the public street or sidewalk area and located so that it will not be obstructed by landscaping or parked vehicles. 
(b)  There shall be ample room in or near such sampling manhole or facility to allow accurate sampling and preparation of samples for analysis. The facility, sampling and measuring equipment shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper operating condition at the expense of the user. 
(c)  Whether constructed on public or private property, the sampling and monitoring facilities shall be provided in accordance with the city's requirements and all applicable local construction standards and specifications. Construction shall be completed within 90 days following written notification by the city. 
(Code 1967, § 21-84; Code 1994, § 78-134) 
Sec. 44-180. - Inspection and sampling. 
    The city shall inspect the facilities of any user to ascertain whether the purpose of this article is being met and all requirements are being complied with. Persons or occupants of premises where wastewater is created or discharged shall allow the city or its representative ready access at all reasonable times to all parts of the premises for the purposes of inspection, sampling, records examination, or in the performance of any of their duties. The city, the approval authority and (where the NPDES state is the approval authority) the EPA shall have the right to set up on the user's property such devices as are necessary to conduct sampling, inspection, compliance monitoring and/or metering operations. Where a user has security measures in force which would require proper identification and clearance before entry into their premises, the user shall make necessary arrangements with their security guards so that, upon presentation of suitable identification, personnel from the city, the approval authority and the EPA will be permitted to enter, without delay, for the purpose of performing their specific responsibilities. 
(Code 1967, § 21-85; Code 1994, § 78-135) 
Sec. 44-181. - Pretreatment. 
(a)  Required. Users shall provide necessary wastewater treatment as required to comply with this article and shall achieve compliance with all federal categorical pretreatment standards within the time limitations as specified by the federal pretreatment regulations. Any facilities required to pretreat wastewater to a level acceptable to the city shall be provided, operated and maintained at the user's expense. Detailed plans showing the pretreatment facilities and operating procedures shall be submitted to the city for review and shall be acceptable to the city before construction of the facility. The review of such plans and operating procedures will in no way relieve the user from the responsibility of modifying the facility as necessary to produce an effluent acceptable to the city under the provisions of this article. Any subsequent changes in the pretreatment facilities or method of operation shall be reported to and be acceptable to the city prior to the user's initiation of the changes. 
(b)  Publication of users not in compliance. The city shall annually publish in the official newspaper a list of those users which were not in compliance with any pretreatment requirements or standards at least once during the 12 previous months. The notification shall also summarize any enforcement actions taken against the users during the same 12 months. 
(c)  Records. All records relating to compliance with pretreatment standards shall be made available to officials of the EPA or approval authority on request. 
(d)  Florida Building Code provisions. The Florida Building Code, Plumbing Volume, Traps, Interceptors and Separators, supercedes all local codes and prescribes the pretreatment requirements and maintenance of traps, interceptors and separators. 
(e)  Penalty. Any person violating this section shall be subject to penalty and enforcement as permitted under this Code and particularly under section 2-261 et seq., regarding code enforcement, or by court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1967, § 21-86; Code 1994, § 78-136; Ord. No. 2003-30, § III, 4-10-2003) 
Sec. 44-182. - Confidential information. 
(a)  Information and data on a user obtained from reports, questionnaires, permit applications, permits, monitoring programs and from inspections shall be available to the public or other governmental agency without restriction, unless the user specifically requests and is able to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the city that the release of such information would divulge information, processes or methods of production entitled to protection as trade secrets of the user. 
(b)  When requested by the person furnishing a report, the portions of a report which might disclose trade secrets or secret processes shall not be made available for inspection by the public but shall be made available upon written request to governmental agencies for uses related to this chapter, the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit, state disposal system permit and/or the pretreatment programs; provided, however, that such portions of a report shall be available for use by the state or any state agency in judicial review or enforcement proceedings involving the person furnishing the report. Wastewater constituents and characteristics will not be recognized as confidential information. 
(c)  Information accepted by the city as confidential shall not be transmitted to any governmental agency or to the general public by the city until and unless a ten-day notification is given to the user. 
(Code 1967, § 21-87; Code 1994, § 78-137) 
Sec. 44-183. - Suspension of permit and service. 
(a)  The city may suspend the wastewater treatment service and/or wastewater contribution permit when such suspension is necessary, in the opinion of the city, in order to stop an actual or threatened discharge which presents or may present an imminent or substantial endangerment to the health and welfare of persons, to the environment, causes interference to the POTW, or causes the city to violate any condition of its NPDES permit. 
(b)  Any person notified of a suspension of the wastewater treatment service and/or the wastewater contribution permit shall immediately stop or eliminate the contribution. In the event of a failure of the person to comply voluntarily with the suspension order, the city shall take such steps as deemed necessary, including immediate severance of the sewer connection, to prevent or minimize damage to the POTW system or endangerment to any individuals. The city shall reinstate the wastewater contribution permit and/or the wastewater treatment service upon proof of the elimination of the noncomplying discharge. A detailed written statement submitted by the user describing the causes of the harmful contribution and the measures taken to prevent any future occurrence shall be submitted to the city within 15 days of the date of occurrence. 
(Code 1967, § 21-101; Code 1994, § 78-138) 
Secs. 44-184-44-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - EXTENSION OF SERVICE 

Sec. 44-201. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Contribution-in-aid-of-construction (C.I.A.C.) means and includes those payments that are received by the city from any fee payor, contributor or person defined previously that are applied to the funding of sewerage improvements that are defined as miscellaneous sewer line extensions. 
    Cost and costs means all costs of labor, materials, equipment, rents, engineering, financing, real property, easements and rights-of-way, legal and other similar expenses, and incidental costs. 
    Force main means a pipeline generally extending from a pump station to a discharge outlet or structure designed to transmit sewage flow under pressure. 
    Miscellaneous sewer line extension is a sewer line designed and constructed to provide service to either properties/lots that are abutting or are serviceable by means of private easement or rights-of-way provided and held by the applicant. 
    Off-site improvements means sewerage system improvements which are generally designed to serve area sewerage service needs and not singularly, and/or specifically required to serve one development, applicant or facility. 
    On-site improvements means sewerage system improvements designed to serve a specific development, project or facility and consists of all improvements related to the project; within the project area, property boundary, and/or including areas immediately adjacent to the property or project. 
    Primary extensions means sewerage system extensions or modifications which are constructed primarily to serve new (growth) developments and newly developing areas. The extensions are generally consistent with the comprehensive development plan, sanitary sewer service element and consist of off-site sewerage construction improvements which are determined by the city as not being the responsibility of the developer, applicant or facility receiving service. 
    Sanitary service tap means the connection point of service lateral to the sewer main. It is generally a manufactured fitting or field drilled opening with a tapping saddle fitting. 
    Sanitary sewage, sanitary wastewater or domestic wastewater means that wastewater primarily derived from human wastes customarily as associated with domestic and/or residential activities or occupancies. 
    Sanitary sewerage or sewerage system means the term for the physical system used primarily for the collection, treatment and disposal of domestic wastewater; it includes the pipes, mains, manholes, cleanouts, pumping stations, force mains, pumps, tanks, control devises and all other appurtenances and facilities. 
    Secondary extensions means sewerage system extensions or modifications which are designed and constructed primarily to receive sanitary sewage from customer or user service laterals. The term "secondary extensions" also includes all on-site sewerage system improvements. 
    Service lateral, commonly referred to as a house lateral, house service, building sewer, building lateral or service, means the pipe which connects the house, building or facility to the city sewer main (normally either four or six inches in diameter). 
    Sewer main, sometimes referred to as street sewer or street lateral, means the pipe (usually eight inches in diameter or larger) installed in the street right-of-way or utility easement to receive and convey, by gravity flow, discharges to it from service lateral connections. 
    Sewer service tap charges (or fees) means the charges (fees) assessed to the applicant for the cost of installation of the service tap and service lateral from the sewer main to the property line or limits of the utility easement. 
    Trunk sewer main means a gravity sewer main designed in accordance with accepted industry practices, principles and standards primarily for the receipt and conveyance of discharges to it from sewer mains and/or force mains. 
(Code 1994, § 78-151; Ord. No. 92-M-1, § 3(21-161, 21-170), 9-10-1992; Ord. No. 96-18, § 1, 6-27-1996) 
Sec. 44-202. - New individual residential or general services. 
(a)  New individual residential service or new individual general service sanitary sewer services shall be provided to a subject property, upon the applicant's compliance with: 
(1)  The provisions of this division; and 
(2)  All applicable new service request procedures and requirements, including reclaimed water requirements, the payment of all applicable fees at appropriate rates, and written application for service on forms provided by the city manager. 
(b)  Under this division there shall be no sewerage extension requirements nor any direct sewerage extension charges for new sanitary sewer service, for individual residential service or general service, provided: 
(1)  There is in place, abutting the subject property, suitable sewerage for the service requested. Suitable sewerage is that system, which under acceptable engineering principles and practices, will adequately serve the subject property without reducing the level of service to other customers, served thereby, below an acceptable standard as the city manager may determine, guided by competent engineering advice upon the stated principles, practices and standards; and 
(2)  For projects outside the city, the applicant has: 
a.  Paid to the city the applicable fee for annexation review of the subject property; 
b.  Filed with the city a petition for annexation executed by the fee simple owner; and 
c.  Had recorded among the public records of the county a notice of and encumbrance to annex, on a form provided by the city manager, which gives assurances from the fee simple owner that the subject property shall be annexed to the city upon all other legal requirements being met, to occur at the convenience of the city council. 
(c)  Where there is not suitable sewerage for the new individual residential or general services sanitary sewer service requested, abutting the subject property, sewerage extensions shall be required. 
(Code 1994, § 78-152; Ord. No. 92-M-1, § 3(21-162), 9-10-1992) 
Sec. 44-203. - Types of extensions. 
(a)  Sanitary sewerage extensions are either primary extensions, secondary extensions or miscellaneous sewer line extensions; any extension not a primary extension is a secondary extension. All cost associated with secondary extensions shall be the sole responsibility of the applicant. 
(b)  The term "primary extension" includes trunk sewer main extensions, and force mains, together with the extension of any and all required downstream appurtenances and facilities. A trunk sewer main is transmission piping not less than ten inches in diameter and associated appurtenances, when designed in accordance with accepted industry practices, principles and standards, for only sewage transmission, and not so designed to accommodate individual residential nor individual general service service taps. A force main is a pressurized transmission piping and associated appurtenances, including pumping station and associated facilities, required as an alternate to a trunk sewer main to overcome positive differential elevation. 
(c)  The term "secondary extension" includes (when line designed as in subsection (b) of this section) any collection/transmission piping, which is ten inches or less, which is not a trunk sewer main, but is required for individual residential or individual general service sanitary sewer service, or is required for collection/transmission of sanitary sewage within new subdivisions or within new multiple service developments, together with all upstream appurtenances and facilities. 
(d)  Primary and secondary extensions may require provisions for reclaimed water which shall be provided in accordance with article III of this chapter. 
(Code 1994, § 78-153; Ord. No. 92-M-1, § 3(21-163), 9-10-1992; Ord. No. 96-18, § 1, 6-27-1996) 
Sec. 44-204. - Costs for primary extensions consistent with comprehensive plan borne by city. 
    The cost of all primary extensions which are consistent with the city's comprehensive plan shall be paid by the city. 
(Code 1994, § 78-154; Ord. No. 92-M-1, § 3(21-164), 9-10-1992) 
Sec. 44-205. - Projects inconsistent with comprehensive plan. 
    A main primary extension project which is not in any current capital improvement program nor incorporated in any current five-year capital improvement element of the comprehensive plan or which is affirmatively inconsistent with the such plan shall be discouraged. City manager initiated and other requests for such primary extensions shall be considered by the city council and may be permitted under those terms and conditions as shall be considered in the best interest of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 78-155; Ord. No. 92-M-1, § 3(21-165), 9-10-1992) 
Sec. 44-206. - Projects consistent with comprehensive plan, but not in compliance with capital improvements element schedule. 
    A primary extension project, incorporated within any five-year capital improvement element of the comprehensive plan or incorporated within any current capital improvement program, which is proposed for construction in advance of such element's or program's schedule but otherwise is consistent with the comprehensive plan, may be undertaken as follows: 
(1)  Such primary extension shall be permitted only after the plans therefor designed in accordance with accepted engineering industry principles, practices and standards and complying with accepted city planning industry techniques and practices, the comprehensive plan and land development regulations thereunder, have been approved by the city manager. The city manager shall be guided by competent engineering and planning advice upon the stated principals, practices, standards and techniques in his consideration for approval. All costs of such extension, primary and secondary, shall be advanced by the applicant, and the primary extension portion shall not be refunded in part or in whole by the city, until following construction of the total extension and acceptance by the city. 
(2)  A project agreement, including cost refund by the city, shall be negotiated between the applicant and the city manager on behalf of the city. No such agreement shall be effective until approved by the city council. Generally, the city shall reimburse, fully the primary extension portion, with payment being made not later than the end of the fiscal year for which construction is scheduled under any current capital improvement program or under the subject five-year capital improvement element. In no case shall reimbursement exceed the primary extension costs, as certified by the city manager. Any such agreement shall set forth the intention of the city to fully refund for primary extension costs, but refund timing shall be subject to budgetary restraints, amendments and repeal, and the city shall not pledge its full faith and credit. However, the city shall agree, with specifics set forth in the agreement, that it shall not fund from sewer impact fees the cost of any other sewerage extension, of which all, or a part, is a project with a scheduled position which is subsequent to the subject extension project as set forth in the specified current capital improvement program or the subject five-year capital improvement element, until the primary extension cost of the subject project shall have been refunded. 
(3)  All sewerage extensions, primary and secondary, however funded, shall become property of the city upon acceptance for service. 
(Code 1994, § 78-156; Ord. No. 92-M-1, § 3(21-166), 9-10-1992) 
Sec. 44-207. - Preliminary project review report. 
    With application, the city manager shall make, or have made, a preliminary project review report setting forth the city's physical requirements for the proposed extension, e.g., the size, equipment, etc., of the sewerage, the proposed route or location and shall provide a copy thereof to the applicant. No application to the city for sewerage extension to any property located outside the city limits, shall be considered until the applicant has paid to the city the applicable fee for annexation review of the property to be served, and has had recorded among the public records of the county a notice of and encumbrance to annex, on a form provided by the city manager, which gives assurances from the fee simple owner that the subject property shall be annexed to the city, upon all other legal requirements being met, to occur at the convenience of the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 78-157; Ord. No. 92-M-1, § 3(21-167), 9-10-1992) 
Sec. 44-208. - City design and installation alternate. 
    At the option of the applicant and in lieu of the procedure set forth in section 44-209, where the applicant desires the city to proceed with the design and installation of the sewerage extension by force account or by contract, the applicant shall:
