(1)  Deposit with the city an amount equal to ten percent of the preliminary estimates, and the city manager shall prepare, or have prepared at his direction, a detailed estimate of the cost of the requested extension, providing a copy thereof to the applicant. If the applicant shall withdraw the request for extension after receipt of the detailed cost estimate, the city may retain such portion of the applicant's deposit as shall be required to pay all costs incurred by the city in making the detailed cost estimate. If the applicant shall authorize installation of the requested extension, the deposit shall be applied by the city to the payment required by subsection (3) of this section. 
(2)  If the preliminary cost estimate prepared by the city is $20,000.00 or more, the deposit required under subsection (1) of this section may be, at the discretion of the city manager, a reasonable amount not less than $2,000.00, but less than ten percent of the preliminary estimate and be based upon the time and labor expected to be required by the city in preparing the detailed estimate. 
(3)  At the city's demand, prior to commencement of construction by force account or prior to bidding any contract for construction of any sewerage extension under this section, the applicant shall pay to the city a sum equal to the estimated cost of such extension as prepared by the city. Such monies shall be used by the city to pay the costs of the requested extension, and there shall be no refund of any portion thereof except as specifically provided for herein. If the actual cost of the extension as completed and finally accepted by the city shall be less than the estimated cost, the difference between the amount paid by the applicant and the actual cost shall be returned to the applicant. If the actual cost shall exceed the estimated cost, the difference between the amount paid by the applicant and the actual cost shall be paid to the city by the applicant prior to the sewerage extension being placed into service. 
(Code 1994, § 78-158; Ord. No. 92-M-1, § 3(21-168), 9-10-1992) 
Sec. 44-209. - Applicant design and installation alternate. 
    At the option of the applicant, and in lieu of the procedure set forth in section 44-208, the applicant may proceed with design and construction as follows: 
(1)  At no cost to the city, the applicant may employ a state-registered engineer of his choice, to provide required plans and specifications, conforming to the preliminary project review report, or the report as amended by agreement with the city manager, and submit such plans and specifications with appropriate fee to the city for technical review and approval. 
(2)  Upon technical review and approval of the plans and specifications made by or under the direction of the city manager, guided by industry-acceptable engineering principles and practices and in conformity with comprehensive plan land development regulations, the applicant may employ a contractor of his choice, holding proper certification/registration from the state department of professional regulation to provide the sewerage extension installation, subject to inspection, approval and acceptance by or under the direction of the city manager. 
(Code 1994, § 78-159; Ord. No. 92-M-1, § 3(21-169), 9-10-1992) 
Sec. 44-210. - Miscellaneous sewer line extensions-Program established. 
(a)  Program established. There is hereby established a program for projects entitled "miscellaneous sewer line extensions." 
(b)  Authorization of funding. The council may, at its discretion, from time to time, authorize and fund the extension of miscellaneous sewer lines in response to requests for service. 
(c)  C.I.A.C. Policy Manual. A manual which establishes policies and procedures for the implementation of the contribution-in-aid-of-construction program. 
(Code 1994, § 78-160; Ord. No. 96-18, § 1, 6-27-1996; Ord. No. 2014-04, § 1, 2-13-2014) 
Sec. 44-211. - Same-Contributions-in-aid-of-construction. 
(a)  Fee established. A contribution-in-aid-of-construction (C.I.A.C.) fee is hereby established. A contribution-in-aid-of-construction (C.I.A.C.) shall be established to provide an equitable method of cost sharing for miscellaneous sewer line extensions. The contribution is a requirement for service only if the applicant decides to apply for city sewer service as opposed to providing an on-site septic or other wastewater treatment system. The C.I.A.C. will be based upon a cost sharing formula using the lot/property front footage as per deed, survey or plat (hereinafter "deed frontage"). The cost per front foot on as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time shall be used to develop the project cost. 
(b)  Parameters for calculation. The following parameters apply when calculating a property's C.I.A.C.: 
(1)  Frontage. Is the deed frontage as pertains to the legal address or lot frontage as determined for the minimum requirements for issuance of a building permit or 75 feet, whichever footage is greater. 
(2)  Corner lots. Frontage shall be determined as the dimension of the frontage facing the street of legal deed address or its dimension of width frontage for issuance of a building permit or 75 feet whichever is greater. 
(3)  Flag lots. Same as subsections (b)(1) and (2) of this section. 
(4)  Lot splits. Separate lots held by the same owner that may or may not be contiguous to each other may pay the C.I.A.C. at the time of application on a lot by lot basis (as per (subsections (b)(1), (2) and/or (3) of this section). 
(c)  C.I.A.C. Policy Manual. All projects are subject to the policies within the C.I.A.C. Policy Manual in place when the miscellaneous line construction is requested. 
(Code 1994, § 78-161; Ord. No. 96-18, § 1, 6-27-1996; Ord. No. 2003-51, § II, 10-23-2003; Ord. No. 2014-04, § 1, 2-13-2014) 
Sec. 44-212. - Same-Location and extent of construction. 
(a)  Miscellaneous sewer lines may be extended to but not necessarily across the full frontage of the contributing lot based upon the determination by the city manager or his designee that adequate service is provided. 
(b)  In situations involving two or more flag lots, either existing or potential, the city may require the applicant to construct on-site secondary line extensions to serve these properties with adequate provisions for easements and accessibility. This requirement shall be the preferred method of service. 
(Code 1994, § 78-162; Ord. No. 96-18, § 1, 6-27-1996) 
Sec. 44-213. - Same-Costs, estimates, reports and C.I.A.C. payment. 
(a)  Cost estimate for projects and determination of the C.I.A.C. The city council may adopt and revise the C.I.A.C. cost per front foot from time to time by resolution, or the city council may approve a C.I.A.C. project as defined in the C.I.A.C. Policy Manual by resolution and specify the project cost per front foot. The city manager or his designee shall prepare a cost per linear foot for miscellaneous sewer line extensions that is based upon most recent cost experience. The city manager is authorized and directed to set and give notice of a public hearing at which his recommendation shall be presented to the city council. Such cost estimate shall include all reasonable direct and indirect expenses for furnishing and installing eight-inch gravity sewer lines, including piping, manholes, fittings, appurtenances, rights-of-way, legal, and engineering costs. 
(b)  Preliminary proposed project report and financial status. 
(1)  The city manager or his designee shall prepare a preliminary project proposal memo and cost estimate for each potential miscellaneous sewer line extension. The project proposal shall identify location of projects, properties potentially to be served and cost estimates for construction. 
(2)  The report shall also verify the availability of funds and the compatibility or potential conflicts with other capital projects including scheduled primary off-site sewer line extensions. 
(c)  Payment of C.I.A.C. The amount of the C.I.A.C. shall be determined by the rate currently in effect at the time of receipt of a properly completed request for a determination of availability. If a main was constructed as part of an area wide extension project or a single roadway extension project, as defined in the C.I.A.C. Policy Manual, upon future connection the property owner must pay the project costs previously established by resolution for that area. 
    For any property designated as a homestead under F.S. ch. 222, the city council may permit C.I.A.C. fees to be paid by installments. Evidence of the debt due, reflecting the payment terms, together with evidence of a marketable lien encumbering the property served, shall be executed in recordable form and the evidence of lien together with a copy of the evidence of debt shall be filed in the public records of the county. Interest shall be seven percent unless waived or reduced by the city manager 
(d)  Properties/lots affected by C.I.A.C. Properties and/or lots for which the C.I.A.C. are applicable are: properties/lots that lie within the unincorporated areas served by the city utility and that abut or are adjacent to miscellaneous sewer line extensions and that apply for and receive service from such lines. 
(e)  Disposition and use of C.I.A.C. All funds collected through the administration of the C.I.A.C. shall be reserved for use in a rollover account for the purposes of continuing and maintaining a miscellaneous sewer line construction program. 
(f)  Review and verification of C.I.A.C. payment requirement. Applications for sewer service shall be reviewed by the city manager or his designee to verify the property as subject to C.I.A.C. requirement or exemption from same. 
(Code 1994, § 78-163; Ord. No. 96-18, § 1, 6-27-1996; Ord. No. 2003-51, § III, 10-23-2003; Ord. No. 2014-04, § 1, 2-13-2014) 
Sec. 44-214. - Same-Negotiation agreements. 
    Negotiated miscellaneous sewer line extension: In the event a developer or applicant requests the extension of a sewer line and agrees to incur all the costs for extension, council may at its discretion approve a negotiated agreement to provide for the equitable reimbursement to the applicant for funds expended beyond those normally applicable for C.I.A.C. Such reimbursement to applicant may take the form of a series of payments over a period of time, not to exceed five years. The city council may elect to deny any such request for miscellaneous line extension if it is perceived not in the best interest of the city and/or cost of extension does not provide a reasonable expectation of enhancement to the city's wastewater collection system. 
(Code 1994, § 78-164; Ord. No. 96-18, § 1, 6-27-1996) 
Secs. 44-215-44-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RECLAIMED WATER[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Graywater disposal systems, F.S. §§ 381.0065, 403.064. 

Sec. 44-241. - Purpose and intent. 
    The city council has determined that the use of reclaimed water is necessary and is in the best interests of the citizens of the city. The purpose of this article is to provide for the use of reclaimed water in selected areas of the city's chapter 180 service area (F.S. ch. 180). It is intended that this article will accomplish the following objectives: provide for the construction of reclaimed water distribution systems; provide for the safe and beneficial use of reclaimed water; and protect the environment and the state's limited potable water supplies. 
(Code 1967, § 21-131; Code 1994, § 78-181) 
Sec. 44-242. - Jurisdiction. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this article, this article shall only apply to the incorporated area of the city and those portions of the city's chapter 180 service area (F.S. ch. 180) where the city provides or plans to provide wastewater service. 
(Code 1967, § 21-132; Code 1994, § 78-182) 
Sec. 44-243. - Sources of reclaimed water. 
    The source of reclaimed water shall be city wastewater treatment plants or other acceptable sources as determined by the city which provide reclaimed water meeting the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 21-133; Code 1994, § 78-183) 
Sec. 44-244. - Construction of new reclaimed water facilities. 
(a)  All reclaimed water facilities shall be designed and constructed in accordance with applicable state and city policies, standards and specifications. Engineering specifications and construction standards shall be incorporated into the land development code within 90 days of adoption of this article. 
(b)  Each new development within the city's chapter 180 service area (F.S. ch. 180) shall include a reclaimed water distribution system as a condition of water or sewer service, provided construction of the reclaimed water distribution system is deemed to be in the best interest of the city as determined by the city manager. 
(c)  The developer shall construct the reclaimed water distribution system and all facilities necessary to extend city transmission mains from the stipulated point of connection to the development. 
(d)  The city may require the developer to oversize all or any portion of the reclaimed water facilities to be constructed by the developer. Additional construction costs associated with any such oversizing shall be borne by the city in accordance with the applicable city oversizing policy. 
(Code 1967, § 21-134; Code 1994, § 78-184) 
Sec. 44-245. - Use of reclaimed water. 
    All uses of reclaimed water shall be in accordance with applicable rules of the department of environmental protection and other regulatory bodies having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1967, § 21-135; Code 1994, § 78-185) 
Sec. 44-246. - Connection to system. 
(a)  When required. Connection to the reclaimed water system is required for all public, commercial, office, industrial/warehousing and multifamily development within the city's urban service area as transmission and distribution mains become available. Single-family residential developments constructed after adoption of the land development code construction standards, as identified in section 44-244, shall include reclaimed water distribution mains, and connection to the system is required as reclaimed water service becomes available. 
(b)  Voluntary connection. Connection to the system is voluntary for all existing single-family residences within the city's utility service district. Distribution mains may be extended into these areas as reclaimed water service becomes available in accordance with the procedures outlined in section 44-249. 
(Code 1967, § 21-136; Code 1994, § 78-186) 
Sec. 44-247. - Maintenance of customer's system. 
    Each customer shall be solely responsible for maintaining the customer's reuse system in good working condition. This will ensure compliance with the provisions of this article. The customer shall pay the cost of all such maintenance required. 
(Code 1967, § 21-137; Code 1994, § 78-187) 
Sec. 44-248. - Limitations of capacity. 
    The city will monitor reclaimed water connections so as not to exceed the capacity of the system. It is the intent of the city to maximize the use of reclaimed water and to provide service to as many customers as practical. At times it may be necessary to limit a customer's use of reclaimed water. Notwithstanding any provision of this article to the contrary, the city makes no representation as to the availability or implementation of reclaimed water service within the city. Furthermore, nothing in this article shall be construed to create a debt or general obligation of the city or a pledge of the full faith and credit or taxing power of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 21-138; Code 1994, § 78-188) 
Sec. 44-249. - Applications for service. 
(a)  Each application requesting the city to provide reclaimed water service to the property identified in that application shall be made to the city manager by the property owner or an authorized representative of the property owner. 
(b)  If service is determined to be available, the applicant shall be notified of such determination and any conditions of service. If service is not available, the applicant shall be so notified. 
(c)  Acceptance by the applicant of the conditions of service shall constitute a contract between the applicant and the city which shall bind the applicant to pay for the services rendered at the rates and charges prescribed by the city and set forth in Appendix A which is on file in the city clerk's office and to comply with all applicable rules and regulations. 
(d)  No reclaimed water shall be provided to a residential customer without verification of a backflow preventer on the domestic water service line immediately after the meter. 
(Code 1967, § 21-139; Code 1994, § 78-189) 
Sec. 44-250. - Construction of private irrigation wells where reclaimed water service available. 
    The construction of new private irrigation wells is hereby prohibited in areas where reclaimed water service is available. 
(Code 1967, § 21-140; Code 1994, § 78-190) 
Sec. 44-251. - Unauthorized work on facilities. 
(a)  Tampering prohibited; costs and penalties. Unless expressly authorized in writing by the city manager, no individual or organization shall tamper with, work on or in any way alter or damage any city reclaimed water facility. Tampering with or working on shall include, but shall not be limited to, opening or closing of valves or causing any water to flow from the system. No unauthorized person shall cut into or make any connection with the system. The offending person shall be liable for the cost of all charges attributable to the correction of such tampering, including attorney's fees. The city may commence an action for legal or equitable relief in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce the provisions of this article. However, payment for correcting damage to the system shall not relieve the offending person from other civil or criminal penalties which may be applicable. 
(b)  Repair of private service valve. Whenever a private service valve requires repair, the customer shall request the city manager to make all necessary adjustments to the city's curb stop (valve). In case of emergency, this requirement shall be waived. 
(Code 1967, § 21-141; Code 1994, § 78-191) 
Sec. 44-252. - Inspections. 
(a)  In order to ascertain and ensure compliance with the provisions of this article and related regulations, the city reserves the right to inspect, secure and/or disconnect any and all devices wherever located which connect to or control any discharge from a reclaimed water distribution system. 
(b)  Inspections made by the city where there is reasonable cause to believe that this article or any related regulation is being violated shall be at such times and with such frequency as the city deems necessary to establish whether or not this article or any regulation is being or has been violated. 
(c)  Inspections made by the city without reasonable cause to believe that this article or any related regulation is being violated shall be conducted during normal working hours at the convenience of the owner or occupant. The city shall give prior notice of at least 48 hours, and the notice shall include a general statement as to the extent and purpose of the inspection. The owner or occupant has the right to be present during the inspection. 
(Code 1967, § 21-142; Code 1994, § 78-192) 
Sec. 44-253. - Denial of access. 
    After proper notice and a good faith effort by the city pursuant to section 44-252, the denial of access to an authorized agent or employee of the city to any property receiving reclaimed water service for the purpose of conducting any inspection permitted under this article shall constitute a violation of this article and shall be grounds for immediate discontinuance of reclaimed water service by the city to the subject premises. 
(Code 1967, § 21-143; Code 1994, § 78-193) 
Sec. 44-254. - Ownership. 
(a)  Conveyance of systems and mains to city. All reclaimed water distribution systems and transmission mains constructed by a developer in a public right-of-way shall be conveyed to the city in accordance with city requirements regarding acceptance and bonding requirements for water and wastewater improvement facilities. 
(b)  Conditions for acceptance by city. The city shall accept the reclaimed water distribution system and transmission mains constructed by the developer provided the city determines that the developer's facilities meet all of the following conditions: 
(1)  The facilities were constructed to city standards as provided in section 44-244. 
(2)  The facilities are in good working condition. 
(3)  The facilities are either in a public right-of-way or in a city-approved utility easement. 
(Code 1967, § 21-144; Code 1994, § 78-194) 
Sec. 44-255. - User rates, service charges. 
    Fees and rates for connection to and for use of reclaimed water shall be as currently established or hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time and are on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1967, § 21-145; Code 1994, § 78-195) 
Sec. 44-256. - Emergency acts. 
(a)  The city manager may interrupt the delivery of reclaimed water to any property when such suspension is necessary in the opinion of the city, in order to stop a violation of this article or any related regulation or to stop a threat which presents or may present an imminent or substantial endangerment to the health and welfare of persons, the environment, or causes the city to violate any conditions of its SFWMD, FDEP or other operating permits. Any such interruption shall continue until such time deemed appropriate by the city manager for resumption of service to the subject property. 
(b)  The city manager may take whatever emergency action he deems necessary and appropriate to protect persons or property from any injury, loss or damage which may reasonably be expected to result from each specific violation of this article or any related regulation. The customer shall be responsible for all costs incurred by the city for any emergency measures performed by or at the request of the city as a result of such a violation attributed to the customer's reuse system or operation thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 21-146; Code 1994, § 78-196; Ord. No. 2008-014, § III(78-196), 1-24-2008) 
Sec. 44-257. - Reclaimed water account. 
    A reclaimed water account shall be established in the name of the customer, who shall be the owner, or the owner's tenant, of any residential unit or general service unit. There shall be a separate reclaimed water account for each residential unit and for each general service unit unless residential or general service units are served by a master reclaimed water meter, which shall constitute a single reclaimed water account. Extraordinary physical service reclaimed water meter connections shall be governed by regulations prescribed in a separate agreement adopted by the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 78-197; Ord. No. 01-44, § 3, 10-25-2001) 
Sec. 44-258. - Monthly reclaimed water charge; imposition. 
    A charge for reclaimed water service for residential and general service units is levied and established consisting of a monthly base charge and a reclaimed water volume charge. The monthly base charge and monthly volume charge shall be established by resolution of the city council from time to time and shall be maintained on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1994, § 78-198; Ord. No. 01-44, § 3, 10-25-2001) 
Sec. 44-259. - Reclaimed water minimum charge; rate schedule. 
(a)  Monthly base charge. The monthly base charge is established to recover the costs of meter and installation, administration and billing of accounts and the cost of maintenance of the appropriate meter. The monthly base charge, even with no usage, shall be assessed to the meter sizes shown below and shall be the appropriate rate for the reclaimed meter size shown for inside city, being the charge made for service to each residential unit or general service unit located within the municipal limits of the city or the appropriate rate for the reclaimed meter size shown for outside city, being the charge for service to each residential unit or general service unit located outside the municipal limits of the city, as follows:

(b)  Staff shall bring forward any proposed reclaimed water rates adjustments to the city manager. Provided that the recommendation is consistent with rate provisions in effect per a resolution adopted in accordance with subsection (a) of this section. All proposed adjustments shall require the city manager properly advertise and hold a separate public hearing at which time the recommendation shall be presented to city council for approval. Reclaimed water base charge for service rendered on and after January 1 of each budget year shall be determined in accordance with the facility charges for sanitary sewer, subsection 44-117(b). 
(Code 1994, § 78-199; Ord. No. 01-44, § 3, 10-25-2001; Ord. No. 2014-27, § III, 7-10-2014; Ord. No. 2016-57 , § III, 11-17-2016) 
Sec. 44-260. - Monthly base charge discontinuance. 
    The owner of any residential unit or any general service unit may make written application to terminate such unit's reclaimed water account to, and on a form to be supplied by, the city manager. Where: 
(1)  All city accounts for such unit due by the owner are current; and 
(2)  Such unit is not being "utilized"; or 
(3)  Such unit is no longer using reclaimed water; 
the unit's reclaimed water account and the corresponding reclaimed water service to the unit shall terminate. Thereafter, reinstatement of municipal reclaimed water service shall require reclaimed water account reinstatement and shall incur an equivalent charge for the reinstatement of potable water service, section 44-333. 
(Code 1994, § 78-200; Ord. No. 01-44, § 3, 10-25-2001) 
Sec. 44-261. - Reclaimed water volume charge. 
(a)  The reclaimed water volume charge shall be the product of the metered number of thousand gallons of reclaimed water used, multiplied by the reclaimed water volume rate shown below for inside city, such product being the volume portion of the monthly charge for reclaimed water service to an entity located within the municipal limits of the city; or as appropriate, it shall be the product of the metered number of thousand gallons of reclaimed water used, multiplied by the reclaimed water volume rate shown below for outside city, such product being the volume portion of the monthly charge for reclaimed water service to an entity located outside the municipal limits of the city, as follows: 
Inside City Outside City Reclaimed Water Volume Rate per 1,000 gals. Municipal Rate County Rate Gallons of Reclaimed Water Used 1,000 × Appropriate Rate  
(b)  Staff shall bring forward any proposed reclaimed water volume charge adjustments to the city manager. Provided that the recommendation is consistent with rate provisions in effect per a resolution adopted in accordance with subsection (a) of this section. All proposed adjustments shall require that the city manager properly advertise and hold a separate public hearing at which time the recommendation shall be presented to city council for approval. Unless the city council takes action to the contrary, reclaimed water volume rates for service rendered on and after January 1 of each budget year shall be determined in accordance with the volume rates for sanitary sewer, subsection 44-121(b). 
(Code 1994, § 78-201; Ord. No. 01-44, § 3, 10-25-2001; Ord. No. 2014-27, § III, 7-10-2014; Ord. No. 2016-57 , § III, 11-17-2016) 
Sec. 44-262. - Collection and billing. 
    The monthly reclaimed water charge imposed above shall be collected by the city in the regular monthly utility billing cycle and deposited in the sewer system revenue fund, and no monies in excess of 9.5 percent of the combined potable water, reclaimed water, and sanitary sewer system metered revenue shall be transferred out of the water and sewer enterprise funds as an administrative transfer. In no case shall an administrative transfer cause the net income for the fund to be negative. For the purpose of establishing the budget in any given year, metered revenue shall refer to the second prior year's metered revenue collected. The term "administrative transfer" used within this section, is defined as a nonreciprocal transfer of revenues, meaning there is not a cost of service associated with this transfer. This administrative transfer is further defined as a return on investments of the water and sewer utility to the city. This section shall not be construed to prevent or establish the transfer of funds for reasonable administrative costs and those required by bond or loan covenants. Each customer, i.e., each unit service address, shall be billed monthly for services rendered, and if not paid within 15 days from the date of billing, the reclaimed water service for such unit service address may be discontinued until all delinquent charges for such reclaimed water service have been paid in full. 
(Code 1994, § 78-202; Ord. No. 01-44, § 3, 10-25-2001; Ord. No. 2008-68, § III(78-202), 1-8-2009) 
Sec. 44-263. - Enforcement; reclaimed water service charges. 
    Any unpaid reclaimed water monthly service charges shall become a lien against the property or premises served and shall be of equal status as an ad valorem tax lien against said property. In addition, and supplemental thereto, compliance herewith shall be enforced by the city code enforcement board as provided by law. 
(Code 1994, § 78-203; Ord. No. 01-44, § 3, 10-25-2001) 
Sec. 44-264 - Administrative procedures. 
(a)  The city manager is authorized and directed to prepare and maintain a City of St. Cloud Utilities Customer Service Manual to administer reasonable administrative procedures, regulations, customer service and billing policies in regard to the implementation of this article as orderly administration shall require. The manual shall be on file in the public services department. 
(b)  The city manager is authorized and directed to prepare reasonable administrative regulations and policies in regard to the collection of impact fees, instatement charges, facility and volume charges and user fees as are and may be established as orderly administration shall require, and the same shall be approved and adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § IV, 7-11-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-14, § IV, adopted July 11, 2013, amended § 44-264 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former §44-264 pertained to reclaimed water regulations and derived from the Code of 1994, § 78-204; Ord. No. 01-44, § 3, adopted Oct. 25, 2001. 
Sec. 44-265. - Backflow certification and testing, fee imposed. 
(a)  The consumer shall be responsible for and bear all expenses of installing, testing, and maintaining the protection devices required by the cross connection control manual to ensure proper operation on a continuing basis with the following exceptions: 
(1)  The required backflow device for single-family residential properties using reclaimed water for irrigation purposes and served by a three-quarter-inch meter, shall be installed, tested, repaired and maintained by the city, however, the responsibility for the cost of such service shall remain with the customer. 
(2)  The required backflow device for all other single-family residential properties using reclaimed or potable water for irrigation purposes shall be tested by the city; however, the responsibility for the cost of testing shall remain with the customer. Installation, repair and maintenance of these backflow devices are the responsibility of the customer. 
(b)  The cost of providing this annual service shall be assessed in monthly installments with the monthly utility bill. For single-family residential meter sizes greater than two inches, all multifamily services, and all general service connections, the customer shall be responsible for providing test results and certification annually to the public works department. Installation, testing, maintenance, and replacement of all protective devices required for use of on-site irrigation with reclaimed water shall be in accordance with the cross connection control manual and conducted by certified personnel approved by the city. 
(c)  The city council may revise the backflow testing and certification fee from time to time by resolution, or in the alternative, with the annual budget presented to the city council. The city manager or his designee shall recommend a revised backflow testing and certification fee that is based upon most recent cost experience. The city manager is authorized and directed to set and give notice of a public hearing at which his recommendation shall be presented to the city council. Unless the city council takes action to the contrary, this cost shall be used to establish and update the amount of the backflow testing and certification fee applicable each calendar year and shall be effective upon the first day of each calendar year following adoption of the budget. 
(Code 1994, § 78-205; Ord. No. 2003-50, § II, 10-23-2003; Ord. No. 2004-121, § II, 10-28-2004) 
Sec. 44-266. - Irrigation; reclaimed water. 
(a)  Restrictions. 
(1)  Reclaimed water irrigation of any residential, commercial, institutional, governmental, or industrial landscape areas shall at a minimum have the following restrictions: 
a.  No irrigation shall be allowed between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on any day unless specifically exempted below. 
b.  Irrigation restrictions shall be in effect yearround. 
c.  The city manager, or his designee, shall determine the allowable days and times when irrigation is permitted. Allowable irrigation days shall not exceed three days per week for any given location and may be restricted further. The days and time shall be set as policy and maintained on file and posted in the environmental utilities department. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful to operate or cause the operation of any irrigation system or device in a manner causing water to be wasted, including, but not limited to, unnecessary watering of impervious areas, other than that which may occur incidental to the proper operation of the primary irrigation system. 
(3)  All new installations of automatic irrigation systems shall be equipped with a water-sensing device, which will automatically discontinue irrigation during periods of rainfall. All existing irrigation installations shall be required to maintain their rain-sensing device in an operational condition. 
(b)  Exemptions. The following activities shall be exempt from the provisions above: 
(1)  Landscape irrigation by microirrigation systems or hand-watering using a self-canceling nozzle. 
(2)  The operation of irrigation systems for system installation, repair, and maintenance. 
(3)  Flushing of water mains required for normal water main clearance and maintenance, and for maintenance of water quality. 
(4)  Landscape irrigation by a licensed pest control operator for the purpose of watering in fungicides, insecticides, and herbicides as required by the manufacturer or by federal or state laws when such application is limited to the minimum manufacturer's recommendations. 
(5)  Landscape irrigation for the purpose of watering in newly planted grass and foliage for the first 30 days after initial installation shall be exempted from daily restrictions, but shall be subject to the irrigation time restrictions noted in subsection (a)(1)a of this section. 
(6)  Irrigation activity for the control of dust emissions authorized by the city manager or his designee. 
(7)  Large commercial, industrial, and common area locations may be reviewed on a case by case basis to assign irrigation days and times on a zone by zone basis as necessary to balance service demands. Such schedules shall be subject to approval by the city manager or his designee. Approval of said schedules shall be consistent with the intent and objective of irrigation restrictions in place at any given time. Assigned alternative schedules shall be subject to change upon revision of the irrigation restriction policies described in subsection (a)(1)c of this section and shall be subject to inspection and enforcement provisions of this Code. 
(8)  The use of water to protect golf course turf from heat and wind stress damage subject to approval of the city manager or his designee. 
(c)  The city manager is hereby authorized to restrict the use of water for irrigation and/or accessory use during those periods of time of critical concern. The city manager shall implement and cause to be enforced, any irrigation restriction declared by South Florida Water Management District due to drought or pending drought by the process above. 
(d)  The city development review committee reviews all site plans and subdivision plans. During this review the city will encourage the use of landscape plants that are indigenous species or those that require little or no irrigation. The city will encourage and provide informational brochures on xeriscape landscaping to applicants for irrigation meters. The city will post scheduling of landscape programs offered through the University of Florida, Osceola County Extension Service. 
(e)  The environmental utilities department shall continue to enhance the reliability and availability of the city's metered reclaimed water program. Capital improvement projects will be coordinated to provide timely extension of reclaimed water mains within the reclaimed water service area. 
(Ord. No. 2007-17, § III(78-206), 2-8-2007) 
Sec. 44-267. - Penalty. 
(a)  Civil penalties. 
(1)  Any user who is found to have violated an order of the city council or who willfully or negligently failed to comply with any provision of this article and the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued hereunder shall be fined for each offense. Each day on which a violation shall occur or continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. 
(2)  Any violations of this article shall follow the following fine schedule levied via monthly utility bills: 
a.  First offense, $250.00. 
b.  Second offense, $500.00. 
c.  Third offense, termination of service and $500.00 reconnection fee. 
(3)  In addition to the penalties provided herein, the city may recover reasonable attorneys' fees, court costs, court reporters' fees and other expenses of litigation by appropriate suit at law against the person found to have violated this article or the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued hereunder. Any person, customer or consumer in violation of any of the provisions of this division shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage incurred by the city by reason of such violation. In addition to any penalty provided by law for the violation of any of the provisions of this division, the city may bring suit in the appropriate court to enjoin, restrain, or otherwise prevent the violation of any of the provisions of this division. 
(b)  Falsifying information. Any person who knowingly makes any false statement, representation or certification in any application, record, report, plan or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this chapter, or wastewater contribution permit, or who falsifies, tampers with or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or by imprisonment for not more than six months, or by both. 
(c)  Code enforcement board. Any user aggrieved pursuant to the terms of this section may appeal said action to the city code enforcement board, or its successor entity. Such appeals shall be taken within 30 days of the date of notification to user of the penalty hereunder and shall be subject to a filing fee of $50.00 for the initiation of the appeal. Notice of the appeal shall be timely provided to the office of the director of environmental utilities and shall specify the grounds on which the appeal is based. The code enforcement board shall consider the appeal at its next available hearing and determine whether a violation or violations have occurred as provided in chapter. In the event that the code enforcement board determines that the violation or violations did occur, the board shall deny the appeal and uphold the determination of the penalty, whereupon, the user shall have 15 days to pay the penalty. If the code enforcement board determines that the violation or violations did not occur, then the board shall grant the appeal and the user shall be entitled to a return of the subject filing fee paid for this appeal. Alternatively or supplementary, compliance with this article may be enforced by direct action of the city before the city code enforcement board as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2008-014, § III(78-207), 1-24-2008; Ord. No. 2008-40, § II(78-207), 7-10-2008) 
Secs. 44-268-44-290. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - POTABLE WATER[4]

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 44-291. - Administrative procedures. 
(a)  The city manager is authorized and directed to prepare and maintain a City of St. Cloud Utilities Customer Service Manual to administer reasonable administrative procedure, regulations, customer service and billing policies in regard to the implementation of this article as orderly administration shall require. The manual shall be on file in the public services department. 
(b)  The city manager is authorized and directed to prepare reasonable administrative regulations and policies in regard to the collection of impact fees, instatement charges, facility and volume charges and user fees as are and may be established as orderly administration shall require, and the same shall be approved and adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1994, § 78-216; Ord. No. 91-M, § 28, 3-21-1991; Ord. No. 92-N-1, § XIII, 9-24-1992; Ord. No. 2013-14, § V, 7-11-2013) 
Sec. 44-292. - Penalty. 
(a)  Civil penalties. 
(1)  Any user who is found to have violated an order of the city council or who willfully or negligently failed to comply with any provision of this article and the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued under this article shall be fined for each offense. Each day on which a violation shall occur or continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. 
(2)  Any violations of this article shall follow the following fine schedule on monthly utility bills: 
a.  First offense, $250.00. 
b.  Second offense, $500.00. 
c.  Third offense, termination of service and $500.00 reconnection fee. 
(3)  In addition to the penalties provided herein, the city may recover reasonable attorneys' fees, court costs, court reporters' fees and other expenses of litigation by appropriate suit at law against the person found to have violated this article or the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued under this article. Any person, customer or consumer in violation of any of the provisions of this division shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage incurred by the city by reason of such violation. In addition to any penalty provided by law for the violation of any of the provisions of this division, the city may bring suit in the appropriate court to enjoin, restrain, or otherwise prevent the violation of any of the provisions of this division. 
(b)  Falsifying information. Any person who knowingly makes any false statement, representation or certification in any application, record, report, plan or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this article, or who falsifies, tampers with or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this article shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or by imprisonment for not more than six months, or by both. 
(c)  Code enforcement board. Any user aggrieved pursuant to the terms of this section may appeal said action to the city code enforcement board, or its successor entity. Such appeals shall be taken within 30 days of the date of notification to user of the penalty hereunder and shall be subject to a filing fee as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time for the initiation of the appeal. Notice of the appeal shall be timely provided to the office of the director of environmental utilities and shall specify the grounds on which the appeal is based. The code enforcement board shall consider the appeal at its next available hearing and determine whether a violation or violations have occurred as provided in chapter. In the event that the code enforcement board determines that the violation or violations did occur, the board shall deny the appeal and uphold the determination of the penalty, whereupon, the user shall have 15 days to pay the penalty. If the code enforcement board determines that the violation did not occur, then the board shall grant the appeal and the user shall be entitled to a return of the subject filing fee paid for this appeal. Alternatively or supplementary, compliance with this article may be enforced by direct action of the city before the city code enforcement board as provided by law. 
(Code 1994, § 78-217; Ord. No. 92-N-1, § XIV, 9-24-1992; Ord. No. 2008-014, § IV(78-217), 1-24-2008; Ord. No. 2008-40, § III(78-217), 7-10-2008) 
Sec. 44-293. - Introduction of fluoride into public water supply. 
(a)  The city manager and the appropriate employees of the municipal water system shall, as soon as practicable, prepare or cause to be prepared plans and specifications for the installation of the equipment necessary to introduce fluorides in quantities and in a manner conforming to the regulations set forth in F.A.C. ch. 64E-8 into the municipal water system. Upon completion of the plans and specifications they shall be submitted to the county health department as provided by law. 
(b)  Upon approval of the plans and specifications by the county health department and any other regulatory bodies having jurisdiction thereof, the city manager and appropriate employees of the municipal water system shall cause the equipment to be installed within nine months, and shall cause fluorides to be introduced into the water distributed by the water system. 
(Code 1967, § 27-2; Code 1994, § 78-219) 
Sec. 44-294. - Alternate meter installation. 
(a)  Individual standard specifications. 
(1)  Applications for an auxiliary meter permit shall be made in accordance with the existing standard application procedures established for potable water and irrigation water services to individual properties. 
(2)  Each service will be allowed up to three spigot connections. The spigot connections will be provided with a permanent hose bib vacuum breaker backflow device specifically designed for that purpose. (Hose bib breakers do not prevent back pressure flow, only back siphonage.) 
(3)  Water consumed through the water auxiliary meter may not be used for landscape irrigation purposes. (Connection of devices such as liquid chemical aspirator devices or similar suction devices is prohibited.) 
(4)  Use of water through the auxiliary meter is limited to private, on-site nonirrigation purposes, and it is not intended for human drinking (ingestion purposes). 
(5)  There shall be no direct or indirect connections and/or discharges to the city sanitary sewer system as a result of the operation and consumption of water through the auxiliary water meter system. 
(6)  Any hose connection to the spigot assembly using a positive closing action hose discharge nozzle assembly, normally available from hardware stores, shall prevent unattended discharge of water through the hose and/or the possibility of reentry of water through the end of the hose. 
(7)  Connection of auxiliary meters to an existing water service may require replacement of the existing service line to increase the capacity of the line, due to increased demand. Upgrading or replacement shall be at the property owner's expense. 
(8)  Charges for water use shall be at the same second meter irrigation rate as those currently in effect for second meter irrigation rates for residential consumption. 
(b)  Violations; penalties. Failure to comply with the interim policies and/or violations of these conditions shall result in the following enforcement action: 
(1)  The immediate termination of the auxiliary water service that jeopardizes the public health or violates the following specifications and requirements for use, without notice; and 
(2)  The prompt installation thereafter of a pressure vacuum backflow device as a minimum requirement (at the owner's expense) for restoration of service; and/or 
(3)  Any person, persons, firm or corporation, or agent of any person, persons, firm or corporation, who neglects, fails or refuses to comply with or violates any of the provisions of this section shall be fined in a sum not to exceed $250.00 per day for a first violation and $500.00 for each repeat violation, at the discretion of the code enforcement board. Each time such person, persons, firm or corporation neglects, fails or refuses to comply with any of the provisions of this section, it shall be deemed a separate offense and punished as herein provided. 
The imposition of penalties herein prescribed shall not preclude the city attorney from instituting an appropriate action or proceeding to prevent a violation of this section. As an alternative or as an additional means of collecting such costs as the city may incur in enforcement of this section, or making any reparations, the city shall have a lien on such lot or parcel of land for such cost, which lien shall be of equal dignity with the lien of state, county and municipal taxes. Such lien may be foreclosed by the city in the same manner provided by the laws of the state for the foreclosure of mortgages upon real estate. Costs shall mean all costs, including reasonable attorneys' fees, court costs, court reporters' expenses and any other expense of litigation. 
(c)  Standards and cost schedule. 
(1)  Attached to Ordinance No. 94-25 as Exhibit A is a draft diagram of a copy of a typical installation diagram for the auxiliary meter installation. The city's responsibility will be limited to the installation of the meter and meter box to which the plumbing connection can be made in accordance to current practices. 
(2)  All fees and charges in this section will be as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(d)  Restrictions. Water use through this meter is subject to the restrictions, regulations and policies established by city council relative to the water conservation ordinance. During a declared water emergency, water use through these meters will not be allowed. 
(Code 1994, § 78-220; Ord. No. 94-25, §§ I-IV, 6-9-1994; Ord. No. 2013-16, § I, 7-11-2013; Ord. No. 2016-05 , § 1, 2-11-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-05 , § 1, adopted Feb. 11, 2016, changed the title of § 44-294 from "Alternate meter installation for single-family residential property" to "Alternate meter installation." This historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Sec. 44-295. - Emergency acts. 
(a)  The city manager may interrupt the delivery of potable water service to any property when such suspension is necessary in the opinion of the city, in order to stop a violation of this article or any related regulation or to stop a threat which presents or may present an imminent or substantial endangerment to the health and welfare of persons, the environment, or causes the city to violate any conditions of its SFWMD, FDEP or other operating permits. Any such interruption shall continue until such time deemed appropriate by the city manager for resumption of service to the subject property. 
(b)  The city manager may take whatever emergency action he deems necessary and appropriate to protect persons or property from any injury, loss or damage which may reasonably be expected to result from each specific violation of this article or any related regulation. The customer shall be responsible for all costs incurred by the city for any emergency measures performed by or at the request of the city as a result of such a violation attributed to the customer's potable system or operation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2008-014, § IV(78-218), 1-24-2008) 
Secs. 44-296-44-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 44-311. - Metered connections. 
    All commercial and church connections and connections outside of the city shall be metered. 
(Code 1967, § 27-17; Code 1994, § 78-231) 
Sec. 44-312. - Fee for meter of six-inch or larger capacity. 
    All water meters of six-inch or larger capacity will pay a meter fee as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time per month to the city, such sum being paid in addition to any water service fee or charge payable under any other provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 27-22; Code 1994, § 78-232) 
Sec. 44-313. - Charges for water taps. 
(a)  Inside city limits. Water taps inside the city limits shall be as follows: 
(1)  Three-quarter inch: the amount as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(2)  One to 11/2 inch: the amount as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(3)  Larger than 11/2 inch: Time and materials with a minimum charge as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(b)  Outside city limits. Charges for water taps outside the city limits shall be at the rate of 1.5 times those inside the city. 
(c)  Service pipe costs. The above charges apply only to a service requiring no more than 30 feet of service pipe from the main to the property line. Any costs over 30 feet shall be in addition to the above charges. 
(d)  Paving replacement. In any case where it is necessary to cut into paved surface or street, the cost of replacement of paving shall be in addition to the above charges. 
(Code 1967, § 27-23; Code 1994, § 78-233; Ord. No. 2013-16, § II, 7-11-2013) 
Secs. 44-314-44-330. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - INSTATEMENT, SERVICE, VOLUME AND FACILITY CHARGES AND DEPOSITS 

Sec. 44-331. - Residential, general service and high risk prepayments. 
(a)  A single-family residential water service prepayment as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time shall be paid to the city by the customer at or before commencement of water service to such customer, except as provided for in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  A single residential water service prepayment may not be required provided the following conditions are satisfied: 
(1)  The customer has a satisfactory credit rating per the credit screening vendor the city utilizes. 
(2)  Within the immediate 24 months preceding the commencement of service, the customer has two calendar years of satisfactory payment of a residential water service with the city. 
(3)  The customer provides a letter from a public utility provider for electric, water or sewer service that demonstrates a satisfactory payment history of a residential service with the utility provider within the immediate 24 months preceding the commencement of service. 
(c)  Prepayments for single-family residential water service shall be applied to the customer's bill after two calendar years of satisfactory payment of the account. Prepayments not refunded within 24 months shall be paid interest on the original dollars annually (not compounded) at a rate specified during the budget process, but not more than six percent. All interest earned will be applied to the customer's bill at the time of termination or at the next billing period after two calendar years of satisfactory payment of the account. 
(d)  A service other than single-family residential service prepayment equal to the base and consumption charges for one and one-half months' services for the history at that address, but not less than the amount on as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time, to the service address, as estimated by the water utility, shall be paid to the city by the customer at or before commencement of water service to such customer at any single service address, and if any customer shall receive water service at more than one service address, a prepayment shall be required and paid for each such service address, except as provided for in subsection (e) of this section. The prepayment shall be retained by the city until the account is terminated. If their service shall be disconnected for nonpayment, the prepayment shall be applied to payment of the account after disconnection. 
(e)  For prepayments in excess of an amount as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time in place of a cash prepayment, the customer may, at the discretion of the city manager or his designee, provide the city with a letter of credit from a bank with a branch office located within the corporate limits of the city or a surety bond issued by a surety company with no less than an A-rating by the A.M. Best Rating Agency. The letter of credit or surety agreement must allow the city manager or his designee to execute the letter of credit or surety agreement in favor of the city for payment of the utility bill of the customer. 
(f)  Any customer may be charged an administrative high risk water service prepayment based on nonsatisfactory payment credit history resulting in a poor credit rating for the service address in question during the previous 24-month period. This amount will not exceed three times the regularly calculated prepayment amount for the service address in question. If sufficient payment history is not available, the high risk prepayment shall be in the amount estimated by the city manager or his designee. 
(g)  Any customer having been granted two extensions of the due date for payment of a utility bill in any 12-month period shall be required to pay a payment arrangement fee per additional arrangement. The payment arrangement fee as adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time shall be billed to the customer. 
(Code 1967, § 27-18; Code 1994, § 78-246; Ord. No. 91-M, § 26, 3-21-1991; Ord. No. 96-24, § II, 10-10-1996; Ord. No. 2013-14, § VI, 7-11-2013) 
Sec. 44-332. - Potable water account-Name. 
    A potable water account shall be established in the name of the customer, who shall be the owner, or the owner's tenant, of any residential unit or general service unit for which the potable water impact fee has been paid or otherwise satisfied. There shall be a separate potable water account for each residential unit and for each general service unit; however, all residential units served by a water meter which serves more than one unit, i.e., served by a master water meter shall constitute a single potable water account. Extraordinary physical service water meter connections for residential units, general service units or mixed units shall be governed by regulations as authorized in this article. 
(Code 1994, § 78-247; Ord. No. 91-M, § 16, 3-21-1991) 
Sec. 44-333. - Same-Instatement charge imposed. 
    As a primary method of funding the costs of establishing (instatement) or reestablishing (reinstatement) a potable water account for such water service, there is imposed a potable water account instatement charge upon each residential unit and each general service unit served with municipal potable water service. 
(Code 1994, § 78-248; Ord. No. 91-M, § 17, 3-21-1991) 
Sec. 44-334. - Same-Instatement charge amount. 
    The amount of the potable water account instatement charge is set at the amount as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time; provided however: 
(1)  All residential or general service units with potable water service existing on April 1, 1991, shall be exempt from the initial potable water account instatement charge; but 
(2)  Each residential unit and general service unit for which a potable water impact fee is paid on and after April 1, 1991, shall be exempt from the initial potable water account instatement charge; but 
(3)  All subsequent instatement or reinstatements of a potable water account shall pay the full potable water account instatement charge. 
(Code 1994, § 78-249; Ord. No. 91-M, § 18, 3-21-1991) 
Sec. 44-335. - Monthly potable water charge imposed. 
    A charge for potable water service for residential and general service units is levied and established consisting of a monthly potable water facility charge and a monthly potable water volume charge. These facility and volume charges are set forth in the rate schedules referenced in section 44-336. 
(Code 1994, § 78-250; Ord. No. 91-M, § 19, 3-21-1991) 
Sec. 44-336. - Potable water facility charge-Rate schedule. 
(a)  The potable water facility charge represents an availability fee for potable water service. The minimum monthly potable water charge, even with no usage, shall be the monthly potable water facility charge. Additionally, the minimum monthly potable water facility charge for multifamily residential units served by a master water meter shall be the product of the number of residential units served by the master meter and the appropriate charge in the rate schedule for a three-quarter-inch or smaller water meter located inside or outside the municipal limits of the city as applicable. For all other residential and general service connections, the facility charge shall be as shown on the rate schedule and shall be the appropriate rate for the water meter size and property location, being inside or outside the municipal limits of the city. The rate schedule and any changes thereto shall be adopted by resolution of the city council and maintained on file in the city clerk's office. 
(b)  Staff shall bring forward any proposed rate schedule adjustments for potable water facility rates to the city manager. Provided that the recommendation is consistent with rate provisions in effect per a resolution adopted in accordance with subsection (a) of this section. All proposed adjustments shall require that the city manager properly advertise and hold a separate public hearing at which time the recommendation shall be presented to city council for approval. 
(Code 1994, § 78-251; Ord. No. 91-M, § 20, 3-21-1991; Ord. No. 91-V, § 2, 5-23-1991; Ord. No. 2003-49, § II, 10-23-2003; Ord. No. 2008-68, § IV(78-251), 1-8-2009; Ord. No. 2014-27, § IV, 7-10-2014; Ord. No. 2016-57 , § IV, 11-17-2016) 
Sec. 44-337. - Same-Customer other than owner. 
    For a residential unit or a general service unit where the customer is other than the owner, the customer's monthly statement, the utility bill, shall reflect the monthly potable facility charge. 
(Code 1994, § 78-252; Ord. No. 91-M, § 21, 3-21-1991) 
Sec. 44-338. - Same-Vacant premises. 
    In the case of a vacant residential unit or a vacant general service unit, the potable facility charge as levied and established in section 44-335 shall be against the owner, and the owner's monthly statement, the utility bill, shall reflect such potable water facility charge. 
(Code 1994, § 78-253; Ord. No. 91-M, § 22, 3-21-1991) 
Sec. 44-339. - Same-Discontinuance. 
    The owner of any residential unit or any general service unit may make written application to terminate such unit's potable water account to, and on a form to be supplied by, the city manager. Where such unit is not being utilized and all city accounts for such unit due by the owner are current, the unit's potable water account and the corresponding potable water service to the unit shall terminate. Thereafter, reinstatement of municipal potable water service shall require potable water account instatement and the associated charge. See sections 44-333 and 44-334. 
(Code 1994, § 78-254; Ord. No. 91-M, § 23, 3-21-1991) 
Sec. 44-340. - Potable water volume charge. 
(a)  The potable water volume charge together with the potable water facility charge equals the monthly potable water charge in section 44-335. The potable water volume charge shall be the product of the metered number of each 1,000 gallons of potable water used and the applicable rate for the consumption interval and property location, being inside or outside the municipal limits of the city. The rate schedule is on file in the city clerk's office and may be changed from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  Staff shall bring forward any proposed rate schedule adjustments for potable water volume charges to the city manager. Provided that the recommendation is consistent with rate provisions in effect per a resolution adopted in accordance with subsection (a) of this section. All proposed adjustments shall require that the city manager properly advertise and hold a separate public hearing at which time the recommendation shall be presented to city council for approval. 
(Code 1994, § 78-255; Ord. No. 91-M, § 24, 3-21-1991; Ord. No. 91-V, § 4, 5-23-1991; Ord. No. 2003-49, § III, 10-23-2003; Ord. No. 2008-68, § IV(78-255), 1-8-2009; Ord. No. 2014-27, § IV, 7-10-2014; Ord. No. 2016-57 , § IV, 11-17-2016) 
Sec. 44-341. - Collection and billing. 
    The monthly potable water charge imposed pursuant to section 44-335 shall be collected by the city and deposited in the water system revenue fund, and no monies in excess of 9.5 percent of the combined potable water, reclaimed water, and sanitary sewer system metered revenue shall be transferred out of the water and sewer enterprise funds as an administrative transfer. In no case shall an administrative transfer cause the net income for the fund to be negative. For the purpose of establishing the budget in any given year, metered revenue shall refer to the second prior year's metered revenue collected. The term "administrative transfer" used within this section, is defined as a nonreciprocal transfer of revenues, meaning there is not a cost of service associated with this transfer. This administrative transfer is further defined as a return on investments of the water and sewer utility to the city. This section shall not be construed to prevent or establish the transfer of funds for reasonable administrative costs and those required by bond or loan covenants. Each customer, i.e., each unit service address, shall be billed monthly for services rendered, and if not paid within 15 days from the date of billing, the potable water service for such unit service address may be discontinued until all delinquent charges for such potable water service have been paid in full. 
(Code 1967, § 27-21; Code 1994, § 78-256; Ord. No. 91-M, § 25, 3-21-1991; Ord. No. 2003-49, § IV, 10-23-2003; Ord. No. 2008-68, § IV(78-256), 1-8-2009) 
Sec. 44-342. - Enforcement. 
    Any unpaid potable water monthly service charges shall become a lien against the property or premises served and shall be of equal status as an ad valorem tax lien against the property. In addition and supplemental thereto, compliance herewith shall be enforced by the city code enforcement board as provided by law and relief on open account/account stated may be sought before a state court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1967, § 27-19; Code 1994, § 78-257; Ord. No. 91-M, § 27, 3-21-1991) 
State Law reference- Limitation on liens, F.S. § 180.135. 
Sec. 44-343. - Backflow installation, certification, testing, and repair; fee imposed. 
(a)  Installation of backflow protection devices. 
(1)  All customers served with potable water by the city shall be subject to the requirements of the city cross connection control manual and shall install and maintain backflow protective devices per the cross connection control manual and as required herein. 
(2)  For all multifamily services and all general service connections, the customer shall be responsible for the coordination and cost of installing the required device and providing satisfactory test results and certification of the device's performance to the city prior to initiation of service or within 60 days of notification by the city of any noncompliance with the city's cross connection control manual. Failure to comply with the requirements of the cross connection control manual shall constitute grounds for termination of service. 
(3)  For new, single-family residential connections served by reclaimed water for irrigation or located in an area served or intended to be served by reclaimed water irrigation, the city shall be responsible for the installation, testing and certification of the initial backflow protective device placement. Costs for this service shall be recovered through the initial service tap fee. 
(4)  For new, single-family residential connections and modifications to existing single-family residential sites served by potable water irrigation or otherwise requiring installation of a backflow protective device, the customer shall be responsible for the coordination and cost of installing the required devices. The city shall inspect, test, and certify the proper operation of the device prior to the initiation of service. 
(5)  The city shall coordinate installation of a backflow protection device and impose a backflow installation fee for the following customers: 
a.  Existing single-family residential potable water customers who have not installed a backflow protection device and provided certification to the environmental utilities department within 60 days of notification by the city. These customers are not in compliance with the cross connection control manual and are required to install a backflow protection device. 
b.  Existing single-family residential potable water customers who after being notified by the city that they are not compliant with the cross connection control manual elect to have the city perform the backflow protection device installation 
For the above-listed customers, the backflow installation fee shall be based upon the most recent cost experience and shall be established by resolution. The city council may revise the backflow installation fee from time to time by resolution. The installation fee shall be adjusted based upon recent cost experience or the current consumer price index as necessary to provide for all associated costs of said installation including labor materials, and parts. The cost of providing this service shall be assessed either via a single payment or by installment payments with the monthly utility bill over a one year period to include estimated interest costs and administrative fees as established by resolution. 
(6)  The following customers are exempted from the backflow installation fee: 
a.  Those customers who have a backflow protection device installed by certified personnel approved by the city environmental utilities department and provide backflow certification to the city within 60 days of notification. 
b.  All customers connected to the city's potable water system as of April 30, 1993, the effective date of the city's cross connection control program, that would have been required to install a backflow protection device per the cross connection control program. If the customer has created conditions that require a backflow device per the cross connection control manual since April 30, 1993, such customer is not exempt. 
(b)  Testing, repair and replacement. 
(1)  The consumer shall bear all responsibility and expenses for installing, testing, and maintaining the protection devices required by the cross connection control manual to ensure proper operation on a continuing basis with the exception that those backflow devices serving individual, single-family residential properties, shall be tested annually, certified, and when necessary repaired by the city. However the responsibility for the cost of such city provided services shall remain with the customer and shall be collected via a monthly backflow testing, certification and repair fee. 
(2)  The city council may revise the monthly backflow testing, certification, and repair fee from time to time by resolution, or in the alternative, with the annual budget presented to the city council. The city manager or his designee shall recommend a revised backflow testing, certification, and repair fee that is either based upon most recent cost experience or the current consumer price index. The city manager is authorized and directed to set and give notice of a public hearing at which his recommendation shall be presented to the city council. Unless the city council takes action to the contrary, this cost shall be used to establish and update the amount of the backflow testing, certification, and repair fee applicable each billing month and shall be effective upon the first day of each calendar year following adoption of the budget. The cost of providing this annual service shall be assessed in monthly installments with the monthly utility bill. 
(3)  For all multifamily services, and all general service connections, the customer shall be responsible for providing test results and certification annually to the city, including documentation of completion of any required repairs and/or replacement. Installation, testing, maintenance, and repair/replacement of all protective devices shall be in accordance with the cross connection control manual and conducted by certified personnel approved by the city. Failure to comply with the requirements of the cross connection control manual shall constitute grounds for termination of service. 
(Code 1994, § 78-258; Ord. No. 2003-49, § V, 10-23-2003; Ord. No. 2008-021, § II(78-258), 5-22-2008) 
Secs. 44-344-44-360. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - IMPACT FEES 

Sec. 44-361. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means the person who applies for a certificate of capacity or building permit. 
    Building permit means an official document or certificate issued by the city authorizing the commencement of construction of any structure. 
    Capital improvement includes the planning of, engineering for, acquisition of land or equipment, and the construction of improvements for potable water facilities and infrastructure. 
    Certificate of capacity means an official document, issued by the city, on which is recorded the reservation of capacity of public facilities for a development. The certificate shall contain a legal description of the property on which development will occur, the name of the applicant and property owner, the type of development, the assumptions used in assessing capacity needs, the amounts of capacity reserved for public facilities, and the length of time and conditions for which such capacity is reserved. 
    City manager means the city manager or the professionally qualified city officials he may designate to manage and observe the operation of the publicly owned treatment works and who is charged with certain duties and responsibilities under this division or his duly authorized representative. 
    Comprehensive plan means the comprehensive plan of the city adopted and amended pursuant to the Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act. 
    Equivalent residential unit (ERU) means the base unit for assessment of impact fees determined to produce estimated use factors of 300 gallons per day of water and shall include a single-family residence of conventional construction, a mobile home, a single-family unit of a multiple-family dwelling, or a single-family rental unit. 
    Feepayer means any person who seeks to develop land by applying for a building permit to make an improvement to land which will generate additional impacts or who seeks to place a mobile home on an approved mobile home lot, shall be required to pay impact fees in the manner and amount set forth in the ordinances of the city. 
    Gallons per day or GPD means the gallons per day on an annual average basis. 
    General service land development means all land development and uses other than residential. 
    Impact fee component means that portion of the impact fee attributable the potable water imposed by the city pursuant to section 44-364. 
    Impact generating land development activity (off-site or on-site) means an activity which requires either new off-site or new on-site potable water service/capacity as a result of an increased number of residential or general service buildings, or plumbing fixtures on subject land. 
    Meter means a potable water meter, used to measure the amount of water delivered. 
    Off-site improvement means improvements located outside the boundaries of the parcel proposed for development. 
    On-site improvement means improvements located inside of the boundaries of the parcel proposed for development; and those required off-site improvements necessary to connect to existing city potable water system, including but not limited to, rights-of-way/easements, and pumping stations shall be considered on-site improvements, regardless of their actual location. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental entity or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. The masculine gender shall include the feminine, the singular shall include the plural where indicated in the context. 
    Reclaimed water or effluent means water, treated wastewater or sewer effluent that has been appropriately treated and which, as a result of the treatment of wastes, is suitable and usable for direct beneficial uses or a controlled use by and for public agricultural, commercial, residential or industrial developments, projects or purposes including, but not limited to, irrigation purposes in green areas of developments or other appropriate areas. 
    Significant industrial potable water user means any industrial user of the city's potable water system who: 
(1)  Has a potable water demand of 28,000 gallons or more per average workday; or 
(2)  Is found by the city, or by any state or federal regulatory agency, to be a significant industrial user under the laws of such agency. 
(Code 1967, § 27-32; Code 1994, § 78-266; Ord. No. 92-N-1, § III, 9-24-1992) 
Sec. 44-362. - Rules of construction. 
(a)  The provisions of this division shall be liberally construed so as to effectively carry out its purpose in the interest of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(b)  For the purposes of administration and enforcement of this division, unless otherwise stated in this division, the following rules of construction shall apply to the text of this division: 
(1)  In case of any difference of meaning or implication between the text of this division and any caption, illustration, summary, table or illustrative table, the text shall control. 
(2)  The word "shall" is always mandatory and not discretionary; the word "may" is permissive.
