(3)  The phrase "used for" includes "arranged for," "designed for," "maintained for" or "occupied for." 
(4)  Unless the context clearly indicates the contrary, where a regulation involves two or more items, conditions, provisions or events connected by the conjunction "and," "or" or "either ... or" the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows: 
a.  "And" indicates that all the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events shall apply. 
b.  "Or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events may apply singly or in any combination. 
c.  "Either ... or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions, or events shall apply singly but not in combination. 
(5)  The word "include" or "includes" shall not limit a term to the specific example but is intended to extend its meaning to all other instances or circumstances of like kind or character. 
(Code 1994, § 78-267; Ord. No. 92-N-1, § II, 9-24-1992) 
Sec. 44-363. - Imposition and determination of fee; annual review. 
(a)  Fee imposition. There is hereby imposed upon all impact generating land development activity a potable water impact fee due prior to the city's placement of a water meter for new construction Payment shall be made in the form of cash, cashier's check, or certified check; however, other forms of payment shall be accepted provided they are received two weeks prior the placement of a water meter. The fee shall be determined in accordance with the schedules set forth in this article. However, if the building permit is for less than the entire contemplated development, the fee shall be computed for the amount of development covered by the permit. In the case of an addition to a building presently connected to the potable water system, the impact fee shall be paid prior to the issuance of a building permit for the construction of such addition, as provided in subsection (a)(1)(d) of this section. The obligation for payment of impact fees shall run with the land, as shall the resulting privilege. 
(b)  Determination of fee. Except as otherwise provided herein, the potable water impact fee shall be determined by the following: 
(1)  Residential and general service. 
a.  As a condition to providing offsite improvements for the potable water system, all residential land developments serviced by a three-quarter-inch meter shall be charged the amount approved by resolution of the city council, and on file in the city clerk's office per equivalent residential unit (ERU), wherein one ERU equals 300 gallons per day (GPD) of potable water flow. A residential land development serviced by a three-quarter-inch meter shall be considered to be equal to one ERU. Meter size shall be in accordance with AWWA recommended standards. 
b.  As a condition to providing offsite improvements for the potable water system all residential land developments served by a meter size larger than three-quarter inch, and all general service land developments shall be charged the amount as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time per equivalent residential unit (ERU), wherein on ERU equals 300 gallons per day (GPD) of potable water flow. The method of calculating the number of ERUs shall be based upon the estimated water flow as calculated by a meter size equivalency factor. The equivalent meter concept relates the flow for those meters larger than three-quarters inch to that of the volume of flow for a three-quarters-inch meter. The three-quarters-inch water meter size is the size most frequently used by the residential customer. A factor relates the non-three-quarters-inch meter to the three-quarters-inch meter flow as used in the potable water utility rate structure. 
Meter Size Equivalency Factor 3/4? 1.00 1? 1.67 1&half? 3.33 2? 5.33 3? 10.00 4? 16.67 6? 33.33 8? 50.00 10? 133.33 12? 186.67 14? 250.00 16? 304.67  
Meter Size Equivalency Factor = ERUs 
The applicant may submit a written request for consideration of an alternate ERU calculation or meter size. Any such request must be accompanied by a water use estimate that is signed and sealed by a professional engineer. This alternative ERU calculation is subject to approval by the city manager or his designee. 
c.  The minimum impact fee for all residential land developments serviced by a water meter sizes larger than three-quarters inch and all general service land developments shall be one ERU per each unit. 
d.  Additions to existing residential or general service building. There shall be no additional impact fee due when application is made for a building permit to construct any addition to a single-family residential building serviced by a three-quarter-inch meter. When application is made for a building permit to construct any addition to a residential building serviced by a meter size larger than three-quarters inch, or any general service building which will increase the demand for water service to the building or structure already connected to the city potable water system, impact fees for such addition shall be paid prior to the issuance of a building permit for its construction, and potable water impact fees to be paid for such additions shall be calculated based on the total number of ERUs which are calculated using the formula described in (b.) above. 
(2)  Industrial users special provisions. Industrial users that are determined to be significant industrial potable water users may be required to pay potable water impact fees as may be established by the city manager, guided by industry standards, toward the goal of just and equitable fees. No fee less than the fee required of a general service user, but for this provision, shall be set until approved by the city council, and no fee more than the fee required of a general service user, but for this provision, shall be set until approved by the user. In the event of any dispute in the latter case, the city council shall be the final authority. 
(3)  Redevelopment or replacement. Where new development involves the redevelopment of land such that existing impact generating development is removed or substantially altered, the new development impact fees shall be computed on the additional or new impacts only. Impact fees shall be computed for the existing development and such sum shall then be subtracted from the impact fees calculated for the new development. The property shall receive an impact fee credit based on the number of equivalent residential units (ERU's). The ERU credit shall be equal to the greater of: 1) number of (ERUs) assessed at time of original impact fee payment for the existing development, if available; or 
a.  The number of ERU's currently vested based upon the meter size in use or historically used at the property at any point the property was served by the city's potable water system. Prior use or credit information is subject to verification and approval by the city manager or his designee. It is the city's intent to collect impact fees for only that additional impact generated by redevelopment over and above the impact attributable to the existing development. 
b.  Outside-the-city surcharge. In addition to the uniform potable water impact fees herein imposed, there is hereby imposed, on all outside-the-city off-site impact generating land development activity, a surcharge equal to 25 percent of such uniform potable water impact fees, due, payable, and collectable in the same manner as that prescribed for the otherwise uniform potable water impact fees. 
(c)  Periodic review of water impact fee amounts. The city manager shall periodically review the fees adopted by resolution as set forth in this section. The review period shall not exceed five years. 
(Code 1967, § 27-31; Code 1994, § 78-268; Ord. No. 92-N-1, § IV, 9-24-1992; Ord. No. 2003-06, § I, 2-13-2003; Ord. No. 2006-152, § I(78-268), 11-9-2006; Ord. No. 2010-051, § 1, 12-9-2010) 
Sec. 44-364. - Property using on-site water well when city potable water service is available. 
    Any property utilizing an on-site water well despite the availability of city potable water service to such property shall not be required to connect to the city potable water system until such time as its on-site water well shall malfunction and require replacement or until public health authorities shall determine that the on-site well water is unsafe for human consumption. At that time any such property shall connect to the city potable water system. 
(Code 1994, § 78-269; Ord. No. 92-N-1, § V, 9-24-1992) 
Sec. 44-365. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The following shall be exempted from the payment of potable water impact fees to the extent there is no increase in impact associated with the property or use: 
(1)  Minor alterations. Alteration or minor expansions of an existing structure where the use, number of housing units, or number of fixture units in the case of nonresidential construction is not changed. 
(2)  Accessory building. The construction of an accessory building or structures. 
(3)  Replacement. A replacement of a building or structure with a new building or structure of the same use provided that no additional impact to the potable water system is created by such replacement. 
(4)  Public schools. Public school facilities as exempted by F.S. § 1013.371(1)(a). 
(b)  Owners or occupants of property in the east of the city water system area who were participants in a community development block grant from the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, Project No. B-78-BS-12-0118 on April 24, 1979, are specifically exempt from any water service impact fee heretofore imposed by the city. 
(Code 1967, § 21-63; Code 1994, § 78-270; Ord. No. 91-H-2, § 23-37, 12-19-1991; Ord. No. 92-N-1, § XI, 9-24-1992) 
Sec. 44-366. - Alternative impact fee calculation authorized for potable water users. 
    If an applicant believes that the cost of improvements needed to serve his industrial development is less than the fee established under this division, the applicant may submit an alternative fee calculation to the city manager pursuant to the provisions of section 44-367. If the city manager finds that the data, information, assumptions, formulae and methodology used by the applicant to calculate the alternative impact fee satisfy the subject requirements, the alternative impact fee shall be deemed the impact fee due and owing for the proposed development. 
(Code 1994, § 78-271; Ord. No. 92-N-1, § VI, 9-24-1992) 
Sec. 44-367. - Procedure for review of alternative impact fee calculation for users. 
(a)  Alternate calculations. The alternative impact fee calculation shall be based on data, information, assumptions, formulae and methodology contained in this article and the studies prepared by independent sources, provided that: 
(1)  The independent source is an accepted standard source of engineering and planning data or information; 
(2)  The independent source is a local study carried out by a qualified planner or engineer pursuant to an accepted methodology of planning or engineering; or 
(3)  Where different data, information, assumptions, formulae or methodology are employed, such differences shall be specifically identified and justified. 
(b)  Submission. An alternative impact fee calculation shall be undertaken through the submission of an application for review of an alternative impact fee calculation for the impact fee component for which an alternative impact fee calculation is requested. 
(c)  City manager determination. Within 20 days of receipt of an application for review of an alternative impact fee calculation, the city manager shall determine if the application is complete. If the city manager determines that the application is not complete, he shall send a written statement specifying the deficiencies by mail to the person submitting the application. The application shall be deemed complete if no deficiencies are specified. The city manager shall take no further action on the application until it is deemed complete. 
(d)  City manager review. When the city manager determines the application is complete, he shall review it and render a written decision in 30 days on whether the fee should be modified, and if so, what the amount should be. 
(e)  Adjustment by agreement. If the city manager finds that the data, information, assumptions, formulae and/or methodology used by the applicant to compute the alternative impact fee calculation satisfies the requirements hereof, the fee determined in the alternative impact fee calculation shall be deemed the fee due and owing for the proposed land development activity. This adjustment in the fee shall be set forth in a fee agreement which shall be entered into pursuant to section 44-369. 
(f)  Appeal. A determination by the city manager that the alternative impact fee calculation does not satisfy the requirements of this section may be appealed to the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 78-272; Ord. No. 92-N-1, § VII, 9-24-1992) 
Sec. 44-368. - Revenue restrictions; return of unused funds. 
(a)  Potable water fund restricted account-impact fee. All potable water impact fees heretofore and hereafter collected shall be held in a trust fund known as the water fund restricted account-impact fee. Funds may be appropriated from this trust fund only by the city council upon its determination that the proposed expenditure is for the expansion of the system, as below provided. Any improvement which directly or indirectly is associated with expansion may be determined by the city council, at their sole discretion, to be an expansion of the system, and nothing contained in this section shall prohibit same. 
(b)  Identification of funds to meet deficiency. When the city council determines that the purpose of a proposed capital improvement, in whole or part, is to overcome a deficiency not attributable to new growth and development, then the city manager shall identify sources of funds to meet such deficiency proportion of the improvement for city council approval prior to the utilization of any impact fees. 
(c)  Fund use, limitation. The collected impact fees shall be used solely for the purpose of acquisition, expansion and development of the capital assets, including debt service determined to be needed to serve new development, to include the principal and interest of loans or parts of loans. 
(d)  Refund. All funds derived from potable water impact fees shall be expended on a first-in, first-out basis. Any such funds, not expended within seven years of their collection date, upon the generating property's then owner's timely application, shall be refunded to such owner. To be timely an application shall be received by the city manager within eight years of the subject collection date. No fee refund shall be made without timely application, and any funds remaining more than eight years after collection shall be deemed abandoned. With his annual budget to the city council, the city manager shall make report as to abandoned potable water impact funds and recommend appropriation improving potable water service. 
(Code 1967, § 27-36; Code 1994, § 78-273; Ord. No. 92-N-1, § VIII, 9-24-1992) 
Sec. 44-369. - Presumptions, agreement and security requirements. 
(a)  Maximum potable water impact generated. The proposed development shall be presumed to generate the maximum impact generated by the development in accordance with the approved site plan and/or requested building permits. 
(b)  Special potable water impact fee agreement. In lieu of the payment of fees as calculated in section 44-363, any applicant may propose to enter into an impact agreement with the city designed to establish just and equitable fees or their equivalent and standards of service appropriate to the circumstances of the specific development proposed. Such an agreement shall include, but shall not be limited to, provisions which: 
(1)  Modify the presumption of maximum impact set forth in subsection (a) of this section, and provide an impact fee which may differ from that set forth in section 44-363 by specifying the nature of the proposed development for the purposes of computing actual impact, provided that the agreement shall establish legally enforceable means for ensuring that the impact will not exceed the impact generated by the agreed upon development. 
(2)  Permit the construction of specific improvements in lieu of, or with a credit against, the impact fees component developer to recover the actual cost of such improvements in excess of the amount which would have been assessed hereunder. 
(3)  Any agreement proposed by an applicant pursuant to this subsection (b) shall be, with formal public hearing and after recommendation by the planning commission, presented to and approved by the city council prior to the issuance of a building permit. Any such agreement may provide for execution by mortgagees, lienholders or contract purchasers in addition to the landowner, and may permit any party to record such agreement in the official records of the county. The city council shall approve such an agreement only if it finds that the agreement will apportion the burden of expenditure for new facilities in a just and equitable manner, consistent with the principal of rational nexus as set forth in state law. 
(c)  Homestead installment payments. For any property designated as a homestead under F.S. ch. 222, the city council may permit the potable water impact fee to be paid by installments in lieu of the fee payment requirements in section 44-363, as the particular circumstances shall dictate. Evidence of the debt due, reflecting the payment terms, together with evidence of a marketable lien encumbering the property served, shall be executed in recordable form and the evidence of lien together with a copy of the evidence of debt shall be filed in the public records of the county. 
(Code 1994, § 78-274; Ord. No. 92-N-1, § IX, 9-24-1992; Ord. No. 2008-15, § I(78-274), 1-24-2008) 
Sec. 44-370. - Credits. 
(a)  Generally. An applicant shall be entitled to a credit against any potable water impact fee component assessed in an amount equal to the cost of off-site improvements contributed or previously contributed, paid for or committed to by the applicant or his predecessor in interest as a condition of any development permit required and/or issued by the city for the same development or for excess production or transmission capacity constructed by the applicant or his predecessor in interest where such excess capacity is constructed at the request of the city. Credit for same must be agreed to by the city in advance of construction or creation of the excess capacity and provided for in a potable water impact fee agreement. Improvements required by previous development permits shall not be given a credit unless they meet the requirements of this subsection. 
(b)  Credit nontransferable. Credit for contributions, payments, construction or dedications of any potable water impact fee component shall not be transferable to another component. Credit shall be transferable only within the same component and within the same development. 
(c)  Credit application. The credit determination shall be made by the city manager upon application. The application shall include: 
(1)  A drawing of the contributed or to be contributed improvement prepared by an engineer registered by the state showing his seal. 
(2)  An appraisal of the contributed or to be contributed land fixing value of the land as of the date of issuance of earliest building permit, actual contribution or agreement to contribute, whichever is earliest. 
(3)  The actual cost, with appropriate documentation, or projected cost, with appropriate documentation, of any improvement contributed or to be constructed and contributed. 
(d)  Credit agreement. If the application for credit is approved by the city manager a credit agreement shall be prepared and signed by the applicant and the city. It shall specifically outline the contribution, payment, construction or land dedication, the time by which it shall be completed, dedicated, or paid, and any extensions thereof, and the dollar credit the applicant shall receive for the contribution, payment, construction or land. 
(e)  Appeal. A determination by the city manager as to an application for credit may be appealed to the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 78-275; Ord. No. 92-N-1, § X, 9-24-1992) 
Secs. 44-371-44-390. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - EXTENSION OF SERVICE 

Sec. 44-391. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Contribution-in-aid-of-construction (C.I.A.C.) means and includes those payments that are received by the city from any fee payor, contributor or person defined previously that are applied to the funding of waterage improvements that are defined as miscellaneous water line extensions. 
    Cost and costs include all costs of labor, materials, equipment, rents, engineering, financing, real property, easements and rights-of-way, legal and other similar expenses, and incidental costs. 
    Miscellaneous water line extension means a water line designed and constructed to provide service to either properties/lots that are abutting or are serviceable by means of private easement or rights-of-way provided and held by the applicant. 
    Potable waterage means a term coined to describe the physical system used by the city for acquisition, treatment and distribution of water for human consumption; it includes the pipes, pumps, tanks, standpipes, mains, control devises and all other like appurtenances and facilities. 
(Code 1994, § 78-286; Ord. No. 92-L-1, § 1(27-41, 27-50), 9-10-1992; Ord. No. 96-17, § 1, 6-27-1996) 
Sec. 44-392. - New individual residential or general services. 
(a)  New individual residential or general services potable water service shall be provided to a subject property, upon the applicant's compliance with: 
(1)  The provisions of this division; and 
(2)  All applicable new service request procedures and requirements, including reclaimed water requirements, the payment of all applicable fees at appropriate rates, and written application for service on forms provided by the city manager. 
(b)  Under this division there shall be no waterage extension requirements nor any direct waterage extension charges for new potable water service, for individual residential service or general service; provided: 
(1)  There is in place, abutting the subject property, suitable waterage for the service requested. Suitable waterage is that system, which under acceptable engineering principals and practices, will adequately serve the subject property without reducing the level of service, to other customers served thereby, below an acceptable standard as the city manager may determine, guided by competent engineering advice upon the stated principals, practices, and standards; and 
(2)  For projects outside the city, the applicant has: 
a.  Paid to the city the applicable fee for annexation review of the subject property; 
b.  Filed with the city a petition for annexation executed by the fee simple owner; and 
c.  Had recorded among the public records of the county a notice of and encumbrance to annex, on a form provided by the city manager, which gives assurances from the fee simple owner that the subject property shall be annexed to the city upon all other legal requirements being met, to occur at the convenience of the city council. 
(c)  Where there is not suitable waterage for the new individual residential or general services potable water service requested, abutting the subject property, waterage extensions shall be required. 
(Code 1994, § 78-287; Ord. No. 92-L-1, § 1(27-42), 9-10-1992) 
Sec. 44-393. - Types of waterage extensions. 
(a)  Waterage extensions are either primary extensions, secondary extensions or miscellaneous water line extensions; any extension not a primary extension is a secondary extension. All cost associated with secondary extensions shall be the sole responsibility of the applicant. 
(b)  The term "primary extension" includes all fire-flow/potable-water transmission/distribution piping eight inches in diameter or larger, all required up-stream appurtenances and facilities, and all fire-flow appurtenances (fire hydrants) on immediately downstream piping which is designed to serve, and in fact serves, only fire-flow appurtenances. 
(c)  The term "secondary extension" includes (when line designed as in subsection (b) of this section) any distribution piping (except as included in subsection (b) of this section immediately above) which is required for individual residential or individual general service potable water service, or is required for fire service and distribution of potable water within new subdivisions or within new multiple service developments, together with downstream appurtenances and facilities, including therein, fire hydrants. 
(d)  Waterage primary and secondary extensions which are required to provide new individual residential or individual general service potable water service and waterage primary and secondary extensions required to provide potable water service to subdivisions and other multiple service developments, may require provisions for reclaimed water and shall be provided in accord with this division and article. 
(Code 1994, § 78-288; Ord. No. 92-L-1, § 1(27-43), 9-10-1992; Ord. No. 96-17, § 1, 6-27-1996) 
Sec. 44-394. - Projects consistent with comprehensive plan. 
    The cost of all waterage primary extensions which are consistent with the city's comprehensive plan shall be paid by the city. 
(Code 1994, § 78-289; Ord. No. 92-L-1, § 1(27-44), 9-10-1992) 
Sec. 44-395. - Projects inconsistent with comprehensive plan. 
    A waterage primary extension project which is not in any current capital improvement program nor incorporated in any current five-year capital improvement element of the comprehensive plan or which is affirmatively inconsistent with the such plan shall be discouraged. City manager initiated and other requests for such primary extensions shall be considered by the city council and may be permitted under those terms and conditions as shall be considered in the best interest of the city. 
(Code 1994, § 78-290; Ord. No. 92-L-1, § 1(27-45), 9-10-1992) 
Sec. 44-396. - Projects consistent with comprehensive plan, but not in compliance with capital improvements element schedules. 
    A waterage primary extension project, incorporated within any five-year capital improvement element of the comprehensive plan or incorporated within any current capital improvement program, which is proposed for construction in advance of such element's or program's schedule but otherwise is consistent with the comprehensive plan, may be undertaken as follows: 
(1)  Such primary extension shall be permitted only after the plans therefor designed in accordance with accepted engineering industry principals, practices and standards and complying with accepted city planning industry techniques and practices, the comprehensive plan and land development regulations thereunder, have been approved by the city manager. The city manager shall be guided by competent engineering and planning advice upon the stated principals, practices, standards and techniques in his consideration for approval. All costs of such extension, primary and secondary, shall be advanced by the applicant, and the primary extension portion shall not be refunded in part or in whole by the city, until following construction of the total extension and acceptance by the city. 
(2)  A project agreement, including cost refund by the city, shall be negotiated between the applicant and the city manager on behalf of the city. No such agreement shall be effective until approved by the city council. Generally, the city shall reimburse, fully, the primary extension portion, with payment being made not later than the end of the fiscal year for which construction is scheduled under any current capital improvement program or under the subject five-year capital improvement element. In no case shall reimbursement exceed the primary extension costs, as certified by the city manager. Any such agreement shall set forth the intention of the city to fully refund for primary extension costs, but refund timing shall be subject to budgetary restraints, amendments and repeal, and the city shall not pledge its full faith and credit. However, the city shall agree, with specifics set forth in the agreement, that it shall not fund from water impact fees the cost of any other waterage extension, of which all or a part is a project with a scheduled position which is subsequent to the subject extension project as set forth in the specified current capital improvement program or the subject five-year capital improvement element, until the cost of the subject project has been refunded. 
(3)  All line extensions, primary and secondary, however funded, shall become property of the city upon acceptance for service. 
(Code 1994, § 78-291; Ord. No. 92-L-1, § 1(27-46), 9-10-1992) 
Sec. 44-397. - Preliminary project review report. 
    With application, the city manager shall make, or have made, a preliminary project review report setting forth the city's physical requirements for the proposed extension, e.g., the size, equipment, etc., of the waterage, the proposed route or location and shall provide a copy thereof to the applicant. No application to the city for waterage extension to any property located outside the city limits, shall be considered until the applicant has paid to the city one applicable fee for annexation review of the property to be served, and has had recorded among the public records of the county a notice of and encumbrance to annex, on a form provided by the city manager, which gives assurances from the fee simple owner that the subject property shall be annexed to the city, upon all other legal requirements being met, to occur at the convenience of the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 78-292; Ord. No. 92-L-1, § 1(27-47), 9-10-1992) 
Sec. 44-398. - City design and installation alternate. 
    At the option of the applicant and in lieu of the procedure set forth in section 44-399, where the applicant desires the city to proceed with the design and installation of the sewerage extension by force account or by contract, the applicant shall: 
(1)  Deposit with the city an amount equal to ten percent of the preliminary estimates, and the city manager shall prepare, or have prepared at his direction, a detailed estimate of the cost of the requested extension, providing a copy thereof to the applicant. If the applicant shall withdraw the request for extension after receipt of the detailed cost estimate, the city may retain such portion of the applicant's deposit as shall be required to pay all costs incurred by the city in making the detailed cost estimate. If the applicant shall authorize installation of the requested extension, then the deposit shall be applied by the city to the payment required by subsection (3) of this section. 
(2)  If the preliminary cost estimate prepared by the city is $20,000.00 or more, the deposit required under subsection (1) of this section may be, at the discretion of the city manager, a reasonable amount not less than $2,000.00 but less than ten percent of the preliminary estimate and be based upon the time and labor expected to be required by the city in preparing the detailed estimate. 
(3)  At the city's demand, prior to commencement of construction by force account or prior to bidding any contract for construction of any potable waterage extension under this section, the applicant shall pay to the city a sum equal to the estimated cost of such extension as prepared by the city. Such monies shall be used by the city to pay the costs of the requested extension and there shall be no refund of any portion thereof except as specifically provided for herein. If the actual cost of the extension as completed and finally accepted by the city shall be less than the estimated cost, the difference between the amount paid by the applicant and the actual cost shall be returned to the applicant. If the actual cost shall exceed the estimated cost, the difference between the amount paid by the applicant and the actual cost shall be paid to the city by the applicant. 
(Code 1994, § 78-293; Ord. No. 92-L-1, § 1(27-48), 9-10-1992) 
Sec. 44-399. - Applicant design and installation alternate. 
    At the option of the applicant, and in lieu of the procedure set forth in section 44-398, the applicant may proceed with design and construction as follows: 
(1)  At no cost to the city, the applicant may employ a state-registered engineer of his choice, to provide required plans, and specifications, conforming to the preliminary project review report, or the report as amended by agreement with the city manager, and submit such plans and specifications with appropriate fee to the city for technical review and approval. 
(2)  Upon technical review and approval of the plans and specifications made by or under the direction of the city manager, guided by industry acceptable engineering principals and practices and in conformity with comprehensive plan land development regulations, the applicant may employ a contractor of his choice, holding proper certification/registration from the state department of professional regulation to provide the waterage extension installation, subject to inspection, approval and acceptance by or under the direction of the city manager. 
(Code 1994, § 78-294; Ord. No. 92-L-1, § 1(27-49), 9-10-1992) 
Sec. 44-400. - Miscellaneous water line extensions-Program established. 
(a)  Program established. There is established a program for projects entitled "miscellaneous water line extensions." 
(b)  Authorization of funds. The city council may, at its discretion, from time to time, authorize and fund the extension of miscellaneous water lines in response to requests for service. 
(c)  C.I.A.C. Policy Manual. A manual which establishes policies and procedures for the implementation of the contribution-in-aid-of-construction program. 
(Code 1994, § 78-295; Ord. No. 96-17, § 1, 6-27-1996; Ord. No. 2014-02, § 1, 2-13-2014; Ord. No. 2014-04, § 1, 2-13-2014) 
Sec. 44-401. - Same-Contributions-in-aid-of-construction. 
(a)  Fee established. A C.I.A.C. fee is established by the city. A contribution-in-aid-of-construction (C.I.A.C.) shall be established to provide an equitable method of cost sharing for miscellaneous water line extensions. The contribution is a requirement for service only if the applicant decides to apply for city water service as opposed to providing an on-site private well supply. The C.I.A.C. will be based upon a cost sharing formula using the lot/property front footage per deed, survey or plat. The cost per front foot as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time shall be used to develop the project cost. 
(b)  Parameters for calculation. The following parameters apply when calculating a property's C.I.A.C.: 
(1)  Frontage. Is the deed frontage as pertains to the legal address or lot frontage as determined for the minimum requirements for issuance of a building permit or 75 feet whichever footage is greater. 
(2)  Corner lots. Frontage shall be determined as the dimension of the frontage facing the street of legal deed address or its dimension of width frontage for issuance of a building permit or 75 feet whichever is greater. 
(3)  Flag lots. Same as subsections (b)(1) and (2) of this section. 
(4)  Lot splits. Separate lots held by the same owner that may or may not be contiguous to each other may pay the C.I.A.C. at the time of application on a lot by lot basis (as per subsections (b)(1), (2) and (3) of this section). 
(c)  C.I.A.C. Policy Manual. All projects are subject to the policies within the C.I.A.C. Policy Manual in place when the miscellaneous line construction is requested. 
(Code 1994, § 78-296; Ord. No. 96-17, § 1, 6-27-1996; Ord. No. 2003-52, § II, 10-23-2003; Ord. No. 2014-02, § 1, 2-13-2014) 
Sec. 44-402. - Same-Location and extent of construction. 
(a)  Miscellaneous water lines may be extended to but not necessarily across the full frontage of the contributing lot based upon the determination by the city manager or his designee that adequate service is provided. 
(b)  In situations involving two or more flag lots, either existing or potential, the city may require the applicant to construct on-site secondary line extensions to serve these properties with adequate provisions for easements and accessibility. This requirement shall be the preferred method of service. 
(Code 1994, § 78-297; Ord. No. 96-17, § 1, 6-27-1996) 
Sec. 44-403. - Same-Costs, estimates, reports and C.I.A.C. payment. 
(a)  Cost estimate for projects and determination of the C.I.A.C. The city council may adopt and revise the C.I.A.C. cost per front foot as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time, or the city council may approve a C.I.A.C. project as defined in the C.I.A.C. Policy Manual by resolution and specify the project cost per front foot. The city manager or his designee shall prepare a cost per linear foot for miscellaneous water line extensions that is based upon most recent cost experience. The city manager is authorized and directed to set and give notice of a public hearing at which his recommendation shall be presented to the city council. Such cost estimate shall include all reasonable direct and indirect expenses for furnishing and installing eight-inch water lines, including hydrants, valves, fittings, appurtenances, rights-of-way, legal, and engineering costs. 
(b)  Preliminary proposed project report and financial status. 
(1)  The city manager or his designee shall prepare a preliminary project proposal memo and cost estimate for each potential miscellaneous water line extension. The project proposal shall identify location of projects, properties potentially to be served and cost estimates for construction. 
(2)  The report shall also verify the availability of funds and the compatibility or potential conflicts with other capital projects including scheduled primary off-site water line extensions. 
(c)  Payment of C.I.A.C. The amount of the C.I.A.C. shall be determined by the rate currently in effect at the time of receipt of a properly completed request for a determination of availability. If a main was constructed as part of an area-wide extension project or a single roadway extension project, as defined in the C.I.A.C. Policy Manual, upon future connection the property owner must pay the project costs previously established by resolution for that area. 
    For any property designated as a homestead under F.S. ch. 222, the city council may permit C.I.A.C. fees to be paid by installments. Evidence of the debt due, reflecting the payment terms, together with evidence of a marketable lien encumbering the property served, shall be executed in recordable form and the evidence of lien together with a copy of the evidence of debt shall be filed in the public records of the county. Interest shall be seven percent unless waived or reduced by the city manager. 
(d)  Properties/lots affected by C.I.A.C. Properties and/or lots for which the C.I.A.C. are applicable are: properties/lots that lie within the unincorporated areas served by the city utility and that abut or are adjacent to miscellaneous water line extensions and that apply for and receive service from such lines. 
(e)  Disposition and use of C.I.A.C. All funds collected through the administration of the C.I.A.C. shall be reserved for use in a rollover account for the purposes of continuing and maintaining a miscellaneous water line construction program. 
(f)  Review and verification of C.I.A.C. payment requirement. Applications for water service shall be reviewed by the city manager or his designee to verify the property as subject to C.I.A.C. requirement or exemption from same. 
(Code 1994, § 78-298; Ord. No. 96-17, § 1, 6-27-1996; Ord. No. 2003-52, § III, 10-23-2003; Ord. No. 2014-02, § 1, 2-13-2014; Ord. No. 2014-04, § 1, 2-13-2014) 
Editor's note- At the direction of the city, provisions for § 44-403, as set out in Ord. No. 2014-02, § 1, adopted Feb. 13, 2014, were codified as superseding provisions as set out in Ord. No. 2014-04, § 1, adopted on the same day. 
Sec. 44-404. - Same-Negotiation agreements for miscellaneous water line extension. 
    In the event a developer or applicant requests the extension of a water line and agrees to incur all the costs for extension, council may at its discretion approve a negotiated agreement to provide for the equitable reimbursement to the applicant for funds expended beyond those normally applicable for C.I.A.C. Such reimbursement to applicant may take the form of a series of payments over a period of time, not to exceed five years. The city council may elect to deny any such request for miscellaneous line extension if it is perceived not in the best interest of the city and/or cost of extension does not provide a reasonable expectation of enhancement to the city's water distribution system. 
(Code 1994, § 78-299; Ord. No. 96-17, § 1, 6-27-1996) 
Secs. 44-405-44-420. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL 

Sec. 44-421. - Applicability. 
    All territory served by the city potable water distribution system shall be governed by this division to the extent permitted by law. 
(Code 1994, § 78-301; Ord. No. 93-A-1, § 27-54, 5-13-1993) 
Sec. 44-422. - Manual. 
(a)  Adoption. There is adopted for the city a cross connection control manual, dated April 30, 1993. One copy of the cross connection control manual is on file in the office of the city clerk for public use, inspection and examination. Compliance with the cross connection control manual and the cross connection program contained therein is required. 
(b)  Periodic review. The cross connection control manual shall be periodically reviewed by the city environmental utilities department to assure compliance with applicable statutes, rules and regulations of the state and the state department of environmental protection and may be amended by resolution by the city council. 
(Code 1994, § 78-302; Ord. No. 93-A-1, § 27-46, 5-13-1993) 
Sec. 44-423. - Property access. 
    Duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter any building, structure or property served by a connection to the public potable water supply system of the city for the purpose of inspecting the piping system on such property. Consent to such access shall be obtained from a person of lawful age and discretion therein or in control thereof; if such consent is refused, the city may obtain an inspection warrant pursuant to state statute. 
(Code 1994, § 78-303; Ord. No. 93-A-1, § 27-47, 5-13-1993) 
Sec. 44-424. - Discontinued service. 
    No water service connection shall be maintained by the city unless the consumer is in compliance with the requirements of the cross connection control manual. Service of water to any premises shall be disconnected if a backflow prevention device is not installed, tested and maintained or if an unprotected connection exists on the premises. Notice shall be given to the consumer prior to discontinuing service except where, in the judgment of the city manager or his designee, the threat to the public health is such that action must be taken immediately. 
(Code 1994, § 78-304; Ord. No. 93-A-1, § 27-48, 5-13-1993) 
Sec. 44-425. - Protection of public potable water supply labeling. 
    The potable water supply made available on the properties served by both the public potable water and nonpotable water supply shall be protected from present or future possible contamination as specified by the cross connection control manual and by state and city building, plumbing or water regulations or codes. Any water outlet which could be used for potable or domestic purposes and which is not supplied by the potable system must be labeled "Water unsafe for drinking" or "Nonpotable water" in a conspicuous manner. 
(Code 1994, § 78-305; Ord. No. 93-A-1, § 27-49, 5-13-1993) 
Sec. 44-426. - Other codes and rules. 
    The cross connection control manual does not supersede the Florida Building Code, the state safe drinking water act, state drinking water regulations or any other city or state statute, ordinance, rule or regulation applicable to public water supply systems, but is supplementary to them. When conflicts exist between the manual and such other codes and rules, the more restrictive provisions shall apply. 
(Code 1994, § 78-307; Ord. No. 93-A-1, § 27-51, 5-13-1993) 
Sec. 44-427. - Public employees. 
    No provision of this division designating the duties of any city officer or employee shall be construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine or penalty for failure to perform such duty. 
(Code 1994, § 78-308; Ord. No. 93-A-1, § 27-53, 5-13-1993) 
Secs. 44-428-44-450. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - WATER AND IRRIGATION CONSERVATION PLAN 

Sec. 44-451. - Irrigation; potable water. 
(a)  Restrictions. 
(1)  Potable water irrigation of any residential, commercial, institutional, governmental, or industrial landscape areas shall at a minimum have the following restrictions: 
a.  No irrigation shall be allowed between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on any day unless specifically exempted below. 
b.  Irrigation restrictions shall be in effect yearround. 
c.  The city manager, or his designee, shall determine the allowable days and times when irrigation is permitted. Allowable irrigation days shall not exceed three days per week for any given location and may be restricted further. The days and time may be set as policy maintained on file and posted in the environmental utilities department. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful to operate or cause the operation of any irrigation system or device in a manner causing water to be wasted, including, but not limited to, unnecessary watering of impervious areas, other than that which may occur incidental to the proper operation of the primary irrigation system. 
(3)  All new installations of automatic irrigation systems shall be equipped with a water-sensing device, which will automatically discontinue irrigation during periods of rainfall. All existing irrigation installations shall be required to maintain their rain-sensing device in an operational condition. 
(b)  Exemptions. The following activities shall be exempt from the provisions above: 
(1)  Landscape irrigation by microirrigation systems or hand-watering using a self-canceling nozzle. 
(2)  The operation of irrigation systems for system installation, repair, and maintenance. 
(3)  Flushing of water mains required for normal water main clearance and maintenance, and for maintenance of water quality. 
(4)  Landscape irrigation by a licensed pest control operator for the purpose of watering in fungicides, insecticides, and herbicides as required by the manufacturer or by federal or state laws when such application is limited to the minimum manufacturer's recommendations. 
(5)  Landscape irrigation for the purpose of watering in newly planted grass and foliage for the first 30 days after initial installation shall be exempted from daily restrictions, but shall be subject to the irrigation time restrictions noted in subsection (a)(1)a of this section. 
(6)  Irrigation activity for the control of dust emissions authorized by the city manager or his designee. 
(7)  Water-cooled heating and air conditioning systems. 
(8)  Swimming pool maintenance. 
(9)  Large commercial, industrial, and common area locations may be reviewed on a case-by-case basis to assign irrigation days and times on a zone by zone basis as necessary to balance service demands. Such schedules shall be subject to approval by the city manager or his designee. Approval of said schedules shall be consistent with the intent and objective of irrigation restrictions in place at any given time. Assigned alternative schedules shall be subject to change upon revision of the irrigation restriction policies described in subsection (a)(1)c of this section and shall be subject to inspection and enforcement provisions of this Code. 
(10)  The use of water to protect golf course turf from heat and wind stress damage subject to approval of the city manager or his designee. 
(c)  The city manager is hereby authorized to restrict the use of water for irrigation and/or accessory use during those periods of time of critical concern. The city manager shall implement and cause to be enforced, any irrigation restriction declared by South Florida Water Management District due to drought or pending drought by the process above. 
(d)  The city development review committee reviews all site plans and subdivision plans. During this review the city will encourage the use of landscape plants that are indigenous species or those that require little or no irrigation. The city will encourage and provide informational brochures on xeriscape landscaping to applicants for irrigation meters. The city will post scheduling of landscape programs offered through the University of Florida, Osceola County Extension Service. 
(Code 1994, § 78-312; Ord. No. 2003-28, § IV, 4-10-2003; Ord. No. 2005-33, § III, 3-10-2005; Ord. No. 2007-17, § IV(78-312), 2-8-2007) 
Sec. 44-452. - Indoor water conservation. 
    The Florida Building Code, Plumbing, supercedes all local codes and prescribes the maximum flow rates and consumption for plumbing fixtures. 
(Code 1994, § 78-313; Ord. No. 2003-28, § IV, 4-10-2003) 
Sec. 44-453. - Unmetered water; leak detection. 
(a)  The city will continue its customer leak detection program that electronically generates a work order for customer notification when the monthly water consumption reading exceeds the annualized monthly average by 175 percent. 
(b)  The water division will meter or estimate and record water utilized during construction, repair, maintenance of chlorine residuals, and valve and hydrant exercise in order to more accurately identify water loss and leak detection. 
(c)  The city will continue to require developments to loop water mains to maintain water quality and adequate fire flow with the water main pressure stabilized at 50 to 55 p.s.i. 
(d)  The city will continue to budget adequate funding for its refurbishment and replacement program. 
(Code 1994, § 78-314; Ord. No. 2003-28, § IV, 4-10-2003) 
Sec. 44-454. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating section 44-451 or section 44-452 shall be subject to penalty and enforcement as permitted under this Code and particularly under chapter 2, article VI or by court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1994, § 78-315; Ord. No. 2003-28, § IV, 4-10-2003) 
Secs. 44-455-44-480. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ELECTRICITY 

Sec. 44-481. - Adoption of Orlando Utilities Commission Policies. 
    Pursuant to the city's interlocal agreement with the Orlando Utilities Commission, the city hereby adopts the policies, as they are promulgated from time to time, of the Orlando Utilities Commission as the same apply to the provision of electrical services within the electrical services area of the city. A copy of such Orlando Utilities Commission Policies shall be on file and open for inspection and copying in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1994, § 78-317; Ord. No. 97-10, § 1, 4-24-1997) 
Secs. 44-482-44-510. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - UNAUTHORIZED USE OF UTILITY SERVICE 

Sec. 44-511. - City's right to inspect utility property located on private property. 
    In the event of unauthorized use or suspected unauthorized use of the utility service as outlined in F.S. § 812.14, the city shall have the right at any time to inspect city utility property located on private property. Indications or evidence of unauthorized connections to or tampering with the city utility's electric service or water service, meters or meter seals, lines, wires, pipes, sewer service, lines or mains and any or all related appurtenances or apparatus shall subject the person benefiting from and/or perpetuating such activity to immediate discontinuance of service, possible prosecution under the laws of the state, adjustment of prior bills for services rendered, payment to the city utilities for unauthorized consumption of utilities, and reimbursement to the utility for all additional expenses incurred by the city as a result of the unauthorized connection. 
(Code 1994, § 78-426; Ord. No. 94-41, § 1, 11-10-1994) 
Sec. 44-512. - Access to customer premises. 
    In accordance with customer agreement for service form and pursuant to this article, authorized city utility employees shall have access to customer premises for the purpose of installing, maintaining, operating, inspecting or removing the utility's property, reading meters or other purposes incident to task performance, and in such performance shall not be liable for trespass. Access to customer premises is defined as a clear, safe, definable path to and the unobstructed surroundings of utility electric, water and/or sewer equipment located on customer or potential customer premises. 
(Code 1994, § 78-427; Ord. No. 94-41, § 1, 11-10-1994) 
Sec. 44-513. - Reporting of theft or diversion. 
    All incidents of suspected theft or diversion shall be reported to the city manager's office immediately upon discovery. The city may establish interference with the electric and/or water service by the following: 
(1)  The existence of an altered or tampered-with electric or water meter, or illegal connection to electric and/or water service may be established by a statement of a person with sufficient knowledge to recognize an alteration, having seen the meter and by the use of photographs taken by the individual making the statement. 
(2)  Actions such as deliberate damage, or alteration or tampering resulting in the improper operation, registration of the meter or receipt of electricity and/or water without passing through a meter, the alteration and/or diversion of water supply lines or sewer lines for other than intended purpose. 
(3)  The person benefited by the improper operation or registration or use of the utility service for one billing cycle may be shown by the testimony of one with knowledge of the person responsible for the payment of charges for electricity and/or water delivered through the meter in question and supported by regular business records showing this responsibility. 
(Code 1994, § 78-428; Ord. No. 94-41, § 1, 11-10-1994) 
Secs. 44-514-44-529. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT UTILITY 

Sec. 44-530. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Words not defined herein shall be construed to have the meaning given by common and ordinary use as defined in the latest edition of Webster's Dictionary. 
    Bonds means revenue bonds, notes, loans or any other debt obligations issued or incurred to finance the costs of construction. 
    Costs of construction means costs reasonably incurred in connection with providing capital improvements to the system or any portion thereof, including but not limited to the costs of: 
(1)  Acquisition of all property, real or personal, and all interests in connection therewith including all rights-of-way and easements therefor; 
(2)  Physical construction, installation and testing, including the costs of labor, services, materials, supplies and utility services used in connection therewith; 
(3)  Architectural, engineering, legal and other professional services; 
(4)  Insurance premiums taken out and maintained during construction, to the extent not paid for by a contractor, for construction and installation; 
(5)  Any taxes or other charges which become due during construction; 
(6)  Expenses incurred by the city or on its behalf with its approval in seeking to enforce any remedy against any contractor or subcontractor in respect of any default under a contract relating to construction; 
(7)  Principal of and interest of any bonds; and 
(8)  Miscellaneous expenses incidental thereto. 
    Debt service means, with respect to any particular fiscal year and any particular series of bonds, an amount equal to the sum of; 
(1)  All interest payable on such bonds during such fiscal year; plus 
(2)  Any principal installments of such bonds during such fiscal year. 
    Developed property means real property which has been altered from natural state by the addition of any improvements such as a building, structure, or impervious surface. For new construction, property shall be considered developed pursuant to this article: 
(1)  Upon issuance of a certificate of occupancy, or upon completion of construction or final inspection if no such certificate is issued; or 
(2)  If construction is at least 50 percent complete and construction is halted for a period of three months. 
    Director means director of public works or designee. 
    DOR code means the department of revenue land use code as defined by F.A.C. 12D-8.008(2)(c). 
    Dwelling unit means a single unit providing complete, independent living facilities for one or more persons including permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation. 
    Equivalent runoff unit or ERU means the median impervious area of residential developed property per dwelling unit (excluding DOR Codes 00 and 04) located within the city and as established by council resolution as provided herein. 
    ERU rate means a utility fee charged on each ERU as established by council resolution as provided herein. 
    Extension and replacement means costs of extensions, additions and capital improvements to, or the renewal and replacement of capital assets of, or purchasing and installing new equipment for, the system, or land acquisition for the system and any related costs thereto, or paying extraordinary maintenance and repair, including the costs of construction, or any other expenses which are not costs of operation and maintenance or debt service. 
    Fiscal year means a 12-month period commencing on October 1 of any year. 
    Impervious area means roofed and paved areas, including, but not limited to, areas covered by roofs, roof extensions, swimming pools, patios, porches, driveways, sidewalks, parking areas and athletic courts. 
    Nonresidential developed property means developed property that is classified by the property appraiser as land use types 03, 05, 06, 07, 09, and 10 through 99 using the state department of revenue (DOR) land use codes, as amended or supplemented. 
    Operating budget means the annual utility operating budget adopted by the council for the succeeding fiscal year. 
    Operations and maintenance means the current expenses, paid or accrued, of operation, maintenance and current repair of the system, as calculated in accordance with sound accounting practice, and includes, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, insurance premiums, administrative expenses, labor, executive compensation, the cost of materials and supplies used for current operations, and charges for the accumulation of appropriate reserves for current expenses not annually incurred, but which are such as may reasonably be expected to be incurred in accordance with sound accounting practice. 
    Private drainage systems means the stormwater management systems within the privately maintained property, right of ways, or easements which are required by the rules, regulations, and codes of the South Florida Water Management District, state department of environmental protection, the county, and city for the development of these properties. These stormwater management systems include, but are not limited to, retention ponds, detention ponds, outfall structures, inlets, pipes, swales, and ditches. These systems are considered private if the maintenance responsibilities are required of a homeowner association, group of property owners, individual property owner, private company, corporation, or any other public or private entity which is not the city. 
    Property appraiser means the office of county property appraiser. 
    Public stormwater management system ("system") means the existing stormwater management within the publicly maintained right of ways or easements of the city and all improvements thereto which by this article are constituted as the property and responsibility of the utility, to be operated from the revenues received as an enterprise fund to, among other things, conserve water, control discharges necessitated by rainfall events, incorporate methods to collect, convey, store, absorb, inhibit, treat, use or reuse water to prevent or reduce flooding, over-drainage, environmental degradation and water pollution or otherwise affect the quality and quantity of discharge from such system. Private drainage systems are not included in the system. 
    Rate resolution means the resolution adopted by the council establishing the ERU rate. 
    Residential developed property means developed property that is classified by the property appraiser as land use types 00, 01, 02 and 04 using the state department of revenue (DOR) land use codes, as amended or supplemented. 
    Revenues mean all rates, fees, assessments, rentals or other charges, income or funds received by the utility, in connection with the management and operation of the system, including amounts received from the investment or deposit of moneys in any fund or account and any amounts contributed by the city, all as calculated in accordance with sound accounting practice. 
    Service area means all of the incorporated areas of the city. 
    Undeveloped property means property which has less than five percent impervious area. 
    Utility means the enterprise fund stormwater management utility created by this article to operate, maintain and improve the system. 
    Utility fee means a stormwater management utility fee authorized by state law and this article which is established to pay administration, planning, operations and maintenance, extension and replacement and debt service for the system. 
(Ord. No. 2007-49, § III(78-500), 6-14-2007) 
Sec. 44-531. - Establishment of utility. 
(a)  The utility is hereby established by the council to provide for the general welfare of the city and its residents. 
(b)  The director shall be the director of public works or designee. 
(Ord. No. 2007-49, § III(78-501), 6-14-2007) 
Sec. 44-532. - Operating budget. 
    The council shall adopt an operating budget not later than the first day of each fiscal year. The operating budget shall set forth for such fiscal year the estimated revenues and the estimated costs for operation and maintenance, extension and replacement and debt service. 
(Ord. No. 2007-49, § III(78-502), 6-14-2007) 
Sec. 44-533. - Required levels of rates for utility fees. 
    The council shall ensure that adequate revenues are received to provide for a balanced operating budget by at least annually setting an ERU rate that will generate sufficient levels of utility fees to limit the amount of funds from other sources, such as the general fund, which would otherwise be needed to meet system requirements. The council shall set the ERU rates by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 2007-49, § III(78-503), 6-14-2007) 
Sec. 44-534. - Imposition of utility fees and rate schedule. 
    The council hereby imposes stormwater management utility ("utility") fees on all property within the service area. 
(1)  Property classification. For purposes of determining the utility fee, all property within the service area shall be classified, into one of the following classes: 
a.  Residential developed property (DOR codes 00, 01, 02, and 04); 
b.  Nonresidential developed property (DOR codes 03, 05, 06, 07, 08, 10 to 99); or 
c.  Undeveloped property. 
(2)  Computation of utility fee for residential developed property. The utility fee for residential developed property shall be one ERU. 
(3)  Computation of utility fee for nonresidential developed property. The utility fee for nonresidential developed property shall be the ERU rate multiplied by the numerical factor obtained by dividing the total impervious area of a nonresidential developed property by one ERU. The minimum utility fee for any nonresidential developed property shall be equal to one ERU, which is the rate for residential property. 
(4)  Undeveloped property. Undeveloped property is exempt from the utility fee. 
(Ord. No. 2007-49, § III(78-504), 6-14-2007) 
Sec. 44-535. - Exemptions and credits. 
(a)  Exemptions. The following areas on developed property will not be counted as part of the impervious areas of the developed property: 
(1)  Railroads; 
(2)  Public roads (including federal, state, county and city); 
(3)  Public airport taxiways and runways; and 
(4)  Open water. 
(b)  Credits. 
(1)  The city recognizes that some customers subject to the utility fee have on their property constructed and currently operate and maintain stormwater facilities that can reduce stormwater runoff impacts from the subject property and reduce the burden on the city to maintain, operate and provide capital improvements to the system. Additionally, the city recognizes that some customers may wish to mitigate the utility fee by constructing and maintaining a stormwater facility that will reduce the impact of the subject property. The credit granted shall conform to the procedures and as defined by the stormwater administrative policy manual. 
(2)  To qualify for the fee credit, a utility customer must operate a stormwater facility and must provide certification by a state registered professional engineer that the facility is operating as designed and is regularly maintained. Further, the engineer must certify that the subject stormwater facility must exceed the minimum requirements of the current land development regulations of the city or for the additional credit, that the facility accepts a measurable amount of off-site stormwater. 
(3)  The utility customer requesting the credit must demonstrate to the city on or before every second year anniversary after the granting of the credit that the stormwater facilities are operating properly and being maintained according to standard practices. The stormwater facility must be certified by a state registered professional engineer that the facility is operating as designed and is regularly maintained according to standard practices. 
(4)  After a particular customer receives a utility fee credit, annually thereafter the city may inspect the stormwater drainage facilities serving the site in order to determine whether those facilities are maintained and functioning properly. If the city inspection determines that they are maintained and functioning property, the stormwater drainage utility fee credit shall be continued. However, if the city inspection determines that the system is improperly maintained and not functioning properly, the city shall notify the customer to correct the deficiency within 30 days. If the deficiency is corrected to the satisfaction of the city within the 30-day period, the stormwater drainage utility fee credit shall continue in effect until the next annual inspection. However, if the deficiency is not corrected to the satisfaction of the city within 30 days, the city may cancel the utility fee credit until the necessary corrections are made. 
(Ord. No. 2007-49, § III(78-505), 6-14-2007) 
Sec. 44-536. - Billing and payment; penalties. 
(a)  The utility fee shall be implemented as part of the normal utility bills for other user fees currently provided by the city. 
(b)  The collection of the utility fees is subject to the same policies, late fees, and collection programs as the other utilities administered by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2007-49, § III(78-506), 6-14-2007) 
Sec. 44-537. - Adjustment of equivalent residential units (ERUs). 
(a)  Requests by customers for adjustment of the equivalent residential unit (ERU) calculation shall be submitted to the director, who is hereby authorized to develop and administer the procedures and standards for the adjustment of ERUs as established herein. All requests shall be judged on the basis of the amount of impervious area on the site. No credit shall be given for the installation of facilities required by the city development codes or state stormwater rules. The following procedures shall apply to all adjustment requests of the ERU calculation: 
(1)  Any customer who has paid his utility fee and who believes his ERU to be incorrect may, subject to the limitations set forth in this article, submit an adjustment request to the director. 
(2)  ERU requests for utility fees paid by a customer must be in writing and shall set forth, in detail, the grounds upon which relief is sought. 
(3)  ERU requests must be made within 30 days after receipt of the subject utility bill and each request shall be initially reviewed by the director within a one-month period from the date of filing of the ERU adjustment request. Adjustments resulting from such request shall be retroactive to the beginning of the fiscal year in which the owner is requesting an adjustment. 
(4)  The customer requesting the ERU adjustment may be required, at his own cost, to provide supplemental information to the director including, but not limited to, survey data approved by either a registered professional land surveyor (R.P.L.S.) and engineering reports approved by a professional engineer (P.E.). Failure to provide such information may result in the denial of the ERU adjustment request. 
(5)  ERU to the utility fee will be made upon the granting of the adjustment request, in writing, by the director. Denials of ERU adjustment requests shall be made in writing. 
(b)  Consideration by the director of the customer's request for ERU adjustment shall not relieve the customer of the obligation to make timely payment of the utility fee. In the event an ERU adjustment is granted by the director which decreased the utility fee, the customer shall be entitled to a refund of excess utility fees paid. 
(c)  Upon receipt of the written denial of the ERU adjustment request, the customer who initially requested the adjustment may, within 30 days of receipt of such denial, appeal to the city manager or designee for review of the denial. 
(1)  The city manager or designee shall complete their review within 45 days of receipt of said request for review. The city manager's or designee's determination on the review shall be in writing and set forth in detail the reasons for their decision. 
(2)  In reviewing denials of ERU adjustment requests, the city manager or designee shall apply the standards and review criteria contained in this article. 
(d)  Any errors in the ERU calculation and resulting utility fee or failure to charge a utility fee may be corrected by the director within one year after sending of the utility bills. ERU corrections which result in an increase in the utility fee cannot be imposed until the customer has consented in writing to the increase or has been given at least ten days' notice by certified mail and an opportunity to be heard by the city manager or designee. Once the utility fee is finalized, the director shall send documentation reflecting the ERU adjustment to the customer and the documentation will also be sent to the billing entity or department. 
(Ord. No. 2013-17, § I, 8-8-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-17, § II, adopted Aug. 8, 2013, amended § 44-537 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 44-537 pertained to adjustment of fees and derived from Ord. No. 2007-49, § III(78-507), adopted June 14, 2007. 
Sec. 44-538. - Utility funds. 
    There shall be established a separate account for the deposit of all fees and charges collected by the utility. These funds shall be for the exclusive use of the utility, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Administrative costs associated with the management of the utility. 
(2)  Planning and engineering. 
(3)  Operation and maintenance of the system. 
(4)  Funding of pollution abatement devices constructed on stormwater systems discharging to the surface water of city. 
(5)  Debt service financing. 
(6)  Extension and replacement costs. 
(Ord. No. 2007-49, § III(78-508), 6-14-2007) 
Sec. 44-539. - Administrative procedures. 
(a)  The city manager is authorized and he is directed to prepare and maintain a City of St. Cloud Utilities Customer Service Manual to administer reasonable administrative procedures, regulations, customer service and billing policies in regard to the implementation of this article as orderly administration shall require. The manual shall be on file in the public services department. 
(b)  The city manager is authorized and directed to prepare reasonable administrative regulations and policies in regard to the collection of instatement charges, facility and volume charges and user fees as are and may be established as orderly administration shall require, and the same shall be approved and adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 2013-17, § III, 8-8-2013) 
Sec. 44-540. - Enforcement. 
    Any unpaid stormwater monthly service charges shall become a lien against the property or premises served and shall be of equal status as an ad valorem tax lien against the property. In addition and supplemental thereto, compliance herewith shall be enforced by the city code enforcement board as provided by law and relief on open account/account stated may be sought before a state court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 2013-17, § III, 8-8-2013) 
Chapter 46 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 46-1-46-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS AND LIMOUSINES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Certificate means a certificate of public conveyance issued by the city manager or his designee authorizing the holder thereof to conduct a taxicab business, limousine service or other vehicle for hire to convey passengers within the city. 
    Driver's license registration means the permission granted by the city manager or his designee for a person to drive a taxicab, limousine or other such means of public conveyance for hire upon the streets of the city. 
    Holder means a person to whom the certificate of public conveyance has been issued. 
    Limousine means any vehicle for hire that is not classified as a taxicab, but is used to transport persons. 
    Taxicab means a motor vehicle for hire regularly engaged in the business of carrying passengers, having a seating capacity of not less than five persons and not operating a fixed route. 
    Taximeter means a meter, instrument or device attached to a taxicab which measures mechanically the distance driven and the waiting time upon which the fare is based. 
(Code 1967, § 241/2-1; Code 1994, § 82-26; Ord. No. 96-01, § 1, 5-9-1996) 
Secs. 46-32-46-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CERTIFICATE OF PUBLIC CONVEYANCE 

Sec. 46-51. - Required. 
    No person shall operate or permit a taxicab or limousine to be operated on a recurring basis as a vehicle for hire upon the streets of the city without first having obtained a certificate of public conveyance. Taxicab or limousine services licensed in other Central Florida jurisdictions may submit such licenses in lieu of a city certificate of public conveyance at the time of obtaining a St. Cloud occupational license. 
(Code 1994, § 82-36; Ord. No. 96-01, § 2, 5-9-1996) 
Sec. 46-52. - Application, form, fee. 
(a)  An application for a certificate of public conveyance shall be filed with the city manager or his designee upon forms provided by the city, and such application shall be verified under oath and shall furnish the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of applicant; if a corporation, the names and addresses of the corporate officers shall be furnished. 
(2)  A financial statement of the applicant, including the amounts of all unpaid judgments against the applicant, and the nature of the transaction or acts giving rise to such judgments. 
(3)  The experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers. 
(4)  An inspection report for each vehicle to be used for hire signed and approved by a mechanic that is certified by the American Society of Engineers (ASE). 
(5)  The location of the proposed depots or terminals. 
(6)  Copies of driver licenses of any owner or holder who will drive a vehicle for hire. 
(7)  Such further information as the city manager or his designee may require. 
(b)  A fee in the amount as currently established or as hereafter adopted or revised by resolution of the city council from time to time shall be paid to the city at the time of filing the application. 
(c)  Upon receipt of a completed application and affidavit, the city manager or his designee shall cause a records and fingerprint check to be completed on all drivers, officers and/or owners of the business. Pursuant to F.S. § 166.0442, the applicant shall undergo fingerprinting to be submitted to the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) for a state and national criminal history record check. Upon determination that issuance of a certificate of public conveyance is appropriate, the city manager's office shall notify the applicant in writing stating the name and address of the applicant, the officers and/or owners, a description of each vehicle authorized, and the date of issuance. Upon receipt of the written notice, a holder shall obtain an occupational license for the business. 
(Code 1994, § 82-37; Ord. No. 96-01, § 2, 5-9-1996; Ord. No. 2017-38 , § 4, 9-28-2017) 
Sec. 46-53. - Reapplication after denial. 
    No application for a permit covered by this division shall be made by any person whose application for such permit has been denied until the expiration of six months from the date of the denial of such application. The applicant for a permit that was denied may petition the city council to reconsider the denial and the decision of the city council shall be final. 
(Code 1994, § 82-39; Ord. No. 96-01, § 2, 5-9-1996) 
Sec. 46-54. - Transfer. 
    No certificate of public conveyance shall be sold, assigned or transferred, in whole or in part. A new certificate of public conveyance must be issued when one or more of the holders change. 
(Code 1994, § 82-41; Ord. No. 96-01, § 2, 5-9-1996) 
Sec. 46-55. - Liability insurance prerequisite to issuance. 
    No certificate of public conveyance shall be issued or continued in operation until there is in full force and effect an insurance policy for each vehicle authorized in the amount as currently established or as hereafter adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time.
